INTERNATIONAL A3-18
 
U.S. Resists Imposing Sanctions on Indonesia
The United States is resisting direct threats of economic or military sanctions against Indonesia over the violence and chaos in East Timor in hopes of preserving its relationship with that vast nation. The Administration, officials say, has made the calculation that the United States must put its relationship with Indonesia ahead of its concern over the political fate of East Timor. A1 

The United Nations mission in East Timor postponed for 24 hours its decision to close its operations and evacuate the last 300 members of its staff. Officials said a skeleton staff would probably remain. A8
 
Secretary General Kofi Annan and the Security Council walked to the brink of confrontation with Indonesia, then backed away when President B.J. Habibie and his army chief, General Wiranto, asked for more time to put East Timor in order. A8
 
Yeltsin Denies Wrongdoing
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia called President Clinton and asserted that accusations linking Mr. Yeltsin and his family to a corruption inquiry were politically inspired, the White House said. A1
 
Felipe Turover, a central figure in an investigation of suspected money laundering and bribe taking by top Kremlin officials, said he saw credit card bills and photocopies of credit cards bearing the signatures of President Yeltsin and his daughters, and that the cards were provided by a Swiss-based construction company that had lucrative Kremlin contracts. A18
 
U.S.-China Meeting on Trade
The United States and China met to set the stage for the resumption of negotiations for China's entry into the World Trade Organization, which the Clinton Administration rebuffed five months ago. A9
 
Israel Confirms Agreement
The Government, in its latest agreement with the Palestinians, approved the transfer of more West Bank land to Palestinian rule and prepared to release 200 prisoners. A7
 
Attacks in Kosovo

HEADLINE: Typical Drug User Is Profiled by U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Trying to paint a more realistic picture of drug users, the Government said today that out of every 10 people who used illegal drugs in 1997, 7 had full-time jobs.
Officials said they hoped the data would dispel the notion that most drug users are burned out and disconnected from the mainstream. 
 "The typical drug user is not poor and unemployed," said Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. "He or she can be a co-worker, a husband or wife, a parent."
About 6.3 million full-time workers, ages 18 to 49 -- 7.7 percent of people in that age range -- admitted in 1997 that they had used illegal drugs in the preceding month, according to the report, which is issued every few years by the Department of Health and Human Services. The proportion has been steady since 1992.

HEADLINE: Lott Says Veto Is Likely to Kill Tax Cut in '99

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that President Clinton's promised veto of the Republicans' $792 billion tax-cut bill probably doomed any tax-relief legislation this year and would set up a major campaign issue for the 2000 election.
In the opening salvo of the biggest political battle in Washington this fall, Mr. Lott all but ruled out any compromise with the White House, saying there was not enough time to negotiate a new plan for taxes and spending for the next decade. 
 "I don't see how we do it," Mr. Lott, a Mississippi Republican, told reporters on the Senate's first day back to work after its August recess.
Mr. Lott's gloomy outlook may just be a bargaining ploy to pressure the White House to budge from its top offer of a $300 billion tax cut. But Senate aides said Mr. Lott had calculated that Republicans stood to gain more politically by doing nothing this year and wielding tax cuts as a major campaign issue next year, than by bowing to the President now.
"These issues will come up in November 2000, and they'll be settled then," said Mr. Lott's spokesman, John Czwartacki.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, backs Mr. Lott's hard-line approach, but other Republican leaders like Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, are willing to discuss a smaller tax package, especially if it involves repealing the estate tax or the so-called marriage tax.
"We're always pushing for tax relief," said John P. Feehery, Mr. Hastert's spokesman. "We don't want to give up."
Michele Davis, a spokeswoman for Mr. Armey, said that tax cuts were still the "No. 1 issue" for House Republicans, who will meet on Thursday with their leaders to discuss what approach to take if Mr. Clinton fulfills his veto threat.
"It's always the case that lower taxes are better than higher taxes," Ms. Davis said.
The White House has floated the idea of a grand bargain to divide the projected $3 trillion surplus among tax relief, Federal programs and debt reduction. Mr. Clinton said in his national radio address on Saturday that he would support a smaller tax-cut bill in exchange for Republican concessions on Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, including a voluntary prescription drug program for senior citizens, and other spending.
Congress will send the President the tax-cut bill next Tuesday or Wednesday, but Mr. Lott said he had not seen any signs that the White House was willing to compromise.
"I haven't seen any indication that the President wants to work with us," Mr. Lott said. "What the President wants is more spending, more spending, more spending for everything. He is not for tax relief for working Americans."
Ms. Davis, Mr. Armey's spokeswoman, flatly rejected any deal that included additional spending.
Republicans and Democrats both feel that the political peril of doing nothing on tax cuts is less than they perceived earlier in the year. Lawmakers say they believe that the public has largely absorbed the idea that doing nothing means plowing back much of any surplus into reducing the national debt, which is popular among conservatives. Reducing the national debt keeps interest rates low and provides flexibility on other fiscal programs. So for political and substantive economic reasons, the default position of reducing the debt is attractive.
"Clinton is in a take-it-or-leave-it position and, for the most part, so are we," said a senior Senate Republican aide. "That wouldn't be so bad. We'd still get debt reduction, plus it would clear away the clutter and focus attention on the appropriations process."
Both sides are positioning themselves to blame the other if lawmakers are forced to dip into the Social Security surplus to keep the Government running next year, as current spending plans would require them to do. Politically, it is also true that both sides are convinced that the issue of taxes and spending plays in their favor, and sets up a classic ideological fight.
Republicans can assert that Mr. Clinton denied Americans a tax cut, even after protecting Medicare and most Social Security money, and instead is seeking to increase Federal spending. Some Republicans say Mr. Clinton would be pressured to approve a tax-cut bill in an election year, just as he was when making changes in welfare. Other analysts suggest that would be highly unlikely. "Maybe next year we'll pass another good, pro-growth tax-reduction package," Mr. Lott said.
Democrats could argue the importance of keeping a Democrat in the White House to stop Republicans from giving away the Federal surplus in tax cuts to the rich, without addressing problems in Medicare, Social Security and other domestic programs that help working people.
"Large tax cuts could deny the nation the full benefit of debt reduction," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said in a speech in New York today, "and depending on economic circumstances, they could force deep and dangerous cuts in core government or Social Security or Medicare."

HEADLINE: YELTSIN DISMISSES GRAFT ALLEGATION

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia told President Clinton in a telephone conversation today that accusations linking Mr. Yeltsin and his family to a corruption inquiry were politically inspired, the White House said this evening.
Samuel R. Berger, the President's national security adviser, said that Mr. Clinton specifically asked about reports that the Swiss authorities had evidence implicating Mr. Yeltsin and his family in taking bribes. The Swiss authorities were reported to have documents showing that Mr. Yeltsin's credit card bills and those of his two daughters had been paid by a construction company that did a great deal of renovation work on the Kremlin. 
 "And Yeltsin denied those reports," Mr. Berger said.
But another White House official, who commented on the condition that he not be named, said this evening that the Russian President's repudiation of the accusations was less categorical.
Mr. Yeltsin did not state his total innocence in so many words, the official said; rather, he insisted that the accusations were not substantive.
An informant, Felipe Turover, said on Wednesday that he had seen credit card bills and photocopies of credit cards bearing the signatures of Mr. Yeltsin and his daughters, and that the cards had been provided by Mabetex Project Engineering, a Swiss construction company that has done $1.5 billion worth of work for the Kremlin. Page A18.
The Swiss and Russian corruption inquiry, which is focusing on allegations of international money laundering and bribes to Russian politicians in exchange for lucrative construction contracts at the Kremlin itself, came up during part of a 40-minute telephone call, White House spokesmen said.
Mr. Yeltsin called Mr. Clinton to discuss a variety of topics, including disarmament negotiations and the Asian economic summit meeting in New Zealand this weekend, according to Mr. Berger.
As Mr. Berger recounted at a news briefing, Mr. Clinton broached the subject of money laundering and corruption by commenting that it would be good if Mr. Yeltsin could sign money laundering legislation recently passed by the lower house of Russia's Parliament.
Mr. Yeltsin said he was prepared to sign a money laundering bill if the Parliament passes one that is consistent with the Russian Constitution, Mr. Berger said. Mr. Yeltsin said he had doubts about a law passed this summer, and vetoed it for that reason.
Mr. Berger, responding to a question, said Mr. Clinton then got to the point, asking Mr. Yeltsin about the credit card bill reports.
Previously, Mr. Yeltsin's press aides have categorically denied that Mr. Yeltsin has anything to hide. And even people who detest Mr. Yeltsin personally and politically agree that he has plenty of enemies happy to say damning things about him.
The White House official said about 40 percent of the total conversation was devoted to government-corruption issues. The two national leaders -- neither of whom speaks the other's language -- spoke through interpreters. The official said Mr. Yeltsin called Mr. Clinton late this morning, which was early evening in Moscow.
A team of Russian law-enforcement officials is coming to the United States early next week to take part in the continuing multinational investigation, whose scope now includes allegations that money from Russia was laundered through the Bank of New York. The Russian contingent will include a high official of Russia's equivalent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, tax investigators and the Kremlin version of a national Attorney General.
The White House official who commented this evening said President Clinton did not indicate whether he felt totally reassured by Mr. Yeltsin's assertions. The American President did not disagree when his Russian counterpart said that the odor of scandal could damage relations between the two countries, the official said.
The United States has already asked Russia for assurances that no international financial assistance has been lost to corruption, although Washington stopped short of asking that International Monetary Fund loan payments to Russia be frozen. The Administration is under pressure by Republicans in Congress who have used the reports of corruption to raise questions about United States aid to Russia and to renew attacks on the I.M.F.
Last week, Swiss authorities investigating suspected money laundering by powerful Russians ordered Swiss banks to provide information on two dozen Russians thought to have accounts in Geneva. The Swiss have frozen at least 59 bank accounts in the past two months in the search for evidence.
Russians known to be under scrutiny include the head of Mr. Yeltsin's property-management team; his wife, daughter and son-in-law; and a former deputy prime minister involved in the military industry and arms exports.
And though no definite link has yet been established between the Swiss investigation and the one in the United States, American authorities are looking into possible laundering of Russian money through the Bank of New York. The bank has said it is cooperating.
As for other subjects touched upon in the conversation, Mr. Berger said they included missiles and missile defenses. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott is in Moscow now for exchanges on those subjects, and a Russian delegation is coming to Washington in mid-September.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton also discussed the Russian Army's battle with separatists in Dagestan, Mr. Berger said. "And President Yeltsin said that he expected and hoped that they would be able to gain control of the situation but it was a very difficult one," Mr. Berger said.

HEADLINE: Do Voucher Plans Steal From Poor Schools?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I have some concerns about George W. Bush's ideas for "fixing" education (letter, Sept. 7). First, research has shown a high correlation between family income and test score outcome. This implies that we already know which schools Mr. Bush would close: the ones that serve those same economically disadvantaged students he says he wants to help. 
 Before we hear any more "solutions" to problems in education, the financing of public schools needs to be equalized within each state. Schools should no longer be financed with property taxes, a formula that limits equal opportunity in education.
 
WENDY HELLER
Indianapolis, Sept. 7, 1999

HEADLINE: With Other Goals in Indonesia, U.S. Moves Gently on East Timor

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER and PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The United States is resisting direct threats of economic or military sanctions against Indonesia in hopes of preserving its relationship with the vast archipelago nation, even as the Administration protests the chaos in East Timor that has left hundreds of people dead, senior officials said.
The Administration, these officials say, has made the calculation that the United States must put its relationship with Indonesia, a mineral-rich nation of more than 200 million people, ahead of its concern over the political fate of East Timor, a tiny, impoverished territory of 800,000 people that is seeking independence. 
 The Defense Department is taking the lead in dealing with the crisis. Hoping to make use of longstanding ties between the Pentagon and the Indonesian military -- a relationship that dates to the early days of the Cold War, when Indonesia was seen as a bulwark against Communism -- the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, has talked by telephone with Indonesia's military commander, Gen. Wiranto, several times this week to discuss East Timor.
Officials say the two military leaders have discussed details of General Wiranto's plan to remove troops from East Timor who have allied themselves with anti-independence militias and replace them with soldiers clearly loyal to the central Government in Jakarta.
"It is not unreasonable to give him at least 24 hours to get folks there, and then you've got to give him a little time to bring them under control," a senior Administration official said. "Wiranto knows that everybody expects to see real traction on this very fast -- and very fast doesn't mean weeks."
While senior Administration officials did not rule out the use of sanctions, they acknowledged that the United States had no firm plans to punish the Jakarta Government if the violence continued. The Administration, they said, is willing to support an Australian-led United Nations peacekeeping force in East Timor, but only if it is invited by the Indonesian Government.
"Because we bombed in Kosovo doesn't mean we should bomb Dili," said Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, referring to the East Timor capital.
"Indonesia is the fourth-largest country in the world," he said. "It is undergoing a fragile but tremendously important political and economic transformation, which the United States strongly supports. The resolution of this crisis matters not just for East Timor but for Indonesia as a whole."
He suggested that American threats of a cutoff of economic or military aid to Indonesia were not necessary.
"It's not a question of making threats," he said. "It's a question of stating what is simply a practical fact of life, which is that it would be very hard for the international community to continue to be of economic assistance if there is a chaotic situation in Timor."
 In Jakarta, the Indonesian Government rejected pressure to allow foreign peacekeepers to enter East Timor. Page A8.
The United States has little direct leverage on the Indonesian military. Because of human rights abuses attributed to the military, Congress has sharply limited military aid and training to Indonesia, and the total military aid package this year totaled only $476,000.
"It's not as if we have a military assistance program that could be cut off," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
The United States has a more potent means of punishing Indonesia through what amounts to its veto power in the International Monetary Fund, which has committed tens of billions of dollars in emergency financial support to Indonesia as a result of the Asian economic crisis.
But Washington has been reluctant to threaten a cutoff of the aid for fear that the result would be a new economic collapse in Indonesia, further undermining its transition to democracy after three decades of authoritarian rule under President Suharto, who was forced from office last year. It could also harm American corporations that have large investments in Indonesia.
The Clinton Administration has focused its attention on persuading General Wiranto to step in personally to insure that his troops stop the violence.
The Indonesian military leader is respected by Pentagon officials for his military professionalism and is seen as the key figure in the crisis, overshadowing President B. J. Habibie, who appears to have little control over the situation and is distrusted by many in the military.
American officials say they are convinced that General Wiranto is not directing the violence in East Timor, but they say he has made few efforts to reign in junior military commanders who may be encouraging the violence as a means of blocking independence for the territory.
The United States is trying to convince General Wiranto that with order restored, a United Nations peacekeeping force could be deployed to East Timor and relieve him of the responsibility of controlling the militias until there is a final decision on East Timor's political future.
In a referendum last week that ignited the violence, an overwhelming majority of Timorese voted for independence from Indonesia, which invaded and annexed the former Portuguese colony in 1975.
A senior Pentagon official said today that the commander of American military forces in the Pacific, Adm. Dennis Blair, arrived in Jakarta today to carry the message to General Wiranto "that he has the responsibility to bring this under control and he had better belly up to that responsibility."
Administration officials are also concerned that the crisis in East Timor could disrupt the difficult relationship between the Indonesian military and its civilian leaders, and could bring down President Habibie, who has been praised by the United States for pushing ahead with democratic reforms.
Administration officials said that if the United Nations sponsored an armed peacekeeping mission in East Timor, it would almost certainly receive military support from the United States, although not ground troops.
"The United States is not planning an insertion of any peacekeeping troops," said Defense Secretary William S. Cohen. He called on the Indonesian Government to act "swiftly and effectively" to stop the militias. "The Government of Indonesia is responsible for bringing order and peace to East Timor," he said.
At a White House news conference, Mr. Berger said that any peacekeeping force would be "overwhelmingly Asian in character."
"We have to recognize that Indonesia is in Asia, and that the Indonesians will respond much better to a solution here that is dominated by the Asians and not dominated by the United States," he said.
The Government of Australia has volunteered to lead an international force and provide 2,000 troops, but has said that it will not go in alone.
American officials say they have been in close contact with the Australian Government and that if the United States participated in the mission, it would probably provide communications, logistics and intelligence support.
"We will look at what is the appropriate level of assistance we can give, whether it be logistical or technical support or other," said Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman. "But I can tell you that there's been no decision made on that."

HEADLINE: Students Face New Standards In City Schools

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
More than a million New York City schoolchildren -- many of them in uniform for the first time -- hoist their book bags and return to school today to face the toughest promotional standards in decades, a demoralized force of principals and uncertainty about the future of the school system's leader, Chancellor Rudy Crew.
This year, for the first time, all high school seniors -- in New York City, the suburbs and across the state -- must pass a Regents English examination to graduate. The new test is a particularly daunting challenge in the city, where fewer than half of the students graduate on time as it is. Younger children and their parents face the anxiety of new promotional standards in every grade from third grade up, which could force as many as 360,000 of the students to attend summer school next year. 
 It is a pivotal year as well for Dr. Crew, who, worried about his legacy after five years in New York, is under pressure to show progress in the system after a year of slumping test scores.
Dr. Crew's contract expires in June and it is not clear that the city's Board of Education will renew it or that he will stay until the last day.
"Assuming that he's going to stay at least through the year, and that he wants his legacy to be a positive one," said Robert Berne, vice president for academic development at New York University, "the stakes are high across the board -- for him, for principals, for teachers and certainly for the results that kids achieve."
On the bright side, enrollment has grown far more slowly than projected for the second year in a row -- with only 1,000 new students added to the system -- relieving somewhat the overcrowding that had forced schools to teach children in hallways, closets and even bathrooms. And the city schools have received $109 million in state and Federal aid to begin addressing a perennial concern of parents: large classes in kindergarten through third grade.
In many of New York City's suburbs, children returned to school yesterday, greeting friends whom they had not seen all summer, sizing up their new teachers and dragging their parents to buy last-minute school supplies.
For many children and educators, it is the push to higher standards, in which New York mirrors a trend across the country, that will cause the most stress, pressure and heartache.
"Parents bring back the worry, with all of the new testing: will our children be prepared?" said Jan Atwell, associate director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a nonprofit group that monitors city schools, and the mother of a high school senior. "All of their work all year long can boil down to a single day's performance. I think there's a lot of stress involved for kids."
Already this summer, in a small-scale introduction of the city school system's efforts to end social promotion, 21,000 third, sixth and eighth graders have been held back, 7,000 because they failed an end-of-summer test, but 14,000 because they may not have realized what was at stake and failed to show up for summer school.
The introduction of new state tests in the fourth and eighth grades last year also proved ominous as 52 percent of all fourth graders in New York State -- and 67 percent of those in New York City -- failed to meet state standards in reading and writing. The results for mathematics and for the eighth grade have not yet been released.
Dr. Crew said at a briefing last week that he expected both math and reading scores to rise this year, as they usually do in the second year of a new test.
But many educators fear that new high school graduation standards, imposed by the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, and the State Board of Regents, will cause graduation rates to plummet. This year's seniors will not be allowed to graduate without passing a Regents test in English with a score of at least 55. Tests in four more subjects will be phased in in subsequent years, and the passing grade will be raised to 65.
Similar requirements in other states have led to lawsuits as parents have contended that their children were not given the education that they needed to graduate.
Until now, children have been allowed to graduate by taking an easier competency test, which is being eliminated. In 1998, 37 percent of city seniors and 27 percent of seniors in the rest of the state did not pass the Regents test in English. The new test was introduced in June, but pass rates have not yet been released.
"It counts, and it counts big time," Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, said of the new exam.
Dr. Crew will have to steer the system through the new standards while grappling with principals who are increasingly demoralized after working without a raise since October 1995 and without a contract since February 1996. Dr. Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have offered the principals' union a raise of 33 percent if principals agree to give up tenure and work a longer year. Those talks have stalemated.
As the school year begins, 195 schools of the system's 1,200 schools, or about 16 percent, lack permanently appointed principals and are being led by interim acting principals, Lewis H. Spence, Deputy Chancellor for Operations, said yesterday. The union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, said the 195 was the highest figure in the last five years.
"We are frustrated and concerned," Mr. Spence said, conceding that the absence of permanent leadership can be a destabilizing force. Many principals, he said, echoing union complaints, have been recruited by New York City's wealthier and higher-paying suburbs.
But he said that Dr. Crew would stand by his decision not to grant substantial raises unless principals moved toward a management system where tenure was based on performance.
In the longer term, Ms. Weingarten of the teachers' union said, the system may also face a drain of teachers. By 2001, she said, 21,000 teachers will be eligible to retire, compared with a normal retirement rate of 2,100 a year.
As for the decline in enrollment growth, Mr. Spence said officials were puzzled by the numbers, which were far below the 15,000 to 20,000 new students arriving in the system just a few years ago. He said changing patterns of immigration -- more families moving out of the city in a booming economy, with fewer families with children moving in -- could be the cause, but the board is working with city planning and immigration officials to determine that for sure.
But as in previous years, Queens schools are overcrowded. This year, the borough's schools are 26,000 over capacity, and the lack of space has forced 8,000 high school students to take six classes instead of the state-mandated seven, said Terri Thompson, a Board of Education member from Queens.
Karen Crowe, a board spokeswoman, said the city plans to build 65,000 seats in the next five years to deal with the problem.
The system has made progress in hiring certified teachers, with the number of uncertified teachers citywide down to an all-time low of 13 percent, Mr. Spence said.
Whether Dr. Crew remains to see the results of the new policies depends in part, he has said, on the political climate. The Board of Education is conducting an evaluation that will help determine whether to renew his contract, a decision that must be made in January. Around that time, a state Moreland Act commission is expected to release the results of its investigation into allegations of mismanagement and corruption in the school construction and leasing program. The commission is also looking at allegations that school officials inflated attendance as a way of collecting more state aid.
By then, the race for for the United States Senate will be heating up, and Mayor Giuliani, a likely candidate, could resurrect issues, like school vouchers, that he and Dr. Crew have feuded over. Dr. Crew has said that he intends to stay until June or beyond -- although he is being wooed by the University of Washington -- but that the political landscape could determine whether he stays or goes.
"The curveball about his tenure in New York is unfortunate, because it will divert attention" and could undermine Dr. Crew's ability to lead the school system, Mr. Berne said.

HEADLINE: Betting the Farm On the Virtual Store

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT

 BODY:
FOR eight years, Fred Parks says, he sold all manner of antiques and collectibles, "everything but tube socks and T-shirts," from a series of stores in downtown Baltimore. About a year ago, he closed his latest store, but he didn't go out of business. He took his expertise in ceramics -- Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Arts and Crafts styles -- to Ebay, the largest of the on-line auction sites.
Now working from home and a studio that he rents for $100 a month, he has lowered his expenses, he says, and increased his prices and profits. "If I opened a store, I might have 35 people on a good day," he said. "I get thousands in my virtual store." 
 More and more people are making a living from on-line auctions, often closing their brick-and-mortar stores or quitting jobs to vend bric-a-brac electronically at auctions like the ones at Ebay (www.ebay .com), Amazon.com (www.amazon.com) and Yahoo (www.yahoo.com). According to a report issued in March by Forrester Research, a consulting company that tracks E-commerce, spending on auction sites will grow from $1 billion in 1998 to an estimated $2.3 billion this year. While none of the auction sites knows how many people have turned electronic auctions into full-time jobs, Ebay estimates that it has about 10,000 "power sellers," who sell merchandise for $2,000 to $25,000 or more each month.
Mr. Parks said he had no regrets about going virtual. "I at this point have no interest in ever having a store again," he said. "Why would I?"
Why? Well, there are the long hours at the computer, and the tedium of wrapping and sending countless packages. Sometimes the auction sites crash, suspending business for days and putting a crimp in the cash flow. And there are the prickly customers who think nothing of firing off rude E-mail tirades. But for Mr. Parks and others, the increased profits and ability to open for business at any hour are ample compensation for the drawbacks of Web auctions.
The Forrester Research study projects that by 2003, auction sites will account for $6.4 billion in spending.
As more store owners get a taste of selling on line, more stores will close, analysts predict. Michael May, a digital commerce analyst for Jupiter Communications, a research firm in Boston, explained: "They are Main Street, mom-and-pop-type stores that realize they are selling a far greater percentage of their inventory through sites like Ebay, and they can't justify paying rent anymore."
For instance, take Mike Baker, who had averaged $30,000 to $40,000 in revenue a year selling baseball cards and photographs from his store in Springdale, Ark. Now he makes bulk purchases of movie star photos and art prints to sell in on-line auctions, and he reports that his gross revenue is in six figures.
Mr. Baker said he had been initially startled by the effectiveness of auction sales two years ago when he posted some Marilyn Monroe photos that were readily available from other sources. "If I got $6 back, I broke even; if I sold them for $12, I did good," he said. They sold for $36.10 each. (Mr. Baker has since self-published a book, "Strike it Rich on Ebay.")
Or take Chris Gwynn, who quit his job as a marketing analyst with the Yankee Group in Boston to sell refrigerator magnets on line. He has now branched out to auctioning new action figures and has created his own site (actionfigureauctions.com) to sell them.
Mr. Gwynn makes less money than he did as an analyst. "But within a year," he said, "I should be doing a lot better than I was."
Auction sites have made it fairly simple for people to hang out a shingle because they require sellers to do little more than enter information in a series of text boxes. That has made it possible for even the computer-phobic to become involved in E-commerce.
"I was scared of it and I thought I was too old to learn," said Claudia Bennett, an antiques dealer in Vernon, Tex. Ms. Bennett, who is 52, is now designing her own Web page, and she says she does not regret closing her 14,000-square-foot store or quitting her job at the post office to underwrite her antiques operation. "Now for the first time, I am making money at it," she said.
While anyone can sell on line, not just anyone can make a living at it. "It's not as easy as saying, 'I am an E-merchant,' " said Mr. Parks, who bought a $1,200 digital camera, lights and a booth to make his ceramics and other wares look appealing on line. "A bad photograph will not make you money."
Even though successful, full-time auction entrepreneurs set their own hours, they say the job is extremely demanding. One such Web merchant, Lisa Harrington, said she had owned a tropical fish store in Houston that went bankrupt. But six years after the bankruptcy, she was drawn into Ebay when she helped a friend who was struggling with an on-line business. She struck out on her own in June 1998, and in the year that followed, she said, she took in $250,000, selling everything from electronics to motorized self-scooping cat litter boxes.
To generate that kind of income, Mrs. Harrington signs on at 8:30 A.M. on workdays and does not sign off until 2 A.M., taking only an hour on some days to watch a soap opera. She takes only Fridays and Mondays off. "They are dead," she said.
On a typical workday, she handles about 600 E-mail messages, monitors 20 auctions and packages about 20 items for shipping. She also has to scare up fresh stock over the phone and on line.
Although customers pay for shipping fees -- and Mrs. Harrington confides that she sometimes makes a small profit on the shipping charges -- there are other costs that new sellers tend to overlook, like the fees charged by auction sites, usually a percentage of the selling price. Mrs. Harrington said that she paid an average of $2,000 a month to Ebay alone. She also uses sites like Utrade, Ubid, Haggle and 321Gone. Mr. Baker also puts in long hours selling his celebrity photos and art prints. "I start at 6 every morning," he said. "I work until 6. Then I take a break. Then I go back up around 10."
Alan Hunter, who auctions sports and political memorabilia on line, said he put in eight hours a day photographing items, writing descriptions, uploading information onto the day's auction sites, answering E-mail and packing up items to be mailed out. "But that doesn't include the time you spend hunting this stuff up," he said. "The toughest part is that you have a commitment to it every single day."
Those who are not willing to put in long hours may get involved in too few auctions to really make money. Even worse, they may be slow to respond to customers, which can result in the posting of complaints referred to as dreaded "negative feedback."
When a transaction is completed, the seller and buyer can write a short message commenting on it. Such feedback is available for all to see, and it works as a self-policing mechanism, warning people away from buyers or sellers who other people think are dishonest.
The problem for someone selling goods at a lot of auctions is that it is easy to accrue negative comments. The more customers a seller has, the greater the chances that some of them will be slow to pay or hard to satisfy. If a seller posts a complaint about a buyer, the buyer may retaliate. "And before you know it," Mr. Hunter said, "you have 20 negative feedbacks." The alternative is for a seller to grin and bear it when dealing with a testy buyer -- a frequent occurrence.
Sellers often try to increase profits a few percentage points by avoiding auction site fees. For instance, there is no rule against a seller getting in touch with auction losers to make separate deals if the seller has multiple copies of an item.
Arlen Miller, who quit his job at Planet Hollywood in Orlando two years ago to deal full time on line in Disney collectibles, said: "I'll look at Ebay stuff, and if I have the same item on my list, I'll go back when the auction is over. You can go in and look at all of the bidders. If it went for $50, and I have it for $30, I'll send a note."
But Mr. Miller draws an ethical line. "I would never step on someone's toes by doing that before their auction is over."
The auction game is outgrowing the boundaries of Ebay, Amazon and Yahoo. The Forrester study predicted that the future of on-line auctions would be in sales of new retail products sold by companies, often on their own sites, rather than by individuals.
"Over time, consumers will prefer buying from businesses rather than individuals since businesses are more accountable and offer first-run merchandise," the report said. A check using Yahoo's search engine turned up a list of close to 200 auction sites, including head-to-head Ebay competitors as well as specialty sites like Justbeads.com, which auctions beads, and Floorspace.com, which auctions industrial machinery.
Off-the-shelf auction software makes it possible for individuals and small businesses to set up their own auction sites. "Auction software costs about $5,000," said Mr. Gwynn, the refrigerator magnet magnate who sells his action figures on his own site. "The server is a few hundred dollars a month."
Mr. Gwynn does not allow other people to sell on his site. If he had set up the site that way, he said, he would have been competing against Ebay; that, he added, would be a losing proposition.
In an early test of his sales plan, Mr. Gwynn said, he auctioned 96 Austin Powers figures, which sell at retail for about $11, in a week. He sold many of them in the $20 range, and some for as much as $38. "They were popular that week, and they were hard to get," he said.
Not all the figures have flown off the shelves. Mr. Gwynn has found it difficult to sell everything from Barbie to "Star Wars" figures on a single site. So he will soon specialize even more. He plans to set up auction sites that are organized to reflect the way collectors collect: by manufacturer. That will make it easier to reach collectors looking for specific toys through on-line bulletin boards and newsletters, he said.
While the on-line auction entrepreneurs do a lot of selling, they do little buying on line. "I never have really been able to buy on Ebay to re-sell and make a profit on it," said Mr. Baker, the print seller.
In fact, some sellers worry about what Ebay and other sites will mean for their sources for items, like garage sales, if everyone is selling everything, including the kitchen sink, on line.
So far those fears have proved to be unfounded. The number of yard sales each weekend proves that people still need to clean out their attics -- and that most of them still do it the off-line way, especially if they don't own a digital camera.
 
Sales Strategies
TOP sellers agree that the most important ingredient for success in on-line auctions is choosing the right words to describe the item up for bid.
The trick is to include as many potential search words as possible in the limited space allowed for the title line of a listing. That way, when a prospective bidder searches for a particular item, there is a greater chance for a hit.
"You take a Marlboro lighter," said Mike Baker, who sells movie star photos and art prints in on-line auctions. "If you write 'butane lighter, Marlboro Zippo style,' you've got four key words. A lot of people would put 'Great, beautiful, hard-to-find Marlboro lighter.' That way you have only two words."
Spelling counts, too. Buyers who search for a product using the correctly spelled word will never find a listing with a misspelling. The result is fewer bids.
In fact, clever buyers intentionally search using misspelled words to find the best deals. For instance, a search on Ebay for "beanie babies" produced 10,066 listings. But a search using the misspelling "beenie" returned only 10 listings, some ripe for the picking without any bids. ROY FURCHGOTT

HEADLINE: Foiled Once, China's Entry In Trade Body Is on Agenda

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Thursday, Sept. 9

 BODY:
After a period of high tension between the United States and China, the two sides met here today to set the stage for the resumption of talks on China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Five months ago, the Clinton Administration rebuffed an offer that the Chinese thought would be accepted, and Washington has been trying to get the talks to resume almost ever since, but tensions only grew worse with NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and the renewed tensions between China and Taiwan. 
 In the first concerted activity to get the talks going again, the United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, arrived here from Washington along with the two chief American trade negotiators who came directly from Beijing.
The Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, met with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Jiaxuan Tang, for 90 minutes this morning in an encounter that was described by an Administration official as "free of any acrimony."
Ms. Barshefsky emphasized this morning that meetings between the Americans and the Chinese over the last day and a half in Beijing were an "ice-breaking session" and "very general" in nature.
Substantive talks about China's membership in the body that governs world trade -- a membership that the Clinton Administration very much wants but on what it calls commercially viable terms -- had not resumed, she said.
President Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, are scheduled to meet here on Saturday, their first face-to-face meeting since Mr. Clinton was in China in 1998. Since then the relationship between Washington and Beijing has plummeted to its lowest depths in years.
Administration officials hope that the presidential discussions on Saturday will help right the course of the relationship and result in the resumption of serious and speedy negotiations that would allow China to enter the trade body.
A new round of global trade talks is being held in Seattle in November. If China fails to enter the World Trade Organization before those talks, the Chinese would most likely face more stringent entry requirements.
The meeting between the two leaders has become the most significant event of the annual economic summit meeting of leaders of the Asian region. They may be able to announce a resumption of negotiations.
But Ms. Barshefsky said that despite the visit of her team to Beijing this week it was still not clear what the Chinese intentions were.
"Do they want to re-engage for the look of it or because they want to substantively re-engage to conclude an agreement?" she said.
To pursue the resumption of talks further, Ms. Barshefsky was to meet here tonight with her Chinese counterpart, the Foreign Trade Minister, Shi Guangsheng.
The White House, buffeted by criticism from the business community and from some quarters in Congress for its failure to seal an agreement with China when it seemed possible in April, has been pushing to resume the negotiations with the Chinese almost since President Clinton turned down the Chinese offer on April 8.
But the Administration has been blocked by a series of unrelated setbacks -- chiefly the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and the Taiwan-China dispute.
One of the most difficult tasks for the negotiators now, officials said, would be how to overcome the appearance that each nation had caved to the demands of the other.
In choosing not to forge a deal when Prime Minister Zhu Rongji was in Washington in April, President Clinton decided he wanted several more concessions from the Chinese, officials said.
The agreement that failed to close -- but was posted on the Internet by the Clinton Administration the day after the White House decision -- would have given broad market access to China for many American goods and services.
But Mr. Clinton wanted stronger safeguards for the American textile apparel industry against Chinese imports and sought other concessions in the area of insurance.

HEADLINE: Sharp Divergence Found in Views of Military and Civilians

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
A deep gap over politics and values has opened over the last two decades between the nation's increasingly conservative military elite and prominent civilians without military service, sowing latent distrust despite the respect each group professes for the other.
These are the first findings of a major study of military and civilian attitudes, focusing on a problem that Defense Secretary William S. Cohen has called a major challenge for him: "to somehow prevent a chasm from developing between the military and civilian worlds." 
 While there were few disagreements about foreign policy between the two groups, the single most striking finding was political.
Ordinary Americans divide about evenly between calling themselves Democrats or Republicans, but the study found that 64 percent of elite military officers called themselves Republicans. Only 8 percent said they were Democrats.
A more modest gap, on political identification had been measured before. Comparable 1976 data found that 33 percent of military officers identified themselves as Republicans and 12 percent as Democrats. The 1976 survey did not cover values. The remainder, in both surveys, said they were independent or had no political affiliation.
The most startling differences were found between the military leaders and the potential military leaders, like students at advanced schools like the war colleges, and prominent civilians who had never served in the armed forces.
The civilians were selected at random from Who's Who and from other lists, like prominent women, the clergy, foreign policy experts, labor leaders and the press. Prominent civilians with military service fell in between.
For example, 45 percent of the military group favored barring homosexuals from teaching in public schools, while only 17 percent of the nonveteran civilian group did. Ten percent of the military leaders supported a ban on the death penalty while 37 percent of the civilians did. And 74 percent of the military group backed permitting prayer in public schools, compared with 46 percent of the civilian group.
Some of the differences can be explained by the fact that the officers were almost all men, while the nonveteran civilian group was two-fifths women.
The results were taken from nearly 4,000 interviews conducted in late 1998 and early 1999 as part of a $500,000 study that will ultimately produce at least 20 academic papers. The study is coordinated for the Triangle Institute for Security Studies, a nonprofit foundation based in North Carolina, by Richard H. Kohn, a professor of history at the University of North Carolina, and Peter D. Feaver, associate professor of political science at Duke University.
In meeting rooms and corridors, the first findings were the hot topic last weekend at the 95th annual meeting of the American Political Science Association in Atlanta. Further data are to be made public at a conference by the Triangle Institute in late October in Caughny, Ill., including a comparison with the views of the general civilian public that may show the nonveteran elite more at odds with ordinary Americans than is the military elite.
That conference, unlike the association's meeting in Atlanta, will focus exclusively on the civilian-military study and will offer more examination of the causes and consequences of the gap.
In papers presented at the Atlanta meeting, scholars had more fear of potential dangers than evidence of any impact of the gap thus far. Prof.Ole R. Holsti of Duke, who longed for the days when generals like George C. Marshall never even voted, said, "A political military is worrisome if it just becomes another interest group."
Prof. Charles Stevenson of the National War College said it was "scary" to have "an officer corps so overwhelmingly Republican."
"In the 19th century, officers frequently had political alignments," Professor Stevenson said, "but they did not favor a single party consistently."
Benjamin O. Fordham, assistant professor of political science at the State University of New York at Albany, said the gap in beliefs had not affected either military spending or the rates of enlistment and re-enlistment. But the professor said he worried that Democrats might not take seriously warnings from a military establishment that they perceived as overwhelmingly Republican.
One clear finding was a widespread unhappiness in the military with current trends in civilian society. But despite the generally high regard the public holds for the military, there were some clear measures of latent civilian distrust.
"Support for the military drops, even precipitously, as connections to the military disappear," wrote Dr. Feaver and Paul Gronke, assistant professor of political science at Duke.
Twenty-one percent, for example, of the civilian nonveteran elite said they would be disappointed if one of their children joined the armed forces. Just 7 percent of the military officers felt that way. On the other hand, 77 percent of officers agreed with the statement that "civilian society would be better off if it adopted more of the military's values and customs;" only 43 percent of civilian elites with military experience agreed and just 25 percent of the nonveterans agreed.
One simple explanation for some of the gap is the differing attitudes of men and women. Women make up 41 percent of the civilian nonveteran elite, but only 8 percent of the military elite. Dr. Feaver said in an interview that on many of the issues examined, as much as half the difference between military and civilian opinions could be attributed to the relative conservatism of men.
But the difference between the Republicanism of the more than 600 almost all-male officers surveyed and the nearly 700 nonveteran civilians is only marginally related to the preference of women for the Democratic Party. The most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll showed that 29 percent of the public was Republican and 31 percent Democrat. Among men, 29 percent also said they were Republicans but just 26 percent identified themselves as Democrats.
Among the nonveteran civilian elite, 30 percent called themselves Republicans, and 43 percent Democrats, while among veterans, 47 percent identified themselves as Republicans, and 23 percent Democrats.
The veterans averaged nearly 60 years old, while the nonveterans averaged around 50.
Two other military groups were also surveyed, nearly 400 officers in the active reserves and 1,700 students in the Reserve Officers Training Corps in colleges and cadets and midshipmen at the service academies, who were identified as "precommissioned" respondents. Among the reservists, 63 percent said they were Republicans and 10 percent identified themselves as Democrats, while 47 percent of the students said they were Republican and 12 percent Democrats.
Dr. Holsti said it was clear that the Republican trend in the military began well before President Clinton took office. There is considerable tension between the Administraton and the military over Mr. Clinton's avoiding the draft, his effort to remove barriers to homosexuals in the services and the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
But Dr. Holsti also said the Republicans in the military were not extremists; only 13 percent called themselves "very conservative." They rejected propositions like removing books attacking religion or promoting Communism or homosexuality from library shelves by the same sort of overwhelming majorities as others in the study.
On military and foreign policy questions, there were many agreements between the nonveterans and the military elite. Both overwhelmingly supported using the United Nations to help settle international disputes and felt the American public would not tolerate large numbers of casualties in military operations.
Both groups heavily rejected the idea that military, rather than political goals, should govern the use of force. Both disagreed sharply with the statement, "We shouldn't think so much in international terms but concentrate more on our own national problems."
But there were also clear differences. Among the nonveterans, 59 percent agreed with the statement that "American national security depends more on international trade and a strong domestic economy than on our military strength." Only 37 percent of the officers agreed. And 65 percent of the officers but only 43 percent of the nonveterans agreed with the idea that "there is nothing wrong with using the C.I.A. to try to undermine hostile governments."
Professor Kohn said in an interview that when the study was completed, "We are likely to have a set of conclusions that are complex."
The current level of discussion of the issue, he said, "tends to be one of extremes," either arguing that the differences between military and civilians are of no consequence, or that they raise the threat of a breakdown in civilian control.
The professor said it was important to identify the differences that were new and also those that did not simply represent the fact that the military was an "unusual and very different profession."

HEADLINE: HOME VIDEO;
Poking Wounds Within a Family

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
"If we're lucky enough, we work for and toward our weakest area," said the filmmaker Alan Berliner, who guessed it was the psychiatrist Carl Jung who first provided that observation. In any event, Mr. Berliner steered toward family, particularly his own, in three acclaimed documentaries, "The Family Album," "Intimate Stranger" and "Nobody's Business," to be released on tape on Tuesday by Milestone Film and Video.
Mr. Berliner's films are praised for their introspection. They also make the commonplace totally involving. "In 'Nobody's Business,' Alan Berliner illustrates the power of fine art to transform life," Lawrence Van Gelder wrote in The New York Times. 
 That film, shown at the New York Film Festival in 1996, was the third in the series. "My family life in childhood was very painful," he said. "I've been inching my way toward 'Nobody's Business.' " The first documentary, "The Family Album" (1986), led him to the general subject of family. A collection of ingeniously pieced-togother snatches from countless home movies, most from the 30's and 40's, the film touches on life's eras: babyhood, school, dating, marriage, child rearing, aging, death. Accompanying them are bits of oral history and family audio recordings. "My school isn't like your school; I'll be a laborer like my father," someone says in a typically striking remark.
Storm clouds of trouble suddenly gather: unemployment and money problems, excessive drinking, fighting, loss of hope and direction, strangulating marriages, child support (or lack of it). Someone remarks that there is a sadness to a broken family, a subject Mr. Berliner gets to in "Nobody's Business."
Before that, though, came "Intimate Stranger" (1991), a film about his maternal grandfather, Joseph Cassuto, a cotton merchant whose family bent but never broke through years of separation and dysfunction. A Palestinian Jew brought up in Egypt, Mr. Cassuto worked for the Japanese Cotton Trading Company in Alexandria. After World War II, he moved to Japan, where he worked for 11 months of the year. He left his wife and four children in Brooklyn. In the film he is described as a man who lived to please his associates. He is not rated highly as a father. "There were a lot of things going on in Brooklyn, U.S.A., but he wasn't around," a son says.
The most caustic comments come from Oscar Berliner, Mr. Cassuto's son-in-law, Alan's dedicated father and the subject of Alan's most accomplished film, "Nobody's Business." In the early 70's, Oscar and his wife (Mr. Cassuto's daughter) divorced after years of domestic discord that deeply affected their young children. Now a gruff, reclusive man in his 80's, the elder Berliner bluntly rebuffs his son's explanation of the reasons to make a documentary about him, which, in Alan's view, include the need for father and son to link with each other and by extension with the world. Oscar says he sees no such need and ducks behind a who-cares attitude. "You're trying to put your head on my shoulders and it won't work," he insists.
Nevertheless, Alan said, Oscar responded to the standing ovation he received from the audience at the New York Film Festival.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Gazing in a Mirror: The Omnipresent Camera

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
IN the age of mechanical reproduction, the hatred that dare not speak its name may well be photophobia. In these image-saturated times, even the most devout lovers of photography can succumb, while acute sufferers may even long for heated discussions of "the death of photography." After all, if other forms of human expression -- painting, sculpture, the novel -- are regularly pronounced dead, why is photography exempt?
Here, unfortunately, is why: Photography, you might say, is us. A century and a half after its invention, it is less a "form of human expression" than an inextricable part of the human condition and contemporary landscape, something involuntary and inescapable, almost like weather. It is no longer possible to catalogue its uses and applications, the fields of knowledge it has extended and the doors of experience it has opened, not to mention the thrilling tricks, illusions and visual manipulations it executes daily in magazines and newspapers and on billboards. At the moment the southeast corner of 26th Street and the Avenue of the Americas is dominated by the spectacle of a towering image of a well-shod young man scaling a brick wall that covers the side, also brick, of a 12-story building. It is an advertisement for shoes, but what dazzles is the giant figure, the blend of real and depicted brick and the way the building's actual windows become part of the image. Photography permeates the social fabric, the media and cyberspace, our very dreams. And it is the most omnipresent of all art forms. 
 Despite talk of the rise of video or the return of painting or the dominance of installation art, nothing in the last three decades of art can match the triumph of photography. Since the late 1960's, when it was put into play by Conceptual Art, photography has changed the history of art and infiltrated every other contemporary art medium while diversifying exponentially.
It has generated a sea change or two in art criticism and theory as well. And it has demonstrated that it is as capable as any other art medium of endless repetition and derivativeness, as suggested by the plethora of snapshots that, in various sizes, pass for art these days. An exhibition at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center offers some respite from the onslaught of photography that in the homeopathic tradition of treating like with like consists of more of the same. "The Promise of Photography: Selected Works From the DG Bank Collection" is a big, genial show of work dating from the early 1960's to the present. Its nearly 300 images by 32 artists are spread throughout the center's dozen ground-floor galleries with a sense of spaciousness and order that feels unusual by today's standards, when so many dense-packed photography installations seem bent on mimicking the medium's saturation of everyday life.
Selected from the DG Bank's enormous collection by Alanna Heiss, P.S. 1's director, and Klaus Biesenbach, one of its curators, "The Promise of Photography" seems like an attempt to clear the air quietly, to loosely yet seriously chart the extraordinary range of art photography without a hint of agenda, polemic or sensation.
In a purely experiential sense, air, or open space, is something that P.S. 1 has in quantity. There are rarely more than one or two artists to a gallery, and the blank walls provide perceptual intervals and pauses that enable each one's work to stand, or occasionally fall, in isolation, although there are plenty of connections and contrasts to be drawn if one is so inclined. The effect is marvelously unforced and unpredictable.
The works on view range from Marco Giacomelli's early 1960's black-and-white photographs of exuberant clerics on ice skates, their dark robes dramatically silhouetted against the snow, to Magdalena Jetelova's overly contrived images of dark Icelandic landscapes streaked with the white hot lines of a laser. In between, the show runs the gamut from artifice to document and back again. There are various kinds of street and landscape photography, work from several generations of Conceptually inclined artists (Dan Graham, Christian Boltanski, Dennis Adams, Candida Hofer) and sundry examples of set-up photography. The most notable of these is "Something More," Tracey Moffat's steamy Outback melodrama of death, desire and derailed travel plans, a tale told in nine images that combine over-the-top Technicolor with the silvers and grays of film noir.
The show is rife with the work of artists who have not had solo shows in New York; the mysterious portraits and landscapes of Bill Henson, who, like Ms. Moffat, is Australian, are a case in point. And there are several younger artists, both known and unknown, whose work reflects a new generation's embrace of the intuitive.
The German photographer Wolfgang Tillmans is represented by a wall scattered with his stylishly romantic images of his friends and surroundings. Nearby the sculptor Gabriel Orozco tactfully makes his presence felt with three color images that characteristically blend the exotic and banal. And across the way, the close-ups by the German artist Tamara Grcic zero in on the details, mostly green, of a grocery store in Chinatown in New York.
It makes perfect sense that these newcomers share a gallery with three color images from the 1970's by Helen Levitt, the great photographer of New York street life whose work has done so much to reveal the joys of the serendipitous encounter.
Ms. Heiss and Mr. Biesenbach seem to have deliberately avoided some of the most obvious usual suspects, skipping William Wegman, Cindy Sherman, Thomas Struth and Thomas Ruff, even though the collection includes their work. And there are several surprises. Hanging opposite the charming Giacomelli images are a series of irresistibly antic images of Japanese children at play by Nobuyoshi Araki, best known in New York for voyeuristic, sexually charged scenes of scantily clad women. Considered against the background of Mr. Araki's other work, the innocence of his photographs at P.S. 1 is almost jarring.
There are also invigorating changes of pace. The walls of one gallery are covered with a single 109-image work from 1990 by the German Conceptualist Hanne Darboven. The color photographs document every page of a week-at-a-glance calendar completely filled with the artist's abstract script, measuring time in wavelike ebbs and flows.
The next gallery presents two photographs by the German artist Katharina Sieverding: enormous X-ray-like images that show the human skull infused with clouds of liquid that suggest the imagination depicted at a rolling boil. A tiny alcove in one corner of this gallery holds one of the show's sweetest surprises, dopey self-portraits of Eva and Adele, the angelic German performance artists (a man and woman) known for a kind of double-cross cross-dressing. They always appear at international art openings dressed as identical female twins in bright vinyl suits and heavy powder, but confuse matters with their shaved heads. The images are accompanied by viewer mail.
The show often progresses in telling juxtapositions of sympathetic or contrasting sensibilities. In one of the early galleries, a photograph generated by the latest installment of Matthew Barney's "Cremaster" film series is a straight-on head shot of the artist as Gary Gilmore, grim, gritty and carefully staged.
Across the way are 12 images from Andy Warhol's "Social Disease," his offhand oddly caricature snapshots from the 1970's of the rich and famous and glamorous at play. They are, by the way, the only images of celebrities in the exhibition.
The German painters Sigmar Polke and Gerhard Richter, longtime colleagues, take opposite walls, each represented by a small gallery with a small series of photographs that share a gray fuzziness and lackadaisical technique. Mr. Polke's double-exposed images of starlike sculptures fashioned from a folding ruler are from 1968 and brim with Post-Minimalist laissez-faire. Mr. Richter's shadowy images, from 1991, show the artist and others in a murky basement and exude some of the sinister, crime-scene ghostliness reminiscent of early works like his Bader-Meinhoff paintings, which were based on news photographs of the German terrorist group.
In another gallery, the straightforward photographs of William Eggleston and Stephen Shore, all from the 70's, cast the American South and the American West, respectively, in a glowing yet desolate light in scenes riddled with social inequity, economic decline and emotional isolation. Their genuineness is pointed up by one large image from the intractably cerebral Rodney Graham, of a tall and glorious ponderosa pine that is hung upside down. Fittingly, the image recreates the inversion of the human retina that makes all vision possible.
"The Promise of Photography: Selected Works From the DG Bank Collection" is at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, through Oct. 24.

HEADLINE: The New Russian Menace

BYLINE: By James A. Leach; James A. Leach, a Republican Representative from Iowa, is chairman of the House Banking Committee, which will hold hearings this month on international financial corruption.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Recent allegations that American and European banks have facilitated money laundering for Russian organized-crime figures underscore how intractable a problem corruption in Russia is and how vulnerable Western institutions are to the lure of servicing the world's most virulent kleptocracy.
Russia is hardly the first country to be victimized by a culture of corruption. The plundering of the Philippines under Marcos, the looting of Zaire by Mobutu and Indonesia's crony capitalism during the last years of Suharto stand as parallels. What sets Russia apart is the pervasiveness of politically tolerated corruption in a country of such size and geopolitical significance. 
 The Russian Government estimates that criminal syndicates control 40 percent of the economy and perhaps half of the country's banking assets, though others put the figures higher. In any country where political stability is questionable and legal protections of property are unreliable, those who come to control wealth, legally or otherwise, can be expected to invest abroad. In Russia, theft exceeds investment, resulting in negative economic growth and a disillusioned society.
The question is how the West should respond. Americans have both a vested and a humanitarian interest in helping the Russian transition to democracy. But there's no credible way to suggest to taxpayers that they should support assistance to a government that allows insiders to recycle aid from the West in the form of laundered bank deposits, personal investments in the stock market or Pebble Beach real estate. American policy in this circumstance should be directed to helping the Russian people, not its rulers.
The struggle of the last half century was to defeat Communism; the challenge in the years ahead will be to constrain corruption. The second struggle may well prove more difficult, because avarice is a more fundamental aspect of human nature than the Communist precept that people are subject to historical determinist forces beyond the individual's control.
We should begin by enforcing our laws, issuing indictments if necessary. Such actions might prompt Russian prosecutors to do the same, calling Russia's new class of thieving oligarchs to account for domestic crimes more serious than international banking violations. We should also emphasize retrieving stolen assets for the Russian people rather than giving new aid, except perhaps food assistance.
For the Russians' part, instead of propelling the flight of capital through a banking system that principally serves as a platform for money laundering, they should establish community-oriented banks and press for the opening of branches of well-regulated Western banks in which people can trust that their savings will be turned into loans for local enterprises. No nation, after all, can prosper if it lacks institutions where people can safely put their money and seek secure loans.
Most of all, we have an obligation to insure that the corrosive impact of foreign corruption is blocked from our shores. America may be as challenged today by the threat of a deterioration of values -- galloping corruption -- as it was yesterday by Marxist ideology.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Matthew Martin)

HEADLINE: New Economic Data Stir Inflation Fears

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
New claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly declined last week, good news for job seekers but a sign of potential trouble to economists who worry about inflation.
A total of 286,000 Americans filed new claims for jobless benefits for the week ended Saturday, a drop of 4,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department said today. That was the lowest level since Aug. 21, when claims were at 285,000. 
 Many economists had been expecting that new claims would actually rise a little to 290,000.
The four-week moving average for claims, which irons out week-to-week volatility, rose just 750, to 287,500 last week.
Economists consider jobless claims levels below 300,000 an indication of an extremely tight labor market. In August, the nation's unemployment rate inched down to 4.2 percent, returning to a 29-year low.
That is good for workers but worrisome to economists. They fear employers scrambling for workers will offer higher wages and benefits, which could drive up prices and trigger inflation.
That has not happened so far. Although growth in productivity the amount of output for each hour worked slowed in the spring, it is one of the forces helping to keep inflation low.
And, the Government last week said hourly earnings for workers rose slightly in August.
On Friday, the Government will release a report on inflation at the wholesale level; many economists are expecting a slight rise to three-tenths of a percent, reflecting higher energy and food prices.

HEADLINE: Helping East Timor, and Indonesia

 BODY:
Time is running out for Indonesia to disarm and disband the army-backed militias that have rampaged through East Timor for the past week, killing hundreds of people and sending thousands into hiding and exile. The violence subsided somewhat yesterday. But unless Jakarta can bring these militias to heel in the next few days, which is unlikely, an international peacekeeping force will be needed to save lives and make sure that the results of last week's referendum approving independence for the province is respected.
Indonesia's consent is needed for such a force to function smoothly. That will require strong pressure from Washington. President Clinton applied some yesterday, announcing the suspension of military ties with the Indonesian Army and emphasizing that American support for future economic assistance will hinge on Indonesia's performance on the East Timor issue. He should be even more explicit and declare that billions of dollars in international loans will stay blocked until President B. J. Habibie accepts international peacekeepers. 
 Washington wants to save lives in East Timor without derailing Jakarta's transition to democratic government. This fall, a partially elected assembly is scheduled to choose Indonesia's next president. That would complete what, for all its deficiencies, would be the most democratic selection process the world's fourth-largest country has ever known. But American policy can advance both objectives at the same time. Democracy can take root in Indonesia only if its armed forces defer to civilian authority and respect election results. In East Timor, Indonesia's army is doing neither.
Last week's independence referendum was organized with the approval of President Habibie, who promised to abide by its result. But a significant faction of Indonesia's army fears that independence for East Timor could encourage secessionist movements elsewhere in Indonesia, and is therefore trying to subvert the referendum by creating so much chaos that Mr. Habibie will be forced to reverse course. If this succeeds, it would demonstrate that the military, which has ruled Indonesia for the past 34 years, remains the real power no matter who wins the presidential election. Many senior officers also oppose an international peacekeeping force.
Indonesian democracy requires that the armed forces obey civilian authorities in Jakarta. East Timor's safety and freedom require that Jakarta agree to international peacekeepers. Washington should use every lever at its disposal to make sure that both requirements are quickly fulfilled.

HEADLINE: Both China and U.S. Upbeat About Talks on Trade Group

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Overcoming a serious obstacle in their soured relationship, the United States and China agreed today to resume negotiations on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, and both sides expressed hopes that China would join in less than three months.
The United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and the Chinese Foreign Trade Minister, Shi Guangsheng, announced the resumption after a discussion here at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. 
 Their agreement sets a positive tone for the meeting here Saturday between President Clinton and the Chinese leader, Jiang Zemin. The Clinton Administration hopes the meeting will restore some steadiness to the relationship between the two countries after a many months of acrimony over the accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and charges that China stole American nuclear secrets.
Ms. Barshefsky did not release a precise schedule but said that "substantive discussions" between Chinese and American trade officials on the outstanding issues would begin and that it was unlikely that the deal would be completed on Saturday.
For his part, Mr. Shi characterized his talks with Ms. Barshefsky as "very constructive."
He said, "We are willing to work together to conclude negotiations at an early date and bring China into W.T.O. at an early date."
China's membership in the World Trade Organization, which would give United States businesses and agricultural producers wide access to the Chinese market, has been a major goal of the Clinton Administration's China policy.
But the decision in April by President Clinton to turn down an offer by the Chinese and the refusal of the Chinese to come back to the table derailed the progress that had been made in rounds of intense negotiations earlier in the year.
Ms. Barshefsky said that the two sides would pick up the negotiations where they broke off. She described the main issues as banking, textiles and anti-dumping measures and suggested that the United States wanted the Chinese to agree to the demands Mr. Clinton made in April.
The stakes for getting China membership in the entity that governs world trade are now high because a failure to reach an agreement before the start of the next round of the organization's trade talks in Seattle that start at the end of November would place even more stress on the Washington-Beijing relationship.
China's efforts to join the World Trade Organization, and its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have lasted 13 years. Only under Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, a reformist, have the talks made serious progress. As China's economy has faltered and as it tries to shut down or shrink inefficient state-run industries, Mr. Zhu has been anxious to attract foreign investment and competition.
Congress will not need to vote on a final deal, but in order for China to take full part in the Seattle trade talks and for American businesses to get the full advantage of China's membership, Congress must pass legislation allowing China permanent normal trading relations with the United States, officials said. At the moment, China is subject to annual Congressional renewal of its trade status.
In the document that was nearly completed in April, China made far-ranging concessions to liberalize its economy, including opening up telecommunications, financial services and agriculture.
