HEADLINE: Tiny Treasures Stolen, Shells and All, at Zoo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Soon after the police first got the call yesterday that two extremely rare, extremely small tortoises had been stolen from the Bronx Zoo, the hypotheses began. Were they taken so they could be ground up and used as aphrodisiacs? Or as ingredients in some exquisite soup? More than one police official even suggested that a vengeful hare might be suspect.
But the leading theory is that the tiny reptiles -- which, as members of an endangered species, are no longer allowed to be sold on the open market -- were taken either by collectors who covet them as pets or by the rogue traders who supply the growing black market in forbidden wildlife. 
 The two Egyptian tortoises were reported stolen yesterday after a zoo keeper on his morning rounds in the Reptile House noticed that the glass had been removed from their case, the police said. The tortoises were last seen on Wednesday afternoon, when the zoo was packed with people on its weekly free day.
Egyptian tortoises, which are found in the deserts of Egypt, Libya and Israel, are among the world's smallest, growing to a length of only four inches. Their size had long made them popular pets until 1995, when an international treaty organization found that the tortoises faced an immediate threat of extinction and banned all commercial traffic in them.
But the ban on legal sales has not stopped the illicit trade.
"They have become the bonsai tortoise and turtle species, coveted by apartment dwellers and collectors," said John Behler, the zoo's reptile curator.
In response to the Egyptian tortoise crisis -- their estimated worldwide population has dwindled to below 5,000 -- Mr. Behler and his colleagues at the zoo started a breeding program in 1995 to try to hatch them in captivity. The tortoises that were stolen yesterday were the first to be hatched in the program back in 1996. Only a few have been hatched since.
The theft of the tortoises was not the first from the Bronx Zoo, officials said. In September 1998, after another species of tortoise was stolen, the zoo upgraded its alarm system. But this time, the thieves bypassed the alarm by removing the glass instead of breaking it.
The black market in illegal reptiles is thriving, experts said.
Craig Hoover, the senior program director of Traffic North America, a branch of the World Wildlife Fund, said: "There's no way to put a number on the illegal wildlife trade, but I would say that it's measured in the billions of dollars."
Mr. Hoover said that recent advertisements for illicit Egyptian tortoises listed prices from $250 to $350.
The legal reptile industry has also soared in recent years. The United States imported 1.8 million live reptiles in 1997, worth some $7 million, and exported 9.7 million valued at $13.2 million, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. (The most common import was the green iguana; the most common export was the red-eared slider turtle.)
The illegal reptile trade is believed to be even more lucrative. The Komodo dragon, a 10-foot lizard, can sell on the black market for $30,000. The Chinese alligator, which lives only along the lower reaches of the Yangtze River, fetches $15,000. Forbidden tortoises are also popular: 70 plowshare tortoises were stolen from a breeding program in Madagascar several years ago, setting off a worldwide search.
To fight the rogue reptile trade, the Fish and Wildlife Service ran a five-year undercover operation, called "Operation Chameleon," in which agents posed as buyers. In 1998, its agents went to Mexico City and arrested Keng Ling Wong of Malaysia, who is known as Anson, whom they called "the kingpin of an international smuggling operation that plundered reptiles from Asia, New Zealand and Madagascar."
And in April, a Florida reptile dealer, Tommy Edward Crutchfield, was sentenced to 30 months in prison for his role in a ring that smuggled rare reptiles from Madagascar.
Whether the Bronx Zoo theft was the work of an organized ring or a determined teen-ager remains to be seen. Mr. Behler, the curator, just wants the little tortoises back.
Breeding them is no easy task. They need a special diet, with just enough protein, the right quality of light and low humidity, and an environment that simulates the desert, with high temperatures in the day and low ones at night.
And Mr. Behler said that unlike snapping turtles, which can lay 50 eggs at a time, Egyptian tortoises lay only one egg at a time. "They are not very fecund," he said.
He gave the following description of the missing tortoises: they are males, tan with black along the plates of their backs, and they are three inches long. Their hind legs are shaped like an elephant's; their front legs are shovel-like. They do not have names. Anyone who has seen them is urged to call (800) 577-TIPS.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASSERTS JAKARTA MUST ACT OR ADMIT TROOPS

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton demanded today that Indonesia permit an international peacekeeping force to try to restore order in East Timor if the Indonesian military is unable to end "this madness" -- the wave of violence that has taken hundreds of lives across the tiny province since it voted for independence last week.
"If Indonesia does not end the violence, it must invite, it must invite the international community to assist in restoring security," the President said at the White House as he prepared to leave for the Asia-Pacific economic summit meeting in New Zealand. 
 But the President did not threaten an immediate cutoff of economic assistance to Indonesia, as some lawmakers and human rights groups had wanted. Nor did he cut off commercial arms sales to Indonesia, which are expected to total about $16 million over the next year.
Instead, he said that he had ordered the Pentagon to suspend its few formal contacts with the Indonesia military, and that he would consider economic sanctions if the killings in East Timor did not stop. "My own willingness to support future assistance will depend very strongly on the way Indonesia handles this situation," he said. Excerpts, page A12.
He said the United States was prepared to assist Australia in its efforts to form an international peacekeeping force for East Timor, an idea Indonesia has rejected. Mr. Clinton made clear that no decision had been made on the extent of American involvement in the mission. The Pentagon has said there are no plans to deploy American ground troops.
The Administration has faced a difficult calculation in deciding how to react to the bloodletting that began after the independence referendum in East Timor. Hundreds of people are reported to have been killed by anti-independence militias backed by elements of the military.
More Roman Catholic priests and nuns became targets in East Timor today in what the Vatican interpreted as a campaign against the church. At the same time, the United Nations sharply reduced the size of its staff in Dili, the capital of East Timor. Page A12.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged today that the United States was unclear on how decisions were being made in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, about how to deal with the killings in East Timor. He said it was possible that "nobody's got the authority" among Indonesia's military or civilian leaders to quell the violence.
While strongly protesting the violence, the United States wants to preserve a relationship with the civilian Government of President B. J. Habibie, which has been responsible for democratic reforms in Indonesia, an archipelago nation of more than 200 million people. East Timor, a former Portuguese colony of about 800,000 people, was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in 1975.
Mr. Clinton touched on the larger policy dilemma when, at the beginning of his remarks on East Timor, he saluted Indonesia for its "important democratic transformation," adding, "It has the capacity to lift an entire region if it succeeds and to swamp its neighbors in a sea of disorder if it fails."
He noted that Indonesia's economy, which was ravaged by the Asian economic crisis, has begun to rebound in recent months, largely as a result of billions of dollars in American-backed emergency aid through the International Monetary Fund.
"It would be a pity if the Indonesian recovery were crashed by this," he said of the crisis in East Timor. "But one way or the other, it will be crashed by this if they don't fix it, because there will be overwhelming public sentiment to stop the international economic cooperation.
"Precisely because Indonesia's future is important, I am so deeply concerned by the failure of its military to bring a stop to gross abuses now going on in East Timor."
The I.M.F. had already suspended all emergency aid to Indonesia, even before the crisis in East Timor, because of concerns over possible misuse of funds previously sent to Indonesia. And because of the current violence, an observation team from the I.M.F. that was to have gone to Indonesia this month has postponed its trip.
"We believe that, in effect, any future assistance from international financial institutions is effectively cut off as of now," Thomas Pickering, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, said today in Congressional testimony. "There will not be any more forthcoming."
The suspension of military cooperation between the United States and Indonesia is little more than symbolic, since military ties between the two countries have been sharply limited by Congress in recent years because of human rights abuses attributed to the Indonesian armed forces.
The United States ended military exercises with Indonesia last year. As a result of today's action, the United States will freeze a $470,000-a-year military training program between the two countries and a handful of officer exchange programs.
Informal contacts between the two nations will continue. Clinton Administration officials said the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, intended to remain in contact with his Indonesian counterpart, Gen. Wiranto, who is considered the key figure in the crisis.
In an appearance before Congress on his nomination for a second two-year term as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, General Shelton said he spoke with General Wiranto by phone on Monday and "laid out for him in no uncertain terms what I thought we needed to see from Indonesia, and specifically from him."
But while he said the United States was alarmed by the violence that has overwhelmed East Timor, General Shelton stressed that American national security interests were not on the line in the tiny territory.
"Certainly if you look at East Timor by itself, I cannot see any national interest there that would be overwhelming -- would call for us to deploy or place U.S. forces on the ground in that area," he said.
The general instead described the crisis in East Timor as a "moral issue" that "very clearly challenges our role as a leader with other nations in that region of the world."

HEADLINE: Black Baptists Hear Forbes But Are Mixed On His Views

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Steve Forbes brought a message of conservative economic, social and political values to the nation's largest African-American Baptist organization, and the reaction was decidedly mixed.
After rousing gospel music and inspirational preaching, the Republican Presidential hopeful took to the podium and, in more subdued and methodical tones, laid out his case for lower taxes, school vouchers and changes in Social Security. And he told the tale -- meant as an inspirational message -- of how his grandfather came to America as a penniless immigrant and became a millionaire many times over through hard work. 
 But the story was less well received than other parts of his talk.
The Rev. Earl Jones, pastor of the First Calvary Church in Brooklyn, said: "My grandfather has been here since 1850. We are not billionaires. We're still working. It's not a question of hard work, but opportunity."
The Rev. Jasper Williams Jr., pastor of the Salem Baptist Church in Atlanta, added: "It's like he was trying to identify with the issues of the struggle. But I wasn't impressed. He wants to make us feel that we could all be millionaires and that's not the real world."
Mr. Forbes's speech was a sidelight to a larger four-day convention here of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., which today elected the Rev. William Shaw as president. Mr. Shaw, of Philadelphia, replaces the Rev. Henry Lyons, who earlier this year was convicted on charges of racketeering and grand theft.
More than 12,000 members of the convention heard Mr. Forbes's speech today. For Mr. Forbes, the event was high in publicity value and an effort to show that a conservative Republican could relate to a black and largely Democratic audience that has provided a forum for nearly every Presidential candidate since Dwight D. Eisenhower.
"This is a major event," Randy Tate, president of the Christian Coalition, said in an interview. "What Steve recognizes is that conservatives can reach out and expand their base without betraying their core principles."
The Rev. William Snorgrass, pastor of the Progressive Baptist Church of Kansas City, Mo., noted that the group has historically heard more from Democratic politicians than Republicans.
"It seems that Republicans are not interested in us," Mr. Snorgrass said. "We've extended invitations to both. Sometimes we feel the Democrats take us for granted, but at least they show up. And we'd like to hear from both."
Mr. Forbes, who inherited the magazine publishing concern Forbes Inc. from his father, Malcolm Forbes, came to the convention to try to build a more broad-based coalition across ideological boundaries, said his traveling press secretary, K. B. Forbes, who is no relation.
But others questioned whether appearances such as this one would help Mr. Forbes at his next political hurdle -- making a good showing in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, where his target audience is Republican and largely white. "This is not a vote-rich environment for Forbes," said a Republican analyst.
In his speech, Mr. Forbes, an Episcopalian, equated education with civil rights, saying, "A good education is a civil right and a passport to economic freedom."
In arguing in favor of school vouchers -- which would provide aid to allow parents to send their children to private schools -- Mr. Forbes said: "No mother in America should be forced to send her child to a lousy school.
"Today we find big government politicians standing in the schoolhouse door to keep children trapped in dangerous and failing schools."
He also restated several of his campaign themes: allowing younger workers to have private retirement accounts instead of the traditional Social Security benefits and reducing taxes across the board.
These views garnered a mixed response. The Rev. Henry Holmes, pastor of the Higher Dimensions Baptist Church in Vero, Fla., a lifelong Democrat, has invited Mr. Forbes to visit his region. "It appeals to me when he talks about economic empowerment for minorities," Mr. Holmes said. "Over the last six years, the wealthy have gotten wealthier and the gap has spread."
And the Rev. John D. Kelly, pastor of Elyton Missionary Baptist Church in Detroit, favored school vouchers as a way to pressure public schools to improve.
Others had their doubts. Mr. Williams of Atlanta felt that inner-city schools should be improved over all but that school vouchers would hamper that effort.
On the subject of tax cuts, Mr. Jones of Brooklyn questioned whether big tax cuts would lead to cuts in Government programs.
"Someone's got to pay the bills." he said.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
SCHNEIDER, ELLIOT BERNARD

 BODY:
SCHNEIDER-Elliot Bernard, 74, of Little Silver, N.J., died September 8 at home. He was an economist and a nationally recognized expert on government-sponsored securities, such as Fannie Mae. He was Director of Perspective Research and a senior vice president at Gruntal & Co., Inc., New York City. He was a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts, and was a Chartered Financial Analyst and member of the Association for Investment Management and Research. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Freda Rosenberg Schneider; by two sons and daughters-in-law, Adam and Pat Schneider of Long Branch, N.J., and Daniel and Linda Schneider of Irvington, N.Y.; by one daughter and son-in-law, Rebecca and Stuart Meiklejohn of Manhattan, N.Y.; by five grandchildren, David and Sarah Meiklejohn, Amy and Emily Schneider, and Isabelle Schneider; by a brother, Irwin Schneider of Chicago; and by a sister, Sophie Ruderman of Lakehurst, N.J. Donations in his memory may be made to Long Branch Habitat for Humanity, PO Box 3306, Long Branch, NJ 07740. For more information contact the Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapel, 2130 Highway 35, Ocean, N.J.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
6 Decades of an Unconventional Legal Life

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
LAST week, a Buffalo man on whose behalf Eleanor Jackson Piel had pestered the courts for 10 years was released from prison, after DNA tests proved he wasn't a rapist. Later this month, she is going to Mississippi for a death row inmate. The date coincides with her 79th birthday.
"I think he's innocent," Ms. Piel, wearing pearls and a pleated silk blouse, said brightly. "I don't know how we'll do it, but we'll find a way." 
 Ms. Piel and Conventional Wisdom have yet to be properly introduced. In the 1950's, the decade of the suburban housewife, she practiced law and remained stubbornly single until she was nearly 35; after she married, she continued her practice, while raising a daughter named Eleanor Jackson Piel Jr.
As a lawyer, she is also an anomaly. In the 1960's she won a civil rights case in the Supreme Court and later not only got a client released from Florida's death row but also successfully sued the state for wrongful imprisonment. Yet she is not regarded as a left-wing advocate.
Rather, Ms. Piel is a solo practitioner whose patchwork caseload has included the Nobel Prize winner Linus Pauling, a Vassar professor, murder trials, discrimination claims and patent lawsuits. Plus volunteer cases, a description she eschews because, she said: "I always expect to get paid. I just never do."
And though litigators specialize in trials, appellate lawyers in appeals, Ms. Piel, the courts' most elegant pain in the neck, does the whole shebang, while conducting her own legal research and typing her own briefs.
Penury? Pride is more like it, for she lives on Fifth Avenue and attends a full season of society benefits for the boards on which she and her husband, Gerard, the 84-year-old scion of the Piels beer family and former publisher and editor of Scientific American magazine, serve.
"I have the best stories at dinner parties!" Ms. Piel said. That fact is not in dispute, counselor.
For to spend a long afternoon in her modest midtown office is to hear decades' worth of tales that are, by turns, moving, long-winded, funny, enraging and, in total, extraordinary:
She grew up in California, the smart, restless Depression-era daughter of a concert pianist and a Santa Monica doctor. "He's the only person who bought a lot of property in Southern California who had deficiency judgments against him," Ms. Piel said fondly.
There is Ms. Piel at 25: it's Tokyo, 1945, and she's a Berkeley-trained lawyer prosecuting war crimes, and then an adviser to a committee whose mission, she said, was to distribute food and get the Japanese economy on its feet. "And by gum, we did!"
She then sets up practice in Los Angeles, reveling in representing the elderly and doing criminal trials.
"Criminal law was such a low level in the profession that anyone who gave it time was a sport," she said. "I couldn't understand why it was so disrespected. To me, facing the unknown and coming up with something on my feet that worked was heaven."
OF course she endures slights. "I was at a party and the host introduced me as the best woman lawyer in Los Angeles," the diminutive Ms. Piel said. "So I hit him."
She rents office space from the lawyers representing the Hollywood 10. Almost nightly at 6, the bottles come out and partyers drop by. One is a New Yorker, Mr. Piel, who is reviving the moribund Scientific American. They correspond for two years. On their wedding day, a judge throws out murder charges against her clients. So her nuptials are announced not on the society pages but in the news section: "Three Youths Freed and Lawyer Wed."
"My mother was mortified," Ms. Piel said.
Move to New York. There's the client charged as an anarchist for inciting riots in Harlem. ("I refused the fee," she said.) Summer 1964: "I decided they needed me," she said airily, "so my husband and I went to Mississippi." A white teacher has been refused service at a Hattiesburg lunch counter because she is with black students, and she is locked up. Ms. Piel gets her out and snips, snaps and nags until the Supreme Court allows her to sue a private institution for deprivation of constitutional rights.
"I am persistent," Ms. Piel said, "and I like to challenge authority. No question about it."
Now the 1980's. Ms. Piel reads a newspaper story about how death row inmates need lawyers. Her desk unusually clean -- a trip with her husband has just been canceled -- she picks up the phone.
Hours before her new Florida client is to die, a judge stays the execution, complaining that Ms. Piel has filed too much paperwork to be read promptly. Years later, the client will be freed. Ms. Piel leads a New York City bar committee that arm-twists nearly 300 big-firm lawyers into taking on death penalty cases.
Perhaps no one dares suggest that slowing down, visiting grandchildren -- Eleanor Jackson Piel Jr. set aside her medical career and is pregnant with her eighth child -- is now permissible. Ebullient and tireless, Ms. Piel arrives home to cook dinner by 7:30 P.M. and is at the office by 9 A.M.
This morning she was late, having driven from her Connecticut weekend home. "I took a swim in the buff," she said. "It was so beautiful. You couldn't tell where the lake ended and the sky started!"

 CORRECTION:
A Public Lives profile on Friday about Eleanor Jackson Piel, a 79-year-old litigator who worked for 10 years to overturn a 1983 rape conviction for a client, misstated the former title of her husband, Gerard Piel, at Scientific American. He was publisher and chairman of the board of editors, not the editor.

HEADLINE: Auto Workers Try to Wring DaimlerChryslerConcessions

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Stephen Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers, is demanding that DaimlerChrysler A.G. make it easier for the union to organize workers at its plants as a condition of leading industry contract talks, U.A.W. officials said.
Mr. Yokich spent the last two days pressing DaimlerChrysler to go beyond a simple promise to remain neutral in U.A.W. campaigns, the officials said. The union is seeking access to employee lists and to factory floors, pledges that plants will not be shut down if the union wins and simpler election procedures. 
 Contracts for 370,000 workers at DaimlerChrysler, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company expire on Tuesday. Companies vie to be the first to craft a U.A.W. contract so they can tailor industrywide patterns to their needs. Mr. Yokich threatened yesterday to work first with G.M. but returned today to DaimlerChrysler, so the officials considered it still in the lead.
The auto maker, based in Stuttgart, Germany, "is trying to create a foundation for good relations with the U.A.W.," said Harley Shaiken, a University of California labor analyst.
"If they take a hard line now," he said, "it will take years to undo it."
Neither Mr. Yokich nor David Barnas, a spokesman for the auto maker, would comment.
For months, the U.A.W. has been pushing DaimlerChrysler to become more union-friendly at an Alabama Mercedes-Benz factory with 1,700 nonunion workers and at a North Carolina Freightliner Corporation plant that employs 1,600.
One way would be to recognize the union if 50 percent of the workers signed cards supporting it, rather than tougher-to-win secret ballot elections. DaimlerChrysler has said that doing so would violate its pledge to remain neutral.
While neither side expects a strike, talks about neutrality are taking unusual twists. The union officials said Mr. Yokich complained yesterday that Thomas Stallkamp, president of DaimlerChrysler's American unit, became a director of the Kmart Corporation this week. The U.A.W. recently lost a hard-fought organizing drive at Kmart's distribution warehouses.
The union, which saw an increase in membership to 846,400 last year, has made gains this year at several auto-parts makers, although unions still represent fewer than a quarter of the 650,000 American auto-parts workers, down from about half in 1976. A renewed organizing surge could make it harder for suppliers like Magna International Inc. and Borg-Warner Automotive Inc. to remain mostly union-free, analysts said. Also, G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler might find it more difficult to win price cuts on parts.
Sean McAlinden, a University of Michigan labor analyst, said union auto-parts workers now average $13 an hour, compared with $10 an hour for nonunion workers.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Stable Prices and Firm Dollar Push Treasury Prices Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a report on producer prices pointed to tame inflation and the dollar climbed.
The benchmark 30-year bond posted its biggest gain of the week, climbing 2 2/32 to 101 7/32. Yields, which move in the opposite direction, fell to 6.04 percent, the lowest in two weeks, from 6.09 percent on Thursday. 
 "Inflationary pressures aren't that great," said Ned Riley, chief investment officer at the BankBoston Corporation, with about $25 billion under management. He said he expected 30-year bond yields to fall as low as 5.5 percent by the end of the year.
For an investor buying bonds now, that would produce a return of 9.4 percent; in contrast, for the year so far, bonds have handed investors losses of 8.9 percent including price declines and interest.
Treasury bond prices gained after the Labor Department said prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers had fallen two-tenths of a percent, excluding volatile food and energy costs, after showing no change in July. The department's overall index rose five-tenths of a percent in the month, mostly reflecting higher energy prices.
"The numbers away from energy look pretty good," said Robert Auwaerter, who is standing pat on Treasury bonds and buying corporate bonds for the $70 billion he oversees at the Vanguard Group of funds. Tame inflation means bonds hold more of their value.
Bonds also got a lift from a climbing dollar, which rose from a three-year low of 107.55 against the yen after Japan sold its currency earlier yesterday, and climbed against the euro. Expectations for further gains in the dollar help American assets, because overseas investors would stand to gain more when they convert proceeds into home currencies.
Not everyone is sanguine. David Brownlee, head of fixed-income investing at Sentinel Advisors in Montpelier, Vt., with some $11 billion, predicted that 30-year yields could rise to as high as 6.45 percent in the months ahead. He has been favoring short-term corporate debt, which offers higher yields than Treasury bonds with comparable maturities. Among recent purchases, he bought some of the $1.5 billion in bonds sold earlier this week by Safeway Inc., the grocery chain.
Many investors still predict the Fed will raise rates at least once before the end of the year. That is evident in Federal funds futures contracts, which signal where investors expect the Fed funds rate to be in the weeks and months ahead.
The implied yield on the contract for December delivery was unchanged at 5.40 percent -- 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the current Fed funds target, and a sign that more investors expect a rate increase by the time the contract expires.
Scott Grannis, who helps manage $50 billion at Western Asset Management in Pasadena, Calif., said the market's woes so far this year reflected concerns about the Fed more than major concerns about inflation. That can be seen in the fact that Treasury inflation-protected securities, or TIPS, which offer protection from quickening inflation, have actually fallen in recent months.
The current 10-year inflation-indexed note yields 4.03 percent, near the high of 4.05 percent reached earlier this month and about a quarter-point higher than when the securities were sold in January.
At a yield of 5.89 percent, 10-year Government notes yield 4.08 percentage points more than the 1.81 percent yield on the most current 10-year Japanese bond and 85 basis points more than the 5.04 percent yield on 10-year German bonds.

HEADLINE: China and Trade

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 9 Business Day article cites a study by the Institute for International Economics that claims the American textile and apparel industries would not be hurt if China joined the World Trade Organization. However, a recent report by the International Trade Commission found that China's increased exports would come at the expense of foreign suppliers, including United States apparel producers and workers. 
 Also, an increase in foreign investment in China could mean more technology transfers useful to China's military-industrial complex, and a higher trade surplus would make it easier for China to buy weapons. Meanwhile, the diversion of trade from the Pacific Rim to China would shift the balance of power in the region against the interests of the United States and its allies.
 
WILLIAM R. HAWKINS
Washington, Sept. 9, 1999
 
The writer is a visiting fellow at the United States Business and Industry Council.

HEADLINE: Tough Times in the Copper Pits;
Excess Capacity and Sagging Prices Force Retrenchment

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF

DATELINE: SAN MANUEL, Ariz.

 BODY:
Thousands of feet below the scrub and cactus near this copper town is an unusual silence. The din of pneumatic hammers, conveyer belts and blasting that was music to the ears for many miners here in the Sonoran Desert has mostly subsided.
The San Manuel mine, among the largest underground copper mines in the nation, has been closed. So too has the nearby smelter that in better times sent wisps of smoke from giant chimneys visible for miles along the San Pedro River valley. 
 A decline in copper prices has led to significant cutbacks in the industry around the world. It has hit particularly hard in the United States, where many of the mines are more played out and more costly to operate than are those abroad. Over the last few months, a string of major copper producers has announced layoffs, reductions and closures.
The sagging market has also prompted a wave of merger proposals that could significantly transform the industry. A plan announced last month by the Phelps Dodge Corporation of Phoenix to consolidate with two other companies -- Asarco Inc., based in New York, and the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company, based in Englewood, Colo. -- would create the largest copper producer in the world. Similar slumps in other commodities, including aluminum and paper, are forcing producers in a variety of basic industries in join together to eliminate over-capacity in the face of the decline in prices. But none has been hit harder than copper.
"Copper has supported families for generations here in the Southwest," said Dennis Duffy, a laid-off miner in San Manuel who is training for a new career in installing computer networks and, to help cope financially, has canceled satellite television service at his home. "It's sad. I hate to see jobs like mine dry up."
The slump began in 1997 with the financial panic and economic downturn in Asia, a major market for copper and copper intensive products like electrical wires, automobiles and pipes. A series of new mine openings in South America flooded the market with copper and depressed prices even further.
In two years, the price of copper has tumbled nearly 50 percent from $1.20 a pound, hitting bottom in May at 61 cents a pound, the lowest in 12 years. The price has since increased to an average of 80 cents a pound, but that is not enough to make copper producers in the United States reverse their retrenchments.
"Copper had a fairly significant run through most of the 1990's," said Chuck Shipley, president of the Arizona Mining Association. "But it really dropped over the edge in the last six months or so."
The town most affected by the decline in copper prices is San Manuel, a company town of 4,000 carved out of thorny wilderness, about 30 miles northeast of Tucson. With nearly every job and business here tied in some way to mining, its future is uncertain.
In June, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the worldwide mining concern based in Melbourne, Australia, announced it would close the mine and smelter here indefinitely, putting nearly 2,200 people out of work. An additional 400 employees were laid off elsewhere in Arizona and Nevada, representing the company's nearly total withdrawal from the American copper industry.
While there are plenty of jobs elsewhere, many ex-miners are reluctant to pull up stakes. As a result, many have had to take jobs around here that pay far less than the $40,000 a year or more many made in the copper industry. Among them are Joseph Coubb, a miner for 12 years at San Manuel, who spoke recently while taking a break from truck-driving lessons in a dirt lot near a high school.
"At least I'll have a job," said Mr. Coubb, though he complained that trucking, unlike mining, would take him away from his family for days at a time.
Jay Rhodes, a spokesman for Broken Hill, said the company was forced to stop most production in the United States because it was unprofitable at such low prices. Closing mines and laying off workers, while unfortunate, he said, was hardly unusual in the industry.
"Copper is a cyclical business," Mr. Rhodes said. "It's been one where when the price increases, the players holding low-grade deposits open them for production. When the cycle is down, they have to put them on hold."
Two other producers with mines in Arizona, where much of the copper in the United States is found, have also announced reductions in their work forces. Asarco laid off 150 miners near Green Valley, south of Tucson, and Phelps Dodge dismissed 1,650 employees at mines and factories worldwide.
The problems in the industry come as copper use is growing, though not enough recently to offset new production. World copper consumption has increased in 11 of the last 13 years, according to the International Copper Study Group, with the proliferation of cars, electrical appliances, computers, telephone lines and new homes.
Low copper prices have resulted in losses for producers like Asarco and Phelps Dodge the last few quarters. But most analysts say that such losses are not especially significant as long as prices do not decline further over an extended period.
Indeed, by reducing production, some companies say they have put a stop to the losses. Thomas Foster, vice president and treasurer of Phelps Dodge, said his company was "breaking even or doing a little better" now that it had trimmed money-losing production.
Over the last decade, many copper producers have tried to increase efficiency by implementing new, cheaper mining and smelting techniques that require fewer workers. They have also tried to cut costs with mergers.
In July, Asarco and Cyprus Amax announced that they intended to join forces. No money would have been exchanged in the merger. But then, on Aug. 20, Phelps Dodge offered to buy Asarco and Cyprus Amax for $2.56 billion. Federal securities regulators recently approved Phelps Dodge's plan to issue stock in the transaction.
If that deal were approved by Asarco and Cyprus Amax shareholders, Phelps Dodge would replace Codelco, the Government-owned mining company of Chile, as the world's largest copper producer.
 On Sept. 9, though, Asarco and Cyprus Amax rejected the Phelps offer as "inadequate and not in the best interest of their shareholders." They urged shareholders instead to approve the merger of their two companies at a meeting scheduled for Sept. 30. In the meantime, Phelps continues to lobby shareholders in favor of its plan.
"The stronger players see the market when it is down as a time to buy," said John Dobra, professor of economics and director of the Natural Resource Industry Institute at the University of Nevada at Reno, "The weaker companies run for cover."
Though many North American mine operators have suffered in recent months, those overseas have remained relatively prosperous. Mines in Chile, Argentina, Peru and Indonesia, where much of the growth in the industry is taking place, have the advantage of higher quality ore, less stringent environmental regulations and lower labor costs.
For example, it can cost nearly 65 cents to produce a pound of copper in the United States, compared with 50 cents a pound in South America.
To stay competitive, many producers are increasingly opening their own mines overseas or forming partnerships with local companies that are already there.
But Professor Dobra said the industry would almost certainly maintain a significant presence in the United States, at least for the next few decades. The cost of quickly transferring production overseas would be too exorbitant, he said.
Opening a mine costs hundreds of millions of dollars, no matter where it is. Closing an existing mine in the United States costs millions more and carries the potential for additional costs to cover liabilities for environmental contamination.
"There is always the hope that the price of copper will rise and these mines will be profitable again," Professor Dobra said.
Kurt Billick, an analyst in San Francisco who follows the metals industry for the investment firm Warburg Dillon Read, predicted that the price of copper would increase modestly within the next year. With improvements in the Asian economies and the round of new mine openings in South America nearly over, the industry has survived the worst, he said. "But copper," he added emphatically, "is going nowhere near the bull market levels."

HEADLINE: Russian Promises Help From Police

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Saturday, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov of Russia said here on Friday that a team of Russian law enforcement officials would arrive in Washington next week, in an effort to prove Moscow's eagerness to cooperate with American inquiries into money laundering.
Mr. Ivanov and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met for two hours at the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-Operation forum Friday night, and Russian corruption and its effect on the international financial system were high on the agenda, an aide to Ms. Albright said. 
 Mr. Ivanov called her last week offering to send the Russian law enforcement officials, saying at the time that the idea came from Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.
American law enforcement officials have said that at least $4.2 billion passed through accounts at the Bank of New York between early 1998 and March 1999, and that as much as $10 billion may have moved through these accounts in the last 18 months. Investigators believe the money was tied to organized crime and corporate embezzlement in Russia.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Slows Yen's Rally, at Least for Now

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Japanese Government sold yen for dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an effort to slow the rise in the value of the yen, which had jumped 2.8 percent on Thursday.
The intervention stopped the yen rally for the moment. Late in the day, the yen was valued at 108.81 to the dollar, off from 107.78 on Thursday. But analysts expect the yen's rise to resume because the economic outlook for Japan has improved. 
 Statements from Japanese officials indicated that the Government was not trying to reverse the yen's course with the latest intervention, although reversing course was indeed the goal of a series of six interventions in June and July.
Instead, the officials indicated that they just wanted to slow the yen's rise because a move that was too rapid could be destabilizing in an economy that is still fragile, even if it is finally turning around. A much stronger yen would make Japanese exports harder to sell abroad and could dampen this key sector of the economy.
"The intervention today was an operation meant to smooth the move in the yen instead of changing direction," said James McCormick, currency strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. Japanese officials, he added, "are happy enough to stand by and let the fundamentals drive the yen as long as it is orderly."
Although the dollar rose against the yen yesterday, it has been in a steady decline against the yen recently. Analysts, however, contend that the weakness of the dollar against the yen does not signal a broader problem for the dollar -- yesterday it rallied sharply against the euro.
At the same time, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers reiterated the Clinton Administration's support of a strong dollar. According to a Reuters report, Mr. Summers said yesterday, "Our policy and approach is unchanged -- a strong dollar is very much in the interests of the United States."
No matter how much it favors a strong dollar, the Administration will probably remain on the sidelines. Any effort to change the dollar's course against the yen would require concerted intervention by the United States, Japan and their other industrial allies. But the Administration has been reluctant to use such concerted intervention unless the dollar was extremely strong or weak. And if the Japanese economy is recovering, intervention is unlikely to alter significantly the sudden flow of new investors into Japan that is powering the yen rally.
The surge of the yen on Thursday followed a Japanese Government report that the economy had grown at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter ended in June. That performance was much better than the small decline that had been expected. Taken with a surprising 8.1 percent rate of growth in the previous quarter, the data helped bolster the belief that the Japanese economy is beginning to recover from its longest recession since World War II.
The prospect of a Japanese recovery has been luring foreign investors into the Japanese stock market for months. As they return, they have to sell dollars and other foreign currencies to buy yen, pushing up the currency's value. They use the yen to buy stocks, which are surging. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks is up 28 percent this year in local terms.
Many economists had thought that the rapid economic growth in Japan in the early months of this year had been overstated. But the small rise in the second quarter will make the recovery seem much more real for many investors. "Now it is clear that the economy at least held onto those gains in the second quarter and that industrial output is moving strongly higher into the third quarter," Karen Parker, the director of currency research as the Chase Manhattan Bank, said in an assessment for clients yesterday.
And that improvement in the economic outlook will make getting back into the stock market more attractive, providing another boost for the yen.
But some economists still think that the Japanese economy could stumble again, especially when the Government cuts back on the fiscal spending it approved to jump start the economy. "There are clear downside risks for the economy because the fiscal spending will have to fade," said Mr. McCormick of J. P. Morgan. But the economic momentum should continue through the quarter ending in September, he said.
The euro fell against the dollar yesterday after the Department of Labor reported that American producer prices, excluding food and energy, declined by one-tenth of 1 percent in August. Some investors took this sign of restrained inflation as another indicator that the Federal Reserve might not raise short-term interest rates again this year. That would give American markets a bit of an edge over those in Europe. The euro was at $1.0364 in late trading, down from $1.0544 on Thursday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 899 words

HEADLINE: Latest Report Says Inflation Is Still Tame

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In the 1970's, a sudden jump in the price of energy or some other important commodity inevitably signaled a nasty chain reaction that would send inflationary ripples through the whole economy.
These days, the prices of oil and other raw materials are climbing once again. But, so far, there are few signs of a ripple effect. 
 In August, producer prices, a gauge of wholesale price inflation, jumped five-tenths of a percent, the Labor Department reported yesterday. It was the biggest monthly increase since last December. But the increase turned out to be largely confined to energy and food.
The core rate of wholesale price inflation actually fell slightly -- 0.1 percent, after staying put in July. Despite the jump in crude oil prices since the spring, producer prices other than for food and energy are just 1.3 percent higher than they were a year ago.
"There are no signs of inflation in the U.S. economy," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Despite rapid growth and tight labor markets, there's no evidence of pricing pressure outside of oil."
The data do not necessarily mean the Federal Reserve will refrain from raising interest rates before the year is over, possibly at its next meeting on Oct. 5. But normally hypersensitive bond investors -- on the lookout for anything that might give the Fed a reason to raise rates -- apparently interpreted the producer price data as signs of benign inflation.
Bonds rallied, sending the yield on the long bond to 6.04 percent from 6.09 percent. Stocks were mixed.
"On balance, this is a constructive piece of news from the Fed's perspective," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "The Fed prefers not to see energy prices go up, but other prices, on which monetary policy has more direct impact, are still moderate."
Wholesale inflation has been running faster in the first eight months of this year compared with the same period last year, 2.3 percent versus zero. But the Labor Department attributed the entire increase to energy products. By contrast, the Labor Department noted in its release, the index for finished goods other than food and energy declined at a 0.4 percent rate the last eight months after advancing 2.5 percent in 1998.
Although most economists agree that the best news on inflation is probably past, there was a reassuring absence of signs that pressures were building along the pipeline that connects the prices of raw materials with those of finished goods. Prices of so-called intermediate goods outside of food and energy -- everything from copper wire to paper and plywood -- rose two-tenths of a percent in August, about half the rate of the previous two months.
Certainly, the fact that Asia is emerging from its recession, Europe is beginning to grow faster, and Latin America is not sinking as much as everyone feared after Brazil's currency tanked, means that the demand for many raw materials will increase, raising prices.
But instead of passing on higher prices, many manufacturers seem to be accepting smaller profit margins or, more frequently, finding ways to trim costs elsewhere in their operations by bolstering productivity.
They may not have much choice. The world is still awash in excess capacity, not just overseas but also in the United States, where the fraction of unused industrial capacity remains well above the historical norm. And optimists think they detect a long-term shift in corporate thinking.
"There's more competitive pressure on pricing than before," said Mr. Rippe of Prudential Securities. "But there's also a different mentality out there."
Few analysts expect energy prices to keep soaring as they have the last four months, but energy prices are likely to stay firm thanks to growing demand, low inventories and the chance that the coming winter will not be as balmy as the most recent winters.
Faster growth abroad and a nascent rebound in manufacturing in the United States are also having an effect on the prices of industrial commodities -- iron and steel scrap, raw cotton and the like -- which jumped nearly 2 percent in August after a 2.3 percent increase in July.
Food prices tell a different tale. Prices bounced up 0.4 percent in August, a sizable rise. But that followed a nearly 1 percent drop in July. Unlike energy and raw materials, there is no reason to think food prices are on a rising trend. Among things that were a lot pricier in August were pork, dairy products and soda. Beef, veal, chicken and vegetables fell less in August than in July. Some things became cheaper, among them fish and coffee.
Meanwhile, prices of many manufactured goods are still flat or falling. Although aircraft, office furniture and construction equipment became costlier, capital goods prices did not budge over all in August as everything from trucks to X-ray equipment was cheaper.
And the prices of consumer goods other than energy products dipped slightly. Among the things that became more of a bargain in August were liquor, clothes, laundry soap and mobile homes.
Stable wholesale prices will not necessarily stay the Fed's hand this fall, however. Apart from the fact that producer prices exclude imports and, more important, services, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, reminded anyone who cared to listen that the Fed had yet to reverse all of its 75-point rate cut of last fall.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Assisting Militias, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton accused the Indonesian military today of direct involvement in the savagery that has swept across East Timor and said that an international peacekeeping force must be allowed to restore order.
"It is now clear that the Indonesian military is aiding and abetting the militia violence," he said in a statement released during a stop in Hawaii en route to an Asia-Pacific economic meeting in New Zealand. "This is simply unacceptable." 
 Mr. Clinton, who earlier had held out the possibility that the Indonesian military might end the violence, said today that international peacekeepers were now essential.
"The Indonesian government and military must reverse this course -- to do everything possible to stop the violence -- and allow an international force to make possible the restoration of security," he said.
Despite the Pentagon's earlier insistence that there are no plans to send American ground troops to join an Australian-led peacekeeping force in East Timor, the President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said today, "I don't think anything is ruled out here."
Mr. Berger indicated that Mr. Clinton, from Air Force One, had been consulting congressional leaders about how deeply the United States might get involved. One official said contingency plans would require moving "thousands of American personnel, though not necessarily onto East Timor." The troops, aircraft and ships would be chiefly drawn from Marine bases on Okinawa.
Mr. Berger also appeared to acknowledge what other senior Administration officials have said privately -- that Indonesia's military has muscled aside President B.J. Habibie, who seems unable to control developments in East Timor. While President Clinton has exchanged messages with Mr. Habibie in recent months, Mr. Berger said, "I think we have focused on where we believe the decisions are being made, which is the Indonesian military."
He said that General Wiranto, Indonesia's senior military commander and defense minister, "has ultimate responsibility for asserting control over" the situation in East Timor although "there may be divisions within the military."
Mr. Berger said the Administration had begun a reviewing other sanctions that could be taken against Indonesia. Earlier this week, the President announced that he had ordered the Pentagon to end its few formal contacts with the Indonesian military, and that he would consider new economic sanctions against Indonesia if "this madness" in East Timor was not ended.
A senior administration official said the White House decided today to suspend a package of commercial arms sales to Indonesia expected to total about $16 million over the next year. "All ongoing and previously approved sales are being frozen," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Even as the American response grew more heated today, the Administration appeared to be running out of options to bring pressure on the Indonesian military to quell the violence or to permit the deployment of an international peacekeeping force.
The most potent weapon available to the United States is its veto power over economic assistance to Indonesia from the International Monetary Fund, which has propped up the Indonesian economy with billions of dollars in emergency aid.
But no new I.M.F. assistance for Indonesia is in the pipeline, and $2.5 billion already committed to Indonesia by the Fund was frozen even before the crisis in East Timor, as a result of allegations that the Indonesian Government had misused an earlier package of aid money.
A few officials in the Administration, speaking on the condition of anonymity, have questioned whether economic sanctions would be wise, especially because they might lead to widescale rioting across Indonesia or a nationalistic backlash.
During a two-hour stopover in Hawaii, President Clinton met with Adm. Dennis Blair, the commander of American forces in the Pacific, who hurried returned home to Hawaii after meeting with General Wiranto in Indonesia. He also spoke by phone with Prime Minister John Howard of Australia, who is working to organize a peacekeeping force.
"The President made clear to Prime Minister Howard that the United States supported such an international peacekeeping force and that we would provide support to such a force if one becomes feasible," Mr. Berger said.
Asked whether American support would go beyond logistical assistance, he said that the Australians "are most interested in those things that we have a special capability in -- in terms of logistics and communications and intelligence." But he added that "we've not made any decisions beyond that or ruled anything out."

HEADLINE: Andreessen Steps Down From AOL

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Marc Andreessen, who became an icon of the Internet age as a co-founder of the Netscape Communications Corporation before it was acquired by America Online last year, is stepping down after seven months as America Online's chief technology officer, the company said yesterday.
In his place, the company hired William J. Raduchel, the chief strategist of Sun Microsystems. 
 The chief technology officer's job at America Online is not to run its vast computer network, but to plan a network of the future that will connect not only to computers but to telephones, televisions and all manner of new gadgets.
Mr. Raduchel's background may fill the bill better than Mr. Andreessen's. He has been involved in Sun's Internet strategy and forging alliances with other big companies, including Fujitsu, Sony and more recently America Online. Moreover, Mr. Raduchel, a 53-year-old former Harvard professor and veteran technology executive, may be more suited to the ways of America Online, where executives tend to be in their late 30's and 40's, than the 28-year-old Mr. Andreessen, who was a student before forming Netscape.
Of course, when Mr. Andreessen took the job at America Online in February, it was seen as a sign that the sprawling company in Dulles, Va., was reaching out to former Netscape employees and to Silicon Valley in general. As one of the inventors of the Internet browser at 23, Mr. Andreessen was the first of the young entrepreneurs who were changing the world -- and getting rich -- by building the Web.
But Mr. Andreessen said he figured out that he would rather be investing in and working with start-ups rather than attending meetings about corporate strategy.
"America Online's mission is to bring the Internet to everyone and to accomplish that mission is clearly a matter of size and scale," he said. "Start-ups have a different role. They are about breaking the rules and trying new things that might fail or might change the world."
So, he has arranged a part-time position with America Online that will allow him to make personal investments in start-up companies as well as advising America Online about investing in or acquiring them.
"I look at all the creativity in the start-up world and it's like white water rafting," Mr. Andreessen said. "You can't tell what's going on from the shore. You have to be in the middle of the rapids."
Over the last year, Mr. Andreessen has made personal investments in Replay, a company that makes digital video recorders, and Accompany, an on-line store. But he says his new role will give him the time to serve on more boards and work more closely with companies.
Another factor that was not endearing about his new job, Mr. Andreessen conceded, was that his English bulldogs could not take the Virginia heat, and he had to send them back to his home in Palo Alto, Calif.
Mr. Andreessen was the last America Online employee among the small group of engineers from the University of Illinois who founded Netscape along with Jim Clark, the founder of Silicon Graphics. Indeed, of the top seven executives at Netscape at the time of the acquisition last November, only one is still working for the company full time. Barry Ariko, Netscape's chief operating officer, is the No. 2 executive in Iplanet, the joint venture between America Online and Sun to sell software that runs Web sites.
Mr. Raduchel was one of the top four executives at Sun and has served over the last 10 years as its chief financial officer and its chief information officer.
He said that like Mr. Andreessen, he has been considering investing in or working for start-ups.
"I had already told Scott that I wanted to look at doing something different after 10 years on the inside as a staff guy," Mr. Raduchel said, referring to Scott McNealy, Sun's chairman, who was one of his economics students at Harvard. But then Steve Case, America Online's chairman, heard that Mr. Raduchel was considering leaving Sun and just two weeks ago called him to offer him Mr. Andreessen's job.
"I wasn't planning to take another job like I had," Mr. Raduchel said. "But I realized I enjoy the leverage that big companies give me. You can paint on a three-by-five card in your house or you can paint on a billboard in Times Square. And that's what I'd rather do."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Hits New High as Computer Companies Rebound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index soared to a record yesterday as investors snapped up shares of Internet companies and software makers. But the swing toward technology stocks came at the expense of industrial stocks, which finished mostly lower, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down.
The Nasdaq index rose 35.04 points, to close at 2,887.06, easily surpassing its previous closing high of 2,864.48, on July 16. For the year, the Nasdaq has gained 31.7 percent. 
 The Dow industrials, however, fell 50.97, to close at 11,028.43, after giving up a gain of 62 points. For the week, the Dow lost 50.02, or 0.5 percent, but it is still up 20.1 percent so far this year.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4, to 1,351.66.
The Nasdaq's strength came from hefty gains by the on-line auction house Ebay, which rose 13 9/16, to 158, and the Internet search provider Yahoo, which rose 7 13/16, to 170 1/2. Software companies also gained ground, with Microsoft rising 15/16, to 95, and Oracle, a maker of business software, picking up 2 5/16, to 46 3/8.
"Technology is back," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "This is a group that had been battered in recent weeks, and it's nice to see money coming back into the group."
Traders suggested that Thursday's unofficial test run for Year 2000 computer glitches may have eased concerns about computer-related companies. Some programmers had feared that the string of nines in Thursday's date, 9/9/99, would cause computer programs to fail. But with no major problems reported, programmers and Wall Street professionals alike gained confidence that Jan. 1, 2000, would pass without difficulty.
Stocks also benefited from a relatively benign Government report on producer prices for August, which eased investor concerns about higher interest rates. The Labor Department said that rising energy costs pushed producer prices up a higher-than-expected five-tenths of a percent, but when the volatile energy and food categories were excluded, the index actually fell a tenth of a percent.
Financial markets tend to set aside food and energy price changes and focus on the figure known as core inflation. The drop in the core rate last month was better than economists had expected.
The markets have been uneasy lately because of concerns that the Federal Reserve, which has already raised interest rates twice this year, would push rates higher a third time because of the economy's strength.
"This was pretty much the icing on the cake," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Capital Markets Group in Charlotte, N.C. "The market is correct to now relax, at least temporarily."
But while most stocks rose, the big industrial companies that dominate the Dow fell. Caterpillar tumbled 2, to 56 3/4, and Chevron, which rose throughout the week as crude oil prices improved, fell 1 5/8, to 95 15/16, as investors took profits.
Maytag, the appliance maker, plunged 14 13/16, to 41 3/4, after saying its third-quarter earnings would miss Wall Street analysts' estimates because of weak sales for its lower-priced goods.
Healthsouth, which runs rehabilitation centers, fell 2 3/16, to 5 11/16. The company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said late on Thursday that it would delay spinning off its in-patient hospitals and warned that its operating margins for the third and fourth quarters would fall below forecasts.
Hon Industries of Muscatine, Iowa, an office furniture company, eased 1 9/16, to 22 9/16. The company warned that third-quarter earnings would be below Wall Street estimates, citing difficulties in hiring new employees.
National Semiconductor gained 2 5/8, to 34 5/8, after reporting better-than-expected first-quarter earnings of $47.1 million, or 25 cents a share.
Amplidyne, a maker of power amplifiers for wireless and satellite telecommunications based in Raritan, N.J., climbed 2 1/8, to 12 1/4, after introducing a set of products to offer high-speed wireless Internet access.
Intuit, which makes Quicken and Turbotax software, gained 5 15/16, to 103, after announcing a 3-for-1 split.
"Most of the market came through this week fairly unscathed," said Mr. Hogan of Jefferies & Company. "But until we hear from the Fed, there's still resistance against taking the entire market to new highs."
The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies rose 3.42, to 441.19.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners 6 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume totaled 808.54 million shares.
Overseas, Japan's Nikkei stock average rose 0.19 percent. European indexes were mixed, as Germany's DAX index rose 0.9 percent, Britain's FT-SE 100 fell 1.1 percent, and France's CAC-40 gained 0.6 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Producer Prices Jump, But Core Rate Slips
Producer prices, a gauge of wholesale price inflation, jumped five-tenths of a percent in August, the Labor Department reported. But the increase, the largest since last December, was largely confined to energy and food. 
 The core rate of wholesale price inflation fell one-tenth of a percent, after holding steady in July. Despite the huge jump in crude oil prices since the spring, producer prices other than for food and energy are just 1.3 percent higher than they were a year ago. Page C4.
 
Nasdaq Index Surges to Record
The Nasdaq composite index soared 35.04 points to 2,887.06, a record, as investors snapped up shares of Internet companies and software makers, but industrial stocks slid. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 50.97 points to close at 11,028.43, while the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index edged up 4.00 points to 1,351.66. C3.
 
Treasury bond prices rose, reflecting hope for tame inflation, sparked by the producer price report and the dollar's rise against the yen. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to a two-week low of 6.04 percent. C3.
 
British Merger May Be Blocked
The European Commission seemed to be preparing to block the proposed $1.4 billion takeover of First Choice Holidays P.L.C. by Airtours P.L.C. The deal would create Britain's biggest single tour operator and narrow competition in a market that has been seeing price wars and falling sales. C2.
 
NEC Shares Jump 12% on Report
Shares of the NEC Corporation jumped 12 percent after a report in Japan's leading business daily, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, suggested that the technology and telecommunications giant planned a sweeping overhaul that would consolidate business units, give division heads greater authority and shed money-losing businesses. The steps are in line with plans announced by Koji Mishigaki when he was named president of the company in February. C2.
 
U.A.W. Demand to DaimlerChrysler
Stephen Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers, is said to be demanding that DaimlerChrysler A.G. make it easier for the union to organize its workers, including those at a nonunion Mercedes plant in Alabama, if it is to lead industry contract talks. C4.
 
Oil Settlement Is Reported
Chevron, BP Amoco P.L.C. and Conoco Inc. have agreed in principle to pay about $155 million to settle charges filed by two whistleblowers that they underpaid oil royalties, according to published reports. Neither the companies nor the Justice Department would confirm the settlement reports. C2.
 
MGM Plans $750 Million Stock Sale
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., owner of one of the world's largest film libraries, said it would sell $750 million of new common shares and reduce some of its debt. Tracinda, the investment company owned by Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire, holds about 89 percent of MGM's shares and may buy more. C3.
 
Korea to Sell Nuclear Generators
The state-run Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Company, or Hanjung, said it would sell $50 million worth of nuclear power plant generators to United States-based ABB-Combustion Engineering Nuclear Power, a unit of ABB Ltd. C2.
 
Court Accepts Oil Tanker Dispute
The Supreme Court accepted a half dozen new cases, including a significant dispute over safety regulations for oil tankers, pitting the State of Washington against the Federal Government. In another case raising a question of the pre-emption of state law, the Court agreed to decide whether automobile manufacturers could be sued for having failed to provide air bags when Federal law permitted but did not require them. A8.

HEADLINE: Indian Tribes Approve Gambling Compacts With California

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Gray Davis and more than 50 California Indian tribes agreed today to binding compacts intended to keep slot machines operating at Indian casinos around the state, and the State Legislature voted to put a referendum on the ballot next March to exempt tribes from the state Constitution's ban on casino gambling, paving the way for a substantial expansion of gambling in the West.
The agreements, reached after an overnight scramble at the end of the annual legislative session in Sacramento, were intended to avert a threatened Federal shutdown of tribal slot machines in the wake of a State Supreme Court ruling last month. That ruling overturned an earlier ballot measure that would have expanded the $1.4 billion annual industry. 
 The constitutional amendment would have to be approved by voters before the tribes would have the right to offer slot machines and blackjack card games and they still would not be allowed to offer roulette or craps games.
But if the constitutional amendment is approved, which seems likely because voters approved the earlier ballot measure, the number of slot machines at Indian casinos around the state could more than double, to 43,000. So could jobs in an industry that already employs about 16,000 people statewide in a no-frills, close-to-home alternative to the grander temptations of Las Vegas, Nev. A separate agreement giving casino employees the right to organize a union must be endorsed by each tribe by Oct. 13, or the 20-year compacts will be nullified.
"For those tribes that adopt it, this compact offers security and economic promise," said Mr. Davis, a Democrat who received more than $750,000 in Indian contributions in his election campaign last year.
He had vowed to help the tribes find a way to preserve their gambling after the court decision last month, but was also under pressure from allies in organized labor to assure rights to collective bargaining.
Daniel Tucker, vice chairman of the Sycuan Band of Mission Indians and a spokesman for the California Indian Gaming Nations Association, said the compacts and the proposed constitutional amendment would "finally allow California Indian tribes to achieve the self-reliance that we have long been seeking."
Indian gambling has been a hotly disputed issue in California for much of the last decade, as impoverished tribes expanded from traditional bingo games into more lucrative slot machines and card games. But under Federal law, tribes are not allowed to offer such gambling without first signing compacts with the state, and former Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican and a staunch opponent of gambling, refused to negotiate a compact with any tribe that already had slot machines, though he reached limited compacts with a handful of tribes.
In an effort to get around Mr. Wilson, about 40 other tribes sponsored a ballot measure, Proposition 5, that essentially required the state to sign a gambling compact with any tribe that wanted one.
That measure was approved with 63 percent of the vote after a $100 million spending campaign, a national record, that pitted the tribes against Nevada casino interests wary of competition. But the State Supreme Court ruled last month that the statute violated the state Constitution's longstanding ban on Nevada-style casinos, rejecting the tribes' arguments that their machines and card games operated more like a lottery than a traditional casino bank. As a result, Federal prosecutors, who had previously won court orders against about 10 casinos, threatened to seize their machines by mid-October unless tribes reached compacts with the state.
Prosecutors had said that if the tribes signed compacts as a show of good faith, they would hold off any further action until a constitutional amendment could be considered by the voters.
At least 58 tribes agreed to sign the new compacts. But Richard Milanovich, chairman of the Agua Caliente band of Indians in Palm Springs, whose 1,150 video slot machines are among those Federal officials have threatened to seize, said his tribe was leaning against signing the measure and would seek a vote of the whole tribe next week. Among his objections was that the tribe would have to contribute some of its gambling profits to a state fund that would then be distributed to tribes that choose not to have gambling.
"We have difficulty with that because it sets artificial limits on the economic viability of those machines and it creates another state bureaucracy that handles money for tribes," said Mr. Milanovich, whose tribe's casino is one of the state's biggest. He said that ceding such authority to the state could violate Indian sovereignty.
Under the compacts, tribes without slot machines would have the first chance to draw from a pool of new machines, and would be allocated 350 machines each. Tribes that already offer gambling could increase their number of machines by acquiring unused allocations from other tribes. There is a limit of 2,000 machines per tribe. A percentage of gambling revenues would also be turned over to the state to be used for programs to treat gambling addiction and to finance local infrastructure needs generated by gambling.
Under the compacts Mr. Wilson, the former Governor, had reached with a handful of tribes, they were limited to no more than 990 machines each. Those agreements were superseded by the new compacts today.
Indian gambling interests have become a major political force in the state and this week, Common Cause announced that for the first time, three tribes have earned places on the group's list of the 10 biggest donors to state legislators over the past two years. Together, the three tribes gave more than $3.6 million to legislative campaigns.
Other businesses in the state, including race tracks and card clubs, have pressed for expanded gambling rights to match the tribes, and bills to allow that moved through the Legislature this week.
A spokesman for Governor Davis, Michael Bustamante, said Mr. Davis would not support any such efforts this year and did not intend to allow "a major expansion of gambling in the state, period." He said the Governor was "still very optimistic," that the handful of the state's tribes that have yet to sign the agreement would do so before the deadline.
But Cheryl Schmit, co-chairwoman of Stand Up For California, a statewide group opposed to gambling expansion, said, "This was not a moderate expansion of gambling, this was a huge expansion."
The Legislature's decision to place a constitutional amendment on the ballot next March eliminates the need for a costly petition-gathering effort that the Indians were preparing, but both sides predicted there could yet be a costly replay of last year's battle over Proposition 5.
"I think the campaign is going to be very heated," said Penny LeDoux, one of the plaintiffs who sued to overturn Proposition 5. "We're disappointed in the compact. It just allows for huge expansion of gambling and has no requirements for involvement or approval by local communities that are affected."
Ms. Schmit said: "This is an unending saga. We're bitterly disappointed with the compacts that the Governor signed. There is money given from tribes to the state to help local communities, but now we'll have to go lobby our legislators to persuade them to help individual communities. That doesn't seem very fair."
