HEADLINE: Debt Reduction Gains Appeal In the Capital

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Representative Baron P. Hill, a moderate Democrat from Indiana, spent a good part of August walking across his district, talking with constituents about what to do with the Federal budget surplus.
Mr. Hill says he heard little enthusiasm for the $792 billion Republican tax-cutting plan, which President Clinton has pledged to veto. Instead, he heard a remarkably consistent call for Congress and the Administration to use the surplus for a purpose long supported by economists but until now seen as a political yawner by both parties: reducing the $3.6 trillion national debt. 
 "The American people get this," the Congressman said. "They want the national debt paid down."
Coming from a Democrat, Mr. Hill's account of what he heard is perhaps not surprising. But having failed to rally strong public pressure in support of their tax cuts, Republicans as well now increasingly see debt reduction as having far more appeal to voters than they previously assumed. And that changing political calculation could prove to be crucial in determining whether the White House and the two parties in Congress push this year for a big compromise deal on taxes and spending, or leave the issue to be fought out on the campaign trail next year.
The reason is that if there is partisan gridlock over how to divide up the surplus, it automatically gets channeled into debt reduction. To the degree that debt reduction is seen as a political winner, both parties will be more willing to walk away from any proposed deal on the surplus, and that seems to be what is happening.
Republican leaders said over the last few days that they would consider the issue closed for the year if Mr. Clinton vetoes their tax-cut bill when they send it to him next week.
They left open the possibility of a negotiation with the White House to salvage a tax cut, their most cherished legislative goal. But they said that locking away most of the surplus for debt reduction -- and keeping Democrats from spending it -- would be accomplishment enough for them to take home to voters in an election year, especially since cutting the debt would leave the nation in better financial condition to deal with looming shortfalls in the Social Security and Medicare programs.
Asked by a reporter on Thursday if this session of Congress would be a failure if it did not produce a tax cut, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert replied that preserving for debt reduction the biggest portion of the surplus -- the part generated by excess Social Security revenue -- would be "a real step forward in most people's minds."
Mr. Clinton also has a case for refusing to budge. In the view of the White House, blocking the Republican tax cut would not be about denying taxpayers their due or fueling wasteful Government spending, as Republicans assert; it would be about insuring that surpluses go primarily to reducing or perhaps even eliminating the debt.
"We have an historic opportunity to lift the burden of debt off the next generation," Mr. Clinton said in an appearance at the White House on Thursday.
Many liberals say that spending on education and health, for example, yields greater benefits to the nation than debt reduction. Many conservatives say tax cuts can do more to stimulate economic growth.
But centrist economic thought holds that debt reduction brings great benefits by holding down interest rates, freeing capital for investment in new technologies and factories, and giving the Government greater borrowing power in the future if needed to deal with a problem like a shortfall in Social Security.
Although polls show some backing for tax cuts, they also support the notion that debt reduction has become a priority for voters. In a poll by ABC News and The Washington Post last week, 43 percent of respondents identified shoring up Social Security as the best use for the surplus, with 24 percent supporting debt reduction and 20 percent backing tax cuts. Given that debt reduction and shoring up Social Security are closely linked, the polls may even understate the support for debt repayment.
While they have argued all year about whose plan would do more to reduce the debt, the two parties are not far apart. Both parties have agreed that the portion of the surplus generated by excess Social Security revenue -- about $2 trillion over the next decade -- should be used only for debt reduction (although some Republicans would use a portion of it to allow individuals to invest some of their Social Security money in the stock market).
The battle has been over the remaining $1 trillion in projected surpluses, the portion that comes from general tax revenue. The Republicans would use that money for their tax cut, saying they could find additional money for debt reduction by cutting spending further. The White House wants to divide it among spending programs and a complicated plan under which the interest savings from additional debt reduction would go to help Medicare.
Whether either approach is credible remains to be seen. Even without a tax cut, Congress is on track to spend next year's non-Social Security surplus of about $14 billion, and Republicans are resorting to every gimmick they can think of to avoid dipping into the $147 billion projected Social Security surplus, money that would otherwise go to debt reduction.
Democrats and the White House have also pledged to keep their hands off the Social Security surplus next year, but are having as much trouble as the Republicans in making the numbers in their proposals add up.

HEADLINE: MILITIAS IN TIMOR MENACE REFUGEES AT U.N. COMPOUND

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Moments after most of the staff had evacuated the besieged United Nations compound in East Timor today, men with hand grenades arrived to menace the remaining workers and the 1,000 terrified refugees taking shelter there. Witnesses said the men had looted supplies with the help of uniformed soldiers and fired at refugees who tried to flee.
As international pressure grew, the armed forces chief, Gen. Wiranto, said for the first time that Indonesia might in the future accept the deployment of the United Nations peacekeeping force that has been the insistent demand of foreign nations. 
 Pressure this week came from a range of sources, but it is not clear which influence might have changed the general's mind. A United Nations delegation came to Indonesia to press the Government to allow peacekeeping troops to try to bring order to East Timor. And Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that continued violence in East Timor and repeated rejections of outside help could lead to charges of crimes against humanity.
President Clinton, en route to an economic meeting in New Zealand, said today in a statement from Air Force One, "It is now clear that the Indonesian military is aiding and abetting the militia violence." He said an international peacekeeping force was crucial. Page A6.
The commander of American forces in the Pacific, Adm. Dennis Blair, traveled to Jakarta to meet General Wiranto and to emphasize the general's responsibility to control the military, and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, has talked by phone with the Indonesian commander several times this week about East Timor.
The turbulence in East Timor has begun to shake the political position of President B. J. Habibie, who has come under criticism from his own party as well as his political opponents and who is the subject of increasing derision in the press.
Reports from East Timor's capital, Dili, today described a scene of continuing tension and fear.
Staff members who had evacuated the United Nations compound, upon arriving in Darwin, Australia, said they had been fired on as they headed in a convoy to the tiny airport in Dili. Around them, they said, lay a devastated city where almost every building had been burned or vandalized and where the only people in evidence were armed men on motorcycles.
As night fell, Brian Kelly, a United Nations official reached at the compound by telephone, said the tension at the unguarded compound had increased as the armed men continued to threaten the occupants.
"What this is is a further racheting up of intimidatory tactics and a further example of the porosity of the security fence we have been offered by the military," he said. "It's all part, I'm sure, of a game plan. The fact is that there is no way of predicting day to day how much more they will attempt."
Recent violence has included the burning of churches and the killing of priests and nuns around the territory. Pope John Paul II sent a telegram to Roman Catholics in East Timor condemning the violence against his followers and saying, "I implore those responsible for so many acts of wickedness to abandon their murderous and destructive intentions."
General Wiranto, in what seemed to be a plea for international understanding, given escalating demands for an end to the violence, said: "We do not object to the idea of foreign peacekeeping troops, but it is not really the appropriate time for a foreign security force to enter East Timor. But we are open for future discussions on such matters."
After weeks of absolute refusal to consider the involvement of foreign troops, the admission by the general that he might need outside help to control the situation -- and even to bring to heel some units of his own military -- illustrated the political toll East Timor has begun to take here in the Indonesian capital.
The violence is the direct result of what clearly seems to have been a sudden offer of independence by Mr. Habibie and of what also clearly seems to have been a deliberate plan by the military to undermine the process by staging a campaign of terror by irregular, military-backed militias.
"Last week Wiranto send battalions supposedly to protect people, but in the night they dress as militia with guns and weapons, and they go around the villages shooting," said East Timor's spiritual leader, the Roman Catholic Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo. He spoke in London after having been forced to flee the territory when gunmen burned his home in Dili and shot some of the 6,000 refugees who had taken shelter there.
In the referendum on Aug. 30, the former Portuguese colony voted overwhelmingly for independence from Indonesia, which invaded it in 1975 but never completely subdued a separatist insurgency.
Today, a faction of Mr. Habibie's political party, Golkar, demanded that he withdraw as its candidate for president in an electoral assembly planned for November, which follows a general election that was held in June.
Mr. Habibie's political stock had already been falling sharply. Many commentators say his disastrous policy regarding East Timor, and the weakness he is now demonstrating, have doomed his hopes for re-election.
The most likely candidate at the moment is the chief opposition leader, Megawati Sukarnoputri. She has maneuvered adeptly around the Timor issue, voicing support for the politically powerful military, which is resisting the separation of East Timor, while asserting that she will honor East Timor's right to independence. On Tuesday she said Mr. Habibie was "not fit to be a presidential candidate."
Public opinion, which has only begun to be aroused here in Jakarta on the issue of East Timor, was violently divided today. In one demonstration, protesters set fire to the flags of the United States and Australia, which they accused of meddling in Indonesian affairs. In another, a group of 80 women demonstrated outside the Defense Ministry calling for an end to military violence.
In Dili, the United Nations evacuated about 300 staff members, including all local workers, who are under threat of reprisals from the militias. The militias opposed the holding of the referendum under the auspices of the United Nations.
About 80 staff members remained in the compound, most of them having refused to leave as long as the refugees there remained under threat. A handful of journalists remained with them, and in telephone interviews their voices shook with exhaustion and emotion.
"The situation here deteriorated dramatically after the convoy left evacuating the U.N. staff and local staff and their families," said Marie Colvin, a British journalist reporting for The Sunday Times of London.
"They took away most of the army, and we were almost immediately besieged by militia," she said. "But this is not chaos. The militia certainly, from what I could see, was operating closely with the army. When the militia threatened to throw grenades over the wall, the army came and said we should give them a truck and they would go away."
When militia members tried to break into a truck filled with supplies that was parked adjacent to the compound, she said, "we saw that when they were unable to smash in the windshield the army came over and smashed it in with a rifle butt."
In Jakarta, the chief military spokesman, Brig. Gen. Sudrajat, denied that the militia had threatened the United Nations compound.
"There are soldiers there to protect it," he said.

HEADLINE: Made in the U.S.A.

BYLINE: By James K. Galbraith; James K. Galbraith is an economist whose most recent book is "Created Unequal."

 BODY:

In Praise of Hard Industries
 Why Manufacturing, Not the
 Information Economy, Is the Key to Future Prosperity.
 By Eamonn Fingleton.
 273 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $26. 
 Eamonn Fingleton is the sort of journalist economists despise. He is a mercantilist, judging economic activities by their contribution to exports. He is a protectionist, favoring high tariffs. He believes that the United States is heading toward a competitive crisis, caused by our faddish choice of unsustainable postindustrial activities -- finance, computer software, information. He believes that the advanced manufacturing industries should be actively supported by government to block the "leakage of world-beating production technologies abroad."
These are provocative arguments not very persuasively made. "In Praise of Hard Industries" is anecdotal, spurning statistics or other corroboration. It is overstated: American manufacturing isn't exactly dead, something that, reading between the lines here about Kodak and Boeing, one learns. The policy prescriptions (savings tax incentives, tariffs) are shallow. And sometimes the argumentation is daft. In two places Fingleton asserts that the high-tech hotshots who make so much money in San Jose are so bright that they could do equally well in, let us say, Akron, if only they chose to move there. So why didn't they?
And yet Fingleton is right on a basic fact. Manufacturing is and will remain the central economic activity in world trade. This book is best at its descriptions of modern manufacturing processes -- Nikon's stepper machines, central to semiconductor production, for instance, or Sony's laser diodes -- and for its screeching critique of our Internet-obsessed business press. New Age gurus take deserved hard hits -- though Fingleton is silent on their leading acolytes, Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich.
Fingleton laid out his view of the hidden strengths of the Japanese economy in "Blindside." Here he says that in the 1990's Japanese policy makers decided to play down their continuing successes (notably in isolating their financial crash from their still strong industrial sectors), partly to stay below American political radar. Hence the looming crisis as he sees it: Japanese (and German) manufacturing continue to advance while Americans place vain hopes on service sectors like software, dominated by small, overvalued companies like Microsoft, highly vulnerable to piracy, outsourcing and low-wage imports.
O.K., but so what? Can the United States survive and prosper as a financial services, software, information and entertainment-producing society whose role in the world is also anchored, as Fingleton does not say, by its position as chief military enforcer and supplier of the world's reserve currency -- the dollar? The fact is, we have full employment without inflation, declining inequality and a balanced budget. There is no very obvious evidence the party will end soon. Would we be better off with high tariffs and so higher prices -- and foregone use of Japanese microelectronics in favor of inferior home production? Would we be better off supplying fewer dollars to world finance and forcing reserves to be shifted to the Euro?
Economists typically respond to arguments like Fingleton's with a one-size-fits-all attack on protectionism and the mercantile fallacy. This is a mistake. The mercantilists in their day (Elizabethan England and 19th-century Germany under the influence of Friedrich List) knew what they were doing. And the pursuit of industrial advantage and of a reserve of treasure is sensible policy for middling powers in an unstable world -- as Japan learned and both China and Taiwan, the survivors of last year's crisis, can attest.
Yet the same course is not necessarily sensible for the leading financial and imperial powers. Countries like ours, or the elites that run them, have other interests. Whether we should, in fact, anchor the world system, whether we can effectively do so, whether it is good for us morally -- these are important issues. But Fingleton does not address them. They would require a more searching critique of the American fin de si<heart>cle than one finds here.

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/POP AND JAZZ;
Melancholy Babies: Angst Is In Again

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
POPULAR music, the id of American culture, market-tests attitudes along with rhythms and tunes. For most of 1999, the pop charts have been divided among four disparate, teen-centered moods: the gooey romance of groups like the Backstreet Boys, the peppy Spanglish pop of Ricky Martin (who is scheduled to perform amid bilingual squeals at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 28), the frat-boy boorishness of bands like Limp Bizkit and the action-movie nihilism of gangsta rap. Part of the audience is soaking up sweet nothings; another part fantasizes on lashing out.
What has been missing for some time amid pop's puppy love and acting up is a mentality that was a staple of early-1990's rock: brooding, questioning, self-lacerating angst. With a buoyant economy and a pop-cultural landscape full of pumped-up wrestlers and invincible action-movie heroes, pop audiences grew impatient with troubled rock stars who turned their frustrations inward, especially when they proclaimed their need to be alone while they worked the arena circuit. 
 But in the 1999 season, angst is going to try for a comeback. Leading the misery brigade is Trent Reznor, who has taken five years to come up with a sequel to "The Downward Spiral." Between albums, he has steered Marilyn Manson to notoriety and supervised the soundtrack to "Natural Born Killers," but Nine Inch Nails's particular blend of industrial crunch and Beatles melody, self-loathing and blurted confessions of bad impulses went silent. Worked over in studio solitude for years, the new Nine Inch Nails album, "The Fragile," which is due Sept. 21, seeks new nadirs of bitter disclosure matched to fine-tuned sonic assaults.
Another forlorn character, Fiona Apple, returns in November with her second album, which, cantankerously, has a 90-word title. Her songs provide a corrective to the dewy-eyed, happy-ever-after romance that has retaken the Top 10; she remembers the ups and downs and messy, self-destructive details of love and lust, and she sings about them in a voice with a melancholy bitterness that makes her seem far older than 22. The reception of both albums will measure whether adolescents still want to admit they're tormented from within. Other songwriters who are about to release albums that are neither sunny nor belligerent include Tori Amos and a subdued David Bowie.
But all those performers have to wonder whether listeners are still interested in the continuity of a career. From the 1960's onward, rock songwriters have been able to depend on loyalty from radio programmers and fans. But newer bands face shorter attention spans and the proliferating choices open to listeners on radio, cable television and the Internet. Having bought one sample of a musical persona, consumers may decide they don't need more of the same -- even as, for instance, Mel C. of the Spice Girls (remember them?) releases a solo album this fall.
Garth Brooks, a commercial champion of the 1990's, has come up with a strategy to beat the burnout. On his next album, he becomes an invented character, Chris Gaines, who wears a toupee instead of a cowboy hat. A tie-in film is expected in December 2000. Mr. Brooks conquered country music by merging it with 1970's pop-rock tactics, from Don McLean to Billy Joel, and turning a country band into an ever-smiling choreographed revue. His less than startling strategy for "Chris Gaines" is to straightforwardly revive 1970's and early-1980's rock in new songs, providing one more reprise for people who miss the sounds of John Denver, Loggins and Messina or Styx.
Since it put the band in bandwagon, pop will also be following through on current hit-making styles in the new season. Expect more teenypop sensations -- recording companies are probably scouting high-school assemblies by now -- and a salvo of tough-talking rap, with new albums due from Nas, DMX, Jay-Z and Method Man before the end of the year. Rappers like DMX and rap-rockers like Limp Bizkit are sharing bills for this fall's second annual Family Values tour, to the enrichment of insurers and security guards nationwide.
The surge of Latin pop holds more promise. It has created opportunities that could stimulate new cultural hybrids, as Hispanic singers with voices to match pretty faces -- notably Marc Anthony, the celebrated young pop-salsa tenor who will release his English-language debut on Sept. 28 -- get a chance to be heard outside their ethnic strongholds.
An infusion of Latin rhythms can only perk up popular music; rumba, guajira and son montuno have already revitalized 1990's dance music and jazz. And for concertgoers who want to look beyond Ricky Martin's grin, this fall brings the chance to hear a plentitude of more seasoned Latin musicians. The wave of music from Cuba brings national tours by Eliades Ochoa, Ibrahim Ferrer and Ruben Gonzalez, all from the Buena Vista Social Club, as well as Cuba's long-running dance band, Los Van Van. A Brazilian master, Gilberto Gil, is touring the United States this month, and this fall so are the genre-crunching rock en Espanol bands Cafe Tacuba and Jaguares, both from Mexico, and Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, from Argentina.
Unlike many of their neighbors north of the border, Latin rock musicians don't sound jaded or rule-bound. Following the example that Mr. Gil set in the late 1960's with Brazilian tropicalia, Latin rockers bend old forms and borrow from all over the place with a gleeful disregard for precedent. As they mash up styles and cross borders, the Latin bands show by example that pop doesn't have to confine itself to predetermined forms and attitudes -- a lesson that, sooner or later, ought to reach the United States mainstream.

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/ARCHITECTURE;
Imaginative Design Finds It's Homeless No Longer

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THE top pick in architecture this season is New York, the city entire. Architects, planners, developers, policy makers, civic groups: we are watching you. You get one chance to make a difference. Don't blow it.
The millennial threshold could be a pivotal moment for architecture in New York. Already, good economic times have sparked a new cycle of building, with construction cranes swiveling their hips all over town. More important is the change in atmosphere. Recently, there's been a break in the climate of hostility toward architecture that has prevailed here for two decades. People are tired of developer schlock and Art Deco retreads, tired of hearing that the only good buildings are dead buildings: new ones that fake the past. 
 Several recent projects have begun to raise the stakes. These include the LVMH Tower, the Austrian Cultural Institute, the New York Presbyterian Church and the recent design for Pennsylvania Station. And in January, Conde Nast employees will have the opportunity to refresh themselves at the Titanium Cafe, the first New York project by Frank O. Gehry. But when is the country's leading architect going to get a shot at the skyline?
For a long time, architecture in this town has been boxed up behind closed doors, as if it were something to be practiced by consenting adults in the privacy of their own homes. You can find architecture in lofts, shops, restaurants or shop windows, but out on the street -- democracy's great forum for celebration and debate -- this ancient art form has long lain dormant. Where are the buildings that interpret the life of the contemporary city to its inhabitants? Buildings as lively as those hips-notizing cranes? Please show us the way to Ricky Martin Tower.
As the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas has pointed out, our older urban centers are survivors. They've earned the right to set their own terms. At the same time, American cities must compete with the suburbs for the attention and dollars of the middle class. But don't middle-class people want more than complacency, reassurance and nostalgia? Don't we know that there's a difference between a city and a theme park? These are the questions that have to be asked.
A city that prizes its social diversity lags behind other places in its efforts to protect the biodiversity of the planet. Apart from Audubon House on Broadway, a project by the Croxton Collaborative, no major building in New York has been designed with ecological factors uppermost in mind. The Architectural League of New York, a veteran team of troopers led by Rosalie Ginevro, hopes to change this. The league will dedicate its entire program this season to the subject of sustainable architecture. Entitled "Shades of Green," the schedule of lectures, shows and panel discussions will explore different ways of building for an environmentally ravaged world. The season will culminate in March, with an exhibition at the Urban Center in Manhattan that will feature 10 recent examples of architecture that responds to ecological as well as esthetic issues. Organized by Peter Buchanan, the British architecture critic, the show will include buildings by Lord Norman Foster, Thomas Herzog and Francoise Jourda.
From Oct. 18 to Nov. 19, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art will exhibit a full-scale segment of Memorial for the Murdered Jews of Europe, Peter Eisenman's design for a Holocaust memorial in Berlin. The project has generated considerable controversy, less for its design than for its prominent location in a city haunted by the frightened ghosts of its past.
In the cold war years, it was apparent that the West had a considerable stake in Berlin as an instrument of geopolitical strategy. Since the toppling of the Berlin wall in 1989, the city has emerged as a key to understanding the past, and even a model for reckoning with it. Eisenman's task is to show that contemporary forms can be more powerful than historical ones in linking past to present. The Cooper Union show will also include sketches and models and will be followed, in December, by an exhibition first shown in Germany, "The German Army and Genocide: Crimes Against War Prisoners, Jews and Other Civilians in the East 1939-1944."
From Nov. 14 to April 23, the Jewish Museum in Manhattan will survey the urban sensibility that Hitler's tribes set out to exterminate. Entitled "Berlin Metropolis: Jews and the New Culture, 1890-1918," the show will include paintings, posters, theater memorabilia and other turn-of-the-century artifacts. Could be essential viewing for those contemplating a visit to Berlin, a city that was poised to become the cultural capital of the 20th century before it destroyed itself.

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS -- POP AND JAZZ

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:

September
 
GILBERTO GIL
The main concern that this Brazilian master songwriter always brings to the table is renewal -- personal, ecological, social, economic, technological. And his concerts are parties, too, with a lot of elastic vocal improvising over reggae, funk and samba. Tuesday. Irving Plaza. 

WOODY GUTHRIE
"The Asch Recordings Vol. 1-4" is a four-disk set, beautifully annotated, that includes unissued and remastered material. The set makes a case that Guthrie's work -- picked from all his life experiences, from the mythopoetic to the political to the domestic and the trifling -- holds up as well as that of any musical figure from this century. Tuesday. Smithsonian Folkways.
 
TOM HARRELL
Mr. Harrell, a trumpet and fluegelhorn player, is regularly cited as one of the best melodic improvisers of his generation, but he's also an ambitious composer, and the arrangements on his records have become increasingly bold. "Time's Mirror" is his first full-fledged big-band album. Tuesday. RCA Victor.
 
STEFON HARRIS
It's exciting to see the rapid growth of the young jazz vibraphonist Stefon Harris, who began as a classical percussionist; he's hanging out with challenging players, writing his own music and making high-quality records like "Black Action Figure," his second. Tuesday. Blue Note. (Mr. Harris will also perform at the Village Vanguard the week of Oct. 19 through Oct. 24.)
 
IGGY POP
His latest release, "Avenue B," begins with the famous wild-child croaking a sober prologue in his thick Midwestern accent about how he has grown inward and bookish in his 50's. Then it proceeds to his stock topic: freaky girlfriends. Tuesday. Virgin.
 
FEMI KUTI
The son of Fela Ransome-Kuti salts his Afrobeat with the kind of sinuous old-school funk Americans have come to love in Lauryn Hill and Macy Gray; his libidinous live performances do the rest. His first domestic album, "Shoki Shoki," will appear in January from MCA; his two local performances are on Wednesday at the Roxy, 515 W. 18th St. (645-5156), and on Saturday at Vinyl, 6 Hubert St. (343-1379)
 
"ROCKIN' IN RHYTHM: THE SMALL-BAND MUSIC OF DUKE ELLINGTON"
Ellington's legacy brings to mind the sight of 14 musicians on stage, but many of his sidemen broke off from the orchestra to record small-group versions of his tunes. The guest music director for this Jazz at Lincoln Center event is the trumpeter Nicholas Payton; the vocalist Dianne Reeves and the saxophonist Joe Lovano are special guests, with members of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra. Thursday through Saturday. Alice Tully Hall.
 
MASTERS OF INDIAN MUSIC
The sitarist Ustad Vilayat Khan, one of India's best, performs duets with his son, Shujaat Husain Khan, and the tablaist Sabir Khan. Presented by the World Music Institute. Friday. Town Hall.
 
TORI AMOS
"To Venus and Back," a double-disk outpouring from the myth-obsessed pop star, has a new sound; but the fresh studio technique can't bury a music driven by Ms. Amos's actorly hunger to express herself and her Dionysian poetry. One disk is new studio material, the other live recordings. Sept. 21. Atlantic.
 
CHRIS CORNELL
In Soundgarden, Mr. Cornell was one of the few great rock singers of the 90's, and with "Euphoria Morning," the first album released by any of the band's members after its breakup two years ago, he proves with a flourish that he can write, produce and sing all by himself; his new mood in the wake of Soundgarden's sludgy sturm und drang is more fragile, full of acoustic guitars and insinuating vocals. Sept. 21. A&M. (Concert at Town Hall on Tuesday.)
 
MAGNETIC FIELDS
The witty singer and songwriter Stephin Merritt has pulled off a dare with "69 Love Songs," a triple-disk album. It seems like an attempt to raid every kind of pop song genre, from country-rock lopers to English music hall ditties to chilly electro. For some it's too clever by half, but this kind of lavish ambition, recorded with a budget that's obviously not Beck-size, is rare. Sept. 21. Merge Records.
 
NINE INCH NAILS
Trent Reznor is still miserable after all these years. But misery has rarely sounded so technologically advanced; the production values on his new album, "The Fragile," are through the roof. Sept. 21. Nothing/Interscope.
 
MATADOR RECORDS SHOWCASE
Just a little while ago, the label that defined early-90's indie rock seemed on its knees; all of a sudden it made some shrewd signings, including the hip-hop band the Arsonists and the British ditty machine Belle and Sebastian, and it's rolling again. Its 10th anniversary will be marked by three New York shows at Irving Plaza. Performers include Cornelius, Arsonists and Red Snapper on Sept. 23; Pavement, Cat Power and Chavez on Sept. 24, and Yo La Tengo, Mary Timony and Solex on Sept. 25.
 
TOM WAITS
"Mule Variations," Mr. Waits's latest album, was a comeback for the reluctant idol. It sounds like a funky, overstuffed scrapbook, and it will be interesting to see how the new material translates to the stage in Mr. Waits's first tour in a decade. Sept. 23 through Sept. 25 and Sept. 27. Beacon Theater.
 
JIM LAUDERDALE AND RALPH STANLEY
Jim Lauderdale, among the in-crowd of Nashville singer-songwriters, has teamed up with the great patriarch of bluegrass, Ralph Stanley; the result, "I Feel Like Singing Today," is a collection of old-time songs perfectly in the language of Mr. Stanley and his great ghostly tenor. Sept. 24. Rebel Records.
 
10TH ANNIVERSARY CABARET CONVENTION
Each of its seven nights presents a separate program, from "Standards for a New Generation" to a 75th birthday tribute to Julie Wilson; with appearances by Ms. Wilson, Karen Akers, Ann Hampton Calloway, Cy Coleman, Mary Cleere Haran and dozens more. Sept. 27 through Oct. 3. Town Hall.
 
MARC ANTHONY
The most popular singer in the history of salsa dares to tamper with success, seeking an audience beyond Latinos with "Marc Anthony," a record that's almost all in English. Sept. 28. Columbia. (He will appear in concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Oct. 3.)
 
EVERYTHING BUT THE GIRL
"Temperamental," an opulent, gauzily lovely record informed by English club music -- house and drum-and-bass -- which somehow sums up a genre despite taking it mainstream. Sept. 28. Atlantic.
 
SOUNDTRACK FOR A CENTURY
A carefully curated, heavily annotated 26-CD boxed set covering jazz, country, Broadway, movie music, classical, rock, gospel and so on -- everything Columbia Records and its associated labels Okeh, Epic, Vocalion and others have touched since 1900. Sept. 28. Sony Music/Legacy Recordings.
 
GARTH BROOKS
His latest release, "Garth Brooks . . . in the Life of Chris Gaines," is a "pre-soundtrack" to the film "The Lamb" (to be released by Paramount toward the end of 2000) in which Mr. Brooks plays a pop singer named Chris Gaines. Mr. Brooks has said: "There's no story here about an alter ego. There's no story about Garth wanting to break out of country. There's no story here about Garth getting so fed up he's got to stretch out." Is this a Zen riddle or something? Sept. 28. Capitol.
 
LOS FABULOSOS CADILLACS
The rock-punk-rap-ska band from Argentina is the granddaddy of the rock en Espanol movement, the first group of the genre to win a Grammy; its new album is called "La Marcha del Golazo Solitario." Sept. 28. BMG/US Latin. (The band plays at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Oct. 8)
 
ISOTOPE 217
A jam band with an ever-changing lineup, it's the more jazz-related version of the Chicago band Tortoise, including some of its members. Their live shows get their fuel from Miles Davis's early-1970's methods -- polyrhythms, dense funk, Rob Mazurek's sweet trumpet lines, unexpected dropouts of sound here and there. Sept. 30-Oct. 1. Knitting Factory.
 
October
 
DAVID BOWIE
After a side trip into electronica, a return to rock-and-roll psychodrama with "Hours . . . " Oct. 5. Virgin.
 
LACE
If the Dixie Chicks weren't Spicy enough, this trio of young women aims with a new album, "Lace," to corner the young new-country market with three-part harmony and post- (or possibly pre-) feminist lyrics like "I don't want a man I can live with / I want a man I can't live without." Oct. 5. 143/Warner Brothers.
 
PAUL McCARTNEY
A new album, "Run Devil Run," includes 12 rock-and-roll oldies, 3 new McCartney originals, no oratorios. Oct. 5. Capitol.
 
TERI THORNTON
"I'll Be Easy to Find" is the second-time-around debut of a jazz singer who's been at it for four decades but found new interest from the music business upon winning the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz vocal competition last year. Oct 12. Verve. (Ms. Thornton will perform at the Village Vanguard the week of Oct. 12 through Oct. 17.)
 
THE MUSIC OF CHARLIE PARKER
An evergreen subject for institutional jazz orchestras; this one splits the bill between a quintet featuring the saxophonist Charles McPherson and the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band playing new arrangements of classic Parker tunes. Oct. 14. Carnegie Hall.
 
COME FLY WITH ME: THE SONGS OF JIMMY VAN HEUSEN
The second season of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series opens with a homage to the writer of some of Bing Crosby's and Frank Sinatra's biggest songs. With Gregg Edelman, Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, Maureen McGovern and Leslie Uggams. Oct. 15 and 16. Alice Tully Hall.
 
HANDSOME BOY MODELING SCHOOL
The new project from Prince Paul, the former De La Soul producer whose last move was a surprisingly effective narrative drama -- complete with a cast of characters -- pulled across the length of a hip-hop album. It's called "So . . . How's Your Girl?" Oct. 19. Tommy Boy.
 
ARTO LINDSAY
The American-born, Brazilian-raised Mr. Lindsay has a good sense for what sounds stimulate the intelligentsia just on the tail end of its hanging-out years; his recent records are smart dance music for the home stereo, with hints of Brazilian rhythm rumbling underneath Mr. Lindsay's serene croon. "Prize" comes out on Oct. 19. Righteous Babe.
 
ORQUESTA IBRAHIM FERRER/RUBEN GONZALEZ Y SU GRUPO
Two years later, "Buena Vista Social Club," the album that piqued North America's interest in Cuban culture, is still selling well, thanks in part to Wim Wenders's documentary film about its genesis. These are the next two appearances (with more to come soon) of the Social Club's stars, the charismatic singer Mr. Ferrer and the pianist Mr. Gonzalez. Oct. 22 and Feb. 4 and 5. Beacon Theater.
 
BOB MARLEY: A REBEL'S DREAM
A tape-manipulated duet-remix-tribute album, organized by Marley's son Stephen. Marley's voice accompanies new vocal and instrumental tracks with Erykah Badu, Lauryn Hill, the Roots, Busta Rhymes, Guru and others. Oct. 26. Island/Def Jam.
 
PAOLO CONTE
A hero in Italy and France with a pothole of a voice, he's an appealingly gruff chansonnier: he sings songs in Italian about memories, his own stubbornness and the loveliness of jazz. If an American did this, kitsch would take it over. But Mr. Conte plays it straight, making us think for ourselves. Oct. 28. Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th St. between Park and Lexington Aves. (772-4448)
 
RICKY MARTIN
His publicists have done their work; now it's time for Mr. Martin himself, the crossover prince, to impress audiences here. Oct. 28. Madison Square Garden, Seventh Ave. at 32d St. (465-6741)
 
DAVE DOUGLAS
It's a typically busy season for the trumpeter and band leader, whose many different bands explore different angles. His Tiny Bell Trio, with a large repertory of skewed Balkan tunes, plays the Knitting Factory Oct. 28 through Oct. 31; his jazz-quartet album "Leap of Faith" will be released by Arabesque on Feb. 1; his sextet album, with violin and cello, appears on RCA Feb. 8, and his debut week at the Village Vanguard, with his quartet, is set for Feb. 15 through Feb. 20.
 
November
 
THE ARTIST FORMERLY KNOWN AS PRINCE
There's no way to predict gold or dross in the Artist's unstoppable flow, but his next album, "Rave Un2 the Joy Fantastic," intriguingly says that it's produced by someone named "Prince." Nov. 2. Arista. (A related article appears on page 89.)
 
FRANK EMILIO
A creator of Cuban jazz in the 40's and the 50's, Mr. Emilio is a blind pianist a stone's throw from the age of 80; "Ancestral Reflections" is an elegant record of rumbas and danzones about his musical past, with an eight-piece Cuban band. Nov. 2. Metro Blue/Capitol. (Recitals at the Stanley Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center, Jan. 13 and 14.)
 
RAGE AGAINST THE MACHINE
This band will never have a shortage of political topics to fume about, and its steamroller sound directly inspired much of the new hard rock; with its next album (as yet untitled), it must prove its staying power. Nov. 2. Epic.
 
COMPAY SEGUNDO
A new album, "Calle Salud," from the 90-plus guitarist who took part in the "Buena Vista Social Club" sessions. Nov. 2. Nonesuch/Atlantic. (Concert at Town Hall, Nov. 3.)
 
"MUSIC OF THELONIOUS MONK: A NEW PERSPECTIVE"
There's much still to be done with Thelonious Monk's work, which was harmonically rich and implied as much as it stated. The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, with a reputation for radical reinterpretation of the jazz canon, is perfect for the job. Guest artists are two pre-eminent interpreters of Monk's music: the pianist Kenny Barron and the soprano saxophonist Steve Lacy. Nov. 4. Carnegie Hall.
 
CAVESTOMP '99
A garage-rock bonanza, disinterring some great bands from the 60's and combining them on three days of long bills with their neoprimitivist progeny. Headlining Nov. 5: the Monks, a German band that hasn't performed in 32 years and has never performed in America. Nov. 6: the Chocolate Watch Band, who in 1967 asked provocatively, "Are You Gonna Be There (at the Love-In)?" Nov. 7: the Standells, who haven't sung about Boston's dirty water in 30 years. Dress code: love beads and motorcycle boots. Westbeth Theater Center, 151 Bank St. (691-2272)
 
SONIC YOUTH
The members of Sonic Youth have accomplished quite a lot of things -- dueting with Cecil Taylor, modeling, popularizing alternative rock, playing feedback solos at Avery Fisher Hall. But with their new album, "SYR4," they try something they they have not done before: making a sobersided double-disk album of notated pieces by avant-classical composers like James Tenney, Christian Wolff and John Cage. Nov. 8. SYR/Smells Like Records.
 
FIONA APPLE
If "Fast as You Can," the single from Ms. Apple's second album, "When the Pawn . . . ," is a portent, we can expect curiously written songs with shifting tempos; if these songs had eyes, they would be staring at you, making you uncomfortable. Nov. 9. Clean Slate/Epic.
 
BECK
His new album is positioned as the sample-mad, ultra-witty follow-up to "Odelay"; last year's "Mutations" was merely a soothing intermission act. Nov. 16. Geffen/Interscope.
 
ENRIQUE IGLESIAS
The debut English-language album (as yet untitled) from a new Latin crossover pop star whose single "Bailamos" has been a No. 1 hit this summer. Nov. 16. Interscope.
 
D'ANGELO
There are a lot of pop stars fighting to become prince of retro-soul, and "Voodoo," the second album by this young performer, may render them weaponless. Recorded live in the studio, finally finished after an eternity of rumors, it's going to be good, but the question is whether it will be as lasting -- in the mercilessly shifting context of pop today -- as records like Sly and the Family Stone's "There's a Riot Goin' On" or Stevie Wonder's "Innervisions," two of its templates. Nov. 23. Cheeba Sound/Virgin.
 
WYNTON MARSALIS
"Live at the Village Vanguard," a seven-disk set drawn from concert performances from 1985 to the mid-90's, may be the most powerful among Mr. Marsalis's onslaught of album releases in 1999; it will show us what we're missing by not having his small band around anymore. Nov. 23. Columbia Jazz.
 
December
 
MAD ABOUT THE BOY
A full-fledged tribute to Noel Coward in his centennial year, using Coward's memoirs, lyrics and scripts, and featuring Karen Akers, Barbara Cook, Michael Feinstein, Bobby Short, Lynn Redgrave and many more. Dec. 1. Carnegie Hall.
 
METHOD MAN
Always the most widely appealing of the Wu-Tang Clan, Method Man is a showman, a bearish rapper who aims to please, rather than to freak you out. Having struck gold with his solo album last year, he's looking to capitalize on his success with his next CD (as yet untitled) -- and perhaps to gain distance from the Clan's dropping stock. Dec. 8. Def Jam.
 
IN HIS SOLITUDE: THE SACRED MUSIC OF DUKE ELLINGTON
Eric Reed conducts the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra in this Jazz at Lincoln Center program, which will include some of Ellington's last works, the relatively underappreciated "Sacred Concerts." It's time for a re-evaluation, and the gospel singer Shirley Caesar, one of the greatest performers on American stages right now, will help that happen. Dec. 9 through Dec. 12. Alice Tully Hall.
 
PARTY AT THE END OF TIME: 1999 LIVE
Featuring the Roots, with Vernon Reid, P.M. Dawn and N'Dea Davenport. Live shows are the essence of the Roots: they've got a live band to make their hip-hop more immediate and flexible. Usually they're following their own agenda, doing their own workshop, but here they'll be the house band for a beginning-to-end cover of Prince's album "1999." Dec. 11. BAM Opera House, 30 Lafayette Ave., Fort Greene, Brooklyn. (718-636-4100).
 
TROMBONE TITANS
Get three jazz trombone players together -- with the battling aggression of trumpeters, but more of a sense of humor -- and there's bound to be trouble. Al Grey, Ray Anderson and Wycliffe Gordon have that humor, as well as virtuosity, making this show look memorable. Dec. 16. Pace Downtown Theater, 3 Spruce St. (346-1715)
 
DMX and JAY-Z
Two separate end-of-the-year mop-up records by the hottest names in hip-hop -- one rapper whose material is growled and encoded to describe a black Gotham, another whose last few records have been the shiniest, bouncingest blowout parties of rap. Dec. 21 and Dec. 27. Def Jam.
 
NEW YEAR'S EVE
Will the power turn off at midnight? Working at the Javits Center, 655 W. 34th St. (216-2000), if there are enough generators: Andrea Bocelli, Aretha Franklin, Chuck Berry, Enrique Iglesias, Sting, Tom Jones, Kool and the Gang. At Irving Plaza: Maceo Parker. Dec. 31.
 
January
 
SHELBY LYNNE
From a virtual unknown, a Southern singer-songwriter album that really sticks in your head. Her new album, "I Am Shelby Lynne," mixes rhythm machines with string sections, flute with pedal steel, guitar-driven Memphis soul with folk music; her voice lurches and staggers and then hits you over the head with a bright, well-written chorus. Jan. 11. Mercury/Island/Def Jam.
 
CLINTON
It's the return of Cornershop, the Indian-English band, under a different name; the idea is to give its new material -- sly, warped, low-fidelity drone-disco -- a new package. The album, "Disco and the Halfway to Discontent," is out in England now, and it may turn out to be one of the funny-but-funky pleasures of the year. January. Luaka Bop Records.
 
February
 
CAMPBELL BROTHERS WITH KATIE JACKSON
Chuck and Phillip Campbell's band has a regular gig at the House of God, a Pentecostal church in Rochester. Their sound incorporates the steel guitar, and it's a natural fit -- it slides, wails and swoops around spirituals. Katie Jackson, a singer from Baltimore, does the rest of the vocalizing. Opening is McCollough's Sons of Thunder, a Harlem-based gospel "shout" band that battles its way to grace with a phalanx of trombones. Feb. 19. Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th St. (864-5400)
 
March
 
LOUIS ARMSTRONG: ONE HUNDRED YEARS
A centennial bash thrown by the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band for the musician who invented hipness; the trumpeter Clark Terry is the guest performer in a repertory drawn from the Hot Five and Hot Seven records, as well as Armstrong's 1930's big band. March 16. Carnegie Hall.
