SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 3; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2476 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: HOLLYWOOD;
Hollywood's Uneasy, Maybe for the Better

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
SOMEONE contemplating the list of films for most recent movie seasons might have been forgiven for wondering whether Hollywood had a hole in the bottom of its ideas bucket. Strip away the sequels, pare away the remakes, ignore the big-screen versions of television chestnuts, discard the book adaptations and the (increasingly rare) play adaptations and often there was not much left.
Add to this the anxiety in Hollywood over recent waves of cost cutting at the studios -- some making fewer movies, others sharing the risk of big productions between a pair of studios or between a studio and an independent production entity, much of the digital filmmaking being done outside the Hollywood orbit in San Francisco and elsewhere, shooting more and more films in Canada or New Zealand or any place cheaper than Hollywood, asking whether that $3 million shot of a tanker ship exploding is really necessary to make the audience happy -- and there is a very real sense of unease here. People wonder whether Hollywood will still make offbeat and sophisticated films, or even survive as anything more than a financing source and distribution-and-marketing service for other peoples' risky visions. 
 No one really knows, of course. Hollywood, bent and twisted by all of these financial, technological and artistic pressures, is clearly in the process of becoming something else, but becoming what? It's a guessing game. But perhaps we are beginning to see, with this year's fall and holiday lineup, just what kinds of movies Hollywood studios and the major independents are going to be making in response to all of the corporatizing and cost-cutting and hand-wringing.
"The period we are coming out of, the one people are lamenting, is one of the weaker periods in the history of movies, a largely boring decade of movies," said one top studio executive. "At times you could feel during the Oscar period that there were no films to vote for."
To this newcomer to Los Angeles -- and a newcomer to the task of covering movies and the movie industry -- this sense of creative unease and financial anxiety seems to seep into every conversation. And yet more than 30 recent interviews with studio executives, producers, writers, directors and, yes, bean counters reveals a growing, if sometimes tentative, hope for Hollywood.
MANY of those interviewed remarked, sometimes with apparent wonder, how good much of this year's fall and holiday lineup looks. Of course, they're paid to say things like that, at least about their own films, and there is always a certain amount of breast-thumping about any approaching movie season, leading to inevitable speculation about how such a period of cost-cutting could have produced such a roster. When the bean counters come in and the budgets go down, shouldn't the movies suffer?
Though many of the films are still in the finishing stages, others have begun to make the rounds either in final form, in rough cuts or in small snippets screened for a select handful. "This fall looks much stronger to me than last fall," said Mark Gill, president of the Los Angeles division of Miramax Films, whose "Shakespeare in Love" won the Best Picture Oscar last year. "Just look at the range of films, how many more things there are that appear to be genuine Oscar contenders."
And although the season has its share of sequels ("Scream 3"), remakes ("The House on Haunted Hill"), long-running series ("The World Is Not Enough," the 19th and latest James Bond adventure) and more than a dozen book adaptations, the evidence also shows that despite fears that cost cutting would make studios timid and shave the sharp edges from quirky films, the reality is oddly different.
"I think this is a surprisingly unpandering-to-the-mainstream movie season coming up," is the way Amy Pascal, president of Columbia Pictures, put it.
Three years ago, Hollywood had just one film ("Jerry Maguire") among the five contenders for the Academy Award for best picture. This year, that will not be the case, executives vow.
"The studios are back," said Stacey Snider, co-chairman of Universal Pictures. "That's the story."
Granted, the beginning of almost every movie season -- especially the fall and holiday season, when so many movies are pitched toward older audiences and Oscar voters -- seems to promise more joy than it eventually delivers. ("Personally, I don't believe anything anybody says about a movie coming out in the fall unless they have actually seen it themselves," said one veteran Hollywood publicist. "There's too much hype and buzz going around at this time of year.") And the financial anxiety at the studios may be creating a bumper crop of wishful thinking. But even if half of these films turn out to be turkeys, it will still be a formidable roster.
When asked to assess those films they have seen -- in either finished form or rough cut or in sufficient clips for them to make what they consider a sound judgment -- or those films about which they have heard detailed descriptions in the etherlike buzz on which Hollywood floats these days like a hydrofoil, those interviewed came up among them with a list of more than a dozen films that they believe will be fighting it out for the top Oscar nominations early next year. (Note: when asked this question, almost everyone of course mentioned either their own film or the films from their studio; all such votes were discounted.)
The films mentioned most frequently (that is, by more than 10 of those interviewed) were "The Green Mile," the director Frank Darabont's adaptation of Stephen King's Death Row tale starring Tom Hanks; "Three Kings"; David O. Russell's story of three G.I.'s searching for buried loot in the waning days of the Gulf War; "The Talented Mr. Ripley," Anthony Minghella's adaptation of Patricia Highsmith's classic dark thriller; "The Insider," Michael Mann's retelling of the clash between a tobacco industry whistle-blower, a "60 Minutes" producer and the forces of big tobacco and big media; "The Hurricane," Norman Jewison's film starring Denzel Washington, and "American Beauty," the theater director Sam Mendes's inaugural Hollywood effort, about the emotional damage caused when a married man develops an infatuation with one of his teen-age daughter's young friends.
Not bad -- if it's true -- for an industry that sometimes sounds like it's on life support. The story of the movie business's financial woes, particularly in the last several years as top star salaries rose above $20 million and production and marketing costs also soared, is like an old, favorite set of worry beads that Hollywood people like to finger in the gathering gloom.
"The town has become much more cost-conscious," said Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group. "We have become aware over time that the economics of the movie business are tougher and tougher, and the only way to make that better is to make your movies cheaper."
But how can this possibly translate into better films? "I think it results in new voices and new ideas and new ways to tell stories in a way that's actually really exciting," Ms. Snider said.
The problem is that something happened over the last several years; the cost of making a movie has skyrocketed, both because of higher salaries for the top actors and directors and other "above the line" talent and for the physical, "below the line" costs of actually making the film. The old formulas (star-studded big-budget explosion pictures, for instance, built on macho images and paper-thin characterizations) don't work reliably enough to be worth the money they cost, and even a summer as successful as the one just passed, with more than a half-dozen movies surpassing $100 million at the box office, isn't enough for the studios to turn a sufficient profit to satisfy their corporate bosses.
"The business is broken," said Bill Mechanic, chairman of 20th Century Fox. "The business fell apart when the budgets of pictures went running sky high." The only answer, he and others said, is to cut costs, so that's what the studios, to varying degrees, have been trying to do. While a few stars will earn astronomical fees, secondary stars are earning less ("the $10 million sidekick," is how one insider put it), and the studios are always on the lookout for cheaper, younger talent. "The cost of a movie is too high to recoup its investment," Mr. Mechanic said. "A film that used to be $15 million is now pushed up to $50 million, but the return is the same as if you'd made it for $15 million. It means you're only going to lose money."
Some filmmakers and studio executives said they believed one reason the coming season looked to be strong was that in order to get top-name actors and directors to work for less than their normal fees, producers were pushed toward the kind of projects that such artists would find appealing rather than those projects that the studios' marketing departments might find appealing.
"The only thing that will attract people to do it for less money is something that's more interesting in terms of material," said Mr.Mechanic.
Another factor that is driving the studios toward finding new voices and richer films is the perception that the audience is revolting against the familiar and the formulaic.
"Sometimes, I think the people making movies are out of touch a bit," said Jeanine Basinger, chairman of film studies at Wesleyan University, whose research takes her into movie houses. "I think they don't realize how cranky a lot of people in the audience have become. People shout out at the screen, 'He's the killer,' and someone on the other side of the theater will shout back, 'I know that, shut up.' " People are bored and they're angry."
The studios do know that, Mr. Mechanic said, or should. "There's something happening out there," he said. "People have just rejected seeing the same thing time in and time out. It's a rejection of the mainstream, in a way, of the same old way of telling stories. I mean, they're booing trailers out there now."
The full impact of having fewer films in the pipeline won't be felt until around the middle of next year, executives say. Projects that might have been made in the past will hit a brick wall, unless their makers can come up with a way to do it cheaper. "I think we'll find that the holes in the sieve are getting smaller," said Dick Cook, president of the Walt Disney Motion Picture Group.
ALL of the filmmakers interviewed said they had felt the economic crunch at the studios in one fashion or another.
"When you make a film that's off the beaten path, there's an enormous amount of pressure to make it for a price that makes sense to the studio," said Sydney Pollack, whose romantic drama "Random Hearts" opens next month with Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas. "It costs so much money to market a film today, the advertising costs and the marketing costs are oftentimes more than the cost of the negative. That would have been heresy 20 years ago."
Oliver Stone, whose gritty football drama, "Any Given Sunday," will open on Christmas Day, has noticed the same thing.
"It's an eternal battle that goes back to the beginning of the movie business, but certainly it's getting tougher," Mr. Stone said. "I liken our jobs, that of the film's director and its marketing director, to co-directors these days. They both spend sometimes the same amount of money. The marketing director has enormous power here."
Filmmakers can make suggestions about the movie's trailer, its poster, its advertising campaign, but in most cases the final decision is not theirs. "Ultimately, you have no say," Mr. Stone said. "You can say, I hate it, I want to change it. You plead. You cajole. You try everything you can, but it's really out of your control."
For some of the directors, the change has been not so much in the drive to save money as in the growing sense that a corporate mind set is taking over the studios. All of the major Hollywood studios are now owned by larger conglomerates, for which the movie business is just one segment of a multi-faceted business empire, and the recent appointment of several top executives who were seen as more from the corporate side than the creative side has also increased some filmmakers' wariness.
Lasse Hallstrom, whose adaptation of John Irving's novel "Cider House Rules" is due for release on Dec. 10, said he had given up trying to understand. "I am not as well educated as I ought to be about all of the financial side of the movie business," he said. "It's still a mystery to me, what happens behind those closed doors. You're always trying to find someone who has the responsibility to make a decision, but it is sometimes impossible. All these mysterious reasons, and you never get to the truth of it."
Those who have been at it longest feel the corporate creep more strongly. "The big change for me as a filmmaker, making films since 1961, is that I used to be able to get an answer on stories I wanted to tell as a filmmaker very quickly," said Norman Jewison, whose film about the incarceration and eventual exoneration of the boxer Ruben Carter, "The Hurricane," is set for an Oscar-aimed limited release on Dec. 29. "Over the last 10 years it's become more and more of a corporate decision. You get the feeling that some of these people think that they are making a product. Good films have never been a product. They are individual statements of their makers, pieces of a very, very fragile vision. I have never felt there was any equation between money and art."
Some of the studio executives just shrug off these kind of complaints. "Movies have always been a business," one said. "We have all decided to go into a very expensive art form; we didn't go into finger-painting or poetry."
Others argue that the cost cutting is not so much imposed by corporate bosses as by the economic realities of an increasingly expensive and mercurial business. "The people who run these studios are highly qualified executives," Mr. Friedman said. "It's not a candy store."
The puzzle is this: There were fears that when studios responded to this -- and to increased pressure from higher-ups in the corporations that own all of the studios -- there would be a rush to the mainstream, seasons of little more than sequels, formulaic comedies, teen-age sex romps and remakes of every television show ever made. How then to explain this coming season?
"It certainly looks like it's going to be a good final quarter, maybe even a great one," said one producer and former studio boss. "And it's coming on the heels of a very lucrative summer, when there were successful movies all over the place, in almost every genre. But people still feel uneasy because, no matter what they tell you, they really don't know what's coming next."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 46; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1799 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: NEW HEROINES;
Mothers and Daughters, Tangled Together Anew

BYLINE: By MOLLY HASKELL; Molly Haskell's most recent book is "Holding My Own in No Man's Land: Men and Women, Films and Feminists." She is working on a memoir about her mother.

 BODY:
ALWAYS lurking in the wings, waiting for a lull in the conversation, jokes about mothers enjoyed a flurry of activity this summer. There was the New Yorker cartoon showing the corpse laid out in the funeral parlor, lifeless but not speechless, berating her son for not wearing a tie. And the joke making the rounds of the Hamptons might have come from a Woody Allen movie: What's the difference between a Jewish mother and a Rottweiler? The Rottweiler eventually lets go. Then real life supplied juicier fodder in the story of a Presidential toddler in Arkansas, torn between devouring mother and grandmother love -- and proved there's no ethnic monopoly on the stereotype of maternal excess. Even when there's a male parent who's a partner in dysfunction, the woman from Venus takes the hit.
In movies as in one-liners, she is a creature of extremes, loving too much or too little. She cradles her grown gangster-son in her lap (Margaret Wycherly and James Cagney in "White Heat"), floats blimplike through space, haunting her son ("New York Stories"), sacrifices her own happiness so that her daughter may rise in the world (Barbara Stanwyck in "Stella Dallas"), turns her son into a psychopath (Mrs. Bates in "Psycho"), competes with her daughter for a man (Joan Crawford in "Mildred Pierce," Anne Bancroft in "The Graduate"). There's no such thing as the "good enough mother," in the British psychoanalyst D. W. Winnicott's fine and forgiving phrase. 
 Would audiences accept such a figure of moderation? In the subversive comedy "Mother," Albert Brooks countered the image of a nasty, sex-starved older woman in "The Graduate" with a more complex image: Debbie Reynolds as a mother with an adult sex life, a creative urge of her own and no particular desire to have her son back in the nest. On the soundtrack, Mr. Brooks's theme song, "Mrs. Henderson," explicitly opposed the more derisive Simon and Garfunkel "Mrs. Robinson," and moviegoers didn't buy it.
From Woody Allen to Bill Clinton, mother-son relationships are part of folklore, but mother-daughter jokes are less frequent because the role of women is not clearly defined, even today (especially today). In following the prescribed path, boys fulfill their destiny and become men by breaking away. But for girls, who become women partly by identifying with their mothers, even the desire for independence will be felt on some level as an act of betrayal.
In "The Turning Point," which crystallized the conflict between career and home as it was beginning to be felt in the 1970's, Shirley MacLaine's character has given up dance to bring up her family, only to have her daughter choose the alternative: ballet under the guidance and surrogate motherhood of Ms. MacLaine's old friend and rival, played by Anne Bancroft. Although the role is, happily, a far cry from Mrs. Robinson, it nevertheless captures the perennial ambivalence toward the working woman: the aging Ms. Bancroft, once a successful diva, is lonely and unfulfilled as a woman.
Two fall films boldly dive into the murky waters of this most complex relationship with stories of moms on the run and the daughters who take care of them. In uncannily similar and very 90's role reversals, it's the single mothers -- middle-aged hellions, slatternly yet seductive -- who must grow up and the daughters who become women, not by identifying with the mothers but by becoming surrogate parents, in fact by displaying the solid, responsible virtues of the husbands the mothers should have had. "Anywhere but Here," with Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman, and "Tumbleweeds," with Janet McTeer and Kimberly Brown, are, in addition, female road movies, spins on "Thelma and Louise," in which women head westward into the sun, leaving men behind, at least temporarily, in a quest for a better life.
IN "Anywhere but Here"(opening Oct. 22), Ms. Sarandon's Adele August abandons Wisconsin, family and friends, virtually kidnapping her daughter, Ann, whom she intends to turn into a child star in -- where else? -- Hollywood. In "Tumbleweeds," a more improvisational independent film, Ms. McTeer's much-married good ol' Southern babe flees into the night from her abusive husband in a ritual that has evidently occurred many times before. Each story springs from the imagination and memories of a daughter who survived to tell the tale: the first is Alvin Sargent's adaptation of the Mona Simpson novel, directed by Wayne Wang; the second is an original autobiographical screenplay by Angela Shelton, working with the screenwriter and director Gavin O'Connor.
What's new is the picturing of women with at least the option of mobility but hemmed in economically by being alone, middle-aged and without marketable skills. These and movies like Allison Anders's "Gas Food Lodging" (1992) are the artistic children of divorce, testimonials from the survivors showing mothers starting over, back on the marriage block, feeling their sexual oats, while at the same time struggling to make ends meet and, fitfully and incongruously, giving their daughters moral guidance. Like most teen-agers, the daughters long for a normal life -- school, friends, stability -- while the mothers delude themselves that they are providing something better in the form of bohemianism and excitement. Who's to say, the movies imply, that someday the daughters won't be the better for it?
Raucous and outrageous maternal heroines, divorcees with big plans and near-empty pocketbooks, have a long and notorious lineage: witness such extreme mothers as Stella Dallas and Mildred Pierce. But there was nothing sororal about those ladies, awesome in their authority, majestic in their willingness to martyr themselves on the altar of their offspring's upward mobility. But the new mothers, vulnerable and without society's support, have surrendered the mantle of infallibility for the instant gratifications of paldom. Moreover, the idea of sacrifice that motivated Barbara Stanwyck's vulgarly ambitious climber and Joan Crawford's pie-baking entrepreneur "to do everything" for their daughters, to provide them with the things they never had, has become suspect in a post-analytic age. Every time Ms. Sarandon piously intones, "After all I've done for you . . . ," Ann and the audience are hip to the hidden agenda of emotional blackmail: a mother using her daughter to fulfill her own ambitions.
Yet in their timeless stories of maternal aspirations and adolescent angst, "Anywhere but Here" and "Tumbleweeds" echo themes and emotions from those earlier films, with their roots in the immigrant experience and the American dream of progress, with the notion of a daughter's having more taste, more of an aptitude for education, than the mother. In "Stella Dallas," "Mildred Pierce" and the immensely moving film "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," the child has more refinement, and therefore more opportunity, than the mother (even if Ann Blyth's Veda in "Mildred Pierce," with her deliciously raised eyebrow and purse-lipped snobbery, is a mockery of true refinement). Lauren Dallas, with her aristocratic genes, and Francie (Peggy Ann Garner), the budding writer in "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," are girls whose eyes open onto a wider world.
Directed by Elia Kazan from the autobiographical novel by Betty Smith, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" (1945) deals with the conflict within a working-poor Irish family over the daughter's desire to continue her education. Dorothy McGuire is the mother whose stern practicality is felt as harshness by her children, in contrast to the charms of the seductive alcoholic father. (James Dunn even won an Oscar for his role, thus confirming the popularity of male charm over female strength.) He encourages Francie, while her mother makes her quit school for reasons that become apparent only later. Mr. Kazan, who made his directorial debut with this film, later discounted both the book (as mushy) and the movie (for its soft-focus treatment of a Brooklyn tenement), but it is a beautifully acted film that earns its emotions, particularly in the denouement when Francie realizes how much she is her mother's child and understands why the mother has made the choices she has.
The same year, "National Velvet" introduced another precocious child, a dazzling 13-year-old Elizabeth Taylor, who became an instant role model to millions of horse-loving, jockey-wannabe little girls like me. It is one of the rare movies in which the mother (Ann Revere) totally nourishes the daughter's ambitions, even though she has had to give up her own career as a prize-winning swimmer. Yet in both films there is a lingering melancholy, a sweet sadness on the part of McGuire and Revere, not just at the prospect of losing their daughters, but also over their own lost dreams. "What might I have done if I'd been born later, started earlier, stuck with it?" are the words they can't even bring themselves to say.
The American investment in education, the mandate of rising expectations (each generation should surpass the previous one) and the new credo of feminist fulfillment run headlong into the unresolvable quandaries of mother-daughter love: how can a daughter separate from her mother without losing some core part of herself? How can a mother let her daughter go without yanking the soul out of her breast?
And yet let go she must. Such is the message hammered home in the old films and the new, although in the latter case their emotional temperatures are as different as black and white. The rollicking spirit of "Anywhere but Here" barely masks the chill of the hapless odyssey and a mother's monstrous theft of her daughter's childhood. Even Ms. Sarandon's bravura acting (she has never been so out-and-out funny) can't quite redeem the selfishness of the character, nor can Ms. Portman's finely tuned adolescent lift the daughter above her unhappy role as sullen teen-age raisonneur. That she is smarter and smoother and more adult than the girl in the novel only makes the gulf between her and her mother seem wider.
"Tumbleweeds" (opening Nov. 19), on the other hand, is all sloppy charm and conspiratorial warmth, picturing mother and daughter as soul mates, reveling in each other's company, roaring at shared jokes in a rapturous affinity, the daughter as often delighted as embarrassed by her mother's Stella Dallas shenanigans. This mother's version of letting her daughter go is to let her stay -- and grow roots and have her own friends.
Yet the final irony of both films is that while grades and jobs and boys will come and go, mothers are forever, deep in the heart and nerve endings. The daughters are indebted to them for the creative juices and the spirit of adventure -- not to mention the hilarious good times -- that these films celebrate.

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/TELEVISION AND RADIO;
Capturing New York's Promethean Fire

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM 

 BODY:
A WORD to the National Endowment for the Humanities, corporate underwriters like Chase, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and viewers like you: Ric Burns is running out of space.
Not that he's complaining. It's just that as his production company, Steeplechase Films, grows into a purveyor of ever-larger documentary sagas -- from an hour to 3 hours to 10 hours and more -- the need for Lebensraum increases. But public television budgets and the Upper West Side of Manhattan being what they are, Steeplechase now operates out of two small suites in two separate buildings a block apart, off 72d Street and Broadway. 
 "There's something to be said for this cordon sanitaire," Mr. Burns said, referring to the production team in one building, the editing team in another and the artistic negotiations that can create occasional friction. Especially now, in the frenzied final weeks of assembling Mr. Burns's most ambitious solo work to date, "New York," an admiring portrait of the city from Henry Hudson's arrival, in 1609, to the millennium.
More than five years in the making, "New York" is 12 hours in 6 equal parts, or as Mr. Burns puts it, the story of Prometheus retold from era to era. The first five parts will be broadcast in November (Sunday through Thursday, Nov. 14-18, 9 P.M.). A sixth episode, scheduled for the spring, will focus on the last 60 years of the century.
When Mr. Burns's co-writer, James Sanders, an architect and historian, and his co-producer, Lisa Ades, sat down at the start of the decade to map their plans, it quickly became clear that New York was indeed Promethean. It had also proved to be a city perpetually engaged in creative destruction -- the process of tearing down the old and rebuilding, in many cases, bigger and better.
It was the ultimate harbor, the ultimate trading post, the ultimate real estate deal and, most important, a crucible of democracy and capitalism like no other.
"It's the simple core of the story, stealing fire from the gods," Mr. Burns said. "This city in the New World, from the very beginning, felt that there was no enterprise too lofty, too difficult for human beings not to accomplish."
"In the 19th century, in a particularly intense way," he said, "the powers that were previously thought to be -- metaphorically anyway -- divine came within the grasp of human beings, transforming the physical, political, social and cultural shape of the city."
If this sounds like the kitchen sink approach, it is. It's also the quintessential Burns approach. Why compose a short story when you can film "Middlemarch"?
THE son of an anthropologist, Mr. Burns, 44, is a polymath with a narrative mission, at 24 frames per second. His conversation bristles with literary references and allusions, as befits a former doctoral student at Columbia University. In his dissertation, he said, he intended to trace the nature of revolutionary ideas in the 19th century and, at the same time, "bring all the qualities of modern literature into focus -- Carlyle, Flaubert, Dickens, Rimbaud -- in explaining the transformation of cultural, political and social authority."
Instead, he fell in step with his older brother, Ken, and helped produce the 11-hour 1990 PBS series "The Civil War." That was the end of the dissertation, but the start of even more research that led him to documentaries like "Coney Island" (the name Steeplechase Films is derived from Coney's famous amusement park) and "The Donner Party." Even now, he has begun work on a three-hour film about Eugene O'Neill, collaborating with O'Neill's biographers Barbara Gelb and her husband, Arthur, a former managing editor of The New York Times.
On his decision to switch to film, Mr. Burns seems to harbor few doubts: "I could have spent 50 years as an academic writing four books for an audience of 3,000 or a life spent telling stories for a larger audience."
Stepping through the office's dormlike clutter, Ms. Ades, whose next project is the history of the Miss America Pageant, remarked, "We're all hunter-gatherers."
Hiding out at the New-York Historical Society, Ms. Ades (pronounced AD-us) pored over uncounted thousands of prints and photographs. "What keeps me awake at night is thinking that I might have missed one."
For fans of Burns brothers documentaries, the format will be familiar: passionately written but with low-key narration. Interspersed with contemporary video of New York are close-ups and pans of etchings, paintings and historical maps as well as early photographic stills; original musical themes repeated in rhythms and keys both joyful and mournful; and the voices of actors and writers breathing life into the words of those who watched or commented on history as it was being made.
There are also "witnesses," contemporary experts whose comments amount to a Greek chorus on the theme. They include Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Martin Scorsese, E. L. Doctorow and Fran Lebowitz.
"Bob Stern compared the city to the greatest fireworks you ever saw," Mr. Burns said, referring to the architect Robert A. M. Stern. "Out of each cascade comes yet another, higher, higher and louder still. Narratively, this aspect of the city's history is a gift. At each stage along the way it seems to be saying, 'You ain't seen nothin' yet.' And you haven't."
Consider this bit of synthesis. "When New York was founded at the dawn of the modern age," says the narrator, David Ogden Stiers, "London and Paris were already 1,500 years old; Rome and Beijing, 2000; Jerusalem, 4,000. And yet somehow, in the centuries to come, the tiny colony on the edge of the world would rise to become the greatest city on earth -- the undisputed cultural and economic capital of the world -- and the supreme laboratory of modern life."
What follows is stunning, though not because New York turns out to be unique in all the ways he and others say it is. It's that the New York story, from raunchy Dutch trading post to luminous global icon, seems to be all of a piece these last 350 years. The more it changes -- and New York is forever changing -- the more it stays the same.
"New York City was founded by the Dutch," says Brendan Gill, the New Yorker writer and preservationist who died in December 1997. "The Dutch didn't give a damn about anything except making money."
New York -- crowded, dirty, noisy, disorganized and often violent -- was home to more people of more different ethnic and religious backgrounds than anywhere else. Yet its blend of frontier democracy and greed acted as a growth hormone of frightening power. It still does.
Expanding on Mr. Gill's observation, John Steele Gordon, a historian who writes the "Business in America" column in American Heritage magazine, said: "New York was founded for no other reason than to make a buck. The Puritans came to New England to worship God as they saw fit. The Catholics came to Maryland, the Quakers to Pennsylvania. The Dutch came to Manhattan to get beaver skins.
"They didn't get around to even building a church for 17 years," Mr. Gordon said. "And ever since, you know, however big the city has gotten, somewhere deep in its soul it is always New Amsterdam. Where modern capitalism was invented."
Everything right down to the Manhattan street grid, adopted in 1811, seems in retrospect to have been designed uncannily to propel the city into yet another era of growth, prosperity and power.
AND just 200 years after the city's founding, DeWitt Clinton proposed what Mr. Stiers, the narrator, describes as a "363-mile-long ditch that if completed would transform forever New York's relation to the entire American continent": the Erie Canal. When it was completed in 1825, "it made New York the only American city that connected Europe on one side with the heartland of the continent on the other," Mr. Stern, the architect, said.
"And that has been New York's strength ever since," he continued. "It still is the major port of entry and transfer point for people flying from Europe to the rest of the country. You see New York, and then you see America."
What you really see, Mr. Burns said, is something he recalled from Ezra Pound, writing about the city in 1913. He recited it from memory:
 "And is New York the most beautiful city in the world? It is not far from it. No urban nights are like the nights there. I have looked down across the city from high windows. It is then that the great buildings lose reality and take on magical powers. . . . Squares and squares of flame set and cut into the ether. Here is our poetry, for we have pulled down the stars to our will."

PUB-DATE: September 12, 1999

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2410 words

HEADLINE: A SEASON TO USHER IN 1,OOO MORE;
A Marathon of Midnights In Times Square

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER REARDON; Christopher Reardon, a former fellow of the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University, writes frequently for Arts & Leisure.

 BODY:
SOMETIME back in the 80's, Peter Kohlmann and his wife decided to celebrate New Year's Eve with a couple hundred thousand strangers. Late in the evening, they made their way to Times Square, melted into the crowd and began to wait. Mr. Kohlmann, who was an aide to Mayor Edward I. Koch at the time, remembers little else about the event, but then there was only so much to remember.
"At midnight the ball came down, everyone cheered and 10 minutes later they went home," he recalled one day last month. "That's about all there was to it." 
 It's safe to say nobody will find this year's festivities so rudimentary, and Mr. Kohlmann is a primary reason. As the executive producer of "Times Square 2000, the Global Celebration at the Crossroads of the World," he is betting the farm to turn a familiar sight into a once-in-a-lifetime spectacle. The 26-hour extravaganza, estimated to cost at least $7 million, is arguably the most daunting event ever planned in New York City, a double wager in theatrical production and crowd control.
The cast and crew number nearly 1,000, and there is no rehearsal. The total audience clogging midtown is expected to reach 1.5 million, prompting one of the largest police details in the city's history. (More than 1 billion television viewers are anticipated.) What's more, the timing has made it necessary to prepare contingency plans for a winter storm or a global computer meltdown.
"You can't go to a textbook and figure this out," said Mr. Kohlmann, who serves as vice president for marketing and special events at the Times Square Business Improvement District. "You have to rely on intuition and sensitivity to what the crowd is going to be feeling."
Geoff Puckett, the creative director for this year's gala, likens it to a pagan festival with high-tech trimmings. Starting at six in the morning, huge video screens mounted throughout the theater district will show distant crowds greeting the new year in each of the world's time zones. Dancers will perform on a central stage as music fills the air and confetti showers the streets. Meanwhile, a cavalcade of giant puppets designed by Michael Curry will try to evoke the splendor of the natural world and the epic span of civilization.
The climax comes at midnight, of course, but this year a new Waterford crystal ball, activated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a surprise guest, will descend the flagpole atop One Times Square. And unlike the first time Mr. Kohlmann rang in the new year there, the show will carry on until the Midway Islands follow the rest of the world into the 21st century.
David Parsons, who is choreographing the dance and puppetry segments, welcomed the unpredictability of it all. "After midnight, what's the feeling going to be?" he mused in a recent interview. "Are people going to hang out for six more hours or go home? It's terribly exciting to think about. What do a million people do on the last day of the millennium?"
"Times Square 2000" is not the biggest New Year's Eve celebration -- after all, four million revelers are expected to gather on the beaches in Rio de Janeiro -- but it is a telling one. Like Olympic ceremonies and Super Bowl halftime shows, it reflects a mass-media imperative to keep outdoing itself. At the same time it seeks to transcend its own tradition and, like Napoleon's coronation or the ticker-tape parade for the first men to walk on the moon, mark a singular historical moment.
"This is like a performance that's always been waiting to happen," said Mr. Curry, 41, who is best known for his work with Julie Taymor on "The Lion King." "There's an established audience, and the whole world knows about it. In terms of preproduction and promotion, it's a dream."
Some New Yorkers are less enthusiastic about the event. "I suspect this is just going to be a wink and a nod and a flash and it's gone," said the historian Mike Wallace, who won a Pulitzer Prize this year for "Gotham, a History of New York City to 1898," which he wrote with Edwin G. Burrows. "It's an ersatz thing, a number clicking over."
The enormous festivals that marked the completion of the Erie Canal in 1825 and the laying of the Atlantic Cable in 1858 sprang from a very different source, Mr. Wallace said. "In those cases there was a palpable sense of accomplishment, and you could see the city's tremendous economic engines revving up."
Mr. Burrows also anticipates a hollow ritual, but he marvels at its appeal. "It's amazing that people still do that in a media age," he said, "that there are still places where people like to gather."
The real puzzle is where to fit them all. This year, streets will be closed as far north as Columbus Circle and as far south as Madison Square Garden. Latecomers who don't have a direct view will be able to watch the events unfold on the outsize video screens.
Such a spectacle was unthinkable a decade or two ago, when rowdy throngs choked the streets. But the police have since mastered the technique of shepherding spectators into neat pens, four per block, and keeping the emergency lanes clear. While the number of arrests has plummeted -- only four people were charged last year for disorderly conduct -- the average turnout has doubled to half a million, 85 percent of them out-of-towners.
Still, there is something incongruous and inhibiting about the idea of making merry in the presence of thousands of police officers. As Mr. Wallace and Mr. Burrows point out in "Gotham," New Year's Eve has historically been a time of plebeian revelry, when spontaneous packs known as "calithumpian bands" ran through the streets beating on pans and hollering into the night.
Letting people vent social tensions has been the impulse for many officially sanctioned spectacles as well, from Dionysian festivals in ancient Greece to Carnival in Rio. In many cases, participants were encouraged to flout cultural norms through cross-dressing, ritual madness or frenzied dancing.
OF course, the observance of such customs was one factor that led area businesses and property owners, including The New York Times Company, to establish the Times Square Business Improvement District in 1992. With an annual budget of $8 million, the BID is a nonprofit organization that seeks to spruce up the neighborhood by deploying extra sanitation and security crews. It also produces annual events like Broadway on Broadway, a one-day musical showcase that takes place today at noon, and the New Year's Eve celebration.
Planning for the millennial gala began in 1994, when the BID invited suggestions for how to mark the occasion. The winning idea came from a Belgian student and four Americans -- a mother, a molecular biologist, a software programmer and a news producer -- who each proposed a marathon of midnights using live video links to other time zones.
Turning that rough concept into a viable production has not been easy, though. While offering a ready-made rhythmic structure, with hourly highs and intermediate lows, it also left some gaping holes to fill. The size of the audience and the location, a famously busy thoroughfare, didn't make things any simpler.
"This is, without a doubt, one of the most bizarre venues I've ever worked in," said Mr. Puckett, 41, whose resume lists numerous Superbowls, Olympics and Disney productions.
The job of solving these quandaries fell to Mr. Kohlmann, who can seem an unlikely impresario for such a splashy event. Tall and trim at age 46, he is more deliberate than Dionysian. But his cautious reserve plays well with the city officials, building owners and business managers whose consent he needs to go ahead with the show.
His track record also inspires their confidence. In 1986 he served as Mayor Koch's liaison with the planners of the three-day celebration of the Statue of Liberty's centennial, which drew two million people. A year later he led the city's bicentennial salute to the Constitution, then orchestrated Earth Day in 1990, which drew 750,000 to Central Park, and a ticker-tape parade for Gulf war veterans in 1991. In 1992 he joined the newly formed Times Square BID, which had just taken over the annual New Year's Eve celebration from the owners of One Times Square.
Mr. Kohlmann set out to restore some cultural cachet to the event, whose television ratings were in free fall. To make it "more telegenic and more exciting," he brought in Treb Heining, 45, a California balloon and confetti artist who had worked on the Gulf war parade. Then he added a light show, refurbished the ball (which had been in use since 1907) and started offering a free video feed to broadcasters around the world.
"Almost every year we've introduced a new element," he said. "But we don't want to stray too far from the tradition. I've always felt this thing is about the crowd, the ball and the space."
Even so, the millennium clearly called for something special. Casting about for reliable talent, he assembled a team that was comfortable straddling the line between art and entertainment. After ruling out costly celebrities and dangerous stunts, they held a series of brainstorming sessions to drum up scenarios for the event. Eventually, Mr. Puckett said, they agreed on a sequence of hourly themes, one for each time zone, and sets of images evoking indigenous "animals, architecture, metaphors, colors, textures and moods."
Mr. Curry saw the unconventional venue as an opportunity to change the dynamic between the performers and the audience. "My first thought was to have something like an overhead stage or an aerial procession," he said.
Last year he tried out a prototype of Father Time that was roughly the size of a city bus; nine puppeteers raised it aloft with long fiberglass poles and paraded through the 12-foot-wide emergency lane.
This year Mr. Curry is using a 40-foot scroll to map out the daylong procession, which includes such fanciful figures as a jellyfish, a sailing ship and a whirling dervish.
Like the theater director and designer Max Reinhardt, who was known for using outdoor venues and open stages, Mr. Curry strives for a kind of transparency. He often makes his puppets, which he likens to kites, out of mesh fabrics that allow light to pass through. What's more, he prefers that his puppeteers remain visible to the audience, as they do in "The Lion King."
"I love the authenticity and challenge of live movement in front of a crowd," he said. "And I love the idea that people can look a performer in the eye and have a pure human connection."
MR. PARSONS, 39, who was a leading dancer for Paul Taylor before starting his own modern dance troupe in 1987, is choreographing parts of the procession, including a duet by Father Time and Baby Time. He is also arranging periodic performances on a stage, which will be erected between 45th and 46th Streets, by his troupe, dozens of folkloric dancers and gymnasts in scuba gear and other whimsical attire.
Mr. Parsons' penchant for combining formal artistry with crowd-pleasing theatrics seems to suit the job. In his signature piece, the 1982 solo "Caught," he uses a strobe light to create a sequence of stop-action images of himself in midair. More than a photographic gimmick, it's an engaging dance where movement is implied and imagined, but never seen.
"Times Square 2000" goes to the other extreme, where the audience sees all. Ordinarily, performing for a big crowd calls for sweeping steps and exaggerated gestures that are visible from afar. But because of the simultaneous television broadcast, Mr. Parsons must also work in finer moves for the camera.
Or rather, 15 cameras. David Stern, the video producer, will edit two shows at once: one for broadcasters and the Internet, and one for the video screens around Times Square. The prospect of all that improvising thrills him. "That's what I do for a living," he said. "I watch a lot of monitors and I make split-second decisions. It's live editing, and it's a lot of fun."
Lately Mr. Puckett has been compiling a script with split-second timing references that will be synchronized with the atomic clock in Colorado. But he emphasized that it would be a story told through images, not words. There will be no host and no singers. The musical score, which will play over a wireless, 16-channel system, includes many vocal tracks, but few are in English.
One advantage of visual pageantry is its appeal to international viewers, but Mr. Puckett said it was primarily an esthetic choice harking back to customs that predate the information age.
"The concept of festival is a lost art in America," said Mr. Puckett, whose research took him to see ceremonial bonfires in Valencia, Spain, ice-sculpture contests in Alaska and other quirky rituals. "We wanted to get off the beaten path."
Some time zones will occasion more fanfare than others. One of the louder flourishes will come at 6 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, when midnight arrives in 41 countries in Africa and Europe. Mr. Puckett plans to set the mood and modulate the energy level of the crowd by shifting attention from the stage to the street or the video screens, or cutting from one song to another. "You want them to feel they've experienced it all," he said, "without sending them into a complete frenzy."
"There was a lot of concern last year that the music might make the audience more active," he said. "But in fact they were less inclined to do their own thing. The music brought people together around a shared experience."
Periodically, Mr. Heining and his rooftop crew will give the audience things to do, like catch confetti. Along with 3,000 to 4,000 pounds of brightly colored tissue paper, he said, they will scatter foam or paper maple leaves and butterflies over the crowd as mementos.
"We're trying to make New Year's Eve a little gentler," said Mr. Kohlmann. "It's an important marketing tool, a way to project the image of Times Square as a fun and exciting place."
A short while later, in his corner office overlooking Times Square, Mr. Kohlmann reached to his bookshelf and pulled down a biography of P. T. Barnum. Leafing through it, he confessed an affinity with the legendary showman. But while he shares Barnum's desire to regale the masses, he is not a man who speaks in superlatives. Rather than promising the greatest show on earth, he opts for the soft sell of elliptical understatement. "We're not claiming to be anything more than a Times Square New Year's Eve."

HEADLINE: A Team That Makes Bright Ideas Brighter

BYLINE: By DOMINIC MARIANI 

 BODY:
JUST about everyone can come up with an idea for a new product. The trick is how to make it and how to sell it.
If you live in Connecticut, there's a group you can talk to: the ProduCTeam. 
 ProduCTeam is a collaborative effort that develops and markets products. The team brings together inventors, manufacturers and business professionals.
The team is a Connecticut-based network of manufacturers, marketers and distributors that was started to study the manufacturing sector of the economy with a state grant seven years ago, but is now almost totally independent. The group is funded by member dues and royalty arrangements from successful products.
ProduCTeam is part of the Institute for Industrial and Engineering Technology in New Britain, an outreach educational function affiliated with Central Connecticut State University's School of Technology. It is dedicated to building and expanding the state's 6,000 small- to medium-sized (under 500 employees) manufacturing companies.
"We like to think of ourselves as a one-stop shopping center for product development," said Alan Kendrix, ProduCTeam's director. "We start with someone's concept and if we like it, we develop it straight on through to taking it to the consumer."
One product the group brought to market was a cocktail waitress's idea for a new kind of insole for high-heeled shoes, called High Heals. Another was the brainchild of a Waterbury police officer, an exterior light, called Life Light, that blinked from any house that 911 was called from.
After witnessing a ladder accident, Bill Moselsky came up with the idea for Shur-Foot, a four-footed, nonskid ladder attachment to prevent slipping.
Another product is the Rapor Fast-Trac Door that prevents unauthorized people from entering a building and stops employees from exiting with confidential equipment or products. The door is used at The Connecticut State Lottery headquarters and in several I.B.M. locations.
There are 100 units in production at Scan-Optics Inc. in Manchester.
The typical ProduCTeam process begins with someone contacting Mr. Kendrix with an idea, often communicated over the network's Website at www.producteam.com.
"I prefer to work with someone who already has a patent or a patent pending," Mr. Kendrix said. "If neither exists yet, we and our manufacturers sign a non-disclosure agreement to protect the intellectual property of the inventor."
Then he and the inventor present the new product idea at one of the thrice-monthly, early morning meetings with associate members (usually 10-12 people). Generally, three new products will be reviewed at each meeting.
Associate members include patent attorneys, engineers and designers, marketing specialists and master product brokers. They offer design, material, packaging and manufacturing suggestions, but also exchange information with one another that improve their own businesses.
If there is any interest shown, an evaluation form is passed out and members exchange ideas on what they call "the road to revenue." The inventor then comes back for another meeting with those interested associates and this time Mr. Kendrix will invite one or more of the 20 manufacturer members of the network.
Once a manufacturer is determined they may be given production space in one of the 14 subsidized "incubation centers," or work/office spaces in the Manufacturing Applications Center in the institute's building on Main Street. Office support, skilled professionals and student engineers are provided to work on developing a prototype of the product.
The Rapor Door group is completing two years of product development in one of the incubation centers. Its operation made use of nearly 3,000-square-feet of university-owned space at $8 a foot. It now has patents for its product in Japan, Israel, Canada, Mexico and the European Economic Community.
"There's no way we could've managed it otherwise," said Joseph Black, the chief executive of Rapor. "Not only was the space essential, but all the other personnel resources as well. And we are now a successful Connecticut company with no intention of ever leaving the state."
Once a prototype has been completed, various marketing and selling functions are farmed out through the network until someone places an order for the product.
"What ProduCTeam and the rest of us here at I.I.E.T. do is essentially to try to bring in manufacturing work to the state of Connecticut," said the institute's executive director, Dr. Edward Rybczyk. "If you bring in the work, businesses will create the jobs."
Mr. Kendrix is a big believer is what he likes to call "social capital."
"We've found that relationships are the best way to drive business," he said. "Someone who knows someone in the right place can help move things along."
According to Mr. Kendrix, if an inventor made a cold call to a major retailer to get that buyer to see his product, the call probably wouldn't get returned. But if one of his ProduCTeam associate members made the call, there would be a much better chance.
Mike Casale of Liazon Marketing in Newtown in an associate member of ProduCTeam.
"What I like best about being part of the group is its multilayered nature," he said. "There are some members with experience in consumer products, others with industrial connections and some who have expertise in mass merchandising. And they all share their ideas and contacts freely."
And it's because of this close-knit network, according to Mr. Casale, that they can surround a product with as many as 10 to 100 seasoned, well-versed professionals in a matter of a few telephone calls. If the network likes the product, they begin to try and sell it. But even if they don't, the very least an inventor will get are experienced opinions as to what's wrong and how the idea can be modified.
According to Jeff Blodgett, vice president of research for the private, nonprofit Connecticut Economic Research Center in Rocky Hill, small and middle-size manufacturing in the state has remained relatively constant since 1977.
However, since 1984 the state has lost one out of three manufacturing jobs, but manufacturing output has increased by about a third due to technological advances and increased productivity. Yet only one out of six residents work in manufacturing compared to one out of two 50 years ago. One-third of all Connecticut manufacturing is exported abroad.
"Areas such as apparel and textiles, primary metals and munitions are down," Mr. Blodgett said. "But the manufacturing of medical instruments and pharmaceuticals have increased. The manufacturing sector as a whole is still vital to the state's economic health."

HEADLINE: ON THE WATER WITH: THE HOUSEBOATERS;
Afloat but Not Adrift, Residents Call House Barges Home

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
SUE SANCHEZ and her 15-year-old son, Justin Spratt, are at home on the water. Standing on the floating deck that serves as their backyard, Ms. Sanchez looks out over Seaman's Creek and a breathtaking view of Fire Island, Jones Beach and the Atlantic beyond.
"You drive down Merrick Road, where there is store after store and you know you're on Long Island," she said, pulling aside the hair blown across her face by a steady ocean breeze. "That's all different. This is where we live." 
 As the summer winds down and boat owners prepare their craft for dry dock, Ms. Sanchez prepares for another season on the water. Living in one of the handful of floating homes moored along a stretch of shoreline in Seaford, she is one of the few dozen hardy souls who reside on area waters year round.
Bilevels, A-frames and cottages built on hulls of fiberglass and styrofoam provide affordable waterfront -- usually a Long Island oxymoron -- by the boatyards of the North and South shores. Unlike the flotilla of pleasure craft with which they share the marina, these house barges have no engines and are not powered to move themselves. And though local regulations and the hardships of living on the water have caused their numbers to dwindle, the houseboaters who remain say they have no desire to leave.
"You're always on vacation," said Ms. Sanchez, waving to a fisherman known as Captain Seaweed on his daily trip through the channel. Justin, a sophomore at Seaford High School, is certified for scuba diving and is now an accomplished waterskier and wakeboarder. Living in their floating cedar-sided contemporary for 10 years, the family has made a lot of friends, like the barnyard finches that nest under their deck, along with the swans, cranes and herons who call this shore home.
"Some of them have attitudes," said Ms. Sanchez of the waterfowl who also have names, bestowed by their human neighbors. "But you have to be kind of different to live here."
Ms. Sanchez has always been a fiercely independent spirit who fits in well with her houseboat neighbors. Known around the marina as Biker Sue, she has toured the country on a black, soft-tail Harley Davidson, and could often be seen riding it straight out of her boat's front door and onto the marina's gravel parking lot. Divorced for 13 years, she recently worked for an advertising firm in Manhattan but is now unemployed.
"The people who live here are more relaxed and self-sufficient," said Ms. Sanchez. "Timmy's an artist and plays guitar, Al's a dentist, Delores is a teacher, Steve's a welder. It's a nice bunch of people. We're always looking out for one another."
They all share a love for the water. Ms. Sanchez, who grew up in a conventional waterfront home in Massapequa, could not afford one now, so this two-bedroom, two-bath houseboat was the next best thing. Complete with a living room, eat-in kitchen, a laundry room that doubles as living space for her two Great Danes and a surfboard suspended from the ceiling, it has most of the comforts of a regular home, only on a smaller scale. "I've had to prioritize what we need," she said. "I don't have space for a closet full of towels."
Since they have to fit in a marina berth, most houseboats are not more than 45 feet long by 22 feet wide. But they can have as many as four levels. Like homes on terra firma, some houseboats are more elaborate than others, with accoutrements like central air-conditioning, oil heat and fireplaces. A few on this stretch of shore have fallen into disrepair, and one or two have been abandoned by their owners, but most are well kept.
Their prices vary from around $20,000 for a fixer-upper to nearly $100,000 for a deluxe model, according to real estate brokers. Rent to the host marina can range from $400 to $800 a month. Water is supplied by the marina; electricity and other utilities are metered separately.
"To me it's much more economical," said Joe Donahue, who rents a floating home at the Hidden Harbor Marina in Seaford, where about 15 houseboats are lined up like an aquatic trailer park. "I have a two-bedroom condo with a million-dollar view, and I'm paying less than a regular two-bedroom apartment."
Mr. Donahue, a systems engineer for Netscape, owns two homes on dry land in Valley Stream and Queens Village, and shares his water residence with Tom D'Elia, who came to visit one weekend and decided to stay.
"I lived in Manhattan but I traveled so much I couldn't justify paying the rent," said Mr. D'Elia, a sales representative for a transportation company who grew up with Mr. Donahue in Wantagh. "This was about one quarter of the rent in New York."
Complete with hardwood floors, a wet bar and hot tub, which makes the craft list four inches to port when filled up, their houseboat is very much a floating bachelor pad. Their social season begins just before the first frost, after most of the other boats have left. "During the summer, we're out on our boats all weekend," said Mr. Donahue, who owns a 28-foot Carver, docked just a few steps from his front door. "But around November, that's when the parties start."
While the marinas bustle with activity during the summer, the winter brings a peace that some houseboat residents look forward to. "Winters are rougher, but they're nicer," said Ms. Sanchez. "It's calm. You don't have all the boat traffic."
Mr. D'Elia said: "It's eerily quiet here in the winter. All of the boats are taken out of the water and shrink-wrapped in white plastic. Looking out on that is strange."
With winter comes the cold weather, the occasional frozen water lines and a few other problems. "We had one winter where the channel froze," said Ms. Sanchez. "I had to wake up at low tide and knock the ice off the poles so the house wouldn't sink." Parking areas are plowed by the marina, but residents must remove the snow that falls on the houseboats, which is often a difficult task. "If it snows too heavy, you have to shovel off the roof or it leans to the side really bad," said Mr. Donahue.
Houseboat living requires diligent upkeep and a close watch on the weather, as the homes rise and fall with the tide. "It's the wind more than the waves," said Justin Spratt. "But it just rocks you to sleep. It's the ultimate waterbed."
Longterm residents of floating homes complain about the salt that pervades the sea air and eventually corrodes televisions, stereos and other appliances.
"It's the worst of both worlds," said Gary Zaremba, a houseboater at the Capri Marina in Port Washington. "You have boat maintenance and house maintenance. There's always something to fix."
Houseboat veterans readily admit that life on the water is not for everyone. "You have to be self-reliant," Mr. Donahue said while repairing the garden hose that supplies his home with water. "A couple of girls moved into the end houseboat recently, and they didn't last a month."
In the early 1980's there were as many as 100 houseboats in the few miles of shoreline between Freeport and Seaford. But in 1984, the Town of Hempstead passed a houseboat code that required a sewage hookup to the mainland and said that houseboat owners must also own the upland property adjacent to its mooring, which made almost all of the floating homes in the area illegal.
"They were impacting the water quality," said Robert Wenegenofsky, an environmental analyst for the Hempstead Department of Conservation and Waterways. "We had to close a lot of the shellfish waters because of bacteria from the waste."
Enforcement of the regulations and attrition has thinned the area's houseboat fleet by nearly 75 percent, leaving about two dozen floating homes that town officials now ignore, save for an occasional summons.
"It's manageable and the water quality has improved," said Mr. Wenegenofsky. "Ideally, we'd like to see them all gone."
Many other local officials agree. In the Town of Huntington, no one can live on a boat moored in town waters for more than 14 consecutive days, according to a law also enacted in 1984. But while several municipalities have outlawed them completely, a few have made some exceptions.
The Village of Manorhaven in Port Washington will not allow any new houseboats in its waters, but the few that were already there have been allowed to stay. "You can be inundated with houseboats," said Jim Tomlinson, the Mayor of Manorhaven. "They enjoy all of the benefits of having property but there are no taxes they pay."
Houseboat owners pay no property tax on their homes, which has long been a thorn in the side of local officials. But the owners argue that the marinas where they rent space do pay property taxes, to which they contribute with their monthly rent. "I pay our fair share of school taxes," said Tony Luccaro, owner of the Thom's Point Marina on Manhasset Bay, where a dozen floating homes are docked.
Michael Mallon has lived on his 40-foot-by-15-foot houseboat in Thom's Point for nine years. He pointed proudly to a more elaborate floating home he had helped build just a few steps down the gangway, complete with shutters on the windows and a raised-panel front door. It was the last new houseboat to be added in the marina.
"The problem is where to put them," said Mr. Mallon, a tugboat captain and popular figure around the Port Washington waterfront. "A lot of towns just don't want them anymore."
Lately, fewer marinas are welcoming them, too. "We're in the marina business, not the floating homes business," said Mike Gagliano, general manager of Ocean Marine in Freeport, which does not rent space to houseboats. "A houseboat takes up the space of three boats. Half of them are a bunch of eyesores. That's not the image we're looking for."
There were more than 20 houseboats at the Treasure Island Marina in Seaford about 10 years ago, but its owner, Mike Leavy, said that he terminated their leases. "There's no money in it," he said, adding that the marina, the second-largest on the Island, rented slips for around $60 a foot, but that houseboats were charged much less. "You get rent, but you have to give services all year round."
Nonetheless, Anna DiPleco, a real estate agent for Accents Better Homes and Gardens in Port Washington, said that houseboats remained popular. "They don't come on the market very often, but when they do they don't last very long," she said. She is selling a fully furnished houseboat moored at Thom's Point for $89,000. Formerly a duck blind, the floating home has been renovated and now has hardwood floors, a wood-burning stove and an upright piano.
"I think it's a great way to live," said Ms. DiPleco, who said she was interested in a houseboat for herself.
Despite the reservations of other marina owners, Mr. Luccaro is pleased to host the floating homes. "They're not a problem if they're set up correctly," he said, adding that he charges about $500 a month for houseboat mooring. "It gives me a steady income. When I was 40 percent empty, that was important." Unlike the Seaford marinas, where most of the houseboats discharge sewage directly into the water, Thom's Point operates a portable pump station that sends waste from the floating homes into the local sewage system. Water supplied to the houseboats runs through two circulators to keep it from freezing. The marina is even wired for cable TV.
"Tony's the greatest landlord in the world," said Patti Daly, who has lived in her houseboat with her husband, Bob, for 10 years. "It's a nice community. Everybody's watching out for each other."
The Dalys' two-bedroom, two-bath home has central air-conditioning, a fireplace and a view of Manhasset Bay. Mr. Daly, who grew up in a bungalow in Rockaway, has always lived by the shore. "The water was always part of my life," he said.
Retired after 40 years with the phone company, Mr. Daly and his wife, who still works at Bell Atlantic, spend some of the winter on St. John in the Caribbean. But Mr. Daly does not know if he could permanently drop anchor anywhere else. "We're just so comfortable here," he said. "It's a great life."

HEADLINE: Welcome to Steakhouse Row

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY 

 BODY:
NIGHT after night, the parking lots are jammed with expensive cars as patrons crowd into four restaurants along the two-mile strip of Northern Boulevard between Great Neck and Roslyn. In the spring of 2000, another one will open on the strip, and a sixth is 10 miles down the road in East Norwich.
These are not places where you will learn the names of obscure French mushrooms and the presentation will be so artful you won't want to mess it up. These are steakhouses, where the menu needs no translation and the food laps over the plate. In spite of more than two decades of warnings about the dangers of red meat, there are more steakhouses feeding more steaks to more Long Islanders than ever before. 
 Leading the way are the establishments on Northern Boulevard, a k a Steak Row -- Peter Luger, the North Shore Steak House, Bryant and Cooper, Burton & Doyle and Rothmann's, with Morton's scheduled to join the lineup next year. While each of these restaurants claims to be different, they all share stratospheric prices, a clubby atmosphere, dark wood and subdued lighting, jam-packed bars miasmic from cigar and cigarette smoke, and addresses near the asset-rich ZIP codes from which they draw their customers. Though steak rules, they all serve lobsters, fish and a variety of other meat dishes like lamb chops and veal. And they all profess not to care about the competition down the road.
To be sure, steakhouses never vanished from the Long Island restaurant scene. The granddaddy of them all, Peter Luger, has been going strong in Great Neck for 39 years. But five steakhouses in a two-mile stretch of Northern Boulevard? What gives?
"People are going back to eating steak because they're reacting to what happened 10 to 15 years ago when, all of a sudden, every doctor in America was telling their patients to lay off red meat, that red meat and cholesterol were taboo," said Dr. John C. Peters, an internist and cardiologist at St. Francis and North Shore-Long Island Jewish hospitals. "We had an extreme opinion. You couldn't even go to a cocktail party where everyone wasn't discussing their cholesterol levels."
"Now we know that there's no reason not to have red meat once or twice a week," he said. "Moderation is really the answer to everything." Consuming meat this way doesn't change cholesterol significantlyy, he said, but warned that exercise was important and that "taking cholesterol-lowering drugs doesn't mean that you can have steak and Haagen-Dazs every night."
Jon Marin, a 61-year-old businessman from East Rockaway and a frequent patron of Bryant and Cooper in Roslyn, said that he had high cholesterol, took his cholesterol-lowering pill every day and gave up smoking 11 years ago.
"I eat lots of chicken, but as long as I take the pill, I'm entitled to eat steak once or twice a week," he said, echoing the sentiment heard among a wide swath of steakhouse customers who grew up in the 1950's, 60's and 70's and are now rolling in cash and imbued with a feeling of entitlement: I work hard, I deserve this!
Steak is a symbol of doing well, and with so many people doing well in the Island's red-hot economy, it makes sense that more people are eating it. It's also reminiscent of the meat-and-potatoes meals many customers remember Mom making, and thus is a comfortable way to splurge.
"When people are paying top dollar, they don't want to experiment," said one maitre d'hotel who asked not to be identified. "They want old, reliable standbys."
At Peter Luger, which the Zagat restaurant guide called "carnivore heaven," the manager, Robert Szkolnicki, said none of his customers worried about consuming meat, including doctors. "In fact, they're the first ones here," he said.
Gillis Poll, a co-owner of Bryant and Cooper, said that his Roslyn steak house drews a large clientele from St. Francis and North Shore-L.I.J. "who come in to unwind, meet on occasion with pharmaceutical salesmen and eat steak."
"A lot of the doctors have told me that it's not the cholesterol that will kill you," he added. "Maybe it's the stress."
"The cholesterol scare is an old wives' tale," said Seth Bromberg, general manager of Burton & Doyle, which opened in Roslyn on July 26 as the newest addition to Steak Row.
Mr. Bromberg would certainly get an argument from Dr. Frederic Vagnini, a former heart surgeon at North Shore University Hospital and owner of Cardiovascular Wellness Centers in Westbury and Manhattan.
"The studies haven't changed," he said. "People need constant education to remind them that the higher intake of saturated fat associated with steaks puts them at a higher risk for heart attacks, strokes and prostate cancer."
Dr. Vagnini said that he recently saw seven patients who suffered heart attacks or severe chest pain after eating a high-fat meal.
"They should have a tunnel from these restaurants to the cardiac catheterization labs of St. Francis and North Shore," said Dr. Vagnini, who recently co-wrote "The Carbohydrate Addict's Healthy Heart Plan." "I wouldn't be surprised if the cardiologists had an interest in the restaurants."
John Fives, co-owner of the North Shore Steak House, which has been grilling in Great Neck since 1980, dismisses what he has read about the dangers of red meat and high cholesterol. "So many of our customers are on the Atkins diet, which encourages lots of protein and fat, that this is the perfect place," he said.
Dr. Robert Atkins, who has set out his maverick diet and health ideas in six books that made The New York Times bestseller list, did not mince words. "The cholesterol issue was a fraud from the beginning," he said. "The epidemic of obesity in the last 20 years is totally a result of dietary changes recommended by our government and the American Heart Association."
"A steak-and-salad diet lowers cholesterol, period," he added. "The driving force behind heart disease is refined carbohydrates. The culprit is not meat, but flour and sugar."
At the North Shore Steak House last week, French-born Reine Stempa, 55, a dental assistant from Great Neck, dug into a porterhouse for two that she ordered for herself. "Meat is good for people," she said. "I never saw a vegetarian who looked good. They have no glow. In Europe, people enjoy every meal."
To explain the increasing consumption of red meat, Allen J. Bernstein, chief executive officer of Morton's, cited the writing of Lionel Tiger, a Rutgers anthropology professor who maintains that today's taste for red meat has an evolutionary basis dating back to the caveman.
"It may well be genetic," he said. "That craving appears to be as strong as ever."
At least he hopes so. Morton's, a well-known Chicago steak house, is due to open next door to Burton & Doyle next spring. Mr. Bernstein, who bought the chain a decade ago, moved its corporate headquarters to New Hyde Park and has expanded from 8 restaurants to 45, said he chose Great Neck after an analysis that considered population density, income, and the size of the area's likely customer base.
"I always felt that the first Long Island Morton's belonged on the affluent North Shore," he said, noting that an average dinner check was $65 per person and that his typical customer was a corporate executive or business owner between 35 and 55 years of age who earns $100,000 or more a year.
"The fact that there may be a variety of steak houses in an area is not a deterrent," Mr. Bernstein said. "We believe our food, service, decor, and price point set us apart from all the others."
Similar sentiments were also expressed at the other restaurants. Mr. Poll described his customers at Bryant and Cooper as loyal. "I don't mind the competition," he said. "It has actually improved my business. My customers try different places, but then they come home."
At Peter Luger, Mr. Szkolnicki said, "Maybe my customers will try another restaurant, but the new ones haven't hurt us."
Joe Walsh, the manager at Rothmann's in East Norwich, dug deepest for customer loyalty, saying that although it opened in December 1998, the steakhouse attracts "older money who remember the original Rothmann's and come back." The original opened in 1907 and was patronized by Theodore Roosevelt, who rode on horseback to eat there, and in later years by Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton and Bob Hope.
For some customers, loyalty is a thing of the past. George Liebner, a 77-year-old accountant from Lake Success, brought clients to Peter Luger and the North Shore Steak House almost every day for nearly 25 years (and to Peter Luger in Brooklyn for the previous 20 years). But he had a heart attack three years ago and forswore meat entirely.
"I can't eat meat," he said, "because the Federal Aviation Administration won't renew my pilot's license if my cholesterol is high. I can't take the chance."
