HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Taking and Teaching The Humbling Course Of Passive Resistance

BYLINE: By MARY ANN CASTRONOVO FUSCO 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
LIKE many teachers, Anna Brown spent part of her summer vacation traveling abroad. But what set Dr. Brown apart was the fact that the political science professor at St. Peter's College visited a country where she was -- in the government's view, at least -- unwelcome. She has been banned from Mexico, labeled a fugitive and a terrorist.
Last January, during a visit to the strife-torn Mexican state of Chiapas, Dr. Brown had her visa seized by Mexican officials who accused her and her fellow travelers with Global Exchange, a San Francisco human rights organization, of being "revolutionary tourists" living with the Zapatista rebels who have been pressing the Mexican government for agrarian and other economic and social changes. 
 On Jan. 4, she was ordered to go to San Cristobal de las Casas to be interrogated by immigration. Instead, she returned home. Published reports of her banishment conflict. Some say it's for life; others, two years. Unsure of her status, Dr. Brown has asked Representative Robert Menendez, a St. Peter's alumnus, to help clarify the situation.
"Who do you call?" she said, sitting in her office in the Dorothy Day House at St. Peter's, where the the six principles of nonviolence hang on the wall of the Martin Luther King Center. "I'm assuming that I am banned, but to be quite honest, I didn't get an official letter from them. But then again, only a gringo would think that. I could see myself sitting in a prison saying, 'Uh, but I didn't get a letter.' " And she laughs at the absurdity of the scenario.
Yet, she did return -- "quietly," she said -- this summer, but not to Chiapas. Although the 35-year-old professor can joke about her ambiguous status, the conflict in Mexico is no laughing matter to her.
"One of the reasons the Mexican government doesn't want people down there is because they can see what's going on," she said. "The more you can see, the more you make it visible, the harder it is in the public eye to get away with certain things."
She describes the situation in Chiapas as "a low-intensity war" being fought by Mexico against its own people. Internal refugees whose homes have been burned and crops stolen to harass them into submission live in makeshift encampments, often without electricity, running water or food.
Life has never been easy in Chiapas, which sits on the Pacific Ocean at the Guatemalan border. Mountainous and lush with rainforests, the land is "stunningly beautiful," said Dr. Brown, and is rich in coffee, cacao, timber, and oil, which makes it desirable to developers.
The current crisis stems from a Jan. 1, 1994, uprising of locals led by Zapatista rebels after a 1993 bill introduced under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari sought to privatize the country's ejidos, or collective farms. Under the current Mexican president, Ernesto Zedillo, negotiations have been an on-again, off-again affair. But human rights organizations charge that Mexico has been using foreign aid earmarked to fight narcotics traffic to send soldiers into Chiapas to keep the natives from rebelling.
"One-third of Mexico's armed forces are in Chiapas now,' said Dr. Brown, who is on the board of the Strategical Pastoral Action Network, a religious human rights group in Rushville, N.Y.
In December 1997, 45 locals, mostly women and children and members of the Abejas, a nonviolent group allied with the Zapatistas, were murdered by pro-government supporters in Acteal.
"Now clearly that is wrong," said Dr. Brown. "I knew that I wasn't about to pick up a gun and go running down there, but I could go down and bear witness to what people were enduring. You don't go down and tell people how to live their life. 'Oh, you poor people, if you only lived like the Americans lived, or if you only did X, Y, and Z.' "
During the trip Dr. Brown took to Mexico during her winter break last December and January, which ultimately led to her banishment, she attended a five-hour commemorative service, including a re-enactment of the murders and a Mass, for those slaughtered in Acteal. During the ceremony, a military helicopter hovered menacingly.
Not all of the causes she champions arouse as much sympathy as that of barefoot peasants being massacred by armed forces. A member of Kairos-Plowshares, New York City, a religious activist group cofounded by Daniel Berrigan, Dr. Brown said she had been involved in 40 acts of civil disobedience, including an effort to shut down the Liberty Bell on July 3 in support of Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row for killing a Philadelphia police officer.
Knowing her political leanings, one could easily conjure an image of Anna Brown as a militantly strident, tie-dyed remnant of the 60's. Indeed, her office is papered with posters proclaiming an array of pacifist and social justice causes. But in a recent interview, she appeared as a nonthreatening icon of neutrality, with a physique closer to that of a model than a guerilla.
She spoke with obvious affection about her parents, siblings, and nieces, and jokingly bemoaned her single status. She praised the work of her colleagues, particularly the Rev. Robert Kennedy, chairman of the college's theology department and a zen master who leads her and and a group of others in meditation each morning.
Her blue eyes sparkled with intelligence as she spoke in a gentle voice of the deprivation and humiliation endured by the poor. Resolute in her faith and convictions, she also made it clear that she knows her way is not for everyone. "I never demand that they think the way I do," she said of her students. "I want them to think about how and why they think the way they do."
To Eugene J. Cornacchia, chairman of the political science department at St. Peter's, "she's absolutely one of the most popular professors here.
"I think it's because she's so sincere in her commitment to social justice, but also to them," Dr. Cornacchia said. "I've seen her work long hours with individual students. She seems to be boundless with her energy. Through her example, she's showing them that you defend what you believe in."
Although he worries for her safety and occasionally teases her by saying, "I hope you'll be here Monday, and not in jail," he allowed that "not everyone would probably agree that it's appropriate for a faculty member to be so active so publicly."
But not everyone teaches at an institution run by Jesuit priests, who historically have been noted educators, intellectuals, missionaries, and most recently, proponents of liberation theology.
"This is a community that seems to be extraordinarily tolerant of faculties pushing students and ideas to the edge," said Dr. Cornacchia. "We have a responsibility, particularly in a Jesuit Catholic institution, to educate our students and enlighten them to the social, political, and economic impacts of what businesses do."
Or, as Dr. Brown says with a laugh, "I always blame the Jesuits for my downfall."
Born in Allentown, Pa., the eldest of four children, she was attracted to the study of political science by an interest in service and leadership instilled in her by her parents, both schoolteachers. "My parents, in many ways, lived the example of what some of the gospel stories are all about. They really led the way."
In 1986, she graduated magna cum laude with a bachelor's degree in political science from Allentown College of St. Francis de Sales in Center Valley. But an internship on Capitol Hill during her junior year soured her on the practice, but not on the study, of politics. "When I saw what it was really like, I wanted to get out as soon as possible," she recalled. "There was a lot of showmanship. It was sad which letters got read and didn't get read from constituents."
She then earned advanced degrees at Fordham University, where she also worked full-time as assistant director of the government relations and urban affairs office. Stimulated by the diversity of people and ideas she encountered, Anna the altruist became Anna the activist.
"Intellectually I was really challenged," she said. "At Fordham, a political consciousness began to be developed, a consciousness that was a bit more radical and now engaged in resistance and civil disobedience."
While at Fordham she participated in her first act of civil disobience, blocking the entrance to the Salvadoran consulate to protest the murder of Jesuit missionaries in El Salvador, with the Rev. Dean Brackley, who is now the rector of the University of Central America in El Salvador. She also served on the board of the POTS (Part Of The Solution) soup kitchen and homeless shelter near the campus, and distributed meals to the homeless living in subway stations.
In this vein, Dr. Brown now gives community service classes through St. Peter's Community Service Office, guiding students in local service projects. She also moderates the campus branch of Pax Christi, an international Catholic peace movement with headquarters in Brussels.
Interestingly, however, with Wall Street just across the Hudson and an array of multinational corporations nearby, many students at St. Peter's yearn to work precisely for the privileged institutions whose policies Dr. Brown decries.
She resists being tagged a communist. "I don't know what that word really means," she said with a laugh. But radical is a label that does not offend her.
"If people have a sense of what the word radical means, it's root," she explained. "Rootedness and roots go down real deep, and they're the base of support. So what comes from that root? What can grow from that root? For me, thought and action should pretty much be linked."
 
'Perfect' Place for an Office
THE letters identifying the three-story building with the yellow brick facade that houses the political science department at St. Peter's College are barely visible. But if you look closely, you can make them out: Dorothy Day House.
Born in Brooklyn in 1987, Dorothy Day cofounded the "Catholic Worker," a publication that supports social reform and opposes war. Having begun her career as a reporter for socialist publications, she was a member of the Socialist Party and of Communist Party affiliates before converting to Catholicism in 1927. She established more than 30 houses of hospitality for the poor and homeless during the Depression. Throughout her life, which she lived in voluntary poverty, she campaigned for racial justice, pacifism, and disarmament. She died in New York City in 1980, and has been proposed as a candidate for sainthood.
"It's so perfect that here is Anna's office," said Dr. Eugene J. Cornacchia, chairman of the political science department. "She's such a perfect example of Dorothy Day's philosophy and values."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 12, 1999

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3243 words

HEADLINE: Making Money, But Not Grades. The Next Step?

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
FROM Montclair to West Windsor, Maplewood to Whippany, school doors opened last week for the state's 1.3 million children. But they opened wider for some pupils than for others, and it is that nagging yet delicate issue that is drawing increasing attention from parents, teachers and administrators.
What can be done to improve the test scores and academic performance of minority students -- even those in the more affluent districts -- which continue to lag behind those of white and Asian students? 
 "There has to be much more monitoring of student achievement," said Elaine Davis, the principal at Montclair High School, who has made closing the achievement gap one of her highest priorities. "In fourth and fifth grade, we have to be asking, 'What is the reading level and what is the math level?' I'm seeing for the first time nonreaders at the high school level."
Schools in Lawrence Township and Maplewood-South Orange as well as Montclair are trying to close the gap in student achievement with new efforts even as a national task force is preparing suggestions for improving academic performance among minority groups.
"This issue is on the front burner," said Dr. Michael Knowlton, superintendent of the Summit public schools, who last spring met in Montclair with administrators from New Jersey, New York and Connecticut who are all dealing with the same problem.
In a report to be issued next month, the College Board's national task force on minority high achievement will take a hard look at the economic and educational factors that contribute to the relatively low number of high-achieving African-American, Hispanic and native American students.
In addition, the report will focus on why minority high school graduates often earn lower grades in college than their high school grades and SAT scores would indicate. And, perhaps most important, it will suggest strategies for improving grades and test scores that will include involvement by parents, schools and the communities themselves.
The task force is also examining social and cultural issues -- including racial prejudice -- as well as educational factors that influence a student's performance from pre-school to graduate school, said L. Scott Miller, director of the task force who wrote "An American Imperative: Accelerating Minority Education Advancement (Yale Press, 1995).
"The issue has emerged in a visible form in part because of the end of affirmative action in some states," Mr. Miller said. "In the process, people became more clearly aware that many of the kids in these programs were middle-class minority kids. Many people were surprised. Suddenly, people can see that these middle-class kids have needs, when they are no longer being admitted to schools that have rolled back affirmative action."
He added: "My hope is that the report will not just bring a greater awareness of the issue. We hope that several different actors will go to work on this issue," including university presidents, minority organizations and foundations willing to invest time and money in poor and middle-class minority children.
It is a subject that many educators prefer not to discuss. New Jersey's Department of Education does not break down test scores by race, and many public school administrators have in-house data that they use for planning but choose not to make public. But the College Board, and districts natiownide that do keep statistics by race, say their results show that black and Hispanic students lag from elementary school all the way through 12th grade.
For instance, black students continue to trail white students on the SAT's, even when the parents of black students have graduate degrees. According to 1998 data, black students whose parents had at least one graduate degree scored an average verbal score of 482 and 472 in math. The average score for a white student with at least one parent with a graduate degree was 566 in verbal and 568 in math.
And in New Jersey, the 1998 SAT scores showed white students received an average score of 519 in verbal and 527 in math, as against 428 in verbal and 427 in math for African-American students and 461 in verbal and 463 in math for Hispanic students.
Nationwide, among students who reported that their family income was from $80,000 to $100,000 a year (70,000 whites and 4,200 blacks), black students averaged 482 in verbal and 472 in math, as against 543 in verbal and 547 in math for white students.
Faced with such disturbing trends, 14 school districts in nine states have formed the Minority Student Achievement Network to encourage research on this gap in achievement and to share information when programs aimed at shrinking that gap appear successful. Although the organization, headed by Dr. Allan Alson, superintendent of Evanston Township High School in Illinois, does not include any New Jersey schools, administrators from Montclair and Maplewood-South Orange have been in contact with Mr. Alson and say they plan to share information with the group.
In Evanston, where about 42 percent of the 2,900 students are black, almost 25 percent of the black students failed at least one course in the 1997-98 school year, as against 4 percent of the white students. Moreover, state reading tests showed that almost half the black students were reading below grade level.
"The very first step is explicit honesty of where we stand," said Dr. Alson, who started the group last year. "If we don't say where we stand, we can't fix it. There are many success stories embedded in the data. You have to understand the success stories as well as the disappointments. I feel shame on us if we are not open in having the discussion. We need teamwork to get this done."
Several districts in New Jersey are beginning to confront the problem head-on.
In Lawrence Township Public Schools, where there are 4,000 pupils, the minority students do "60 percent as well as non-minority students" in testing, said Superintendent Claire Sheff Kohn. The district, which is made up of about 30 percent minority students, has instituted after-school tutoring programs and is working with pupils as young as pre-school to close the gap.
"This is something we are looking at constantly and trying to bridge that gap," said Ms. Sheff Kohn. "We do have a gap and it tends to also be correlated with socio-economic status."
The district is also trying to identify by the end of kindergarten students who are showing the potential for having difficulties in reading and working with those students in first grade so that they do not fall behind in reading skills.
In Montclair, where about 44 percent of the 1,600 public high school students are white. black students scored lower in math, reading and language on the Metropolitan Achievement Test -- a standardized test that rates students on math, reading and language abilities. In ninth-grade reading, 54 percent of the black students -- many of whom come from middle-class families -- scored higher than half of the students taking the test, as against 95 percent of the white students. In math, 69 percent of the black students did better than half of the students taking the test, as against 97 percent of the white students.
The district, which expects 1,800 students at the high school by 2001, spends a healthy $8,782 for each pupil and is a community of many well-educated professionals. Still, Ms. Davis, the principal at Montclair High School, believes students need to be watched more closely in elementary school so the district can intervene early to help with problems in basic reading and math skills.
Indeed, in 1997 she hired a reading specialist, Pamela Joyce, who teaches five reading and writing classes to high school freshmen, sophomores and juniors.
Better reading skills, Ms. Joyce is quick to point out, can make a difference in test scores, "You have to use more higher-level thinking skills when you read," she said. "You have to analyze, interpret and evaluate. On the tests, those are all the things that they are testing. The skills on the tests are also life skills, so it's scary when kids don't achieve."
Last week, before school opened, Ms. Davis summoned students to ask their opinions on the most important issues facing the school, including raising test scores. Students told her that their peers needed to be encouraged to take the tests more seriously and to drop the notion that it isn't cool to be smart and do well in school.
"We have to change the paradigm that learning is not in," she said. "It's not just looking at instruction. It's also looking at their attitude when they take the test."
Students told her that there should be an effort to increase the number of African-American and Hispanic students in honors classes and that students need to encourage other minority students to take these classes and then provide a support system for them by ogiving help with study skills.
The students also said that it would help to enlist successful minority college freshmen in the effort to persuade high school pupils that there is a "a big payoff" for working hard in school.
Marlo McGriff, a senior, is an A student and president of the school orchestra at Montclair, takes all honors courses. Yet Marlo, who is black, does not think the school can solve all the problems that create underachievement. "A lot of this has to do with the resources you have," he said. "The disparity comes from the family."
Marlo said he sees many minority students from single-parent families and many -- unlike himself -- do not have a home computer that can scan photographs into a report. Marlo, who was the only black student in his honors English and history classes last year, said his parents have always insisted that his education is a top priority. His father owns a manufacturing company and his mother stays home.
"Education is all they ask of me right now, that is my sole focus," he said.
If he is working on a report and needs something at 11 P.M., his parents will get it for him, he said. "I know a lot of people's parents can't do that."
Suzanne Podhurst, a senior and close friend of Marlo's, believes that support from parents and peers helps academic performance, she said.
"Just having support makes a difference," Suzanne said. "My parents are amazing, they help a lot.'
Her friends, like Marlo, don't find it odd if someone stays home to study on a Saturday night rather than going to a party. They even get together and study and keep each other calm through the heavy pressures that go with honors classes.
Edmund W. Gordon, a professor emeritus of psychology at Yale University who is co-chairman of the College Board's national task force on minority high achievement, agrees that better attitudes about education and intellectualism would make a difference in school performance.
"I place a high degree of responsibility at the feet of the schools, but I don't blame the schools alone," said Mr. Gordon, who is black. "Within the black, Hispanic and Native American communities there is not the same respect for intellectual activity."
Economic factors still play a major role in minority students not doing as well in testing, he said. Even families that have now achieved affluence may have been poor just one generation ago. "They have recently gotten there and they have not come out of middle-class traditions," he said.
It is important that attention and resources be given to poor children, Mr. Gordon said, but also to middle-class minority students who could be doing much better in school.
"If society will become integrated, society must be integrated at all levels," he said.
Schools must also work to make minority students feel that they are in the learning community where they belong, said Peter Horoschak, superintendent of Maplewood-South Orange School District, who for six years was superintendent in Shaker Heights, Ohio.
The district in Ohio, Dr. Horoschak said, was a racially mixed district not unlike Maplewood-South Orange and Montclair in economic make-up and with a similar gap in test scores. While Maplewood-South Orange does not separate the scores of its 6,100 students' tests by race, the gap is evident to administrators who see that the elementary schools with greater minority populations are not scoring as well as those with more white students.
"This is also related to socio-economic status," Dr. Horoschak said. "Our job is to help every student achieve. Number one is that the student feels accepted in the environment. This is the place for them and that they are suppose to be here and they belong."
This year, Dr. Horoschak said, he hired Marilyn Davenport -- who was an elementary school principal in New Mexico when he was superintendent in Albuquerque -- to be director of elementary instruction in the district. He said he plans to concentrate her efforts in Seth Boyden and Clinton Elementary Schools, which have had lower test scores than other schools in the district and have 60 to 80 percent minority students.
Ms. Davenport's program, built around a theory developed by a clinical psychologist, Howard Gardner, that children have multiple intelligences, will include working on new techniques with teachers, tapping into parent and community resources, holding seminars for parents and encouraging teachers to share their success stories.
"We teach the children how to get smarter," she said. And teachers "constantly point out how they are smart," to build confidence and self-esteem.
In New Jersey, as around the rest of the country, the consensus is that the racial gap cannot be closed without intervention in the young grades. In Madison, Wis., one of the 14 districts participating in the Minority Student Achievement Network, administrators and teachers are trying to make sure that students are reading at grade level by the third grade.
"Reading is the first major thing for us," said Art Rainwater, superintendent of schools in Madison, a district with 25,000 pupils, of which about 8,000 are minority students.
"We believe that reading is the key," Mr. Rainwater said.
The district has trained 500 community volunteers who tutor and aid in reading in the schools. In math, the district is requiring students to complete algebra and geometry by the end of tenth grade and begins teaching strands of those concepts as early as kindergarten.
The district also brings successful black professionals into the school to mentor and serve as role models.
Another focus of the Madison school district is to raise minority attendance in middle school and high school. On any given day in Madison's ninth grades, 91 percent of the white students will be in attendance, 84 percent of the Hispanic students will be there and 78 percent of the black students will attend, said Kurt Kiefer, coordinator of planning, research and evaluation in the district. "It's phenomenal," Mr. Kiefer said. "On average, every kid misses one day per week."
While educational institutions struggle to lift minority test scores, some educators believe that a portion of the problem lies in the test.
"Montclair's situation is totally common," said Monty Neill, executive director of the National Center for Fair and Open Testing in Cambridge, Mass. "Test scores parallel race and class. The only distinction is how much. Test items will assume a cultural knowledge. The cultural knowledge of upper middle-class whites is on the test."
Then, some districts will use that data to "track" students and put them at levels in math and reading where they will stay throughout school. This takes away the opportunity for higher level courses, like honors classes, that benefit test takers in exams including the SAT tests.
"Instead of relying first on standardized tests, let's rely on what teachers see in their classrooms and what they learn about students," Mr. Neill said.
Calling the test culturally white is "nonsense," said Brian O'Reilly, executive director of guidance and admissions testing program for the College Board.
The racial gap in scores "is an extremely complex issue," Mr. O'Reilly said. "It would be nice if there were an easy answer. If there were, something would have been done about this years ago."
Test data must also be looked at more carefully than just one set of numbers, administrators say. Students who do extremely poorly on a test pull down the average of those doing very well.
"We have black students do exceedingly well and others way below," said Jeanne Pryor, assistant superintendent in Montclair. "A very low performance will negate a very high one."
Still, no one expects this issue to have a quick fix.
"Montclair, like so many districts is really struggling with this problem,' Dr. Pryor said. "I would hope we will make more gains in the next five years than we've made in the last 10."
 
Just What Are All Those Tests, Anyway?
DURING the 1999-2000 school year, more than 215,000 New Jersey public school students will take mandatory state tests to assess their skills in reading, writing and math.
Since the state began testing in 1978, the exam has continued to evolve. In the next decade, it will become more comprehensive, including portions on science, social studies, languages, physical education and visual and performing arts.
Most districts give additional skills tests, but the assessments in grades four and eight and the junior year of high school are the only ones required by the state. The scores are not broken down by race, but do look at the socio-economic factors of the districts.
The function of the state tests is to evaluate the student's progress and to determine if the school is succeeding in teaching the necessary skills.
"It also gives schools a wealth of information about their curriculum and individual teachers," said Richard Vespucci, spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Education.
The tests are an early indicator as to whether a student in fourth grade needs help with basic reading and math skills. Students cannot graduate from high school unless they pass all three portions of the High School Proficiency Test.
The state's 80,000 fourth-grade students in the public schools will take the Elementary School Proficiency Assessment in May that tests language arts and literacy and math and requires the student to give a speech. Fourth graders will also take field tests in social studies and visual and performing arts, but those scores will not be placed in their records.
In March, 75,000 students will take the Grade Eight Proficiency Assessment, which will include tests in language arts and literacy, math and science and a field test in social studies.
In October, high school juniors will be tested in reading, writing and math and take the trial field tests in science, language arts and literacy and math. This will be the last year of the High School Proficiency Test. In the 2000-2001 school year, the exam will be called the High School Proficiency Assessment. It will be "more rigorous and cover a broader area" than current tests, Mr. Vespucci said.
Students will still be required to pass the test for graduation. If they fail in October of their junior year, they are allowed to take the tests again in the spring and in their senior year.
State test scores, broken down by district, can be found on the Department of Education's web site: (http://www.state.nj.us/education). DEBRA NUSSBAUM

HEADLINE: The Return of the Adjustable Mortgage

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
DAVID HOCHEISER, a loan officer at Bank of America Mortgage in Fairfield, N.J., is struck by how much the mortgage market has changed in recent months.
"I have 27 loans in my pipeline right now, but only two of them are 30-year fixed-rate loans, while the rest are adjustables," Mr. Hocheiser said. "We're coming into a whole different kind of mortgage market." 
 By many accounts, that is not an understatement. While rates for conventional 30-year fixed-rate mortgages had sunk to less than 7 percent as recently as April, they have been mounting rapidly and hit 8.31 percent in mid-August, according to HSH Associates, a financial publisher in Butler, N.J., that tracks the market. Meanwhile, the difference in cost between fixed-rate loans and adjustables has widened enough since the beginning of the year to make fixed-rate mortgages no longer look like "virtual no-brainers," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an HSH vice president.
The result?
In contrast to the pattern of the last two years, in which historically low rates have made fixed-rate mortgages, which carry the same annual rate over the term of the loan, the all-but-automatic choice of most consumers, "we're seeing a shift," said Neil Bader, chief executive of Skyscraper Mortgage, a Manhattan-based mortgage broker. "We're seeing people lock in at shorter-term adjustables, usually where the rates are adjusted every three or five years," Mr. Bader said. Rates on such mortgages are recalculated after an initial period, and frequently yearly thereafter, to reflect changes in such interest indexes as the one-year Treasury bill rate.
Of course, in a real estate market where houses often seem to be mercilessly scarce and home prices are still skipping upward, mortgage rates are not necessarily a top concern for all consumers.
At White Horse Financial Services in Bronxville, N.Y., Edna Haber, a mortgage broker, reports that most of her customers -- in a market where "20 people seem to be chasing every house" -- are more concerned with simply getting the property they want.
Mortgage rates have softened a bit since mid-August, averaging 7.88 percent as of midday last Thursday. And by historic standards -- as well as the standards of the 1990's -- such rates are still low, Mr. Gumbinger said. Still, the recent rate increase seems to have already spurred many consumers to look hard at adjustable-rate mortgages.
"I'm seeing a huge change in thinking," Mr. Hocheiser said. "Even when the rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 8 percent some two years ago, we were still putting people into 30-year fixed-rate loans. But now people are asking more for adjustables."
One consumer who recently decided to opt for an adjustable-rate mortgage over a fixed-rate product is Robert Maina, who works for an investment bank. Mr. Maina and his wife, Claire, who now live in Bayside, N.Y, are buying a three-bedroom colonial-style home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. When Mr. Maina began looking into mortgages in early July he discovered that the rate for a 30-year fixed-rate loan would have been roughly 8.25 percent. He subsequently decided to go with a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage on which the rate will be fixed at 7.75 percent for the first seven years, and adjusted annually after that.
"As first-time home owners we wanted to be as conservative as possible," said Mr. Maina. "Besides, we view this home as a starter home and I don't plan on being in the house more than seven years. After that, if we're still there, we can always adjust our payment after we refinance."
Rate changes and a renewal in the popularity of adjustable-rate mortgages are not the only recent developments in the mortgage market. There has been a dramatic increase in the amount of mortgage-related information available on the Internet and the number of lenders participating. New mortgage products include loans whose rates can only go down, as well as those that can be used to pay off other debts, like credit card loans.
A new Federal law has been enacted that gives homeowners the right to cancel private mortgage insurance once their equity reaches 20 percent. Borrowers who have less-than-terrific credit are finding it easier to obtain mortgages than they once might have. And finally, there has been a dramatic shift by consumers away from refinancings, which accounted for a whopping 70 percent of all mortgage volume a year ago.
Chase Manhattan Bank now offers its customers a home equity line of credit that carries none of the expenses usually associated with mortgages -- like closing costs or appraisal fees -- yet still lets them take a tax deduction on their interest payments, as well as consolidate outstanding bills, like credit card payments, often at lower total monthly payments.
AND some companies, including City Line Mortgage, a small mortgage banker in San Diego, now offer mortgages whose rates automatically go down when prevailing rates decrease, as a way of hanging onto customers who might otherwise go elsewhere to refinance. City Line is licensed to do business in 26 states, including New York and New Jersey, but not Connecticut.
On the mortgage insurance front, the Homeowners Protection Act, which took effect on July 29, gives consumers who are getting mortgages the right to cancel their private mortgage insurance once their equity reaches 20 percent. Such private mortgage insurance -- known as P.M.I. -- is usually required when down payments are less than 20 percent; its costs are added to the monthly payments on the mortgage itself. Under the new Federal law, cancellation is supposed to become automatic at 22 percent.
Consumers who have less than exemplary credit have benefited lately from lenders who are willing to overlook bad credit histories. In August, these mortgage shoppers found that they were in a better position when using the Internet as well. That is when Mortgage.com, an on-line lending site, announced a partnership with Intuit Inc. to provide "subprime" mortgages at Intuit's QuickenMortgage.com Web site.
Some of the recent changes in the mortgage market have had widespread effects. The rise in interest rates, for example, has reduced the number of homeowners who are refinancing their mortgages.
"Refinancings have just about completely dried up," said Sterling Edmunds, president of Crestar Mortgage. "Consumers feel that because rates have gone up they've probably missed the boat, and they're probably right."
Donald E. Lange, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, agreed. "Refinancings are the first casualty when rates rise," Mr. Lange said, "and we've seen our refinancings drop from about 50 percent to about 20 percent" since the beginning of the year for the industry as a whole. Mr. Lange is also president and chief executive of Pacific Financial Services in Torrance, Calif.
Use of the Internet by mortgage shoppers, either to look up mortgage-related information or to get actual loans, has been rising, and is expected to increase even more.
Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., projects that on-line mortgage lending will grow from $18 billion in 1999 to more than $91 billion in 2003, a figure representing 10 percent of the value of all mortgages. James P. Punishill, an analyst at Forrester, points out that compared with a year ago, consumers now have a veritable bonanza of choices on line.
Interest rates are not necessarily lower on line, he cautioned. But instead of automatically going to a mortgage broker, consumers can save money by quickly comparing rates from dozens, if not hundreds, of lenders at sites like QuickenMortgage.com, LendingTree.com and RealEstate.com, which provides rates from more than 220 lenders.
"A year ago the choices were still pretty limited; we had a handful of lenders, and none had their own products," Mr. Punishill said. "But now consumers have the pricing transparency that can help them save."
Mr. Punishill has noticed another significant change on line: instead of encouraging consumers to bypass mortgage brokers, a growing number of Internet firms, like LoanCity.com, are offering consumers access to brokers as part of their services.
LoanCity.com offers a "personalized service" feature that the company claims lets consumers work with brokers to complete all the paperwork and still saves them about a third of the fees involved in a traditional loan. "A lot of consumers don't want to eliminate brokers entirely," Mr. Punishill said. "As a result, these firms are now offering what might be described as 'lite' advisory services."
While most mortgages being issued in recent weeks continue to be the traditional fixed-rate types, the increase in interest rates in recent months has changed the focus of many consumers. Adjustable-rate mortgages are "the hottest product right now," said Mr. Lange of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"The borrower has become much more sophisticated than even two or three years ago," he said. "They're looking at mortgages and are asking themselves how long they really intend to live in their new home."
The result?
"Borrowers now may decide to go for a mortgage where the first five years are fixed, and the next 25 years are adjusted," Mr. Lange said. "They've decided that such a product works just fine for them, and also that they can save between three-quarters and one percentage point in interest to go from a fixed product to an adjustable. Also, by moving from a fixed rate to an adjustable, they can effectively negate the fact that rates have gone up between one and one-and-a-quarter percentage points lately."
MR. LANGE added that relatively attractive terms are helping ease the risks of adjustable-rate mortgages. For example, he pointed out that the interest rates on most adjustable mortgages can increase by only one to two percentage points per year, as well as a lifetime cap of about six percentage points.
"That cap may seem high," Mr. Lange said, "but the perception now among consumers is that the Federal Reserve has a good handle on inflation, so there is now a higher comfort level switching over to an adjustable than there was in the past."
The switch to adjustable-rate mortgages has not been a landslide. Margaret Scott, a senior mortgage consultant at the New York Mortgage Corporation, a mortgage broker, said most of her customers choose 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, like the couple who came to her in late August. They were thinking of either buying a $1.2 million home or having one built for them.
"I started talking to them about other mortgage products, but they quickly rejected them," Ms. Scott said. "From their perspective there were so many other things to think about other than rates, like whether they should put a lot of money down to reduce the overall cost. Like many people today, they were looking at their home as a long-term investment."
Nevertheless, real estate experts say adjustable-rate mortgages are more popular than they have been in years. Last fall, for example, adjustable-rate mortgages accounted for just 2 to 3 percent of the mortgage business at Crestar, but that number has now swollen to 25 to 30 percent, with most customers interested in one-, three- and five-year adjustable-rate products, said Mr. Edmunds, the company's president.
Like many mortgage lenders, many of whom have seen their business volume shrink as interest rates have climbed, drying up their refinancing business, Crestar has been busy rolling out more options for adjustable-rate customers.
"We've come up with numerous mortgages that have all sorts of features," said Susan Huber, a senior vice president of secondary marketing. Last spring, for example, Crestar began offering a 30-year annually adjusted mortgage that lets consumers pay interest for only the first 10 years, and whose rates, Ms. Huber said, are far less than those of similar products. Crestar's product, she added, is pegged to carry an interest rate that is just 1.5 percentage points higher than the Treasury security to which such loans are generally pegged. By contrast, she said, similar loans now run 2.75 or 2.875 percentage points higher.
Despite the growing appeal of shorter-term adjustable-rate mortgages, experts urge consumers to look before they leap.
"People are so used to lower rates, but they should be careful not to lock in too short a period, perhaps with a one- or three-year product," said Mr. Bader, the chief executive at Skyscraper Mortgage. He pointed out that on a five-year adjustable-rate mortgage, consumers can still get a rate in the range of "the low sevens," and if they are willing to pay points -- the upfront fee of a percentage of the total loan, with one point being one percent of the mortgage -- they can get a rate in the "high sixes." He recommends that consumers pay a few extra points and buy down their interest rate. Each point paid will lower the interest rate by roughly one-quarter of a percent.
"People have all but forgotten about points, but remember that each point is one percentage point of a loan and two points is effectively a half-percent of interest rate reduction," he said. "By paying two points on your mortgage, you can bring rates down to where they were five months ago."
BUT Mr. Bader also advises consumers to ask their banks about longer "lock-in" periods -- the time for which a lender promises to hold a certain interest rate while a loan is being processed -- in case interest rates keep going up. While banks usually lock in rates for 60 days, some banks are starting to tout 90-day locks, he said. He emphasized that the longer lock-in periods are especially critical in fierce housing markets like that of Manhattan.
"The market is so tight now that sellers can't find new houses to move into, so they're asking for longer closing periods," he said. At Bank of America, Mr. Hocheiser said he has noticed that while mortgage loans used to close within 35 to 60 days as recently as a few months ago, they now tend to close within 60 to 120 days.
Some consumers, however, may find that it pays to speed up the closing process. Mr. Gumbinger said one way consumers can soothe some of the sting of the recent rate hikes is to ask for a shorter commitment period, which is the time between when a lender promises to make a loan -- generally after it has already been approved -- and the time the loan is actually made. Consumers who have good credit, as well as their paperwork in order, may be able to close their loan in just 30 days, he said, allowing them to get a slightly lower interest rate, perhaps in the range of an eighth of a percentage point.
What about other defense strategies?
Mr. Gumbinger advises consumers to consider offsetting the recent increase in interest rates with a larger down payment, as well as getting a "float-down" option in case rates might actually be lower by the time the buyer closes on the loan. While a float-down option usually entails paying a small fee -- such as one-eighth or a quarter of a percent -- they give consumers access to lower rates if they fall during the closing process.
Finally, Mr. Gumbinger urges consumers not to panic. "When rates are higher and rising, it's more important to sit down and really try to decide how long you plan on staying in a home so that you can find the best mortgage," he said. "With a 30-year fixed-rate loan, you're buying stability, but it's expensive."
Ms. Scott also urges consumers to shoot for the future. "Today, it's more about a home being a long-term investment," she said. "It's not so much about rates as it is about a good buy."

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
New Brunswick Adding to Its Revival

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE dreary slice of New Brunswick at the southern end of the city's reviving downtown is not much to look at. It is occupied by a timeworn 1929 hotel and a huddle of small shops covering a triangular block.
But last month the city's Redevelopment Authority designated the nonprofit New Brunswick Development Corporation to transform the block with a 550,000-square-foot, 15-story mixed-use building. Christopher J. Paladino, the corporation president, has announced plans to develop the $100-million project with public and private funds over the next two-and-a-half years in partnership with the Advance Group of Bedminster. 
 Called Heldrich Plaza, the project will combine conference and retail space with a 200-room hotel, 198 rental apartments and a new home for the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development, part of Rutgers University. There will also be a 300-car underground garage on the 1.8-acre site, bounded by Livingston Avenue and George and New Streets.
The center and the plaza are named for the chairman of the state's Employment and Training Commission, who is also a retired Johnson & Johnson executive. Mr. Heldrich is credited with convincing the pharmaceutical giant in the 1970's to remain in New Brunswick, a decision that spurred the downtown revival.
The Heldrich Plaza site is considered pivotal to the downtown's 25-year-old revival. It is framed to the west by the city's cultural district, where three theaters stand, along with a 175,000-square-foot structure housing the university's planning and arts schools. To the east it faces a 135,000-square-foot block-long building that houses a retail component and offices of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. To the southeast is an underdeveloped stretch of land.
More than $80 million in public and private money has been invested in the southern end of New Brunswick's downtown since 1994, according to city figures.
The project "will have a major impact on the downtown and fill in the last side of the triangle," said Glenn Patterson, director of the city's Department of Planning, Community and Economic Development. It is expected to create 2,500 construction and permanent jobs and when completed, in 2002, generate about $1 million a year in taxes, he said.
It is also intended, said Mr. Paladino, to be a catalyst in moving redevelopment in a southeasterly direction along George Street to a five-block stretch extending from New Street to Commercial Avenue and connect to Rutgers' Douglass/Cook campus.
The project started modestly enough 18 months ago out of the need to build a new 50,000-square-foot home for the Heldrich Center, a two-year-old national training and research institute that holds conferences on labor issues. It now occupies 10,000 square feet at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, across from the development site.
Since then the center's search for a new home has attracted a $24 million commitment from the state, which along with the city saw it as the anchor to a major redevelopment effort. In the process, the project blossomed to its current size.
Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the state's Department of Community Affairs, said the project reflected not only "the continuation of downtown New Brunswick's revitalization," but the state's pledge "to provide the resources to put cities back in business."
The state has already provided a $3.4 million grant to the Heldrich Center. The next step, said Carl Van Horn, its director, is to enter a long-term agreement with the state's Department of Labor to provide the balance of the funds for new headquarters space, which is needed because "we're busting at the seams." Mr. Van Horn said that given the current support for the center he is optimistic the funding will be granted.
So is Mr. Paladino, who said the state commitment would enable his corporation to attract the remaining $76 million for the overall project. Most of it will come from the sale of bonds by the New Brunswick Redevelopment Authority, he said, noting that about 25 percent would come from private banking sources.
He said his corporation had also received a $1.6 million state loan as part of the funds needed to acquire the site, adding that he expected the City Council to approve the nonprofit group as the redeveloper this week. Before construction can begin, the 82-room hotel, home to more than 200 long-term residents, and 12 shops must be razed and the tenants must be relocated.
As with other redevelopment efforts in the city some shop owners on the site have voiced concerns over the process. Mr. Paladino said his company, as it has done before, would help all viable businesses that want to continue to relocate elsewhere in the city.
THE new building, designed by Ford Farewell Mills and Gatsch, Architects in Princeton, will have shops on the ground floor and conference space for the Heldrich Center and the hotel on the second floor.
The third and fourth floors will be occupied by hotel rooms and Heldrich Center offices; the rest of the hotel will rise through the seventh floor.
The apartments will occupy the eighth through the 13th floors and the building's mechanical systems will be housed in what Michael Farewell, one of the architecture firm's partners, calls "a lantern-like crown" on the 14th and 15th floors.
While the varied uses will "feed off one another," said Mr. Farewell, each will have a separate entrance and lobby.
There were previous attempts to redevelop the site, all of which focused on recycling the hotel into such uses as housing for students or the elderly. But none moved forward.
"The earlier efforts were not large enough to turn around the block," Mr. Paladino said, noting that until recently timing also was not on the side of a project the scale of Heldrich Plaza. Today, he said, "we can use the additional investment in the downtown as leverage," noting that it was the state's commitment that "makes it all work."
Peter Cocoziello, president of the Advance Group, the co-developer, said those factors along with what he called "a general push back to the cities" were the reasons his company, known as a suburban office developer, was drawn to the project. Mr. Cocoziello was referring to such state initiatives as its buying a million acres of open space, making development more difficult in the suburbs, and encouraging the reuse of former polluted sites in the cities.
Mr. Cocoziello also said that tenants in Heldrich Plaza apartments would be offered, for an extra fee, hotel services, from housekeeping and room service to the use of the swimming pool and health club. Estimated rents for the studio to two-bedroom apartments, ranging from 675 to 1,150 square feet, are $1,150 to $1,750.
The hotel and conference center will cater to small business groups. A feasibility study done by PKF Consulting, a real estate and hotel consulting firm in Manhattan, said there would be a demand for such a center from corporations in northern New Jersey, which is "an underserved marketplace." As home to Rutgers, Johnson & Johnson, St. Peter's Medical Center and the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, the city also has a built-in market niche, added Mr. Paladino.
David E. Arnold, executive vice president at PKF, said for the hotel/conference center to succeed it not only must be part of a larger project, but the city must continue to improve.
Local officials said the Heldrich Plaza project will help do just that by fueling development farther south. There are signs such a ripple effect is possible.
One is the recent $14 million purchase by the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury of two office buildings, totaling 210,000 square feet, and nine acres, now used for parking, just southeast of the Heldrich Plaza site. The plan is to invest $10 million to renovate the buildings in the coming year, and twice that amount in the next few years to develop the parking lots into a mix of housing, retail, garage parking and possibly more offices, said Joseph Taylor, the company's president.
Key to that five-block area's revival is the city's plans to raze the four-building, 246-unit Memorial Homes public-housing complex, just off Route 18, and replace it with 198 rental and for-sale town-house residences. They will rise on six parcels in the area, including the old Memorial Homes site, Mr. Patterson, the city's planning director said, adding that construction could begin on the first 64 residences by next spring or summer.
A new elementary school now under construction at the corner of Throop and George Streets will replace an existing school two blocks to the east, bringing the redevelopment just about to the doorstep of the Douglass/Cook campus, Mr. Patterson added. The existing school will be converted into 32 apartments, he said.

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE;
Hot and Heavy

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
Lawns were parched; the Governor issued a drought warning.
New Jerseyans were parched; July was the hottest on record. 
 Life was good. Just ask merchants, restaurateurs and hotel owners along the 127 miles of Jersey Shore.
Officials said the beach communities saw increases of up to 10 percent in beach tag sales, many realtors said all of their properties were rented and the Garden State Parkway -- the state's Shore highway -- reported a 3 percent increase in traffic, according to the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission.
The season did end on a downbeat note for some, however, because of rainy weather and beach closings over the Labor Day weekend caused by Hurricane Dennis.
"It was a banner season," said Carl Jennings, the recreation director in Long Branch. "Unfortunately, the last three weekends were a little washed out, particularly Labor Day weekend, when we were closed. I'd say it's the most patrons we've had in the past 10 years. In July our revenues were really up."
In dollar terms, the sale of beach tags from Memorial Day through the end of August raised $185,227 in Long Branch, as against last year's total of $147,784, which included Labor Day Weekend. The township's monthly total for this past July was $83,386, compared with $65,037 last summer.
The additional revenue came in handy, Mr. Jennings said, since beachgoers were so hot they often stayed on the township's 2.3 miles of public beach well into the evening, making it necessary for lifeguards to work overtime.
In Cape May, Dane Wells, an owner of the Queen Victoria bed and breakfast and Queen Victoria Hotel, said revenue at the 21-room inn and the 11-room hotel was up 7 percent over last year.
There was at least one other difference this year, said Mr. Wells, a board member of the New Jersey Hotel/Motel Association.
"This is the first time I've ever seen our guests pleased to see rain," he said.
Mr. Wells said he also noticed some changes in his clientele. For one thing, he said, they have become more upscale, asking for amenities not typically associated with bed-and-breakfasts, like private baths with whirlpools.
Karen Crossland, the night manager at the Pilot House restaurant in Cape May, said she had noticed more automobile and even shopping cart traffic this summer.
"In the supermarket, finding a place to park, just getting from point A to point B, it was just more difficult," she said.
Ms. Crossland said the few rainy days at the end of the season actually helped her local antiques business, Promises Collectibles, because the sunshine is "very hard on straight retail."
Bruce Dwyer, manager of The Crab Trap, a restaurant in Somers Point, said that while the hot economy and the hotter summer helped fuel tourism, it also made it harder for him to keep waiters, busboys and other seasonal help. "I guess the job market's too good," Mr. Dwyer said.
Laura Otterbourg, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, said most of her information was anecdotal because "we won't have the '99 data till March."
The scant information reported by the commission was based on a survey conducted before Labor Day. For more comprehensive figures, the state hires a Canadian tourism research company, Longwoods International, to begin gathering information after Labor Day on overnight visits, sales tax revenue and overall economic activity and employment and then breaks down the information by county.
Nonetheless, Jeanne DiPaola, executive director of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce, said, "Just from general conversation with business people, for the Long Beach Island and southern Ocean County area, it looks like it was a good season, but no record breaker."
Despite the sunshine and the strong economy, Ms. DiPaola said, power failures on the July 4th weekend and bad weather over Labor Day meant the season was probably about as good as last year. "If there was any chance of breaking records this season, it was kind of diluted by that," she said.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
That Never-Ending Spending

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
THE stack of beautiful shirts on the cover of Roger Rosenblatt's book about why Americans buy (and buy and buy) is exactly right. A visual reference to "The Great Gatsby" -- specifically, the moment in the novel when Jay Gatsby tries to woo Daisy Buchanan by heaping his exquisitely tailored blouses on a table -- it neatly sums up both the style and the substance of the subject matter within.
"Consuming Desires: Consumption, Culture and the Pursuit of Happiness" (Shearwater/Island Books, $24.95) is a dazzling stack of essays itself, finely observed and thought-provoking over all. It examines what its editor calls "the painful and thumping heart of the rapacious American appetite." 
 Mr. Rosenblatt, an essayist for Time magazine, has assembled 13 writers: economists, novelists, short-story writers, journalists. The idea is to figure out what's frantic and what's sensible about consuming, and to reflect on the cost of our national spending spree.
True, Mr. Rosenblatt notes in his useful and literary introduction, consumption has long been a particularly American activity. But these days, he writes, "ordinary citizens are becoming like the big spenders of the past, going on near-desperate hunts for new stuff to buy and to long for."
In explaining this, he says, the book's essays yield two main thoughts. One is that our consumption is driven by an inchoate, unsatisfied yearning for family love and for community. The other is that our striving Western -- especially American -- sense of self demands outer expressions of individualism.
Several of the essayists bring up the idea of longing. Edward Luttwak, a critic of what he calls "turbo-capitalism" at home and abroad, considers the buying frenzy (with consumer debt at 89 percent of household income in 1997) as a misery indicator. Purchases temporarily repair the wounds arising from repeated job relocations, fractured families and isolation, says Mr. Luttwak, an expert in both military affairs and economics. "Americans are emotional destitutes," he writes, "as poor in their family connections as are Afghans or Sudanese in money."
THEN there is our frantic consumption of popular culture and style as a substitute for real community connection. Films have always been a binding force for our economically and ethnically disparate population, explains the critic Molly Haskell, adding that in the movies, characters can "consume without the tedium of labor."
And looking at the apparent paradoxes in suburban and hip-hop fashion, Alex Kotlowitz, who often writes about race and poverty, says poor, black, urban teen-agers aspire to Coach wallets and the outdoorsy look of Ralph Lauren as a way of belonging to the larger society. Their white, middle-class counterparts, trying to be edgy at a safe distance, affect an inner-city style -- huge, low-slung jeans and unlaced high-tops. It's a gesture of commercialism, Mr. Kotlowitz says, "that in the end only accentuates and prolongs the myths we have built up about each other."
As for that Western sense of individuality, Juliet Schor and Bill McKibben each write convincingly about the Americanness of acquiring things for comfort or cachet.
Ms. Schor, a women's studies professor at Harvard, repeats some of the theories she expounded in her 1998 book, "The Overspent American." But they bear repeating here. Identity in America, she argues, increasingly depends on prestigious brand names. And who we are, or think we are, has little to do with keeping up with the Joneses these days. It's about identifying with people on the upper rungs of the socioeconomic ladder -- the boss, say, or characters on television dramas, or celebrities.
Mr. McKibbon, who often writes about the environment, says his identity, too, is defined by consumerism -- in his case, the rejection of it. In a witty meditation on blackflies and other hardships of rural living in upstate New York, he comments on the "catechism" of the consumer society ("the elevation of each one of us above all else") and jokes about his voluntary simplicity.
He writes that he feels "special" because of his wreck of a car, his old clothes and because "it's a 20-mile round trip to get a quart of milk."
AT the same time, "Consuming Desires" goes beyond the ideas of identity and yearning. In one delightful essay, the writer Bharati Mukherjee wickedly exults in a trip to the mall. In another, the novelist Jane Smiley muses on the link between feminism and consumerism. It all began with housework, she argues entertainingly, describing the history of labor-saving gadgets in this country.
There's even something for a book reviewer -- a complaint by Andre Schiffrin, editor in chief of The New Press, about the quality of the books we consume today. Nonfiction, especially, has suffered under the new economic order in big-time publishing, he argues.
That's certainly true when it comes to business titles, where such bottom-line thinking has produced its share of junk: books written as advertisements for consultants, books that promise quick riches, books that glean "management lessons" from sports, war, nursery rhymes or the animal kingdom -- books, in other words, with the wispiest or silliest of premises. "Consuming Desires," published by a small press, is a welcome exception.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Some Birthday Cake For a Toothless Wonder

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, the rising powers of the Pacific organized a loose economic confederation known as APEC to bind together their fractious region. Each year since 1993, the region's leaders have donned silly shirts, flown to some spectacular setting and held a summit meeting. The latest one starts here this morning, in a country much more like England in the '50s than Asia in the '90s.
An opportune time and place, then, to pose this question: Should everyone acknowledge that this whole idea of creating a "Pacific Community" to rival the European Community has been a failure and put APEC out of its misery? 
 Maybe so. After 10 years, no one quite knows what the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation -- the name just stops there because its members could not agree on "Organization" or "Forum" or even whether some among them were really countries at all -- is supposed to do.
When its big chance to ride to the rescue arrived -- in the form of the Asian economic meltdown of 1997 -- APEC froze in the headlights. It could not come up with an agenda of economic reforms or even coordinate emergency financial aid. That work was left to the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the United States Treasury.
APEC's record on trade is only slightly better. The first summit conferences produced agreements in principle to dismantle all tariffs and other trade barriers in the Pacific by 2020. But like a vow from the Red Sox to win the World Series by 2020, those are hopes, not plans. Tariffs were indeed reduced on some high-technology goods, but on everything else, Japan dug in its heels, and many other countries, reeling from economic crises, slammed on the brakes. These days, the World Trade Organization does most of the globe's rule-setting and dispute arbitration.
Then there is the biggest failure of all: the enormous hesitation to turn an economic organization into a political one, capable of decision-making on issues that affect the world's prosperity.
THE phrase "Pacific Community" was first used by President Clinton at the initial conference, in Seattle in 1993. "We can't imagine now how we could have weathered the cold war without NATO," Mr. Clinton said then. "In the same way, future generations may look back and say they can't imagine how the Asian-Pacific region could have thrived in such a spirit of harmony without the existence of APEC."
As he attends the meeting this weekend, Mr. Clinton won't be talking much about the Pacific Community. His theory that economic cooperation would beget political cooperation was appealing when Asia was in economic ascendancy. But now the region is doing more fraying than knitting. From North Korea to the Taiwan Strait, from unrest in Indonesia to nuclear tensions in the subcontinent, Asia appears more chaotic, more unstable and more susceptible to implosion than at any time since the Vietnam War.
That doesn't mean that meetings like this one are useless. They create an easy, natural forum for leaders to talk. Imagine what diplomatic gymnastics it would take to get Bill Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China speaking face to face without the cover of an annual regional get-together.
But many former optimists in the Clinton Administration acknowledge, at least privately, that APEC's utility is diminishing. "If we come out of this with nothing, absolutely nothing, on Indonesia and East Timor, you've got to wonder, what's the use?" one Cabinet member said the other day.
The problem is partly that the so-called community is an artificial one. NATO was bound together by a common desire to contain Communism. The European Union is bound together by tight geography and a semblance of ethnic and cultural cohesion. But these days, APEC stretches to include the United States and Vietnam, Canada and Papua New Guinea, Mexico and Malaysia, Japan and Russia -- an easy recipe for political paralysis.
"It's been a disappointment," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who has long experience in Asia. "The idea was right, but it involves too many countries with too many diverse agendas."
One result is a growing racial divide. The largely Anglo-Saxon nations of North America, Australia and New Zealand keep pressing for faster trade liberalization, Western-style economic reforms and United Nations peacekeeping forces in places like East Timor, against resistance from the Asians, who are far more loath to mess with the internal affairs of neighbors and who resent what they view as American-inspired domination. "There's a sense that Washington is trying to use this as another tool of influence," a senior Japanese official complained recently.
Perhaps that is all it is good for. President Clinton will endure the leaders' meeting in the hope of accomplishing some serious work on the side, chiefly with the Chinese. As for the community, the trade ministers have so far agreed on nothing of substance, and Indonesia's president, B. J. Habibie, has decided not to show up -- for fear, many here think, of a coup while he is chatting with the neighbors.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Edward P. Owens;
Vanguard Health Care Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
EARLIER this year, as worries piled up about everything from an overheating economy to possible Government price controls on drugs, the stock market took a scalpel to the health care industry. The Standard & Poor's health care composite index fell 20.4 percent from its peak in mid-April through early August.
But more than a few pockets of strength remain. "The selloff was concentrated in big-cap stocks that had done well for many years," said Edward P. Owens, who runs the $10.65 billion Vanguard Health Care fund. "The biotechnology and Japanese drug sectors have been strong through the year." 
 Looking ahead, he sees health care stocks tracking the general market. "It's pretty unlikely that the 30-plus percent gains of the last four years will continue," Mr. Owens said from his office overlooking Quincy Market in Boston, where he is senior vice president at Wellington Management, a money management firm.
The best values may be found in a hard-hit group -- health care services stocks, like drugstore chains, pharmaceutical distributors and hospitals. "Health care services has been left far behind," he said, "and probably will be the best-performing part of the health care sector over the next three or four years."
The fund has managed to stay in positive territory this year, returning 6.7 percent through Sept. 3, compared with 6.0 percent for the average specialized health care fund, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher, and 0.25 percent for the S.& P. health care index. For the three years ended Sept. 3, the fund returned 28.7 percent, annualized, versus 16.9 percent for its peers, according to Morningstar, and 32.5 percent for the index.
Vanguard closed the fund to new investors in February, when it hit $10 billion in assets, and has no plans to reopen it, a company spokesman, John Demming, said.
Mr. Owens takes a measured approach to health care investing. "I'm a very conservative, fundamentally oriented investor with a value approach to a growth sector of the economy," he said. The fund also maintains an unusually low turnover rate of 11 percent, far below that of the average health care fund.
Mr. Owens checks a computer program that shows relative valuation, price movement and other characteristics of 1,600 health care companies worldwide, but usually concentrates on corporate developments.
"I spend most of my time studying medical and trade journals and analyst reports," he said. "I don't have any hard 'sell' or 'buy' points."
And Mr. Owens asks many questions of companies' management. He meets with executives of three or four companies in his office each day, travels to others and sees 15 to 20 companies a day at four or five annual health care conferences. One focus is on research and development. "The drug pipeline is a leading indicator of changes in growth rates," he said. "You can see a company improving ahead of everything else if you see a pipeline that's big relative to the company's size."
He is not wedded to a particular measurement of value and looks at factors ranging from balance-sheet strength to price-to-earnings and price-to-cash-flow ratios.
ABOUT 21 percent of the fund is invested overseas, the high end of its historical range, including 9 percent in Japan, the highest level ever. "In the last three or four years, the Japanese F.D.A. tightened drug approval procedures and created a major slowdown in drug approvals," Mr. Owens said, referring to the Japanese equivalent of the United States Food and Drug Administration. "They're coming out of that now, and approvals will start to increase."
He bought Eisai, a Japanese drug company, in late 1998 and early 1999 at an average cost of $16 a share. "We think the pipeline will allow it to become a global pharmaceutical firm over the next decade," he said. Eisai brought to market Aricept, the first effective palliative for Alzheimer's, marketed with Pfizer, and has launched a new ulcer drug, Aciphex, marketed worldwide by Johnson & Johnson, he said. He expects annual earnings growth of 15 percent over the next three years. On Friday, the stock closed at 2,585 yen, or $23.7505, 33.9 times his 2000 earnings estimate of 70 cents a share.
In April, Mr. Owens increased fivefold his position in McKesson HBOC, the drug distributor based in San Francisco. McKesson's purchase in January of HBO, a health care information company, was a "disaster," he said, because financial results had to be restated as a result of accounting irregularities at HBO. That led to a big charge as well as the ouster of some top executives and pulled McKesson's price down to $32 a share by the end of April, from a high of $89.75 in January.
But he said that McKesson's distribution business is sound, and that, despite the problems, HBO remains a leading provider of health care information technology. "We think the reaction to the bad news was excessive, and over the next year or two the correct valuation will surface," he said, adding that he expected the share price to rise 30 to 50 percent in two years.
He estimates an earnings growth rate of 30 percent a year over three years. The stock is now at $34.125, 19 times his 2000 earnings estimate.
Mr. Owens recently added to his position in Monsanto, whose Searle division produces Celebrex, the first of a new class of arthritis drugs. "I think success with this drug will make them one of the better-performing drug companies over the next two years or so," he said. The company's agricultural division, which does work in genetics, is a worry for investors because of opposition to genetic engineering of crops. "We think the value of the stock is supported by the pharmaceutical division alone," he said.
He estimated annual earnings growth of 25 percent over three years. The stock closed on Friday at $38.0625, 29.3 times his 2000 earnings estimate of $1.30 a share.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
When an Expense Is Not an Expense

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
CORPORATE profits are surging this year, to the delight of those who thought a slowdown might crimp results at United States companies. Earnings at S. & P. 500 companies rose 10.5 percent in the first quarter, 14.7 percent in the second.
All the more remarkable, then, that corporate tax receipts are down this year from last. Through July, according to the Treasury, corporations paid $140.7 billion, 6.4 percent less than in the corresponding period last year. 
 Obviously, companies are reporting lower earnings to the Government than they are to their shareholders. Nothing new there. After all, tax accounting methods differ from those used to compile shareholder reports.
But the downturn in tax receipts is new. Corporate tax receipts have not dropped since 1983, and that was when the United States was shaking off a crippling recession. And the decline comes at a time when individual tax receipts are running 6.7 percent ahead of 1998.
Forget, for a moment, what the drop might say about how inflated the earnings reported to shareholders have come to be. What's behind the decline?
Corporate tax shelters are an explanation offered by Christopher E. Bergin, editor of the magazine Tax Notes, which published an article about falling tax receipts in late July. "Increasingly, U.S. corporations are looking at their tax departments as profit centers," he said. Once, tax staffers were ridiculed as numbers nerds; now they are revered.
Martin A. Sullivan, the economist who wrote the Tax Notes article, said that if the decline in taxes continues through the rest of fiscal 1999, which ends in September, overall taxes paid by American companies as a percentage of their profits would be about 19.9 percent, the lowest rate since 1984. Five years ago, corporations paid 24.6 percent of profits in taxes.
The trend may indicate "that corporate tax receipts are being adversely affected by corporate tax shelters," Mr. Sullivan said.
What sorts of shelters? Only the financial engineers know for sure. But Robert Willens, managing director at Lehman Brothers, said corporations could legitimately reduce their tax bills by structuring asset sales as tax-free exchanges and using government-bestowed tax credits, like the one benefiting companies with heavy research and development costs. And, the more income a company generates overseas and leaves there, the lower its tax bill.
But one of the biggest contributors to the falloff in tax receipts may be stock options.
Here's why: Under shareholder accounting, stock options are not considered an employee compensation expense, even though they clearly are. So companies that use them -- and rare is the publicly traded company that doesn't -- effectively overstate their earnings.
But for tax accounting purposes, when an employee exercises an option, the difference between that option's strike price and the prevailing market value of the underlying stock is an expense to the company that issued the option.
So the widespread use of options not only hypes corporate earnings, it cuts companies' tax bills and Treasury receipts. What a combination.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk
