HEADLINE: Airlines Prepare to Disclose Pledges of Customer Service

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The major airlines will disclose next week exactly what pledges of customer service they are making as part of a voluntary program they agreed to earlier this year to stave off Federal legislation on passenger rights.
Each airline is supposed to tell the Transportation Department by Wednesday how it will implement the voluntary plan. David Fuscus, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the big airlines' trade group, said that the airlines would probably post their plans on their Web sites soon. The promises are to take effect on Dec. 15. 
 Consumer advocates say they hope the plans will help travelers learn about their rights, even though some of the rights are not new.
A new study by the General Accounting Office says that many of the guarantees the airlines are expected to offer are already required by other laws, or are practices that are widely followed in the industry.
Other guarantees, while offered voluntarily, would become legally enforceable if published by the airlines, the G.A.O. said. The agency, an investigative arm of Congress, solicited an opinion from the Transportation Department, which regulates airlines. The Transportation Department said that failing to fulfill such promises -- concerning issues like offering the lowest available fare to a customer shopping for tickets, or responding to customer complaints -- would be an unfair trade practice.
By law, airlines must have copies of their legally binding contracts of carriage, the fine print that backs up an airplane ticket, available for inspection at ticket counters, but "most consumers don't even know what that is, or even ask for it," said one expert, Laurie J. Berger, the editor of the Consumer Reports Travel Letter, published by Consumers Union.
Earlier this year, some lawmakers tried to write this kind of guarantee into a new law, but the airlines sidestepped that move by telling Congress they would act voluntarily.
The new G.A.O. report, scheduled to be released on Monday, compares the voluntary agreement, announced in June by the Air Transport Association, with contracts of carriage and with pertinent Federal statutes and rules. It found that many of the new promises were not mentioned in the contracts of carriage, a point that had been raised by passenger rights advocates, who questioned whether the voluntary agreements are enforceable.
"If it is in the contract of carriage, a passenger can clearly bring a breach of contract case if a violation of the contract occurs," said a senior lawyer at the G.A.O., David K. Hooper.
But, Mr. Hooper added, "if they hold out a promise and renege on that promise, the Department of Transportation can go after them under unfair and deceptive trade practices statute."
Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who favored legislation and requested the G.A.O. report, said he was unhappy with the airlines' being allowed to write their own rules.
"What we've got here is scattershot gobbledygook," he said in a telephone interview on Friday. "Some airlines will do a better job than others, but it's going to take months to sort all of this out."
Among the 12 voluntary measures, the airlines are promising to make every reasonable effort to return checked bags within 24 hours. The issue is not addressed in contracts of carriage, but the Transportation Department said it would be unfair and deceptive not to deliver bags in a "reasonable" period of time, the G.A.O. reported.
Under the customer service commitment, airlines are also promising to disclose policies for accommodating the disabled. But Federal regulations already provide specific guarantees, the G.A.O. noted. The airlines are also promising to establish a policy for carrying children without their parents. Contracts of carriage already specify the minimum age for unaccompanied minors (5 years old) and set conditions for nonstop and connecting flights, the G.A.O. said.
Airlines are also promising to inform customers about delays, cancellations and diversions in a timely manner. The issue is not addressed in the contracts of carriage, the G.A.O. found. But the report said that according to the Transportation Department, it would be an unfair practice to say that a flight was canceled because of weather or mechanical breakdown if it was actually canceled for economic reasons like a lack of passengers.
Some items in the customer service plan are new, like allowing customers to hold a reservation while they shop for better deals.
Mr. Wyden said that the voluntary commitments left out some rights he would like to establish for fliers. "The one that concerns me the most is, if you call this afternoon and they're overbooked, they won't tell you that before they sell you a ticket," he said. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 609 words

HEADLINE: America's Unmet Obligation

 BODY:
Though rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Al Gore and Bill Bradley are both trying to restore a shamefully neglected issue to its rightful place at the forefront of public debate. The issue is health insurance -- specifically, this country's grievous failure to provide coverage for nearly one-sixth of its population.
Many politicians -- and public attention -- have turned from this issue ever since President Clinton's proposal for universal health coverage crashed in 1993, a victim of political mismanagement. But the problem has not gone away, and remains a vivid and embarrassing rebuke to American democracy. As Mr. Bradley observed last week in announcing his candidacy, "While kings and dictators come to this country for the best health care treatment in the world, you and I both know that this care is not available to the 45 million citizens who have no health insurance at all." 
 Indeed, as Congress bickers over regulating health maintenance organizations, and otherwise seeks to improve the system for people who do have health insurance, the plight of those who do not have insurance gets worse by the day. Despite an extraordinary economic boom and an unemployment rate that is at the lowest level in more than 25 years, the number of uninsured Americans has steadily risen by about one million a year over the past decade. This number will probably continue to rise as more children are born, more Americans switch from manufacturing jobs that provide insurance to service jobs that do not, and more Americans leave the welfare system, which provides health benefits.
Mr. Bradley has yet to propose a specific program, although he is expected to soon. Mr. Gore is further down the programmatic road, having last week unveiled a plan to provide health insurance for 11 million to 15 million uncovered Americans, mostly children. The proposal is modest compared with Mr. Clinton's original plan to guarantee health insurance for everyone. Mr. Gore's rationale for not being more ambitious is that "we have all learned that we cannot overhaul the system in one fell swoop." He also notes that his program seeks to cover one of the most vulnerable segments of the population.
The centerpiece of the plan would expand the Children's Health Insurance Program, a Federally subsidized state-run program created in 1997 that helps insure children in families earning up to about $33,000 a year for four people. Mr. Gore would raise that income ceiling so that families earning 2.5 times the official poverty level, or about $41,000, could qualify. The program would also allow uninsured parents of children who are eligible for Medicaid or CHIP to buy subsidized insurance for themselves, and in various ways would encourage states to seek out and enroll every child who may be eligible.
Constructive as they are, Mr. Gore's ideas will still leave some 30 million Americans without any real help. Most of these are working poor adults, including a disproportionate number of minorities. Mr. Gore may be right when he suggests that after the Clinton debacle in 1993, only an incremental approach will pass muster with Congress and the country. It may also be true that if he and Mr. Bradley continue to push health care to the front of their campaigns, the opportunity may come around again to force Congress to take a more sweeping approach. But for now, these Democratic rivals have helped put the question of universal health care back on the national agenda and, in so doing, have reminded everyone of America's unmet obligation to 45 million people for whom a medical setback could mean financial ruin.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Some Optional Ephemera

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
When Jerre L. Stead, chief executive of Ingram Micro, the world's largest computer distributor, says he was hoping that his stock options would be worth $100 million, he's unusual only in acknowledging an ambition that other chief executives keep to themselves. Mr. Stead was even more unusual in forgoing any salary since his hiring in 1996 to get even more options.
But his options, to buy shares at $18, have little immediate value now; the shares closed last week at $15.9375. 
 Mr. Stead, 57, says he has always planned to give away all his options wealth. He has assigned blocks of options to each of his four grandchildren. He plans to give the rest to causes including homeless relief, research into Alzheimer's disease (his mother's ailment) and the economic development of Maquoketa, Iowa, where he and his wife, Mary Jo, grew up. He also plans to support the Center for Ethics and Values at Northwestern University, where he teaches occasionally; the University of Iowa, his alma mater, and some Presbyterian and Methodist church projects.
"We never planned to spend the money," Mr. Stead said last week. "Mary Jo and I lived on $2,800 a year in a 40-foot trailer when we were in college."
A year ago, with Ingram's stock at $54 a share, Mr. Stead's options were worth $126 million. Last week, the stock's slide accelerated after the company announced a gloomy outlook and Mr. Stead's decision to step down as chief executive, though he will remain chairman.
Mr. Stead, professionally upbeat, with cards that read "coach" rather than "chief executive," says that his options have not expired and that the stock and the company will rebound.
In any case, he won't go begging. At the Legent Corporation, his former employer, he pocketed $15 million from options. SAUL HANSELL

HEADLINE: The Price of Low Inflation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Inflation? It Just Doesn't Add Up" (Economic View, Aug. 22), Sylvia Nasar looked at reasons the American economy is unlikely to return to the "bad old days" of high inflation rates. She noted how a study suggested "that a host of small, incremental changes -- including the decline of unions, the growing of temporary help firms, even welfare reform -- have made the labor market more efficient." 
 But so-called efficient wages are really stagnant wages, as employers have kept down labor costs as their dominant strategy to increase profits.
Even during good economic times, American companies have been downsizing, offering lower wage increases or eliminating cost-of-living increases, cutting health care and pension benefits, outsourcing and generally building an army of low-wage, low-benefit workers.
What are efficient wages to employers, and possibly to economists, are not efficient to American families, who now need two breadwinners just to get by. There is a hint of "let them eat cake" in much of today's economic writing.
 
LOUIS COHEN, Ph.D.
Manhattan, Aug. 24

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Student Aid

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry and Purchase College have each received $800,000 grants from the United States Department of Education to begin a four-year program for high school students "of diverse economic and educational backgrounds." Known as Upward Bound, the program will provide students with additional academic support so they are more likely to complete high school and pursue post-secondary educations.
Westchester's first Upward Bound program will include 80 high school students from Sleepy Hollow and Yonkers, the colleges said. Beverly Army Gillen, a Mercy College spokeswoman, said the program would offer students academic enrichment, mentoring and tutoring assistance in math, science, literature and foreign languages. 
 Also, students will take part in six-week summer residential programs at the colleges.
Nationally, only 183 Upward Bound grants were awarded among a pool of 942 applicants, Wendy Serkin, a Purchase College spokeswoman, said. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: From Defending Big Tobacco to Fighting Ford Motor for a Lone Client

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 11

 BODY:
When C. Mark Pickrell was an associate at a big New York law firm three years ago, helping to defend a large cigarette company against anti-smoking lawsuits filed by Mississippi and New Jersey, a colleague nicknamed him Brimstone, joking that he would surely go to hell for having represented Big Tobacco.
Now Mr. Pickrell is in another courtroom struggle, fighting a big corporation, not defending one. 
 He is representing a one-man Internet newsletter against a lawsuit filed by the Ford Motor Company. And using skills developed in legal battles over smoking, he is trying to start a legal war over whether Detroit auto makers colluded to avoid the expense of manufacturing sport utility vehicles that might produce less air pollution while getting better fuel economy.
Mr. Pickrell sees many parallels between his former legal work and the current lawsuit. "As I look at it, I keep saying, 'It's like tobacco.' " Mr. Pickrell said. "The similarities that I've seen are unbelievable."
Ford officials declined to comment on any issue regarding the litigation with Mr. Pickrell's client, Robert Lane, any antitrust issues or any comparisons between smoking and sport utility vehicle issues. Auto industry officials in the past have dismissed suggestions of collusion.
Mr. Pickrell has won the first round in his fight. Ford had sought a preliminary injunction against Mr. Lane, who operates the Internet site, www.blueovalnews.com, which provides news on Ford vehicles for auto enthusiasts. The injunction would have prevented Mr. Lane from using, copying or discussing boxes full of internal Ford documents that someone had mailed him anonymously. But a Federal judge turned down most of Ford's request last Tuesday, saying that the free-speech provision of the First Amendment protected Mr. Lane. Mr. Pickrell, who is the sole lawyer in his law office in Nashville, heard about the lawsuit from a friend on Aug. 27, a Friday. He sent Mr. Lane a fax that afternoon, offering his legal services for a nominal fee. Mr. Lane called back that evening to say that he was due in Federal court in Detroit for a hearing the following Monday morning and did not have a lawyer.
Mr. Lane, a 33-year-old nursing student who lives several blocks from Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., could not afford to pay for a last-minute, full-fare airline ticket to Detroit for Mr. Pickrell. But Mr. Lane is married to a flight attendant for Northwest Airlines, who sent Mr. Pickrell a so-called "buddy pass" to allow him to buy a very cheap ticket at a rate available only to friends of airline personnel.
Arriving in Detroit on Sunday morning, Mr. Pickrell, also 33, spent all day and night looking up legal precedents on CD-ROM's and electronic data bases on his laptop, drafting a legal brief and making photocopies at a Kinko's store. Mr. Lane said that the two men were able to talk for only 15 minutes about what he would say on the witness stand.
"He said to me, 'Whatever you do, don't lie,' " Mr. Lane recalled.
One of the Ford lawyers mentioned in the hearing that what had really upset Ford was Mr. Lane's posting on his Internet site of internal Ford documents relating to the Environmental Protection Agency.
Mr. Pickrell contended that the lawyer's comment showed Mr. Lane should be treated legally not as someone who recklessly disregarded trade secrets and copyrights, as Ford asserted. but rather as a journalist who had been gathering news about a public policy issue involving the environment.
Even before the judge ruled in Mr. Lane's favor, Ford's lawyers had demanded from Mr. Pickrell extensive information about the contents and source of the documents in Mr. Lane's possession. Mr. Pickrell has responded by asking Ford for extensive documents regarding its discussions with competitors and the Environmental Protection Agency regarding air pollution technologies and regulations.
While representing Brown & Williamson, a large cigarette company, Mr. Pickrell had learned a lot about the issue of whether tobacco companies deliberately avoided selling cigarettes that would emit fewer carcinogens. R. J. Reynolds broke ranks with other tobacco companies in 1988 when it began marketing the Premier as a "safer" cigarette. While the Premier was a failure in the marketplace, plaintiff lawyers responded to it by saying that the product showed that less dangerous cigarettes had long been possible.
With this legal background, Mr. Pickrell said that during the current lawsuit he immediately became interested in Ford's decision 21 months ago to break ranks with other auto makers and redesign all of its sport utility vehicles to emit as little air pollution as cars. Federal regulations allow sport utility vehicles to emit two to three times as much pollution per mile as cars.
Some top auto executives have suggested that Ford broke a "gentleman's agreement" among Detroit auto makers not to compete on who could build the least polluting vehicles. While Japanese auto makers have done well in the American car market, Detroit completely dominated the sport utility vehicle market until the last couple years.
By coincidence, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, read a news report in May mentioning auto industry cooperation and wrote a letter to the Justice Department urging an anti-trust investigation into whether auto makers had conspired not to install pollution-control equipment, particularly on sport utility vehicles. Mr. Nader became famous in the 1960's partly for persuading the Johnson Administration to file an identical anti-trust lawsuit then accusing Detroit auto makers of conspiring not to develop or install pollution-control gear; the consent decree from that case expired during the Reagan Administration.
Jennifer Rose, a Justice Department spokeswoman, said that the agency was preparing a response to Mr. Nader's letter, but she declined to elaborate.
Ford documents briefly posted this summer on Mr. Lane's Internet site show that the auto maker is working on improvements in pollution and fuel economy. One document, for example, projected that the fuel economy of Ford Explorer and Mercury Mountaineer sport utility vehicles could be improved by 26 percent over the next decade. But the documents gave no indication of the cost or feasibility of such a change.

HEADLINE: Russians Say Bank Scheme May Not Be What It Seems

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN and MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Irritated by allegations of money laundering, some of Russia's leading businessmen insist that the West has overlooked a simpler explanation for the billions of dollars that have flowed through several suspicious accounts at the Bank of New York.
While acknowledging that some Russian money stashed abroad may have been gained from organized crime or other criminal activity, they suggest that many of the thousands of transactions now under investigation can be attributed to Russian importers engaged in old games of dodging Russian tariffs and taxes. 
 The businessmen agree that laws may have been broken, but insist that they were Russian, not foreign, laws. A government was cheated, they say, but it was the discredited Russian administration, not the United States Government or the International Monetary Fund. And yes, funds were used in dubious ways to buy goods, but it was furniture, food and electronics for consumers.
There is no question that these businessmen have their own motives in touting this explanation. They want to remove the taint of money laundering and organized crime that has cast a cloud over all Russian companies, legitimate and corrupt.
Still, in the context of Russia's chaotic economy and get-rich-quick approach to capitalism, their explanations appear largely plausible, if incomplete.
This week, in interviews with foreign and Russian reporters, businessmen described schemes that break or bend Russian law, but are nonetheless common in an economy in which many in business have learned to cheat the Government. Whenever possible, these businessmen say, profits are kept or taken abroad, and companies like Benex -- which is thought to have moved billions of dollars through the Bank of New York -- are essential to that process.
"No one is saying Benex was not partly criminal," said Yuliya Latynina, a respected financial journalist who has written several articles on the subject this week. "But it was a service that anyone could use, Russian companies or just ordinary people. It was very, very important for the importers."
According to one leading businessman, who says he has looked into the practice, the scheme, in its simplest form, works like this:
A Russian importer buys water at $3 a bottle from a foreign supplier. But to avoid a heavy tariff, he draws up an official contract setting the price at $1. The remaining $2 a bottle is paid under the table using fictitious shell companies and foreign accounts like Benex, which carry out wire transfers.
Schemes to transfer undeclared profits and payments out of Russia have been an open secret since the country plunged headfirst into free-market capitalism in the early 1990's.
They were developed by importers who first fed Russia's pent-up appetite for the Western consumer goods and quickly set about ways to duck rigid customs duties. These duties are not only high but unpredictable, changing profit levels with one stroke of a bureaucrat's pen.
Such schemes to shift or keep capital abroad may also have been used, even set up, by organized crime groups, many of which are linked with Russian importers. In the early 1990's, in the absence of any civil court and credible banks, such importers were extremely vulnerable to racketeers.
At this point, the businessmen say, only the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the people behind the Benex scheme can make an accurate accounting of where money came from and where it went, and they are not talking. Russians concede, however, that the amount of money passing through the mysterious accounts is huge.
"An awful lot of people in this town are afraid of this story," one leading Russian banker said.
One Russian businessman, who said he had looked into the allegations, said a total of $6.3 billion had passed through the mysterious accounts maintained by Benex and similarly murky organizations, like Lowland, and Becs, over the last four years. The newspaper Kommersant, citing its own sources, estimated the sums passing through these firms at $9 billion.
Reports in the United States have stated that $4.2 billion to $10 billion passed through Benex accounts over an 18-month period.
Since imports ran at $60 billion last year, and are estimated at up to $50 billion this year, the sums are credible, some analysts say.
But Benex clearly has other uses.
Russia's major banks, eager to dodge creditors after the August 1998 financial crash, may have used clearinghouse accounts like Benex to take money out of Russia, the analysts say.
"They had experienced people who targeted this niche," the banker said, so that after August 1998, they were the only ones with a reputation to pick up where the pseudo-bankrupt banks left off."
Others used Benex to get money into Russia. One foreign businessman in Moscow, who said he had contacted a service recommended by a business associate, said his company had transferred $70,000 through Benex from the United States. He said he had used the service when his own accounts in a Moscow bank were frozen during the financial crisis and he desperately needed dollars.
"I don't consider myself a money launderer, but I used the service because it was recommended to me as trustworthy," he said. "They only charged a 1.8 percent commission, compared with the 3 percent I had been paying at my bank."
Other banks, scouring their accounts, also turned up odd payments made through Benex. An official at Menatep, a major bank that has frequently been mentioned in connection with the Bank of New York scandal, said that an internal audit showed that $12 million had been paid through Benex, used exclusively to buy apartments in Moscow. Given the size of Menatep's banking business, the amount was relatively small, he said.
The Benex accounts may also have been used by Russians looking for a safe haven for their money and an alternative to a banking system that has all but collapsed.
According to a study by Canadian and Russian economic institutes, capital flight from Russia totaled about $130 billion from 1992 to 1998. It continues at a rate of up to $2 billion a month, according to economists here.
About a third of the capital flight, the study concluded, was legal. Demand for services enabling the flight was large, and the access to them, while a tightly held secret, was relatively easy for those with the right contacts.
"Russian businessmen have an almost pathological desire to keep their money abroad because they feel uneasy about keeping it here," said Aleksandr Lebedev, the chairman of the National Reserve Bank and a leader in the Our Home Is Russia party of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, a former Prime Minister and the chairman of the vast Gazprom concern. "Criminal money is not the lion's share. Most of the money leaving the country is legal, but for a lot of businesses, it is not easy to find a way to do it, so they are eager to find someone who can offer them a service."
Several businessmen, fearing that the practices of importers and other businesses will tarnish everyone, have criticized the Government for failing to conduct a vigorous and public investigation of the root causes of the Bank of New York scandal. "The Russian Government has to understand that this mess has to be cleaned up," Mr. Lebedev said. "But if the scandal succeeds in pushing money out of foreign banks, back to Russia, then it will be a good thing."
But some importers say that unless Russia's tax and customs laws are overhauled, they and their competitors could not survive without the kind of services that Benex and other brokers offer.
"If I obeyed the law I would pay $110,000 for a shipment of goods instead of $70,000," said one thriving importer who explained a tax-dodging scheme similar to the one ascribed to Benex. "There is no way I could do business. I would be undercut by all my competitors."
Another importer, an appliance wholesaler, said the scheme was carried out with a network of dummy companies, banks and the connivance of corrupt Government officials.
This importer faced customs duties and value added taxes totaling 60 percent of the value of the goods he bought. So instead of paying for the goods with an aboveboard contract, he turned to a broker who specialized in under-the-table money transfers.
The broker works regularly with two or three Russian banks, which the importer said sets up dummy companies whose sole function is to transfer money abroad. The dummy companies transfer money to accounts like Benex or directly to the supplier.
Typically, the dummy companies have a life span of three months, declaring bankruptcy just when they are required by Russian law to declare their earnings. No sooner does one company die than another is born -- sometimes registered in the name of people who have lost their passports, or alcoholics who have sold their passports for a drink, the wholesaler said. The final touch is added by the collusion of Government bureaucrats, the importer said.
"You have bureaucrats who dreamed up laws that are all but impossible to adhere to, and then you have bureaucrats who are supposed to implement the laws," he said. "The latter helps people find a way around the laws, in collusion with the former."

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND JIANG HEAL RIFT AND SET NEW TRADE COURSE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sunday, Sept. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton and China's leader, Jiang Zemin, declared an end on Saturday to months of frozen relations following the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, and their trade ministers began meeting this morning in hopes of closing a broad deal that would get China into the World Trade Organization this year.
Both American and Chinese officials emerged from the two leaders' hourlong meeting, on the fringes of the annual Asian economic summit conference here, brimming with confident assessments of the encounter. It was the first between the two leaders in more than a year. 
 Chinese officials appeared particularly pleased that Mr. Clinton had been openly critical of President Lee Teng Hui of Taiwan for his statements this summer that described the island as a separate state.
Mr. Clinton, according to his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, told President Jiang that Mr. Lee "had made things more difficult for both China and the United States" with his comments, which appeared to inch Taiwan toward independence. But Mr. Berger said Mr. Clinton had repeated a warning that if China resorted to military force against Taiwan "there would be grave consequences in the United States."
Much of the meeting was consumed with discussion of the final deal to usher China into the World Trade Organization, membership in which would give the Chinese prestige and protection from economic sanctions and trade disputes.
Mr. Clinton walked away from a deal in April, during a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, but soon came to regret the decision.
By all indications, any final deal negotiated in coming days or weeks is likely to resemble closely the offers to open markets that Mr. Clinton judged insufficient five months ago. The soured political atmosphere between the two countries appears to have affected the White House assessment of what constitutes a good deal.
After the accidental embassy bombing, which killed three Chinese, and charges of nuclear spying by the Chinese in American weapons laboratories, Mr. Clinton's aides apparently view the trade accord as the one concrete step they can take to begin to repair relations.
The issue now is how quickly a deal can be struck. The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, was negotiating today with her Chinese counterpart on the three big remaining differences: automobiles, textiles and the rules that prevent Chinese industry from "dumping" products in the United States at below-market prices.
"With the dose of political will, this is stuff that can be worked out in two days," an American official said.
But Mr. Clinton's national economic adviser, Gene Sperling, cautioned against expecting an agreement while the two leaders are in New Zealand for the summit meeting and simultaneous state visits.
"I think that there's enough issues that are on the table that I would not have significant expectations over the next several days," Mr. Sperling said.
China's spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, also declined to estimate how long the negotiations might take.
"China will never accept terms that exceed the economic capacity of the country," he said, a reference to the fear in China that opening markets at a time of severe economic downturn would worsen unemployment and deflation.
"As long as the United States is flexible, I don't think the accession will be that difficult," he said, using the term for the process of joining the trade organization. "But if the U.S. persists in its high demands, that will be difficult."
For the United States, the advantage of an agreement is straightforward: All the concessions and reductions of trade barriers come from the Chinese, with none from Washington. For China, membership is a mixed bag. While it must agree to open its highly protected markets to foreign competition, as a member of the trade group it would gain protection against unilateral sanctions by all of its trading partners. Disputes would go to the World Trade Organization's court, and China would be able to challenge efforts by the United States and others to restrict imports of its goods.
Completing the deal is likely to prove politically difficult in both countries. At a time of growing economic troubles in China, Mr. Jiang risks accusations that he is allowing the world's most powerful economy too much access to China's markets. The complaints have been particularly strong in the telecommunications industry because the deal proposed in April would allow foreign companies to own a majority share of Chinese cellular telephone concerns.
Mr. Clinton must worry about a possible revolt in his own party, one that would particularly hurt Vice President Al Gore's candidacy for next year's Presidential race. Labor unions have already protested White House trade policy, and some have withheld endorsements of Mr. Gore.
Some of the country's biggest unions say they will actively oppose any trade deal with China. They are particularly incensed about China's insistence that the United States agree to curb its powers to act unilaterally against dumping. China is already at the center of several dumping charges.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Jiang went into detail about those problems at the Saturday session, according to officials who were present. They left the hard bargaining to the trade negotiators.
"The leaders would step in only to resolve serious logjams," a Clinton aide said.
Mr. Jiang seemed particularly eager to score points at Taiwan's expense, telling Mr. Clinton, according to Mr. Berger, that the the island's status was "the most important" of the questions Mr. Clinton raised. At a photo session as the two leaders were sitting down, Mr. Jiang said in response to a reporter's question that "if there were to be any foreign intervention, or if there were to be Taiwan independence, then we would not undertake to renounce the use of force."
Apparently in an effort to defuse Chinese suspicions that the United States was behind Mr. Lee's statements that talks between Taiwan and the mainland should constitute "state-to-state relations," Mr. Clinton insisted that American policy toward Taiwan had not changed. The United States has recognized only one China since President Nixon's opening to Beijing a quarter of a century ago.
"We favor one China," Mr. Clinton said in the presence of reporters, eager to show he was not diverting from the policy of Democrats and Republicans before him. "We favor a peaceful approach to working out our differences."
Mr. Jiang urged Mr. Clinton to stop arms sales to Taiwan, particularly recent sales intended to counter growing missile threats to the country. Mr. Clinton declined, citing the requirements of the Taiwan Relations Act.
Mr. Clinton briefly raised human rights concerns, and Mr. Jiang responded by describing the recent crackdown on Falun Gong, a religious group that has attracted a huge following. Mr. Jiang called Falun Gong "a cult," and gave Mr. Clinton some books about it. Presumably they were officially sanctioned volumes that disparaged a group that was banned in July.
This morning, in his first detailed discussion of Asia's blossoming recovery from a two-year economic crisis, Mr. Clinton warned that many of the financial reforms that seemed so urgent a year ago had been quietly abandoned.
"This is not a time for complacency," he told an audience of chief executives of American and Asian companies. He called on the leaders here, who represent nearly half the world's economic activity and more than half its population, to endorse a series of free-trade initiatives that will be negotiated as part of a new global round of trade talks that begin in Seattle in December.

HEADLINE: Why Are We Working So Much?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Americans Lead the World in Hours Worked" (Business Day, Sept. 7): 
 You say that "increasingly efficient Europeans and Japanese workers are chipping away at the United States lead in productivity -- the amount of goods and services produced for each hour worked," implying that American workers are more productive per hour worked. Yet the numbers you report from the International Labor Organization study indicate otherwise.
American workers may produce more in a year, but their productivity is not greater in terms of output per hour worked. Compare the average total of $49,905 of goods per worker produced in the United States divided by the average 1,966 hours worked (for an average of $25.38 worth of goods produced per worker) with $46,100 for Germany divided by 1,560 hours worked (for an average of $29.55 worth of goods per worker).
 
STEPHAN KROLL
Canton, N.Y., Sept. 7, 1999
 
The writer is a visiting assistant professor of economics at St. Lawrence University.

HEADLINE: The State, as Seen by Centuries of Tourists

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
THERE is a certain voyeuristic thrill in eavesdropping on people who are talking about us, especially when we learn that most of them really do like us after all. Now, a new book that reprints the writings of people who have traveled through the state since the 17th century shows that outsiders, from common folks to statesmen, have long been impressed, and sometimes unimpressed, with Connecticut.
The outspoken opinions of a Boston woman who traveled on horseback through coastal Connecticut in 1704; the musings of John Adams, seeking to restore his health by drinking the spring waters at Stafford in 1771, two decades before becoming President of the United States; the enthusiasm of a 19th century Englishman upon visiting the new factories of the Naugatuck Valley -- these are some of the first-hand accounts of travelers to the state, featured in a new book "Connecticut Observed: Three Centuries of Visitors' Impressions 1676-1940." Published by the Acorn Club, founded in 1899 to publish books about Connecticut history, in conjunction with the Connecticut Humanities Council which provided half the funding, the anthology introduces excerpts from the diaries of 18 visitors from other parts of the country and from Europe. 
 The writers comment on the geography, people, traditions and institutions that have shaped the state's identity, from descriptions of the primitive and wild landscapes of early colonial days to observations on the economic and social problems of Connecticut on the eve of World War II.
"It's a good snapshot of what was going on in Connecticut over the past 300 years," said Richard Buel Jr., professor of history on leave from Wesleyan University. "If you want a quick, enjoyable primer on the colony's and the state's past, this is a good way to get it."
Mr. Buel was co-editor of the book with J. Bard McNulty, emeritus professor of English at Trinity College. Both men are long-time members of the Acorn Club, an institution limited to 25 people whose major qualification for membership is an abiding interest in Connecticut history.
The project originated with a bibliography compiled by Christopher Bickford, former director of the Connecticut Historical Society, who recommended that the club assemble an anthology of the best of the travel literature available in the society's collection and in other libraries. The entire club took part in a preliminary review of the bibliography, chose the accounts that seemed most interesting and appointed committees to cut the list to 18 entries from the original 150.
"We wanted to give a sense of the development of the colony and the state in each of the particular periods covered by the anthology: the colonial period, the Revolutionary era, pre-Civil War, post-Civil War and the 20th century," Mr. Buel said.
The earliest visitors, residents of more developed areas like Boston, New York or European cities, tended to look down on Connecticut as a rustic, primitive place.
In 1676 an English traveler named William Edmundson described the area between New London and Hartford as "a great wilderness, and very dangerous to travel, the Indians being in arms," while Sarah Kemble Knight, the spirited Bostonian who journeyed to New Haven in 1704 to settle a cousin's estate, wrote that "the Roads all along this way are very bad, encumbered with Rocks and mountainous passages, which are very disagreeable to my tired carcass."
The religious fervor of the colony's early inhabitants met with criticism on the part of several visitors. Passing through Connecticut on a tour of New England in 1744, Alexander Hamilton, a Scottish-born physician residing in Maryland and not the future Secretary of the Treasury, commented on a group of residents of Saybrook who "fell to disputing upon points of divinity as learnedly as if they had been professional theologues. 'Tis strange to see how this humor prevails, even among the lower class of the people here. They will talk so pointedly about justification, sanctification . . . original sin and a thousand other such pretty, chimerical knick knacks as if they had nothing but studied divinity all their life time."
Conversely, John Adams, whose journal entries reveal a thoughtful, compassionate man, found much to praise during his restorative weeks in Connecticut in 1771.
"The place where I now sit has the command of a great view," he writes from Stafford, ". . . and here is a fine spacious road laid out very wide and of great length and quite straight, which lies right before me now, with the Meeting House in the middle of it, more than half a mile off."
Even during the Revolution, which is barely mentioned in the accounts, visitors commented on the beauty of the countryside, as well as on the rigid religious beliefs of the colony's residents. "Here we are in the center of Connecticut, whose inhabitants are bigoted and strict in their tenets," writes Elbridge Gerry Jr., son of the governor of Massachusetts, deploring the fact that traveling was prohibited on Sunday.
More temperate comments on laws governing the Sabbath appear in the memoirs of Captain Jean-Francois Landolphe, captain of a French vessel that was frozen in New London harbor during the notorious winter of 1779-80. He was finally able to sail back to France by having his sailors saw the ship out of the ice.
Visitors in the 19th century described the state's major cities, New Haven and Hartford, which were co-capitals until 1873, taking notice of the many new churches, the universities such as Yale and of pioneering institutions like Hartford's Retreat for the Insane and the Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb. Anne Newport Royall, a prolific journalist and author, described it in 1826 as "the glory of Hartford, and indeed of the United States."
By the late 1800's, it was the state's thriving industrial factories that were the focus of visitors' comments. Daniel Pidgeon, an English engineer, came to the state in 1883 "with the intention of visiting some of the Naugatuck and Housatonic factories, and of seeing how the homes of labor in New England differ from those of Old England."
In a 20-page excerpt from the book he wrote on his return, Mr. Pidgeon discusses the relationship between water power and industrial development, the role of interchangeable parts in manufacturing and every aspect of the industrial revolution in Connecticut.
He lauds the fine brick buildings.
"One scarcely knew in the distance whether they were factories or castles," he writes, describing the workers dining-rooms -- "very clean, well furnished . . . set with small, separate tables" -- the sprinkler systems, the "girls' toilet-rooms" and especially the machines: "pulsating and quasi-living beings," he calls a pin-making device.
While Pidgeon saw no drawbacks to the coming of industrialization, the last selection, written in 1940 by a journalist from North Carolina, emphasizes the darker side of the economic changes that had transformed the state.
Touring Connecticut for the first time to gather material for a book, Jonathan Daniels heard of factories closing and of businesses moving south. Jobs, in the waning days of the Great Depression, were hard to find and there was tension among the various ethnic groups of the labor force -- the very workers who had immigrated from Europe to do the work of the Industrial Revolution.
Written with insight and sensitivity, the account portrays a world that is still recognizable: a Connecticut of suburbs and cities, of rich and poor, of "the stone walls, the white houses with the green blinds, the churches and their spires, and the Common and the Town Hall," as well as "the back porches of tenements not lovely to behold."
 
For more information on "Connecticut Observed" call the Connecticut Humanities Council at (860) 685-2260.

Chart: "What's the Word on Connecticut?"
The following are excerpts from "Connecticut Observed: Three Centuries of Visitors' Impressions 1676-1940."
 
Johan Adams, who became the second President of the United States, became ill in 1771 and traveled to Stafford (below) to visit its springs, which had a reputation for restorative powers. After three days there, he went on to explore more of Connecticut.
 "The place where I now sit has the command of a great view," he writes from Stafford, "... and here is a fine spacious road laid out very wide and of great length and quite straight, which lies right before me now, with the Meeting House in the middle of it, more than half a mile off."
 
Wearying of the waters and of "sauntering about" the neighborhood on his horse, he decided to explore the Connecticut River Valley.
"The State House is pretty large, and looks well," he writes of Hartford, where he stopped to "get my head and face shaved," and he finds Middletown "the most beautiful town of all." But his most impassioned words are reserved for the stretch of road between Hartford and Wethersfield.
 "I have spent the morning in riding through paradise. Nothing can exceed the beauty and the fertility of the country. The lands upon the river, the flat low lands, are loaded with rich, noble crops of grass, and grain, and corn."
 
 
Daniel Pidgeon, an English engineer, toured the factories of New England in 1883. He stopped in an Ansonia to visit it spin and telegraph wire factories and the clock factories of Waterbury. Below, the Scovill Manufacturing Co. in Waterbury.
 "One scarcely knew in the distance whether they were factories or castles," he writes, describing the workers diningrooms - "very clean, well furnished ... set with small, separate tables" - the sprinkler systems, the "girls' toilet-rooms" and especially the machines: "pulsating and quasi-living beings," he calls a pin-making device. Effusive as he is about the mills, it is the "Connecticut mechanic" for whom he reserves his highet praise.
 "This remarkable character, who, more than any other person or circumstance, has given its distinctive features to American manufacturer, is a figure of so much industrial importance that we cannot make his acquaintance one moment too soon. His natural bent is strongly towards mechanical pursuits, and he finds his way, very early in life, into the workshop ... whatever be the work on which he is engaged, (he) bends the whole force of an acute but narrow intelligence to scheming means for accomplishing it easily. ... The workshops of Massachusetts, Rhode Island and, especially, of Connecticut are full of such men."

HEADLINE: Homely Virtues

BYLINE: By David Glenn; David Glenn, who contributes to Dissent and Lingua Franca, is writing a book about the city of Milwaukee and the American social contract.

 BODY:

FOR COMMON THINGS
 Irony, Trust, and Commitment
 in America Today
 By Jedediah Purdy.
 226 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $20. 
 NINETEEN SEVENTY-FOUR was a grim year for American public life. The Nixon White House was tottering through its last act. The huge civic hopes of the mid-1960's were long since dead, and into the resulting void had come private comforts of all kinds: jogging, yoga, quadraphonic stereo systems. That year pollsters found that the number of Americans who trust the Federal Government to "do what is right" most of the time had dropped from 53 percent to 38 percent. (It has never exceeded 44 percent since.)
But 1974 was also a time when American social movements, both left-wing and right, were rejuvenating public life through many hundreds of small-scale, local projects. Is there a food co-op or a battered women's shelter in your town? Odds are it was founded within a few years of 1974. This was the era when the political engagement of evangelical churches first bloomed, and also when caravans of exhausted urban new leftists trekked into Vermont and northern California, hoping to begin self-sufficient new communities in the spirit of Thoreau.
Jedediah Purdy is a child of this second 1974. He was born that year in West Virginia, shortly after his parents moved there to farm and (in his father's words) "to pick out a small corner of the world and make it as sane as possible." He was raised in a milieu of craftspeople and environmentalists, and was schooled at home by his parents before going on to Phillips Exeter and Harvard. In "For Common Things," Purdy argues that if we want to heal our national malaise, we should look toward the civic virtues of his parents' world: attentiveness, honesty, devotion to place.
Purdy begins with a description of the malaise. We have become a nation of small-souled ironists, allergic to "cleaving to demanding values, or respecting them in others." Even our cynicism about Washington is narrow and passionless. And our various withdrawals have placed us in peril: "Our private lives -- our work, our families, our circles of friends -- are pervasively affected by things that can never be private: law and political institutions, economics and culture. We ignore these essentially public matters at the risk of misunderstanding our own well-being."
The potential remedies? Purdy warns us against the "therapeutic politics" represented by President Clinton's various task forces. (On this point he is nicely -- and uncharacteristically -- blunt: "This President has made a practice of catching the public's eye by doing very little with great moral gravity.") He also warns against any revival of the "Promethean politics" represented by fascism and revolutionary socialism. Instead, we should learn from nonutopian reformers like . . . his West Virginia parents, whom he convincingly portrays as dogged and effective school and ecological activists. Theirs is "a politics not so much of transformation as of maintenance, of tending to human possibilities more than radically reworking them."
All of this is argued soundly enough. Sometimes, though, Purdy seems not to have absorbed his own lessons. He praises Vaclav Havel and the Polish dissident Adam Michnik for having made adjustments to the politics of banality and compromise in their newly democratic societies -- that is, for not having clung too long to the heroic mode of politics that they embodied under Stalinism. But 30 pages later, in a discussion of strip mining in West Virginia, Purdy frowns at the reformist proposal for a carbon tax that would help to mitigate the consequences of the coal industry's ecological crimes. He calls the carbon tax a "good idea," but worries that its advocates are too glib, too much like "optimistic bureaucrats." The situation requires "a more severe gaze." This passage is easy to applaud -- who isn't repulsed by glib progressive rhetoric? -- but it seems more hollow the more one looks at it. For Purdy doesn't offer a pragmatic critique of the carbon tax, and he doesn't explore whether populist social movements might directly challenge the coal industry's power. Boiled down, the passage tells us only that Purdy dislikes cant and admires honesty and severity. But this particular posture is awfully close to turning up one's nose at the everyday banalities and frustrations of political life, exactly as Havel and Michnik warn we must not do.
Purdy has exactly the right heroes: Czeslaw Milosz, Albert Camus, George Orwell. He worries about fundamental and difficult problems, and he has smart questions to ask. So it is with real sorrow that I report: "For Common Things" is written in a prose that does no honor to Milosz, Orwell or Camus. Purdy was plainly striving
for an austere, morally urgent voice -- and at a few points, when he touches on concrete bits of West Virginia life, he achieves this. But the vast majority of the book is weighed down by a plodding eat-your-vegetables earnestness: "I cannot help believing that we need a way of thinking, and doing, that has in it more promise of goodness than the one we are now following." After a hundred pages of this I found myself yearning for Thomas Geoghegan's recent "Secret Lives of Citizens" -- a book that asks many of Purdy's questions, but reads like a melancholy democrat's fever dream, with hundreds of small sad jokes, digressive stories about Chicago ward politics and glimpses of wry, self-possessed former girlfriends.
The esthetic weakness of "For Common Things" casts an interesting light on the book's argument. Purdy believes that his parents' civic virtue can survive even outside enclaves like their rustic world of West Virginia. But he has very little to say about how these virtues might be transmitted to the national stage -- nothing about the potential for reviving or cleansing real-world political parties, movements, institutions. (When he does write about political renewal, he turns to the heroic figures of Eastern Europe -- not the most relevant models for our own condition.) We're left with the impression that public virtues will be spread only through individual conversion and persuasion -- a method of transmission that has serious limits, as this book inadvertently demonstrates. When making abstract arguments about responsibility and public life, it's all too easy to wind up (like Bill Bradley and Al Gore in certain modes) choking on your own high-mindedness.

HEADLINE: East Timor Isn't Kosovo

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel teaches at the University of Southern California and is author of "Temptations of a Superpower."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Because we bombed in Kosovo doesn't mean we should bomb Dili," said Samuel Berger, the national security adviser, about the atrocities in East Timor, which seem to have been committed by militias supported by elements of the Indonesian military. Well, why not?
The case for intervention in Dili is stronger than it was in Kosovo. Kosovo, after all, was a province of Serbia and had been for centuries. East Timor was never a part of Indonesia until it was seized by the Jakarta Government in 1975. Its people overwhelmingly voted for independence in a recent United Nations-monitored election that the Indonesian Government promised to honor. Yet, after days of violence and hundreds of deaths, the West has only asked, albeit forcefully, that Indonesia allow international peacekeeping troops into East Timor. 
 If the United States intervened for humanitarian reasons to support the Kosovars, even to the point of bombing Serbia, why shouldn't it do the same against Indonesia?
One reason is that -- all the rhetoric aside -- we did not intervene in Kosovo primarily for humanitarian purposes. The plight of the Kosovar refugees is what tugged at the public's heartstrings. But if American foreign policy were driven mainly by such concerns, we would have sent a few thousand troops to Rwanda to stop the genocide of the Tutsis by the Hutus.
What tipped the balance in the case of Kosovo, as well as Bosnia, were two concerns: that the conflict would spread to other areas of the Balkans and beyond, and that American leadership of NATO -- and even the alliance itself -- would be thrown into question. The Kosovo operation was in part meant to prove that NATO was still relevant in a post-Soviet Europe.
None of this applies to conflicts outside Europe. Witness, for example, the West's nonresponse to, and even lack of interest in, the Russian repression in Chechnya. Of course, Indonesia may respond to pressure from the West and allow in troops. But that doesn't change the basic equation. East Timor is not Kosovo; the West will not start bombing to save it. This is not only because East Timor is far from the North Atlantic world, but also because of the size and importance of Indonesia.
It is the world's fourth most populous nation, rich in natural resources and a prime trading partner for American corporations. It is a logical counter to any potential Chinese expansion. Furthermore, unlike puny Serbia, it is a serious military power.
Moreover, we have good reason to avoid weakening the Indonesian Government. This is because the civilian officials do not appear to be in control of the military units carrying out repression in East Timor. Punishing the fledgling democratic Government by military action could defeat our own purposes.
So where does that leave the noble principle of humanitarian intervention, so triumphantly affirmed in Kosovo? About where it began: as the exception rather than the rule.
Intervention will occur where it can be done relatively cheaply, against a weak nation, in an area both accessible and strategic, where the public's emotions are aroused, and where it does not get in the way of other political, economic or military needs.
However realistic this may be, it is deeply regrettable on moral grounds. The special tragedy of this case is that the "international community" monitored an election whose predictable results -- an overwhelming vote for independence -- it had no intention of guaranteeing.
But in the end, the quest for self-determination -- which is what led to the current murderous repression -- is relative, not absolute. People have the right to seek their own independent state. But others will come to their defense only where they believe their own self-interest is involved. That is where the line is being drawn today in East Timor.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agencies come and go, but Mercedes-Benz doesn't shift many gears in its campaign for 2000.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
EVER notice the resemblance between the Mercedes-Benz logo and the peace symbol? The first campaign for Mercedes-Benz USA from its new agency resembles recent campaigns from its previous agency even more closely.
Not that there is anything wrong with that. Still, the considerable publicity generated by an abrupt switch between the two New York agencies last winter, plus the acrimony -- as evidenced by a lawsuit seeking $25 million in damages -- led to some predictions that the campaign promoting the Mercedes-Benz lineup for the 2000 model year would differ from what went before. 
But the television and print campaign by the new agency, Merkley Newman Harty, echoes the work of its dismissed predecessor, Lowe & Partners/SMS, in content, style and attitude. The warmly emotional tone is back, intended to present the brand as less austere and more approachable. Returning, too, are elements like the one-word titles that appear in the lower right corner of the screen during television commercials.
Another constant is the wry, cheeky sense of humor that imbued past ads. Telly Savalas, for example, is shown playing the lollipop-loving detective Theo Kojak with a full head of hair. Rhett Butler tells Scarlett O'Hara, "Frankly my dear, I don't give a hoot." And Mercedes-Benz employees are portrayed as sufficiently dedicated to their jobs to replace the dummies in crash tests.
Those significant similarities between the campaigns are just what executives at Mercedes-Benz USA, a division of DaimlerChrysler A. G., said they wanted. The new effort begins today and continues through the fourth quarter with a budget of $50 million to $60 million -- the brand's largest model-year introductory spending ever.
"It's absolutely a continuation, building on what came before," said Mike Jackson, president and chief executive at Mercedes-Benz in Montvale, N.J. "What makes it strong is consistency."
"We've had wonderful success in this glorious economy, which has been satisfying," he added, referring to record sales that have almost doubled the last three years. "But the strategies Mercedes-Benz has been pursuing since the early 90's are what has driven our success."
Mr. Jackson discussed the campaign last week at a meeting at the Merkley Newman office in lower Manhattan, where he was joined by colleagues and agency executives.
Joachim W. Eberhardt, vice president for marketing at Mercedes-Benz USA, said: "We had always been satisfied with the ultimate creative product from the former agency. That was never a bone of contention."
Rather, company executives have attributed the dismissal of Lowe, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to what they described as increasing difficulties in achieving what they wanted from the agency during the creative process. The dismissal also came after the retirement of Marvin Sloves, former co-chairman at Lowe, who had worked closely with Mr. Jackson and Mr. Eberhardt on Mercedes-Benz advertising.
Interpublic is suing Mr. Sloves for $25 million, accusing him of influencing Mercedes-Benz to leave his former agency and breach of fiduciary duty. Mr. Sloves has denied the accusations and is fighting Interpublic in New York State Supreme Court.
Though there was widespread industry speculation that Mercedes-Benz USA had wanted Mr. Sloves to join the agency that replaced Lowe, that has not happened. Other senior executives who worked at Lowe on the account, with total billings estimated at $125 million, did leave for Merkley Newman, which is a unit of Omnicom Group.
"There was a combination of continuity and new people who added some new strategic insight, some new creative strength," said Alex Gellert, partner and group account director at Merkley Newman, who had been executive vice president and group account director on Mercedes-Benz at Lowe.
Similarly, the partners and executive creative directors at Merkley Newman responsible for the 2000 campaign -- Andy Hirsch, Marty Orzio and Randy Saitta -- had been group creative heads on Mercedes-Benz at Lowe.
What is new is a theme, "The Mercedes experience," that celebrates the factory and dealer employees behind the scenes as much as the brand's logo, heritage, products and driving performance.
The goal is to "create advocates for the brand" among car buyers, Mr. Jackson said, because "there's still nothing as powerful as the word-of-mouth referral from those enthusiastic about your product."
The idea is "not 'Mercedes-Benz is the best car,' " he added, "but 'Mercedes-Benz is the best car for me.' "
The initial commercial, and a related print ad, present humorous mistakes like the hairy Kojak, the misspoken Butler and the Mona Lisa with a toothy smile. "Change one thing and it's just not the same," they assert. "But if every part is exactly right . . . magic. Welcome to the Mercedes experience."
One commercial is evocative of perhaps the best spot created by Lowe in the six years that agency handled the account. The spot used production techniques to make it seem as if people driving and building Mercedes-Benzes decades ago were joining Marlene Dietrich in singing "Falling in Love Again."
This time, special effects and recreated footage are combined with contemporary actors dressed in period costumes to offer an unusual retrospective of Mercedes-Benz safety tests since the 1930's.
Ten TV commercials will appear on local and national broadcast and cable stations and networks. Fourteen print ads will run in newspapers and magazines. There will also be Internet ads, brochures and materials for dealer showrooms.

HEADLINE: Bridging Two Worlds to Make On-Line Digital Music Profitable

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
An Internet start-up company plans to introduce a new Web site on Monday that is designed to bridge the competing worlds of on-line digital music and the traditional recording industry.
Garageband.com will focus on the thousands of small and struggling musicians and groups in the United States. Many have found it impossible to sign with a major recording studio but have also discovered that they cannot make a profit by giving their music away over the Internet. 
 Founded by two Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, Tom Zito and Amanda Lathroum, with Jerry Harrison, a music producer who was a member of the rock group Talking Heads, the San Francisco-based company says it hopes to entice undiscovered musical groups with the promise of recording contracts and distribution agreements.
At the same time, it plans the use digital audience polling as a way to improve the company's odds for releasing commercially successful CD's.
Garageband.com is taking a new approach to the Internet MP3 phenomenon, which has frightened the nation's $13.5 billion recording industry with the specter of mass distribution of pirated music over the Internet.
MP3 is an Internet standard for the digital distribution of music, and in the last two years it has spawned an explosion of Web sites, including MP3.com, Shoutcast.com and Broadcast.com, offering Web surfers access to music on their personal computers. But these sites do not offer pirated copies of commercial recordings.
Instead, they aggregate the works of musicians who produce their own recordings and offer their music free to anyone who cares to download the MP3 files. And while some musicians use the sites to promote their CD's, the large majority do not have contracts with record labels.
For all the interest and controversy the MP3 standard has created, it has yet to generate a viable business model for sustaining small and innovative musical groups, said Mr. Zito, Garageband.com's chairman and chief executive.
"The MP3 advocates say record companies are toast," Mr. Zito said. "We believe record companies know a tremendous amount about marketing and promotion and getting music into the hands of consumers."
Moreover, he argued, the value of all music downloaded over the Internet last year was less than $1 million, suggesting that a viable Internet music economy is a long way off.
What is more, the exact shape of such an economy is still being determined as the recording industry and consumer electronics manufacturers struggle to agree on a format that will protect copyrighted music without alienating consumers.
"The Internet offers recording artists the ability to reach fans directly in a way that has never been possible," said Roger McNamee, a managing director of Integral Capital Partners in Menlo Park, Calif. "Garageband has an interesting spin if they can figure out a way to scale it without becoming just like the record companies."
The idea for the new company was formed last year when Mr. Zito visited Mr. Harrison's home and saw a large pile of demo recordings sitting on his floor. They had been sent by aspiring music groups hoping that he would help them produce a CD.
"He asked me, 'Is there anything good there?,' Mr. Harrison recalled. "I responded, 'How would I ever know? I will never have time to listen to even a fraction of them.' "
Mr. Zito approached Ms. Lathroum, who was then an executive and market researcher at the Netscape Communications Corporation, and asked if it would be possible to use the Internet to create an effective audience rating system for music.
The resulting Web service will permit musicians to upload recordings that will be rated by music enthusiasts on the Web. By next year, Garageband.com plans to begin awarding a recording contract for the most popular music each month.
"I would say that this is an Internet version of Dick Clark's "American Bandstand," but I'm pretty sure few people on the Net are old enough to remember American Bandstand," Mr. Zito said.
Garageband.com is hoping to attract listeners who are willing to sample unknown recording artists by offering prizes like backstage passes to concerts and visits to recording studios.
But the emphasis will be on the people who make the music.
"We're creating an on-line community by musicians for musicians," said Mr. Zito. "Obviously, we believe the fans will come where the musicians are, because that's where they'll hear the best music."
Currently, only about 600 of the 30,000 CD's published each year are profitable, Mr. Zito said. The promise of Garageband, he said is that by employing sound statistical techniques he hopes to get a reliable indicator of which recordings will be popular -- and profitable.

HEADLINE: Why China Smiles

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Last year, in the aura of Bill Clinton's buoyant visit, the Chinese called the American President a great statesman and the United States a strategic partner.
Then suddenly this spring, as "U.S.-led NATO" bombed Yugoslavia and then hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Mr. Clinton was described as a fiend, and the United States as an evil empire. 
 With their meeting in New Zealand on Saturday, President Jiang Zemin is once again dancing with "my old friend" Clinton, as he put it a few days ago. Beijing newspapers this morning featured pictures of the two smiling leaders shaking hands and did not even mention the Belgrade Embassy disaster, which killed three Chinese and prompted days of angry demonstrations outside the American Embassy in Beijing.
Warier and perhaps wiser than before, China and the United States are starting to restore normal relations. They seem determined to seal the bond by finally, after years of tortured negotiations, agreeing on terms for China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
These wild gyrations in Chinese-American relations are a reminder of the subterranean passions that have always buffeted ties between the two countries.
But China's rapid return to smiles also reflects a more basic truth, Chinese foreign policy experts and Western diplomats say. For economic and strategic reasons, they say, China's leaders see no good alternative to cooperative relations with the United States in the years ahead.
Recent events, including the American pursuit of the Kosovo war and pugnacious assertions of virtual independence by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, have sharpened the sense in some quarters here, especially the military, that a showdown with the United States over Taiwan may occur at some point.
But for the immediate future, China's leaders hope their hand will not be forced on Taiwan, because they are far more anxious to concentrate on overhauling the economy and building up national strength.
"There's a large consensus here that the relationship with the United States is the cornerstone of our global strategy," said Jin Canrong, an expert on international politics at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. To speed China's modernization and avoid a costly arms race in Asia, he said, most officials believe that "we have to deal with the United States in a steady way."
China's renewed push to join the World Trade Organization shows how deeply its foreign policy has become intertwined with domestic goals. Entry into the trade body, the leaders feel, will aid their drive to shake out state enterprises and create a market-driven economy -- their only path to prosperity at home and greatness abroad.
Over the last year, with unemployment growing and sporadic reports of social unrest, the pruning of state enterprises slowed, and powerful industries lobbied against making deep concessions to the West on trade. Rumors spread this summer that Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, the main torch-bearer for economic reform, had threatened to resign.
But by summer's end it appeared that the leaders had unequivocally decided to plunge ahead with ambitious economic reforms regardless of the short-term risks, and in so doing to resume trade talks with the United States.
In recent weeks, President Jiang has staked his own prestige on the state enterprise overhaul, blitzing the country to deliver speeches with titles like "Fortify Confidence, Deepen Reform, and Create a New Situation for State Enterprise Development." Proposals to speed along change -- consolidating and saving key state firms while letting others go private or bankrupt -- will be the centerpiece of a Communist Party meeting this month.
Entry into the W.T.O., officials here have concluded, is essential to that task.
Aides to Prime Minister Zhu have been heard invoking an old saying: "Let the water flow to wash the sand away." In this case, the water is the stiff competition that will result from trade organization membership, washing away the inefficiencies of hidebound enterprises.
Despite rhetoric about entering the W.T.O. on relaxed, developing-country rules, the Chinese have already agreed to make sharp cuts in farm and industrial tariffs and to begin opening industries like automobiles, telecommunications and banking to outside competition.
Membership, if it is achieved, will of course bring some direct economic benefits. A study by the China International Capital Corporation, an investment bank in Beijing that is a joint venture by the Government and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, concluded that the resulting freer trade would increase the gross domestic product by between one-half of a percent and 1 percent a year.
But that same report pointed to some of the hazards: millions more farmers would become redundant, for example, with no obvious new opportunities opening up soon. And China's fledgling social security systems are not ready for a new surge in industrial layoffs.
Officials from the United States and China have cautioned that a trade agreement has not been clinched.
In any case, Taiwan remains the most dangerous and convoluted issue in Chinese-American relations.
Despite continued bluster in the official press, Chinese officials have assured the Americans that they are not planning any military action unless Taiwan takes further steps toward formal independence. And for now, China appreciates President Clinton's restatement of American support for "one China" and counts on Washington to restrain Taiwan from precipitous moves.
Yet the Chinese also resent American arms sales to Taiwan and they know that if they ever do attack Taiwan, the United States is likely to join the battle.
