HEADLINE: Disappointed Democrats Offer Chance for Bradley

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
There are a lot of things in Bill Bradley's biography that Joan Lydic likes: his Rhodes Scholarship, his Hall of Fame career with the New York Knicks, his three terms as a senator from New Jersey. And oh, yeah, he is a down-to-earth guy.
But Mrs. Lydic, 55, a family therapist from St. Louis who attended a rally last week for Mr. Bradley in Keokuk, Iowa, has another reason for supporting him over Vice President Gore, his sole rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination: he was never part of the Clinton Administration. 
 "I'm uncomfortable, being a mother, with what went on there," Mrs. Lydic said. "It sickened me. I know Al Gore is different. But if Al Gore were principled, he should have wanted to resign."
Mrs. Lydic and other disenchanted Democrats represent both the central opportunity and major challenge for Mr. Bradley as he gears up his insurgent challenge to Mr. Gore, the party's presumptive front-runner.
In interviews in a campaign swing through Missouri and Iowa last week, it was clear that many of Mr. Bradley's supporters are fueled, at least in part, by a deep disillusionment with Mr. Clinton -- and by extension with Mr. Gore. And while few blamed Mr. Gore for the Administration's ethical problems, many said they believed the Vice President had been badly tarnished by his close association with the President.
"I like Bradley, from a moral point of view," said Merel Young, 68, a retired teacher from Keokuk. "I think that makes him more electable than Gore."
But building a base among anti-Clinton Democrats is not likely to be enough for Mr. Bradley to wrest the nomination from Mr. Gore, whose support in the Democratic establishment runs deep. To win, Mr. Bradley will have to assemble a broader coalition that picks off Mr. Gore's supporters on the party's right and left, analysts say. And while the election is still a long way away, Mr. Bradley will have to hustle to widen his appeal by the early primaries this winter.
"Right now, two-thirds of Bradley's appeal is soft," said Fred Siegel, a professor of history at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in Manhattan. "People like him because he's an adult, he seems like a fully formed human being with a backbone, who is not going to be tossed by the winds. And he's not caught up in the Clinton scandals."
"To vault to the next level, he has to go further," Mr. Siegel added. "He has to lay out specifics for what a Bradley Presidency would look like."
So far Mr. Bradley has been unwilling to do that, avoiding major policy pronouncements on the issues he says will define the coming election: the economy, health care, race relations and foreign policy. Those will come in the fall, when voters are more focused on the race, his campaign says.
But in his recent speeches, Mr. Bradley has provided clear indications of how he plans to establish himself as the anti-Gore alternative.
At the heart of every speech is a liberal critique of the Clinton Administration's economic policies: that the nation's roaring prosperity has not trickled down to struggling working-class and poor Americans.
It is a difficult argument to make, because the strong economy is probably Mr. Gore's strongest political asset. But with a New Deal-like pitch to traditional liberalism, Mr. Bradley evokes the spirit of his father, a small-town banker, who he says refused to foreclose on a single home during the Great Depression.
"If the stock market is skyrocketing and family farms are going bankrupt," Mr. Bradley told 18 people at a diner in Newton, Iowa, "you shouldn't feel good about where the economy is going."
Mr. Bradley has also placed race relations front and center in his campaign, saying, "The only thing deserving of hate is hate itself." Polls indicate that blacks -- who represent 30 percent or more of the Democratic primary vote in some Southern states -- remain loyal to Mr. Gore.
But in a sign of Mr. Bradley's desire to grab black votes from Mr. Gore's left, he appeared before a Harlem organization run by the Rev. Al Sharpton last month -- even though his visit angered centrist white voters and Jews who view Mr. Sharpton as divisive.
But Mr. Bradley is doing more than trying to outflank Mr. Gore in the party's liberal wing. He is a staunch advocate of sweeping gun restrictions and changes to the campaign finance system. Both are issues of concern not just for liberals, but also for middle-class reformers and centrist suburban voters.
Both candidates have extensive proposals on both issues, but Mr. Bradley's go significantly further. He has called for licensing all gun owners, registering all guns and banning so-called Saturday night special handguns, as well as for public financing of Congressional campaigns and free television time for candidates.
To broaden the appeal of his economic message beyond the very poor, Mr. Bradley advocates making it easier for workers to form unions, expanding access to health care and bolstering pensions.
And for independent voters, Mr. Bradley offers a populist, Perotlike critique of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore's leadership styles, asserting that politics today is "obsessed with the mechanics of winning, which is polling, fund-raising and spinning."
Finally, by focusing on the importance of character and virtue in politics, Mr. Bradley seems to be directly addressing the small-town, moderate Democrats who tend to vote in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, where he must perform well next year to survive.
It helps Mr. Bradley that most of this does not seem forced. He can fairly claim that he has been concerned about race relations since he was a boy and that the civil rights movement inspired him to enter politics.
And he was talking about the importance of character in politics long before Monica S. Lewinsky became a household name.
He also seems to benefit from his unhurried, easy manner. In Keokuk he shook hands and signed basketballs until the last supporter had drifted off, leaving him alone in the fading afternoon sun.
"He reminds me of a good old country doctor," Katie Wood, 48, of Hannibal, Mo., said.
But Mr. Bradley can be maddeningly short on specifics, and even some supporters say his gauzy appeals to human goodness may begin to lose voters if they do not soon include hard details.
"I've been on the campaign just two weeks, and people are already asking me where he stands on things," said Nancy Parrott, a Bradley organizer in southeastern Iowa. "Right now, we are just giving them resumes."
If Mr. Bradley often dodges questions on broad policy matters, he can be quite specific on issues that concern Iowa voters. In Ottumwa, he told farmers that he supported Justice Department oversight of agricultural mergers that threaten small farmers. In Des Moines, he told peace activists that he opposed sending American troops to East Timor. And in Grinnell, he told college students that although he opposed legalizing gay marriages, he supported giving homosexual partners legal rights and protections comparable to those of married couples.
By nature cautious and methodical, Mr. Bradley admits to fearing that candor will cause him problems as the campaign heats up.
When a woman in Newton asked him about his position on public financing of private schools, Mr. Bradley acknowledged that he had voted for a pilot voucher program while in the Senate, a position strongly opposed by the powerful teachers unions. But he added that he did not consider vouchers "the answer to the problems of public education."
"I've tried to be as candid with you as possible," Mr. Bradley told the woman. "That leads to the maximum possibility of distortion."

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Complacency Is in Season

BYLINE: By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
A new venue has been added for Fashion Week: the Tomar Studios, located on the 13th floor of a warehouse building in the far West 20's. It is a precinct enjoying its status as the art and fashion world's latest epicenter of hip, and so it seemed fitting that the sun-filled studios saw more than a half-dozen young, mostly unknown designers introduce their millennial lines over the weekend.
But these collections for spring 2000 had less in common with anything avant-garde than with an art exhibition just down the hall from Tomar Studios. Titled "Mainely Maine," it featured uncomplicated paintings of New England landscapes. Barrier-breaking it was not. 
 And neither were the clothes coming down the runways 100 or so yards away. The designers -- Fiona Walker, Lotta and Chompol Serimont, among others -- offered mostly wearable, almost quaint, daisy-trimmed sundresses, skirts of paisley and gingham, and coated linen sport jackets. All that accessibility can be slightly dull. Even the models sometimes seemed too bored to pout.
Those expecting complexity or, more likely, grand spectacle will have to wait for Alexander McQueen's much-anticipated show on Thursday, or perhaps the Mayor's NYC 2000 fashion show, to be held on an outdoor runway in Times Square tonight. It will feature the work of 90 designers from around the world, made specifically for the event, and will be emceed by the swimsuit model Vendela. The items will be auctioned later to support city schools.
There were attempts at drama over the weekend, but they tended to be misguided. Ms. Walker, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, who now has a shop on West 46th Street, put welder's glasses on some of her models and set her collection to the blaring techno music of Bjork and Fresh Aire, ill-suited companions for her generally peaceful knits, cropped pants and pretty linens. Ms. Walker seemed desperate to supply the show with a homage to futurism that the clothes lacked. "I wanted everything to be about technology for the millennium," she said after the show. "The clear glasses enhanced that idea."
Antilika, a graduate of the Moscow College of Art and Design, also aimed to create clamor. Her clothes were the least commercial of those shown on Saturday, but her vision seemed the most contrived and regressive. She put images of babies as well as O'Keeffe-like representations of female body parts on the midsections of her uninventively cut dresses. A woman cannot escape her sexuality, Antilika very literally seemed to be saying. A woman is trapped by her function as a breeder. It's an idea that seems curiously out of step in these post-feminist times. What woman of any political stripe is going to feel empowered by putting on a dress that appears to have fallopian tubes depicted on it?
A more contemporary dissertation on female sexuality was in evidence on Sunday when a pair of evening-wear designers, Sully Bonnelly and William Calvert, unleashed their collections away from the West Chelsea venue. Mr. Bonnelly was born in the Dominican Republic, and wisely enough he has capitalized on the current American affection for Latin culture. His flared, fake suede pants and chiffon tops were shown in rich tropical limes and fuchsias. His cuts were slim and fabrics sheer in a brash, sexy manner that both Camille Paglia and Ricky Martin could appreciate. Mr. Bonnelly called one garment a "salsa dress." The designation seemed unnecessary; it was clear that the item was intended for the dance floor. It was clear that just about everything on view was intended for the dance floor -- one where an orchestra more electric than Lester Lanin's might be playing.
Young society women on the Lanin circuit will find one of their most passionate advocates in Mr. Calvert. Of all those who showed over the weekend, he possesses the most articulate vision. He is intent on dressing women who quietly appreciate all that the boom economy has provided. His geometrically cut gowns, inspired by Geoffrey Beene, and luxurious fabrics are meant for those who want to achieve an effortless beauty rather than worked-for glamour. He avers a girlish idea of femininity that has so many young designers in its grip and opts for making women look elegantly grown-up.
The new collection introduces more color than in Mr. Calvert's past collections. "Now, when you see someone walking down the street in black, you think how weird, how boring," Mr. Calvert said before his show. He isn't the first designer of late to express this thought, but he's certainly one of the more talented ones to convey it.

HEADLINE: Campaign Reform's Moment

 BODY:
One of the most important election events of the current season takes place this week, not in Iowa or New Hampshire or any other primary state, but on Capitol Hill. Tomorrow the House of Representatives votes on the Shays-Meehan campaign finance reform bill to ban unregulated "soft money" donations to political parties, regulate phony "issue ads" on television and impose new fund-raising disclosure rules. The bill, which would curb abuses and practices at the heart of the 1996 fund-raising scandals, appears likely to pass. But the more votes it gets, the better the chances will be for Senate approval of what would become the most sweeping electoral reforms in a generation.
Congress and the political establishment have begun feeling the pressure from voters and even donors. The Committee for Economic Development is rounding up business leaders opposed to soft-money donations. Gov. George W. Bush last week announced that his campaign would list donors on its Web site, a positive step but nothing like real reform. The bill sponsored by Representatives Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Martin Meehan of Massachusetts passed last year by a vote of 252 to 179, including 61 Republicans who broke with their party leadership to back the bill. If supporters stand firm, the majority ought to be just as big this year. But in a repetition of their junkyard tactics of 1998, House Speaker Dennis Hastert and Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, are offering amendments and substitutes that would gut the bill's main provisions or split the delicate coalition backing reform. 
Some Democrats and Republicans may be tempted to waver. Anti-abortion groups are pressuring their allies to support amendments that would gut the legislation's regulation of television campaign ads sponsored by independent groups. Republicans and Democrats who favor campaign reform have urged anti-abortion forces not to oppose the Shays-Meehan bill, but without success. Tomorrow they need to vote for reform, in defiance of the misguided wishes of people with whom they might agree on abortion.
Another danger to reform comes in the form of "poison pill" amendments. One would throw out the whole bill if any part of it was declared unconstitutional. Others would increase ceilings on donations to candidates, a premature step. Another would weaken the ability of unions to raise money. If passed, it would drive Democrats from the bill. A poison pill administered by Mr. DeLay would deregulate campaign activities as long as they were conducted on the Internet. Still another measure would require that a candidate raise at least 50 percent of his contributions in his home state, a measure that if passed would force blacks and other urban minorities to oppose the underlying bill.
The gravest danger to reform is posed by three seemingly attractive "substitute" amendments from Republicans that, if passed, would supplant the Shays-Meehan bill altogether. The one sponsored by John Doolittle of California would repeal all campaign limits and merely require disclosure, an obvious step backward. Another pushed by Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas would allow soft money for state parties, a loophole that would simply rechannel the flow of corrupt money. A third pushed by Bill Thomas of California sounds harmless enough. It would strengthen filing requirements and take other constructive steps. But because it is a substitute, its passage would defeat Shays-Meehan.
Without a campaign overhaul, the parties are sure to spend $500 million to $750 million in soft money this year, twice as much as in the last Presidential election. A "yes" vote on Shays-Meehan can head off more corrupt fund-raising and more scandals in the coming election cycle. Tomorrow the House faces a test of its members' sincerity and of whether it is listening to the public instead of special-interest donors.

HEADLINE: In America;
Underground Dreams

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
It could happen. I'm not saying it will happen. But the stars are moving ever closer to a favorable alignment. A subway line under Second Avenue in Manhattan -- a dream that has tantalized commuters for most of this century -- is now approaching the realm of the possible. Don't bet the mortgage just yet. The cynics and the naysayers are still holding the high cards. But it could happen.
And if you are one of the unlucky thousands who ride to work while being poked and jostled by the unruly elbows, backpacks and umbrellas on the hopelessly and sometimes dangerously overcrowded Lexington Avenue line, you know for sure that it should happen. 
 Construction of the city's subway system began 100 years ago. William McKinley was President and Robert Van Wyck was Mayor, the first Mayor of all five boroughs. The subways soon became indispensable and shortly after World War I East Siders were being told that a Second Avenue subway line was in their future.
They had no idea how far in the future. For one reason or another -- a Depression, a World War, a lack of vision, a fiscal crisis -- the Second Avenue subway never happened. Highways and bridges and tunnels and vast acres of parking lots materialized during those decades. But no subway under Second Avenue.
"The East Side of Manhattan was developed around the Second and Third Avenue els," said Bob Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, which is part of a coalition of civic and business groups that is calling for work to actually get started on creation of a Second Avenue line.
"When the els came down, the East Side was zoned with the understanding that there was going to be a Second Avenue subway replacing those elevated lines. But it hasn't been built. Consequently, the Lex is jammed well beyond its carrying capacity, to the point where it just doesn't work. People can't get on and off the trains. The platforms and stairs can't carry the numbers of people that are there. It is literally approaching an unsafe situation at the most crowded stations."
In the mid-1950's a full-scale Second Avenue line probably would have cost a few hundred million dollars. Now it would cost several billion. And yet, Mr. Yaro and many others are saying, "I think its time has come."
There are several reasons to be at least somewhat optimistic. To get the subway line built you have to have the support of top state officials. It so happens that Gov. George Pataki very much wants to build a tunnel connecting the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal. That would keep thousands of suburban Long Island commuters from having to travel to Penn Station on the West Side of Manhattan and then doubling back to the East Side by subway to get to work. (It would also add thousands of new passengers to the daily crush of the Lexington Avenue line.)
And it just happens that the Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, represents the Lower East Side, which is woefully short of subway service and would benefit tremendously if the Second Avenue subway were built.
One has to keep in mind, of course, that for Mr. Silver's local constituents to benefit, a full-length Second Avenue line would have to be built, not the truncated 125th Street to 63d Street proposal being considered by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Mr. Pataki, friend of the suburbanites, meet Mr. Silver, who says he's a champion of the urbanites. Let's make a deal. If not now, when? The number of New Yorkers using mass transit has soared over the past couple of years. And these are the best of economic times, with the Federal, state and city governments all running surpluses. All we need is a little vision.
"We're running out of capacity to move people into the central business district," said Gene Russianoff, the senior attorney with the Straphangers Campaign, which is also part of the coalition supporting a new subway line. "If we want to have the jobs of a growing economy, we have to be able to get the people to them. And we've maxed out. The Lex is at 140 percent of capacity during rush hour. It's a nightmare."
There is wide support for the new subway line, ranging from the Auto Club of New York to the New York City Partnership and the Environmental Defense Fund. The stars are in alignment. All we need is leadership.
Mr. Pataki? Mr. Silver?

HEADLINE: THE DEBATE ON AID FOR THE ELDERLY FOCUSES ON WOMEN

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
It is not an accident that Flo, a feisty sixty-something woman, is the star of the pharmaceutical industry's latest advertising campaign in the battle over adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare.
Nor is it a coincidence that the White House held an event not long ago to focus on Medicare as a women's issue. Or that the Democratic women of the Senate formed a working group last year to examine what the various proposals to restructure Social Security would mean to women. Or that the Older Women's League, an advocacy group, issued a report on Mother's Day this year titled, "The Face of Medicare Is a Woman You Know." 
 All of this reflects a basic demographic and political reality that increasingly colors the debate over restructuring Medicare and Social Security: old age is largely a country of women.
Women not only tend to live longer; they also are more economically insecure, have more chronic health conditions and, as a result, eventually become more dependent on those basic safety-net programs, health policy analysts say. Politically, that means they are becoming a prime audience -- and target and symbol -- in the great struggles over entitlements. Some defenders of these programs say that highlighting this vulnerable population -- as opposed to the image of the more affluent retirees -- is not only good policy but could be a potent political appeal.
"Women perceive it as a twofold issue: One, they're more likely to have all the problems of old age because they're likely to live longer," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "And second, whatever caregiving responsibilities exist, women expect to fall squarely on their shoulders."
Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who also works for the pharmaceutical industry, said, "When you do focus groups, women say, 'Look, I'm going to live longer. I could outlive my income.' Women just presume there's a higher chance they'll need a Government safety net more than men."
The demographics are clear: At birth, the American woman's life expectancy is 79.1, six years longer than a man's. Women account for 54 percent of the Medicare beneficiaries from age of 65 to 74, and 61 percent of the Medicare population from 75 to 84, according to the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a health research group. They account for 71 percent of the 85-and-over Medicare population. Reflecting this skew, women make up more than two-thirds of the nursing home population and two-thirds of the users of home health-care services.
Older women also have higher poverty rates than their male counterparts: 17 percent of the women on Medicare have incomes below the Federal poverty level ($7,740 a year in 1996), compared with 11 percent of the men on Medicare, according to a report by the Older Women's League. Nearly 7 in 10 of the Medicare beneficiaries living below the poverty line are women, that report said.
"The good news is we live longer than men, and the bad news is that we live longer than men," said Judith L. Lichtman, president of the National Partnership for Women and Families, a liberal advocacy group for such causes as expanded family leave.
Ann F. Lewis, a Presidential counselor, said, "When you start talking about the fact that women live longer, are paid less, are far less likely to have pensions with their work, and far more likely to carry the responsibility for caregiving in our families, every woman in the audience starts to nod."
Ms. Lichtman and other advocates say women's groups have long recognized that "aging is a women's issue," because of women's work patterns, caregiving responsibilities, economic status and longevity. But in the last few years, as Social Security and Medicare appeared headed for overhauls, advocates say these groups have organized to insure that women's interests are protected.
"The reason you're hearing more about this now is the programs that women and men, but especially women, rely on for old age, Social Security and Medicare, are under new strains," said Joan Entmacher of the National Women's Law Center, an advocacy group that focuses on women's legal rights.
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, said the Democratic women in the Senate began meeting on the issue a year ago, when Social Security restructuring appeared imminent and the debate over privatizing the program was taking off. Any major restructuring is now considered unlikely until after the 2000 election. A few months ago, the Democratic women produced a checklist of necessary ingredients for any Social Security overhaul, including preserving the program as a guaranteed benefit with protection against inflation.
"Others wanted to talk about macroeconomics," Ms. Mikulski said. "We wanted to talk about it at the macaroni-and-cheese level."
There is a clear political rationale for presenting Social Security and Medicare as women's issues, just as liberal advocates a decade ago tried to cast welfare and poverty as children's issues. Preserving and improving expensive entitlement programs for frail and economically vulnerable widows is much more appealing than doing so for affluent retirees.
"It puts a human face on it," Ms. Mikulski said of the focus on women. "And I believe a far more realistic face. We're not talking about the gilded golf cart here."
While Democrats and their sympathetic advocacy groups have been hitting this issue particularly hard, the focus on women is bipartisan. Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Connecticut Republican who is a senior woman on the House Ways and Means Committee, contends that Republicans have "been the lead party" in trying to protect older women's economic security through such measures as tax credits for caregivers and the purchase of long-term care insurance. "I think part of my job is to educate them about what we're doing and why we're doing it," Mrs. Johnson said.
In the near term, these demographic undercurrents are strong in the struggle over whether to add prescription drug coverage to Medicare, as proposed by the Clinton Administration this year. The Administration and the Older Women's League contend that this coverage gap is a particular hardship for older women, who spend a greater share of their income on health care than men, 22 percent compared with 17 percent.
Republican leaders, for their part, contend that they will focus on the needy in the debate over assistance for prescription drugs.
The drug industry, which fears that a major new Government benefit will lead to price controls, is sounding alarms in the person of Flo, who warns that "the White House plan puts bureaucrats in charge of our medicines."
The campaign presents Flo -- "an actress, but her story and concerns are real," according to campaign literature -- as being in the two-thirds of the Medicare population that has private drug coverage and plays to worries of people in this group that their insurance will be replaced by a less-generous and more-intrusive Government plan.
The advertisements say they are produced by Citizens for Better Medicare, a coalition of business, drug industry and some patients groups, but a spokesman for the group said they were primarily paid for by the pharmaceutical industry. The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of American have taken the lead in this campaign.
Some advocates of new prescription drug benefits have reacted angrily to the Flo advertisements. "The Flo campaign is really outrageous," said Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut. Deborah Briceland-Betts, executive director of the Older Women's League, said her organization had mounted an anti-Flo campaign: "The message is Flo is a fake, and she doesn't represent the majority of older women in America who are trying to figure out how to cover the costs of drugs."
The struggle over Flo is a symbol of what is to come, advocates on both sides agree. "We're all talking to women on these issues," said Ms. Lichtman. "They are, we are."

HEADLINE: After Summer's Power Failures, Concerns About Large Utilities

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA and PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Over and over again this summer, the lights went out in this muscular, make-it-work city.
There was the blistering midsummer weekend when temperatures topped 100 degrees and up to 100,000 homes in the Chicago area lost power, a weekend in which officials recorded more than 50 heat-related deaths. 
 There was the day the power company, faced with trouble in two transformers, plunged Chicago's downtown Loop into darkness in the middle of the afternoon, leaving 2,300 businesses in the dark, trapping people in elevators, short-circuiting Federal court proceedings and even silencing the cacophony at the Chicago Board of Trade.
And there was the Sunday that power failures prevented the city's Field Museum of Natural History from opening its doors on what was supposed to be one of the summer's busiest weekends.
Cities around the country have faced similar frustrations. In New York, on one of the hottest days of the year, a power cable short-circuited, leaving 200,000 homes in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan powerless for 18 hours, the worst blackout to hit the city in 22 years. In New Orleans, power plant failures led to blackouts that disrupted service for more than half a million customers.
The reasons behind the power failures vary, but they all hint at deep-seated problems at the nation's largest electric power companies. Utilities that are now the lifeblood of the electronic age are grappling with deregulation, aging and long-neglected equipment, new and sometimes confusing transmission networks and unprecedented demands for electricity to power the technology behind a booming economy.
Utility experts are warning that the industry's emergency power reserves are getting dangerously low, largely because of a decadelong reluctance by utilities to build power plants because of the costs and uncertainty of power demands.
While there have been a significant number of blackouts in the last few years, the high temperatures this summer thrust the utilities' problems into a particularly harsh spotlight, raising questions about whether they are adequately prepared to cope with the nation's soaring energy needs.
"There have been several high-profile outages that have caused people to get excited about reliability issues," said Eugene F. Gorzelnik, a spokesman for the North American Electric Reliability Council, an industry trade group in Princeton, N.J. "It's not that the system is falling apart. But as you look at the next 10 years you don't want to wait for things to fall apart."
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has announced an investigation of the power failures. Some elected officials have filed suit against power companies over failures or taken steps to lure competing utilities in the hopes of creating alternatives.
After the Chicago power failures, Mayor Richard M. Daley, seething with anger, denounced Commonwealth Edison, the giant utility whose power system was at fault, because among other things it had failed to replace insulators made of plastic that were so old and faulty that most utilities got rid of them decades ago.
"We are sick and tired of them," the Mayor said of the power company, "and they had better change."
And regulators in several states are considering forcing utilities to pay a penalty for periods that they fail to provide power.
"I don't think I've heard as much complaining about electric utilities and shortages and outages in a long time," said Robert Burns, a senior researcher at the National Regulatory Research Institute, which does studies for state public utility commissions. "It's been decades since there have been this many problems."
As a result, the nation's utilities are redoubling their efforts to make sure this summer's experience is not repeated. Some are scrutinizing maintenance practices or, like Commonwealth Edison in Chicago, firing top-level executives. Others are trying to accelerate the pace at which they build plants, with their earlier reluctance overcome by the need for more power.
Executives at the nation's biggest utilities say the high-profile power failures are not representative of the industry. Yet many of them acknowledge that the utility industry is struggling through a period of major change. The advent of deregulation of the industry that began with the Federal Government meant new competition, new challenges and new sources of power.
Many utilities now have to open their transmission lines to competitors, which has spawned the buying and selling of power across regions. Florida utilities now sell to the Southeast, Wisconsin utilities to the East, and New England utilities to the Middle Atlantic.
"You have utilities that are running power from region to region, so you have a lot of traffic," said Patrice Hagmann, a spokeswoman at the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group in Washington for shareholder-owned electric companies. "You may need a traffic cop to control things."
The Federal Government previously regulated transmission lines that crossed state boundaries. States have the power to control utilities in their borders, and many still do, while other states have freed the companies of controls in the hope that competition will bring less expensive electricity.
Here in Chicago, where a series of power failures inflamed a city and its outspoken Mayor this summer, the culprits were faulty transformers and wires.
"The outages revealed a number of weaknesses and shortcomings in our system," said David Helwig, the interim senior vice president of transmission and distribution at Commonwealth Edison. "Quite frankly, many of the problems can be traced to maintenance that wasn't done."
Chicago has suffered through power failures before, including a serious one in a heat wave in 1995 in which there were more than 400 heat-related deaths in a month. Although industry experts say that Commonwealth Edison, which is owned by Unicom Inc., has improved the operation of its five nuclear plants in recent years, its substations, cables and the distribution networks that serve the greater Chicago area have long been neglected.
For instance, Commonwealth Edison still uses an old plastic, the "bakelite" insulator, in its cables. "That stuff was starting to be replaced years and years ago," said Mr. Burns at the National Regulatory Research Institute. "Talking about bakelite is kind of like talking about having a rotary phone. There shouldn't be as much of that stuff out there anymore."
Concerned that outdated and inadequate plants could continue to short-circuit the city's power and eventually turn into a political liability, Mayor Daley insisted that Commonwealth Edison institute around-the-clock inspections of its equipment. In recent months, Commonwealth Edison has acknowledged major technical and public relations blunders.
"This level of service under these conditions is a disgrace to us," John Rowe, the chief executive, said at a news conference after the latest power failure. "It's a personal disgrace to me. I will not tolerate it, and you will not have to."
Commonwealth Edison has tried to make amends by holding public forums, offering cash refunds to some customers and promising swift changes at the top. Mr. Rowe fired two high-level executives and promised to spend $1.4 billion over the next three years to upgrade equipment.
Still, a few weeks ago, Chicago began courting a subsidiary of the Wisconsin Energy Corporation with the promise of donating land to help the utility build a power plant, opening the door to an alternative source of electricity.
In New York City, there are similar concerns about an aging power system and soaring demand. Indeed, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has already filed suit against Consolidated Edison, charging the utility with "gross negligence" in the Washington Heights blackout.
But Con Edison officials say they are operating one of the most reliable utilities in the nation, yet one that is at times vulnerable to extreme weather and extreme demand.
"We had the underground equivalent of an earthquake with all the heat and humidity," said Mary McCartney, a spokeswoman. "If we didn't take the network off line it was basically going to destroy itself."
On the day the power failed, energy consumption hit a record 11,850 megawatts in the New York City region, Ms. McCartney said. The utility's capacity is 12,000 megawatts, with an 18 percent buffer, clearly straining the system and raising questions about whether Con Edison has enough power to meet demands and extreme weather conditions. The utility admits that this summer demand was 10 percent higher than it had projected.
Con Edison buys the bulk of its power from other utility companies, in places like Pennsylvania and Maryland. "Capacity is a major issue," Ms. McCartney said. "It's something every utility is looking at."
Other cities have been equally burdened this summer, but for differing reasons. In Louisiana, the big utility, the Entergy Corporation, said that unusually high demand for power in the four states it serves created a wide power failure; four or five power plants malfunctioned at just about the time the Tennessee Valley Authority decided to stop shipping power to the utility, because of heavy demand in other regions. Crippled by the events, Entergy decided to shut down power to hundreds of thousands of its customers.
"There was extraordinarily high demand and we just didn't have enough power to cover it," said Carol Clawson, a spokeswoman at Entergy, which is based in New Orleans. "One of the dilemmas utilities have is how do you prepare for this kind of thing: Do you go out and build extra power plants to prepare for a once-in-a-decade event? And do you charge customers for that? Do you build additional generation because you think one day in July it will be really, really hot?"
Responding to concerns about periodic power failures, Mr. Richardson, the Energy Secretary, announced an initiative last July to help prevent major power failures, including the creation of a team of experts to investigate blackouts, pushing for new standards to reduce energy consumption, and trying to determine whether there is a shortage of power plants and transmission sites.
"Consumers should not have to wonder whether the lights will go out when the thermometer hits 90 degrees," Mr. Richardson said. "While the causes of recent power outages are still being reviewed, the fact is that some systems are being stretched to the limit. Clearly, there is cause for concern."
Industry experts, however, point out that the nation's utilities are not in crisis mode; service is generally reliable. But power companies need to move swiftly if they are going to meet growing customer demands.
"Across the country, I think the quality of service has improved, but we've become so dependent on electricity we're less tolerant," said Douglas Fischer, an analyst who covers the utility industry at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis. "One problem we do have, though, is a shortage of power."
After a heavy buildup of power plants and transmission lines in 1970's and 1980's, electric utilities were slow to invest in expensive power plants. Now, with deregulation and uncertainty about how competition and buying and selling power will work, many utilities are also reluctant to invest in the power plants and power lines that many people fight to keep out of their neighborhoods.
The most recent figures available show the nation's consumption of electric power rose to 3,367 billion kilowatt hours in 1998, up from 2,578 billion kilowatt hours in 1988.
Industry officials say the power plants now being built may not keep up with growing consumption. In 1990, there was a 22 percent cushion of extra power available for emergency use in the United States. That figure fell to 16 percent in 1997, and is expected to drop to 10 percent by 2007 if consumption continues to grow at the current pace, according to the Edison Electric Institute.
While the utilities say they are working aggressively to meet the challenges, Robert K. Johnson, the executive director of the Electric Consumers' Alliance in Indianapolis, said regulators needed to keep a watchful eye on the industry.
"My concern," Mr. Johnson said, "is that the outages, while they may individually be explainable in different ways, collectively could be symptoms of transitional problems in the industry that need to be addressed."

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
On-Line Radio Tries The All-Talk Format

BYLINE: By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
An entrepreneur who made his name in rock radio almost 30 years ago is now trying his luck at Internet radio.
Bob Meyrowitz, 56, whose DIR Broadcasting in the early 1970's created the syndicated radio series "King Biscuit Flower Hour," plans to start a radio network on the Internet this week. Recognizing that, so far, so-called streaming, or continuous, audio is not always of the highest fidelity on the Net, Mr. Meyrowitz plans an all-talk network, which he calls Eyada.com. 
 Dave Herman, who was host of the morning show on the New York rock station WNEW-FM for 26 years, is Eyada.com's program director.
Initially, Eyada.com will offer one channel of programming about the entertainment industry, with 15 hours of programming each weekday and four hours each on Saturday and Sunday evenings. The lineup of hosts for the entertainment channel, which begins officially transmitting on Wednesday, includes Lionel, host of Court TV's "Snap Judgment"; Richard Johnson, editor of Page Six, the gossip page of The New York Post; George Rush and Joanna Molloy, The New York Daily News husband-and-wife gossip columnists, and Bob Berkowitz, the former host of Real Personal, a discontinued sex advice program on CNBC.
Next month, Eyada.com plans to introduce an all-talk channel for sports, and it expects to add channels on teen-agers, women and business by the end of 2000, Mr. Meyrowitz said.
He said he had raised just under $10 million from private investors and hoped to reach 20,000 listeners a day, ranging from age 20 to 40. The network intends to sell banner ads and audio commercials.
Lisa Allen, a senior analyst for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., criticized Eyada.com's planned programming, which she said "is not uniquely suited to the new medium."
She also predicted listeners would ignore the advertising. "If there's one thing that's clear, it's that Internet users do not like ads and avoid them," Ms. Allen said. "There's no reason to think they'll listen to radio ads on line."
But Mark Mooradian, a senior analyst for Jupiter Communications in New York, said that if the network could establish its brand, it might be able to create a niche for itself before the likes of Don Imus and Howard Stern hit cyberspace. "They're not on line yet, but I promise you they will be in a year," Mr. Mooradian said.
 JANE L. LEVERE

HEADLINE: Prayers Turn Political on the Future of Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Diana Gonzalez had not been to church in many years, so she was somewhat skeptical when she heard that St. Cecilia's Church in East Harlem was holding an ecumenical prayer service on a seemingly secular subject: the fate of Vieques, P.R., a small island that is home to a United States naval base, and that, for many Puerto Ricans, has long symbolized their colonial status.
"I wasn't sure what to expect," she said. "It is a political issue." 
 What she got was a religious service deeply laced with politics, not only from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is well known for interweaving the religious and the secular, but from the Archbishop of San Juan, Roberto Gonzalez Nieves.
"I found it amazing," she said of the Archbishop's use of religious teachings not only to make a case for the removal of the naval base, but to defend the granting of clemency to 14 Puerto Rican nationalists, 11 of whom were freed from prison Friday. "I didn't know he could do that."
But do that he did, before a church packed with raucous nationalists, who offered standing ovations.
The issue of Vieques has smarted in the Puerto Rican consciousness almost since the United States began using the island for naval exercises during World War II. But it has threatened to boil over since April, when one civilian was killed and four others were injured during a practice bombing run. Since then the base has been the site of almost continuous civil disobedience, although the authorities have made no arrests.
Nationalists say the military presence has harmed the 51-square-mile island's natural resources and its economy, and endangered its residents' health. The Navy says Vieques a small island seven miles off Puerto Rico, is the only place where it can stage realistic battle scenarios.
Yesterday's service, which also featured performances by the popular Puerto Rican singer Danny Rivera and by Mr. Jackson's daughter Sandita, was designed to show solidarity for the activists, and to capitalize on the burst of Puerto Rican patriotism engendered by the release of the members of the Puerto Rican nationalist group. The group, the Armed Forces for National Liberation, known as the F.A.L.N., was responsible for 130 bombings in the 1970's and 1980's.
Mr. Jackson wasted no time in making his point: if the United States fought for Kosovo's right to self-determination, if it believes in East Timor's right to self-determination, why do the people of Puerto Rico not deserve the same chance?
"It is a sin for one individual to own another -- it's called slavery," he said to appreciative murmurs.
"It's a sin for one nation to own another -- it's called colonialism," he said, bringing down the house.
Mr. Jackson also said that while he supported the Clinton Administration's offer of clemency, he had questions about the way it was handled. The offer, he said, came with no advance word to the prisoners, their families or their lawyers. And, he said, it came on the day that he and the Archbishop had scheduled a visit to Vieques, and called it an "attempt to divert attention" from Vieques.
Later, he said he believed that the lack of preparation for the announcement caused the delay in the prisoners' decision to accept the conditions imposed on their clemency, and he said that, in turn, had caused Hillary Rodham Clinton's "confusion" on the issue. Mrs. Clinton had said that the clemency offer should be withdrawn because the prisoners took too long to renounce violence.
Mr. Jackson said Mrs. Clinton would make a "strong candidate" for Senate, but refrained from saying whether he would support her.
The Archbishop, who was a priest at Holy Cross Church in the Bronx in the 1970's and 1980's, called the military activities on Vieques "an offense against the principles for which the United States wishes to stand." He quoted sections of the Roman Catholic catechism to build a case that there is no defense -- including good intentions -- for harming the innocent, and that peace is impossible without justice.
"For these reasons we appeal to principles that surpass all social, political and economic factors," he said. He also earned a wild ovation by striking an overtly nationalist tone, saying in Spanish that all Puerto Ricans, whether in New York or on the island, are "a single family, a single nation." And he referred to the F.A.L.N. prisoners as "political prisoners," and said mercy must go alongside justice and peace.
Afterward, the Archbishop said he was not advocating any particular future for Puerto Rico, a self-governing United States commonwealth that has considered both statehood and independence, both of which were voted down in a recent referendum. Rather, he said, he wanted whatever option the island picked to "foster the national identity of the Puerto Rican people."

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Indonesia Invites U.N. To Send Forces to Timor
President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia capitulated to international pressure and invited the United Nations to send a peacekeeping force to East Timor, conceding that Indonesian forces have been unable to control the violence there. A1
 
For many of the nearly 100,000 people who have fled or been forced out of East Timor, the nightmare has not ended. Militia men roam the refugee camps, harassing aid workers and journalists, searching for refugees who they believe voted for independence for East Timor. A1 

Asian officials say that the United States will have to play a central role in the peacekeeping force that Indonesia is reluctantly permitting into East Timor if the troops are to be inserted quickly enough to bring a halt to the killings. President Clinton insists that American troops would have only a "limited" role. A7
 
Bishop Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo of East Timor, the religious leader of most of the 800,000 people of East Timor and a winner of the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize who fled his homeland last week, called for a war crimes tribunal to bring charges of genocide against Indonesian military commanders and militia leaders. A6
 
Greece-Turkey Relations Warm
Relations between Greece and Turkey have improved with a suddenness that no one had expected in the wake of earthquakes in both countries. A1

North Korea has tentatively agreed to end its testing of long-range ballistic missiles in exchange for a commitment from the United States and Japan to move forward with economic assistance for the Communist Government there, American officials said. A7

Political Loss for Schroder
The political plight of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany intensified as his Social Democratic Party was thrown out of government in the eastern state of Thuringia and suffered election setbacks in the Ruhr, Germany's industrial heartland. A3
 
Call for Change in Kosovo
Sir Mike Jackson of Britain, the NATO commander in Kosovo, warned that soldiers have done about all they can to restore order, and civilian authorities must take over. A5

NATIONAL A8-15
 
Debate on Aid for the Aging Focuses on Women
Women are at the forefront of political struggles over entitlements because they live longer, are more economically insecure, have more chronic health conditions and eventually become more dependent on basic safety-net programs. A1
 
Concerns for Utilities
The power failures across the country this summer hint at deep-seated problems at the nation's largest electric power companies. Utilities that are now the lifeblood of the electronic age are grappling with deregulation, aging and long-neglected equipment, new and sometimes confusing transmission networks and greater demands for electricity to power the technology behind a booming economy. A1
 
Buchanan on Party Choice
Patrick J. Buchanan said that he was strongly leaning toward switching to a run in the Reform Party nomination. Lagging badly in his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Buchanan said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," "We are very close to making that decision." A8
 
Nationalist Controversy
The political firestorm surrounding the release of 11 Puerto Rican nationalists from prison continued unabated in San Juan. While it appeared that most Puerto Ricans supported their release, only a minority of islanders share the radical pro-independence politics of the nationalists who were released under a clemency offer extended by President Clinton. A8

Hundreds of Korean-born Americans laid red carnations at the Korean War Memorial in honor of the United States servicemen whose sacrifices gave them a second chance in life as adopted children of American families. Republican lawmakers promised a broader investigation of the tear-gas assault on the Branch Davidian compound than the one planned by a special counsel appointed by Attorney General Janet Reno. 2 Dead in Plane Crash
Two airplanes collided yesterday at an air show, killing both pilots, the police said. A twin-engine Cessna and an L-19, a World War II-vintage plane, were flying in close formation when one clipped the other and both crashed to the ground, witnesses said. (AP)

HEADLINE: North Korea Said to Agree to End Missile Tests

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
North Korea has tentatively agreed to end its testing of long-range ballistic missiles in exchange for a commitment from the United States and Japan to move forward with economic assistance for the Communist Government there, American officials said tonight.
The agreement, which was reached today in Berlin after five days of negotiations there by American and North Korean diplomats, appears to end the immediate threat that North Korea will test a new long-range missile this autumn. 
 American officials cautioned, however, that the agreement was dependent on what one described as "the always questionable sincerity of the North Koreans," and that North Korea could quickly reverse course and resume tests of its long-range missiles within weeks.
"They could be back in business with the missiles in a hurry," said one Clinton Administration official. "This is one positive step in what has proved to be a long, frustrating process."
The North Koreans have begun preparations for a new test of their latest long-range missile, which is believed to be capable of striking portions of Alaska and Hawaii. Washington officials have been monitoring activities at the North Korean launching site by satellite.
The Japanese have been particularly alarmed by the threat of a new test, because the last long-range missile tested by the Pyongyang Government flew directly over Japan.
The talks in Berlin were being held about the time that the Administration thought the North Koreans might test the new Taepodong 2 rocket. North Korea is marking the 50th anniversary of Communist rule this month, and some analysts had suggested that the missile test would be staged as part of the celebrations.
The United States, South Korea and Japan had shown an unusually high degree of diplomatic coordination in condemning North Korea and pledging to slow down food and oil assistance if the test was carried out. Today, while meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, during the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, President Clinton, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea committed to penalizing North Korea if it conducted the test.
Last month, Japan and the United States also agreed to conduct joint research on a missile-defense system that in theory could destroy ballistic missiles from North Korea.
In June, a United States envoy, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, laid out proposals essentially offering to lift some trade sanctions and to begin a formal recognition of North Korea in return for a halt to its missile testing and an end to its export of missile technology to the Middle East and Pakistan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Sees U.S. Playing Support Role In East Timor

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Monday, Sept. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that American troops would have a "limited but important function" in the peacekeeping force that Indonesia is reluctantly permitting into East Timor, although Asian officials insist that the United States will inevitably be drawn into a central role if troops are to be inserted quickly enough to stop the killings.
Speaking to reporters at his hotel this morning, Mr. Clinton described an array of tasks for American forces, such as flying troops from several nations into East Timor and supplying them with intelligence reports and communications help. 
 "All of that would require some presence on the ground in East Timor," Mr. Clinton said. But he said that the United States did not anticipate providing ground troops. "The Australians are willing to take the lion's share of the role," he said.
Acknowledging that many of the forces that would be used in East Timor had not trained together as NATO forces did before going to Kosovo this year, Mr. Clinton added, "We might be asked to provide some command and control."
Since Friday, a small team of American military officials from the Pacific Command in Hawaii has been in Australia to develop a plan for moving the peacekeepers into place, perhaps beginning this week.
United States officials say they believe that the American participation can be held to about 600 troops, though Australian officials and Asian diplomats who have been briefed on the plans say they expect the figure to be much higher.
"The assets offered by the Americans are very pleasing to the Australian defense community," John Howard, the Australian Prime Minister, said here, where he has frequently been meeting Mr. Clinton on the sidelines of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
The back-room negotiations over the composition and timing of an East Timor peacekeeping force dominated much of the first day and a half of a summit meeting that is supposed to focus on restarting a series of trade and economic initiatives after the recovery from the Asian financial crisis.
But President Clinton was clearly far more engaged on a host of security issues. On Sunday, he held a three-way meeting with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, jointly committing to penalize North Korea if it conducts a long-threatened missile test and to offer it economic enticements to freeze such tests. Administration officials said that the North Koreans agreed to such a freeze during negotiations in Berlin on Sunday, but the agreement is tentative and does not settle long-term problems between North Korea and Japan and South Korea.
And while Mr. Clinton's security officials were jousting this morning with Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation, his economic team was engaged in an increasingly complex negotiation with the most populous nation -- China.
On Saturday, Mr. Clinton and President Jiang Zemin agreed that both countries had to plunge into an effort to get China into the World Trade Organization in the next three months. But negotiations on Sunday were fitful, although the Chinese had desperately wanted the deal in April when Mr. Clinton walked away.
This morning, as the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, re-entered meetings with her Chinese counterpart, it looked increasingly unlikely that the major obstacles could be resolved before Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang left New Zealand on Tuesday.
Mr. Clinton also met for the first time with the new Russian Prime Minister, Vladimir V. Putin, on Sunday and in an unusually direct acknowledgment, told him that corruption could "eat the heart out of Russian society." Critics of the Administration's Russian policy say those warnings should have been delivered much earlier.
But East Timor has dominated much of the conversation among the leaders of 21 "economies" represented here -- the word is used to allow the participation of Taiwan and Hong Kong -- and Mr. Clinton was awakened at 1 A.M. today to be told that Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, had finally agreed to allow in the peacekeeping force.
This morning, Mr. Clinton praised several nations that had pressured Jakarta to change its mind. He added, "It's important to get the details worked out and get the force in in a hurry."
Conspicuously absent from his list was America's closest ally in the Pacific, Japan, which is Indonesia's largest supplier of foreign aid. Tokyo had declined to join in threats to cut off aid and other economic ties if Indonesia failed to stop the violence or let in the peacekeepers.
He held open the possibility of lifting the threat of sanctions as soon as Mr. Habibie carried through on the commitments he made Sunday night.
"If that happens," he said, "we can resume our work with the people of Indonesia."
Pentagon officials and diplomats say they expect the force to total about 7,000 troops, though it could take weeks to reach that level. About 4,500 would probably come from Australia, with New Zealand, Canada, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Sweden, France, Britain and Portugal all supplying far more modest numbers.
The United States would provide the aircraft and ships to transport armored vehicles and other equipment to East Timor, and Mr. Clinton suggested this morning that the process could start within days.
In Washington, congressional leaders expressed support as long as the commitment remained limited.
"Obviously what's been happening there is shocking and appalling," said Senator Trent Lott, the Republican majority leader from Mississippi. Speaking on CBS's "Face the Nation," he endorsed American logistical help but said, "If it involved troops on the ground, I think then a lot more questions are going to be asked."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: SPY KNOWN FOR 30 YEARS -- The Government said that for more than 30 years it had evidence of the espionage activities of Melita Norwood, the 87-year-old woman who admitted giving nuclear weapons research documents to the Soviet Union. Home Secretary Jack Straw said M.I.5 decided not to interview her out of fear of jeopardizing other investigations. It decided seven years ago never to prosecute her, he added. Two other people identified as agents in a book based on K.G.B. files were former Labor M.P.'s, Tom Driberg and Raymond Fletcher, both now dead. Warren Hoge (NYT) 

NORTHERN IRELAND: PROTESTANT PROTEST -- The ruling executive of Northern Ireland's main Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, unanimously condemned the report of an international commission to restructure the province's police service and said it would draw up alternative recommendations. But the 110-member body approved the continued participation of its leader, David Trimble, above, in the review of the deadlocked Northern Ireland peace pact under way in Belfast. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
GERMANY: SCHRODER UNBOWED -- Reeling from defeats in state and municipal elections, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder vowed to press ahead with an unpopular austerity program, involving budget cuts of $16 billion. After several costly months of wavering, he is trying to project the statesmanlike image of a leader prepared to take tough steps for Germany's future economic health. Roger Cohen (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
SRI LANKA: HIGH TOLL IN CLASHES -- In the fiercest fighting in months, 53 soldiers and more than 100 Tamil separatist rebels were killed in the northern Wanni region as the Government began an offensive to expand the territory in its control. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
PAKISTAN: TEST TREATY OPPOSITION -- Foreign Minister Sartaj Aziz told the newspaper Dawn that Pakistan will not sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty until the United States lifts all sanctions imposed after Pakistan tested nuclear devices in May 1998. The United States still restricts the sale of military equipment to Pakistan. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
CHINA: 2 OFFICERS REPORTED EXECUTED -- China has court-martialed and executed a general and a colonel for selling state secrets to Taiwan for at least $1.6 million, military officials said. They said retired Maj. Gen. Liu Liankun, 58, was executed by lethal injection in Beijing in August during renewed tension between China and Taiwan. Col. Shao Zhengzhong, 56, was also executed, the officials said. (Reuters)
 
AFGHANISTAN: REPORT ON WOMEN -- The United Nations monitor for violence against women said after a visit to Afghanistan that the Department of the Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice, which applies dozens of prohibitions to women, was "the most misogynist such entity in the world." However, Radhika Coomaraswamy of Sri Lanka saw some improvements, especially in the growth of private home schools and better access to health care. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: EXPULSION VOIDED -- A Supreme Court panel has overturned the February 1998 expulsion of Tom Hansen, an American accused of violating his tourist visa by serving as an observer at Government peace talks with Zapatista rebels. The high court found that his expulsion violated constitutional rights. More than 200 other foreigners have been expelled from Chiapas on similar grounds. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
ECUADOR: 12 FOREIGNERS ABDUCTED -- Eight foreign oil workers, including an American, and four European tourists have been kidnapped by more than 20 armed men in military uniforms near the northern border with Colombia. Ecuadorean Army officials said they suspect a left-wing Colombian guerrilla group may have been responsible, but added that they could not rule out right-wing paramilitary units from Colombia or common criminals. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: PROVINCIAL SUCCESS -- Despite running far behind in presidential polls, the governing Justicialist Party has won three of four provincial elections for governor. Victories in La Rioja, Misiones and San Luis were expected, as was an Alianza triumph in Chaco. The results confirm a trend in which the Justicialists will control most provinces no matter who wins the presidential vote next month. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
UNITED NATIONS
 
BELLAMY'S NEW TERM -- Carol Bellamy was appointed to a second five-year term as executive director of Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund. Her first term ends in May. Secretary General Kofi Annan said Ms. Bellamy, a former New York City Council president and former director of the Peace Corps, had served "with distinction and devotion." Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: DEFENSE SITES BOMBED -- American warplanes bombed two Iraqi air defense sites in response to antiaircraft fire, the United States European Command in Germany said. The planes bombed an air-defense warning site south of Mosul, about 250 miles north of Baghdad, the military said, and bombed an antiaircraft artillery site northwest of Mosul. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: AMERICANS JAILED -- Citing evidence that three Americans had been tortured, a judge gave them unusually light sentences for possessing weapons of war and trying to smuggle guns aboard a plane. The three -- Gary Blanchard, 36, John Lamonte Dixon, 36, and Joseph Wendell Pettijohn, 35 -- were given the same concurrent sentences: six months for possessing weapons of war and 21 months for taking dangerous materials on a plane. They could have been sentenced to life. (AP)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Edges Ahead by 1.90; Technology Issues In Retreat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks ended a lackluster session with mixed results yesterday as investors stepped back from Friday's rally in technology shares. The Dow Jones industrial average struggled to a slight gain, but most stocks ended lower as the dollar sank to a three-year low against the Japanese yen.
After shifting in a narrow range for much of the session, the Dow rose 1.90 points, to 11,030.33. 
 Broader stock gauges were lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.53, or 0.5 percent, to 1,344.13, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 42.29, or 1.5 percent, to 2,844.77.
Traders said investors, who sent the technology-dominated Nasdaq to a record of 2,887.06 on Friday, were ready to take profits yesterday.
"This is a time of constant rotation between sectors," said Robert Freedman, the chief investment officer for the John Hancock Funds in Boston. "We move to a new high, then spend another week or so consolidating before it's another group's turn."
Internet stocks had the steepest declines yesterday, as Yahoo lost 9 3/4, to 160 3/4, and Ebay fell 10 1/16, to 147 15/16.
America Online fell 6 3/16, to 90 1/8. Traders attributed the drop to an article in Barron's magazine in which a short seller -- an investor who bets that the price of a stock will fall -- said America Online's stock price could be cut in half because of price competition.
In a short sale, a trader sells borrowed shares on the expectation the price will fall before the stock has to be repurchased on the open market to replace the borrowed shares.
3Com rose 1 5/8, to 28 7/8, after saying it would spin off its Palm Computing unit, the maker of Palm electronic organizers.
Stocks were also pressured by the latest slip in the value of the dollar. Signs of economic growth in Japan have strengthened the yen, pushing it to more than three-year highs against the dollar.
A weaker dollar can hurt stocks in several ways. For one, it can entice foreign investors in United States stocks to keep their money in investments in their own country. It also makes imported goods more expensive.
Some analysts think higher prices of cars, electronics and other Japanese products could increase the chances that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for a third time this year to keep inflation in check.
Among Dow components, J. P. Morgan was the biggest decliner, shedding 3 1/4, to 124 13/16.
Procter & Gamble fell 1 7/16, to 101 11/16, after announcing plans to form an Internet-based company to sell beauty products.
Other consumer products companies, however, held up well. DuPont rose 2 3/4, to 68 1/2, and Eastman Kodak gained 2 7/8, to 75 15/16.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
Bond prices fell yesterday on expectations that further losses in the dollar, already at a three-year low against the yen, will sap international demand for United States fixed-income securities.
"There's a perception problem" when the dollar falls against the yen, said Mike Faust, who manages $400 million in global bonds at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser in San Francisco. The exchange rate is a "proxy for foreign demand" for Treasuries because Japan is the biggest foreign buyer of United States Government bonds.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 5/32, to 101 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.05 percent from 6.04 percent on Friday.
The dollar's decline against the yen the last three months has handed Japanese investors in Treasuries losses of 9 percent to 10 percent in yen terms, depending on the maturity of the security. United States investors would have made 1.2 percent to 1.8 percent over the same period.
