HEADLINE: Capitalizing on Asian Doldrums;
A G.E. Financial Unit Goes Rummaging for Bargains

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Six years ago, GE Capital's Japanese presence consisted pretty much of Taketo Yamakawa, a one-man show in a small office, scrambling to come up with opportunities in a stifled economy.
GE Capital, the biggest and most profitable unit of General Electric, one of America's biggest and most profitable corporations, had just bought a Japanese credit card company that it saw as its gateway to Asia -- and had put Mr. Yamakawa in charge. "I was struggling, trying to identify businesses and companies that GE could do," Mr. Yamakawa recalled. 
 Since then, GE Capital has done plenty. Barely in the time it has taken for Asia to begin to recover from its economic collapse, GE has gone on an acquisition binge that has solidified its position as a global powerhouse, left many of its competitors in the dust and bestowed a much-needed vote of corporate American confidence on the ailing but now improving region.
The last two years alone, it has made at least eight major investments in four Asian countries, expanding its assets to about $20 billion in the region. Acquisitions included two consumer-credit businesses, a life insurance company and a $5 billion leasing company in Japan, a consumer-credit business and a portfolio of car loans in Thailand and a life insurance unit in the Philippines. It also has its sights on a stake in a South Korean bank.
Though its General Electric parent has operated in Japan for more than a century, GE Capital traditionally had been weak in Asia, Japan included. So, company executives began sniffing around the region in the early 1990's with an eye to setting up corporate alliances or building companies from scratch.
Then the 1997 Asian financial meltdown and resulting recession turned the area into a vast bargain basement. Here was GE Capital's chance to buy up distressed companies and establish itself in the one part of the world where it lacked a strong presence.
"There's no question that financial turmoil has resulted in an environment that facilitates deal creation," Denis J. Nayden, president of GE Capital, said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Stamford, Conn. "Yes, we have moved into that opportunity."
To be sure, weaving those disparate businesses into the GE corporate net has not been easy. Throughout Asia, and particularly in Japan, culture clashes and resistance to foreign dominance have historically curbed the market for acquisitions, and some companies that have swooped in have crash-landed.
But GE Capital has had a lot of practice in business integration. Over the last 12 years, it has absorbed more than 300 companies, growing into the world's largest nonbank financial institution, with $300 billion in assets. In the process, it has mastered the art of identifying and acquiring underperforming companies and using its management expertise to turn them into moneymakers.
One of the first plums that GE Capital plucked in Japan in the wake of the economic crisis was the consumer-finance business of the Lake Corporation. Mr. Yamakawa, who today oversees GE Capital's consumer-finance operations in Japan, had long been impressed by Lake's lending business but believed its expansion into real estate and stocks was a big mistake.
As the company's financial problems worsened in late 1997, Mr. Yamakawa pounced. Though GE Capital would not say what it paid, it folded Lake's profitable operations -- its 2,800 people, its computer network, its buildings and its customers -- into a new company last year that it named the Lake Company, leaving the golf courses and other sagging properties in the original one.
Mr. Yamakawa then visited as many of Lake's 564 branches as he could, often making the rounds on weekends. He centralized some of the back-office operations and set up a call center, raising productivity and cutting costs. Most important, he brought in discipline -- in planning the business, budgeting for costs and charting out both short- and long-term strategies.
"Generally a Japanese company does not have discipline," Mr. Yamakawa said.
Now, the new Lake wants to become Japan's most efficient, most profitable consumer-finance company. Already, it is achieving double-digit growth, using giveaway umbrellas or lottery tickets to coax 1.5 million customers into transferring their accounts from the old Lake.
Even though Lake charges 27 percent on its unsecured consumer loans, compared with Japanese bank-deposit rates of around three-tenths of a percent, customers are flocking to its automated loan machines. What drives them is the ease of the transactions: if their applications are approved, the machines spew out the cash on the spot. Indeed, borrowers often pick up the cash in the morning and repay in the evening at another machine.
While GE Capital has accumulated an estimated $5 billion in assets elsewhere in Asia, Japan is the main arena of action. Its assets here total around $15 billion, and it has set a target of earning $500 million a year from its Japanese operations within two years, up from last year, though the company refuses to disclose figures. That growth would far outpace the time it took to reach a similar figure in Europe.
Another Japanese prize for GE Capital was a joint venture last year with Toho Mutual Life, an ailing insurer. Basically, GE cherry picked the best employees and most profitable operations and put them into a new company called GE Edison. It then sent in a team headed by one of its integration specialists, Masanori Miyajima, to coach Toho Mutual executives on the "GE way."
Mr. Miyajima introduced the GE practice of using graphs and charts in presentations and explained the principles of Six Sigma, a control management method that GE has embraced for achieving high quality and minimal defects in its products.
The integration team initiated studies of Edison's problems and ways to improve operations. It also helped draw up 90-day, one-year and 18-month plans for restructuring the business, setting the stage for its review process. (Typically, if an acquisition falls short of targets for an 18-month plan, GE concludes that something serious is wrong and reassesses the acquisition.)
By August, GE Capital was examining how to redesign the business practices at Edison's headquarters and at all 56 of its branches. The old system was unwieldy: a customer seeking a benefit payment at a branch office would fill out a form, the office would enter the claim in its computer and then send the form by mail to the head office, which would retype it into its computer.
Mr. Miyajima's group transferred the claims operation to a central location in the city of Yokohama, outside Tokyo. Now, branch offices relay all information to the new customer care center. As a result, said Rone Baldwin, the former president of GE Japan who now runs GE Edison, claims are paid more quickly, productivity has shot up 30 percent and overhead has gone down.
Mr. Miyajima also sought to instill the more informal GE culture at a company that had long been obsessed with protocol. He instituted casual-dress Fridays and instructed employees to dispense with honorifics like "director" and replace them with the simple "Mr."
While the Japanese seemed to adapt to the new openness, their American managers said they had remained vigilant. "I find that a larger proportion of people tend to think in hierarchical kinds of terms," Mr. Baldwin said. "People are sometimes more reluctant to speak up or be aggressive to senior people. I have to engage them more. I always worry more about what I'm not hearing than what I'm hearing."
Mr. Baldwin is trying to change other Japanese habits as well, like the practice of branch managers' greeting him at the train station when he comes to town. He tells them he would rather they stay in the office and work, and his campaign has apparently paid off. A regional manager in Osaka drew cheers from the other participants at a strategy meeting not long ago when he turned to him and said: "Baldwin-san, please understand if I don't escort you back to the train station. I'd rather use the time to work on my strategy plan."
It was a small but significant triumph in GE Capital's effort to instill a global GE culture wherever it goes. Daniel H. Mudd, president of GE Capital Japan, says that driving home its core concepts across its global empire is a key engine for the company's growth.
"Some companies have a very strong financial system that regulates and governs what they do, and some companies have a very strong marketing orientation: Coca-Cola, American Express," Mr. Mudd said. "My own view is that the way GE uses its levers is with culture, the business culture. It's not national culture. It's not an American culture, not an Anglo-Saxon culture.
"The challenge is taking that set of values and keeping their meaning the same, but adapting the interpretation to work in different countries," he added. "We want employees to intuitively share and understand a set of values and that GE culture, whether they're in Mexico, Japan, Spain or the United States."
Sometimes, of course, the GE way can seem downright bizarre to the American company's new Japanese employees. A few months ago, GE Capital held one of its signature let-your-hair-down workout sessions at Japan Leasing, which it acquired late last year for $5 billion. These discussions, aimed at breaking apart a business and drawing up new approaches that focus on the customer, have been a successful tool for integrating Asian businesses into the company, and in this case they led to fiery debate, with sheets of paper covered with captions and colored ink pasted up around the room.
Japanese rarely air their dirty laundry in public, so it was a bit intimidating for Japan Leasing's managers to be summoned to an open forum to discuss what was wrong and how to improve.
"The language of the workout is very new to Japan, and the discussion style is also new to Japanese," said Kohei Tanaka, president of the new Japan Leasing. "When we gave notice to people to please join the workout, people thought, 'What the heck is this thing?' "
Now employees regularly try to break apart the business to find new solutions, and these organized debating sessions are becoming a way of life at Japan Leasing. That is a departure from the old style.
"In Japan, we understand each others' intention, even without saying anything," Mr. Tanaka said. "All employees join the company at the same time in April and midcareer employees are not common. It's a homogeneous culture. The culture is to expect without saying anything."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Yen Hits3-Year High as Bank of Japan Ends Intervention

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Japanese yen resumed its more than two-month rally against the dollar yesterday, jumping 2.2 percent to a three-year high, and analysts said the rally should continue.
Yesterday's surge came after the Bank of Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market on Friday and staved off the rally for a day. The selling of yen for dollars worked for one day only because Japanese officials made clear then that they were not trying to change the direction of the yen. Instead, they were just trying to slow its rise. 
 "Further yen gains are a good bet in the near term," Karen Parker, director of currency research at Chase Manhattan Bank, said in a commentary for clients yesterday morning.
She pointed out that Masaru Hayami, the governor of the Bank of Japan, said that Japan could not move to reverse the direction of the yen without intervention support from the United States. And such support, based on recent comments from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, does not seem likely, she said.
In New York, the yen settled at 106.44 to the dollar, up from 108.81 on Friday. This was the strongest the yen has been since the spring of 1996.
In other currency trading, the dollar was down slightly against the single European currency, which settled at $1.0411, up from $1.0364 on Friday. Setbacks in local elections for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany knocked the euro lower earlier in the day, but it rebounded. For the year, the euro is still down 10.8 percent.
The rally of the yen has been fueled by the apparent turnaround of the Japanese economy after the longest recession since World War II. As foreign investors have gained confidence about the nation's economic outlook, they have bet that the Japanese stock market would go up. And to buy Japanese stocks, foreign investors have to buy yen, which is pushing its value higher.
So far this year, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks is up 29.4 percent in yen terms after a jump of 1.1 percent yesterday, to 17,909.29.
The changing view of the Japanese economy has been supported by surprising growth figures for the first two quarters of this year. It became harder to dismiss as an aberration the annual growth rate of 8.1 percent in the first quarter after the second-quarter annual growth rate came in at an unexpected nine-tenths of a percent.
But the rising yen also could pose a threat to the economic recovery. As the yen strengthens, it makes Japanese exports more expensive abroad. And these higher prices could cut into sales in this sector that is so important to the overall economy.
The Japanese authorities have worried about this threat, which is why they tried to change the direction of the yen with six big interventions in June and July. But they appear to have given up that strategy, possibly because it is difficult for any government to stand against the movement of its currency if investors around the world are pushing it in one direction.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Ready to Scrap Some North Korea Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Tuesday, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Rewarding North Korea for a tentative agreement to stop testing its new long-range missile, President Clinton said today that he was preparing to lift some of the trade sanctions that have barred commerce with the North for close to half a century.
The move is the first concrete step by Mr. Clinton to begin lifting economic sanctions that have been in place since the Korean War began in 1950. 
 But the gesture revives the question, raised by Congressional critics of the Administration's negotiations with North Korea, of whether the President is rewarding the hard-line Communist Government in Pyongyang for defusing a crisis that it created -- perhaps for negotiating advantage -- when American spy satellites detected that a missile launching appeared imminent.
The agreement on missile testing, disclosed on Sunday, is very limited, far from explicit and of unknown duration. In talks in Berlin with Charles Kartman, the State Department's chief negotiator with North Korea, the North Koreans agreed to suspend long-range missile testing while negotiations are under way on a more permanent ban.
But nothing binds the North to the agreement, other than the fear that whatever sanctions the United States lifts in coming weeks could be reimposed.
The text of a statement released in Berlin makes no clear mention of the missile test ban, saying only that both countries will "endeavor to preserve a positive atmosphere conducive to improved bilateral relations and to peace and security."
But Mr. Clinton, speaking to reporters here this morning before boarding a plane for Queenstown on New Zealand's South Island, said, "We understand and expect North Korea will refrain from testing long-range missiles of any kind while our discussions continue."
He called the tentative accord "an important initial step." In return, he said, he is looking at "easing sanctions" and moving toward a normalization of economic relations.
White House officials, working on the fringes of the Asian economic summit meeting that ended on Monday evening, portrayed the accord as a modest but important victory at a time of sudden instabilty throughout Asia.
"What we feared," one Administration official here said today, "was a new crisis in Korea at the exact moment that there's heightened tension between China and Taiwan and the insertion of peacekeeping troops in Indonesia. That would have been an ugly combination, and we may have ducked it."
Briefing reporters on Monday evening, Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, played down the scope of the sanctions to be lifted.
"Essentially North Korea would be in the same status as Syria," he said, meaning that the types and amount of commerce would still be strictly controlled. In theory the eased sanctions will allow some American companies to invest in North Korea -- though few American companies appear very eager to enter one of the world's last Stalinist nations, and one of the poorest.
State Department officials, speaking in Washington, said it would also be possible to transfer money to North Korea from family members in the United States. Most cash funneled into the country flows through Japan, which has a large Korean population centered in Osaka.
The lifting of the sanctions appears to be the first step in carrying out a strategy developed by former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, acting as a special envoy to North Korea for Mr. Clinton.
The report that Mr. Perry gave to Mr. Clinton has never been made public. But those familiar with it describe a proposal for a finely tuned series of moves to lift sanctions as North Korea begins to freeze its missile arsenal and end sales of missile technology to countries that Washington regards as rogue nations.
A 1994 accord froze activity at North Korea's biggest nuclear weapons plant, but it did not deal with the missiles that could carry small nuclear weapons. Mr. Berger suggested today that if the North Koreans made the moratorium on missile launchings permanent, a greater easing of sanctions could follow.
"If we're going to embark on a different course," he said, "a course which could conceivably lead to a long-term moratorium on a missile program, that suggests the possibility of a different kind of relationship with North Korea.
"Obviously, if that's the case, it's appropriate for us to take some steps which would ease some of the sanctions that we have in North Korea."
He added that "if they tested, obviously we would be going down a different path."
It is unclear how quickly a long-term ban on testing might be negotiated, but past experience with North Korea suggests that it could take years.
South Korea's President, Kim Dae Jung, also here for the economic conference, praised the North Korean commitment and characterized it as a victory for his own "sunshine policy," a series of modest economic openings to the South for North Korea. "We view this as a sign of sincerity in the North," Mr. Kim said.
Japan has been by far the most concerned about another missile test, especially after a previous test, in August 1998, crossed Japanese territory and created a political uproar. Japanese officials were distinctly more muted in their reaction today.
Japan has said it would consider returning to the kind of economic relationship the two countries had before the 1998 launching, but it has offered little else in the way of incentives.
The launching bolstered the position of conservatives in Japan who have long argued for a more robust military. The strong domestic reaction to the missile test last year also cleared the way for Japan to announce that it was joining an American-led project to develop a "theater missile defense" system.
One theory about the new North Korean missile, the Taepodong 2, is that it was invented as a negotiating chip, not as an offensive weapon. Many times in the last decade North Korea has created a crisis, then sought its reward -- usually food aid -- for defusing it.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Wondering if China Wants a Trade Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: QUEENSTOWN, New Zealand, Tuesday, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Two days after President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China rekindled their relationship and sent their negotiators off to strike one of the world's biggest trade deals, here's what they came up with: Confusion about whether China really wants a deal to enter the World Trade Organization this year and a vague agreement to meet in two or three weeks.
It was not exactly the display of urgent resolve that Mr. Clinton had hoped for when he asked Mr. Jiang to resume the talks immediately, perhaps thinking it was possible to close a deal while the two leaders were still here. And as the negotiators packed up and left New Zealand last night, Mr. Clinton's aides appeared mystified by China's strategy. 
 "No one is quite certain what this is all about," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic aides said, wondering aloud whether the Chinese were posturing, delaying, or had decided that a quickly declining economy at home made this a bad time for Mr. Jiang to allow fierce foreign competition into China's markets. Most theories, however, center on the how China may be seeking to parlay the accidental American bombing of their embassy in Belgrade on May 7 into some valuable trade concessions from the White House.
From the start, the negotiations over the conditions for China to enter the World Trade Organization have been about far more than trade. Its entry is one of the few areas where the United States and China can claim real progress in a relationship hurt by differences over Taiwan's future, charges of spying, and longstanding arguments over human rights.
Mr. Clinton argues that further integrating China into the world economy will force it to operate under global rules, and that if the deal is good enough he can demonstrate the economic benefits for American farmers and workers. Thus, Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Jiang in Auckland was carefully stage-managed to allow both sides to announce a resumption of relations after the embassy bombing.
Both Chinese and American officials described their meeting on Saturday as surprisingly free of rancor, and that China sought no further apologies for the embassy bombing that killed three people.
Two weeks before the meeting, Mr. Clinton sent a letter to Mr. Jiang urging that the two men use the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting here to resume negotiations. The message was reinforced by Senator Diane Feinstein, the California Democrat, who saw Mr. Jiang on a visit to China and told him that if China wanted to get Congressional approval of the deal, he had to act quickly.
"There's an assumption that if Congress can't get this passed before the Presidential election is in sight, it's pretty hopeless," Commerce Secretary William Daley said earlier this week. Next year Mr. Clinton's aides are unlikely to engage in a divisive argument over trade that could once again split the Democratic Party, and further widen a rift between Vice President Al Gore and American labor unions, which are opposed to the deal.
"The Chinese understand the calendar," Mr. Daley said.
They may understand it, but they do not appear driven by it. A round of preliminary negotiations in China last week, and then a second round here between China's trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, and American Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, never engaged in the substance of the issues dividing the two countries. Those range from American quotas on Chinese textiles, to the rights of foreign auto makers to enter China's markets, to the rules that ban the "dumping" of Chinese goods in the United States.
Even after Mr. Clinton implored Mr. Jiang at their Saturday meeting to start serious negotiations the next morning, the talks wandered in circles, participants say, drifting into differing understandings of what the two sides had already settled in April. In a private aside, Mr. Clinton raised the issue again with Mr. Jiang on Monday.
Mr. Clinton's efforts to implore the Chinese back to the table is a sharp reversal from April, when he walked away from a deal offered during an official visit to Washington by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. At the time he said it was insufficient, although American businesses said they were astounded at the breadth of concessions Mr. Zhu was willing to make at the time. When he returned to China Mr. Zhu was harshly criticized for giving away too much, particularly in telecommunications and agriculture. It is now unclear whether Mr. Zhu's concessions are still on the table, and many in the White House -- including Mr. Clinton himself, some officials say -- now regard the rejection of the deal in April as a mistake.
The head of the National Economic Council, Gene Sperling, sidestepped questions about the talks, telling reporters that "we've decided there is little to be gained by negotiating in public." Other officials spent much of the day yesterday insisting that they never expected a deal would be signed here -- even though several top Administration officials had told reporters, just a few weeks ago, that the talks could be wrapped up in days.
The turn of events has put Mr. Sperling, Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Clinton in an extraordinarily difficult position. All week they appeared to be more eager for China to get into the World Trade Organization than the Chinese are. That is a reversal from April, when China was pressing for admission, and the United States appeared to be insisting on ever-greater concessions.
American officials insist that they will not lower their demands for market openings simply because of the bombing. "It's a strategy I would try as well," one top official involved in the negotiations said today, "but in the end it won't work. And if it keeps us from getting a deal through Congress, it could backfire."
Nonetheless some American officials concede that Mr. Clinton would probably take a deal that was only slightly better than what he walked away from in April. The question now is how long it will take to get both sides to that point.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japanese Yen Rises 2.2% In a Rally Against the Dollar
The Japanese yen resumed its more than two-month rally against the dollar, jumping 2.2 percent to a three-year high. Analysts said the rally should continue. In New York, the yen settled at 106.44 to the dollar, up from 108.81.
The surge came after the Bank of Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market on Friday and staved off the rally for a day. But the selling of yen for dollars worked for only one day because Japanese officials made clear that they were not trying to change the direction of the yen, only slow its rise. Page C11. 

Giant Securities Fraud Is Suspected
Martin A. Armstrong, chairman of an investment and economic research company and its brokerage firm subsidiary in Hong Kong, has been charged with engaging in an enormous securities fraud that United States prosecutors say has left Japanese companies with more than $500 million in losses. A1.
 
Motorola Seeks Set-Top Box Maker
Motorola, long a dominant player in the semiconductor and cellular telephone markets, is trying to acquire General Instrument, the leading maker of cable set-top boxes, people close to the talks said. In doing so, Motorola is trying to be a leader in merging voice, data and video applications and funneling them directly into homes through one broadband cable device. Shares of Motorola fell $8.375, to $90.375. C2.
 
Stocks Mixed as Nasdaq Retreats
Stocks ended mixed as investors stepped back from Friday's rally in technology shares. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.90 points, to 11,030.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.53 points, to 1,344.13, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 42.29 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,844.77. C11.
 
Four Securities Firms Back Primex
The four largest securities firms in the United States have joined forces to back Primex Trading, which is aiming to be an electronic version of the New York Stock Exchange. The support gives Primex a jump-start in the world of electronic trading. C2.
 
Vencor in Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
Vencor, the troubled nursing home chain, filed for protection yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. C8.
 
Leo Burnett Realigns Management
Leo Burnett in Chicago, the agency company, is making two big changes, a corporate reorganization and a realignment of senior management. Effective Jan. 1, Richard B. Fizdale will relinquish his duties as chief executive and remain chairman. Roger A. Haupt, left, the chief operating officer, will assume Mr. Fizdale's duties as chief executive. Accompanying the management realignment is the formal adoption of a holding company structure for Burnett. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.
 
Talks Progress on U.A.W. Pacts
With the auto industry fat and happy, and both labor and management eager to keep it that way, the United Automobile Workers moved closer to agreeing to new contracts with DaimlerChrysler and General Motors. C7.
 
Incyte Shares Fall on Patent Ruling
Shares in Incyte Pharmaceuticals plunged and shares in Affymetrix soared after a ruling in favor of Affymetrix in a patent dispute over gene chip technology. C7.
 
Amex Could Face Rival for Funds
The American Stock Exchange is facing some fierce competition for its most popular products, financial instruments known as exchange-traded funds, which blend the characteristics of mutual funds, closed-end funds and stocks. Market Place. C12.

HEADLINE: U.S.-to-Jakarta Messenger: Chairman of the Joint Chiefs

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
As the violence in East Timor worsened, the Americans relied on one person to deliver a tough message to the Indonesian Government, senior Administration officials said today.
The go-between was the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, who dealt on the telephone with his counterpart, Gen. Wiranto, the head of the powerful Indonesian military forces. 
 While President Clinton condemned the Indonesian armed forces' refusal to stop the violence in East Timor, General Shelton spoke three times with General Wiranto, culminating on Friday with what senior officials called an "ugly message."
Using specific and emphatic language, General Shelton said the United States would block the International Monetary Fund from delivering the billions of dollars that Indonesia needs for additional recovery from the Asian economic crisis, senior Administration officials said.
In response, General Wiranto asked the United States to wait 24 hours while he visited East Timor to see whether his army was maintaining order, the American officials said. If he thought the army was lax, General Wiranto promised to ask for international peacekeepers.
Early Sunday morning General Wiranto phoned General Shelton with his report from East Timor, which was not good, and with the news that he was recommending that President B. J. Habibie ask immediately for the outside force.
The Administration decided late last week that it had to step up the pressure on Indonesia, officials said, to counteract a growing perception that the White House was dealing timidly with the crisis to preserve a relationship with Indonesia, a country of 200 million people that has rich natural resources.
"We weren't looking very valiant, and nobody liked that around here," an Administration official and. "Our spine got stiffened."
As Washington shifted from resisting sanctions to making a serious threat to the Indonesian economy, General Shelton relayed the increasingly urgent messages that the Indonesian army had to end the killings and destruction in East Timor. That message was underlined by Adm. Dennis C. Blair, commander in chief of the Pacific command, who traveled to Jakarta.
Now the Pentagon is beginning preparations to provide logistical support, about 150 American troops to work on communications, supplies and intelligence, for a multinational mission for East Timor, and the Administration is arguing that the channel to the Indonesian military speaks to the value of the years of training given to Indonesia's future military leaders in the United States and the millions of dollars in military aid for Indonesia.
"It was a big plus to have someone who could call the Indonesian military," a senior Administration official said. "They were the ones calling the shots. We had a unique asset, and I don't see how our military could have done it without their past history with these generals."
 General Shelton first met General Wiranto when the Indonesian visited Fort Bragg, N.C., in the early 90's. As the crisis deepened and it became clear that only General Wiranto could halt the massacres and destruction to the small territory, and not President Habibie, the Administration looked to the military to convey its messages.
"There's no question that General Wiranto could have turned off the violence much sooner," a senior military official said. "But he and the rest of the Government were waiting to see if their plan to get something less than full independence for East Timor would work."
At the request of the White House, General Shelton placed his first call to General Wiranto last Monday, and he received assurances that with the imposition of martial law in East Timor there would be peace in two days. But when militias and elements of the army continued terrorizing and murdering civilians, Admiral Blair went to Jakarta for a tense 30-minute interview with General Wiranto on Thursday. They allowed no aides in the meeting and spoke in English to avoid the need for interpreters.
Admiral Blair informed General Wiranto that the Administration was cutting off the remainder of American military relations with his country, according to Administration officials, and he left the country, canceling a speech that he was to deliver at a military academy in Bandung.
Two days later, after General Wiranto had traveled to East Timor with a team of diplomats from the United Nations Security Council, he called General Shelton with his decision to yield to international pressure and ask for security forces.
"That was the first credible sign that Indonesia would allow in peacekeepers," said a senior Administration official.

HEADLINE: Investment Manager Faces U.S. Charges Of Bilking Japanese

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
As a global investment manager, Martin A. Armstrong had little trouble selling himself to sophisticated clients overseas. On the strength of an apparently stellar performance record, an impressive Web site and his claims of running one of the world's largest economics advisory firms, he raised more than $3 billion from Japanese companies eager for American-style gains in their portfolios.
Now, those companies are facing giant losses and probably ruing the day they heard of Mr. Armstrong's investing techniques. 
 Mr. Armstrong, 49, chairman of Princeton Economics International Ltd. and its Hong Kong brokerage subsidiary Cresvale International Ltd., surrendered late yesterday to Federal authorities in Trenton and was charged with engaging in an enormous securities fraud that has resulted in more than $500 million in losses to investors.
According to a complaint unsealed yesterday by Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, Mr. Armstrong lied about returns he was generating in his customers' accounts and illegally pooled their money, essentially using funds raised from new investors to pay off older customers. The fraud appeared to be a desperate attempt to hide huge trading losses. Indeed, Mr. Armstrong owes some $1 billion to investors, in both principal and promised gains, prosecutors say. But only $46 million in assets remains in the accounts, they said.
The complaint said fraud occurred in accounts held by the Republic New York Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of the Republic New York Corporation, which also owns Republic National Bank of New York. As the case is sorted out, Republic's planned merger with HSBC of London has been delayed. The bank is conducting an internal investigation into the management of its futures division, operated out of Philadelphia, where the accounts of Princeton Economics clients were held. The shareholder meeting to vote on the proposed merger has been postponed until Oct. 12.
Karen Ng, a spokeswoman for HSBC in London, declined to comment on whether the new developments would affect the planned merger. A spokeswoman for Republic New York declined to comment. The bank was not charged with any wrongdoing and has suspended two top officials of the securities subsidiary.
The lawyer representing Mr. Armstrong, Marc Durant, a partner at Durant & Durant in Philadelphia, said his client vigorously disputed the accusations and maintained his innocence. "He definitely will fight this," Mr. Durant said. "He disputes how the fiduciary, which was Republic New York Securities, handled the funds and the accounts. He believes he's being made a scapegoat for honest, noncriminal trading losses." Although Mr. Armstrong acknowledges there were substantial losses in the accounts, he disputes prosecutors' figures of $500 million.
The arrest of Mr. Armstrong is the latest piece of a puzzle that began to emerge in May when the Financial Supervisory Agency, Japan's securities regulator, surprised management of Cresvale's Tokyo offices with an audit of its accounts. Cresvale, which also has offices in London, New York and Sydney, was acquired by Princeton Economics in 1995.
According to prosecutors, Cresvale raised $3 billion from investors on the strength of Mr. Armstrong's fictitious record as a money manager. An April 1998 announcement of a new hedge fund started by Mr. Armstrong, for example, put his firm's investment returns at more than 28 percent a year since 1992. Instead, prosecutors say, Mr. Armstrong lost hundreds of millions in risky currency and commodities trading.
To hide his losses, Mr. Armstrong paid old investors with the proceeds raised by newer clients, a venerable type of fraud known as a Ponzi scheme. It was named for Charles Ponzi, who swindled $15 million from 40,000 people after World War I. The people thought they were investing in postal reply coupons, but Ponzi actually pocketed most of the money, paying early investors with cash from new investors.
Mr. Armstrong of Maple Shade, N.J., was released on $5 million bond on his signature. He did not return a telephone call to his office seeking comment. A secretary at Princeton Economics in Princeton, N.J., said no one was at the office late yesterday afternoon to comment.
Prosecutors say that Cresvale sold what it called Princeton Notes, backed by Princeton Economics, to Japanese companies promising returns of at least 4 percent and the potential for much more. With low interest rates in Japan, the promised returns were attractive. No one outside of Japan, nor any individuals, are known to have invested with Cresvale.
As of late August, there were 113 accounts managed by Princeton Economics. Among the companies that had invested money with Princeton Economics were the Alps Electric Company, the Chudenko Electronics Company and the Gun Ei Chemical Industry Company. Bloomberg News reported yesterday that Alps Electric said it might lose as much as $185 million in the current fiscal year because of its investment with Princeton Economics. Shares of these companies and others that invested in Princeton Notes have fallen in Japanese trading in recent days.
Mr. Armstrong published journals and newsletters on financial subjects, giving him the patina of an intellectual. He was quoted in numerous publications, including The New York Times, on subjects ranging from projections on interest rates to the trading of foreign currencies and other commodities. He was a critic of the European monetary union, and commented on the silver market when Warren E. Buffett was buying silver last year.
In April 1998, he joined Magnum Global Investments to form a hedge fund offering institutions and wealthy investors access to what he called his market-forecasting expertise. A promotion for the hedge fund stated that Princeton Economics could forecast trends on markets more accurately than other managers because of its economic model, "which provides specific forecasting on more than 30,000 economic and financial statistics worldwide." The model predicted the 1987 stock market crash, the 1994 bond crash and the demise of the yen since mid-1995, according to the sales material.
But Mr. Armstrong had had run-ins with regulators before. In 1985, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission filed a complaint against Mr. Armstrong and three consulting companies he ran for failing to register as commodity trading advisers and for not maintaining proper records. Two years later, the commission filed a second complaint charging that Mr. Armstrong's company, Economic Consultants of Princeton, misrepresented hypothetical performance results and omitted a required disclaimer in its advertisements.
When he filed to overturn the commission's findings in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, Mr. Armstrong said he had begun working at a coin and stamp dealership at age 13. He was a millionaire at 15, according to court documents, and opened his own collectors' store when he was 21. In 1973 he began publishing commodity market predictions as a hobby. The appeals court upheld the commission's ruling; the Supreme Court declined to hear his case.
Mr. Armstrong's link to Republic Securities appears to be James Curley, a director of Cresvale, who was chairman of Republic Securities from March 1994 through June 1996. Since 1994, James Sweeney has been president of Republic Securities. On Sept. 1, Mr. Sweeney and William H. Rogers, president of the firm's futures division, were suspended by the bank pending the outcome of its investigation. The bank is cooperating with Federal authorities.
According to prosecutors, the futures division of Republic Securities was dominated by Mr. Armstrong's trading, accounting for 90 percent of its business. Princeton Economics may have opened accounts at Republic as early as 1995.
Prosecutors say that Mr. Armstrong conducted his fraud with the help of letters on Republic New York Securities stationery from Mr. Rogers; the letters inflated the values of customers' accounts. Authorities allege that when a customer wanted confirmation of his account's value, Mr. Armstrong would figure how much the client should have earned under its agreement with Princeton Economics, then request that Republic Securities issue a letter confirming that amount. Mr. Rogers would then provide Princeton Economics with that letter.
If the actual balance in the investor's account was less than the figure supplied by Princeton Economics, funds from other accounts were generally transferred to cover the shortfall, prosecutors said.
In addition to the criminal charges, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit yesterday against Mr. Armstrong and Princeton Economics alleging securities fraud. The judge in the case froze the assets of both Mr. Armstrong and Princeton Economics and appointed a receiver for the company. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission also filed a complaint alleging that Mr. Armstrong defrauded customers through material misrepresentations. Neither Mr. Armstrong nor his firm were registered as commodity trading advisers, as is required.
Ms. White said, in a statement: "This case should send the clear and concise message that those who commit securities fraud in the United States, even if they use offshore entities and victimize foreign investors, cannot escape responsibility for their actions."

HEADLINE: U.N. MOVING AHEAD TO ORGANIZE FORCE FOR EASTERN TIMOR

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Security Council members worked late tonight on a draft resolution to authorize the use of force in East Timor, and some members assembled troops, ships, advisers and aircraft in preparation to move quickly into the territory to end the violence there.
Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali A. Alatas, told Secretary General Kofi Annan and the Security Council today that his Government would welcome speedy deployment of a multinational force but had some questions about the nationalities of its commander and the troops. 
 The Indonesian President, P. J. Habibie, met today with a United Nations human rights official, who said the Indonesians agreed to the creation of an international commission to investigate possible atrocities in East Timor. Page A16.
 The Security Council was refining a draft from Britain that would mandate troops to control militias that have been terrorizing the East Timorese and driving them from their land. The draft, which the Council is expected to act on in a day or two, indicates that the commander would be an Australian, a decision strongly backed by the United States.
Although Mr. Alatas said Indonesia would place no conditions on the force, he said it would prefer soldiers from members of the Association of South East Asian Nations. Some of those nations, including Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines, have said they will take part. British Gurkha troops based in Brunei are also on call.
For many Indonesians, however, Australia is a provocative and politically explosive choice to lead the troops because it has been a strong supporter of East Timorese independence leaders in the past and the two countries had very rocky relations until relatively recently. Some Council members also have qualms about the choice, a diplomat said.
In Darwin, an Australian port 250 miles from East Timor, preparations for action already have begun, with the Australians apparently confident they will lead the force.
Australia has appointed a commander, Maj. Gen. Peter Cosgrove, a Vietnam War veteran, and is assembling ships, helicopters and a high-speed catamaran capable of carrying more than 500 troops. France has sent four military officers to advise the Australians, and 10 American military experts are in Darwin to help draw up plans.
A Pentagon spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig R. Quigley, said the United States is preparing to use cargo planes to transport troops and equipment, but had not selected ships or soldiers for duty.
The Council appears united on the need for a quick deployment to restore order in East Timor; on Tuesday in Dili, the United Nations closed its besieged compound there and, with Jakarta's permission, began evacuating 1,300 refugees hiding there to Australia.
After selecting a commander, the Council is unlikely to specify the number or nationalities of soldiers in the force, leaving those decisions to the countries contributing troops.
In Jakarta, nationalists are demanding that no Americans, New Zealanders or Portuguese take part. Portugal was the former colonial power in East Timor, and Americans, New Zealanders and other non-Asians are apparently viewed as prejudiced against Indonesia.
One diplomat suggested that Indonesia's long years under often harsh Dutch rule left a legacy of revulsion against European domination that explains the persistent racial subtext in the debate about peacekeepers.
Secretary General Annan told the Council today that Indonesian "sensitivities" had to be taken into account, diplomats said.
"We didn't come here to prevent any country from participating," Foreign Minister Alatas said, but he hinted broadly that the issue should be weighed. "It is up to the countries themselves to consider whether it is appropriate, whether their presence would or would not exacerbate the situation."
Mobs in Indonesia have been attacking Australian diplomatic and trade missions during the last week, including an attack today on the office of the representative of Western Australia in Surabaya. Mr. Alatas called the demonstrations responses to protests at Indonesian consulates and its Embassy in Australia, which he said cannot get basic supplies.
Despite the outside chance that mounting political pressures will cause President Habibie to balk, diplomats here were relieved to hear Mr. Alatas's message today and are more or less optimistic.
"I'm not sure if I'm optimistic or pessimistic," Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States representative to the United Nations, said in an interview after the Council meeting. But he said he saw no real opposition to quick action, and he marveled at the speed with which the situation had turned around.
"Forty-eight hours ago we were looking at the worst," he said. "Twenty-four hours ago we were trying to parse the meaning of Habibie. Now we're working on implementation. That's a pretty impressive record for the Security Council and for Kofi. So far, even if we got there too slowly, the last 48 hours have been a major step forward."
Portugal's envoy, Antonio Monteiro, said he welcomed Mr. Alatas's assurances that he would not set conditions. "We are very encouraged," he said.
Sir Jeremy Greenstock, Britain's representative and one of five envoys sent to Indonesia last week to urge the Government to accept outside help in East Timor, said today on his return that he thought Government officials had underestimated the scale of the crisis. The week of violence by pro-Indonesian forces was set off by a vote for independence by the territory's population.
Mr. Alatas told reporters today that while he would like more discussion on the composition of the force, "what is important is that Indonesia would like to see this security cooperation, the sending of a force, as soon as possible."
He said an international peacekeeping force had been authorized under a May 5 agreement on the future of East Timor, but only in the third phase of the process, after the Indonesian Parliament had ratified the referendum results, probably in November, and the United Nations took over administration of East Timor until the new country's first elections. Until the parliamentary ratification, Indonesian troops were supposed to be responsible for law and order.
"Now, however, the situation is different," Mr. Alatas said.
Setting up a multinational force with Security Council backing rather than an full-dress United Nations peacekeeping operation is essential to the Clinton Administration because of Congressional restraints on any American role in the latter type operation and on payments for such operations. A Security Council force does not require Congressional notification and the bills for it go to the countries involved.
One unknown factor in the Indonesian political environment is the attitude of Megawati Sukarnoputri, whose party came in first in Indonesian parliamentary elections in June (but did not gain a majority). Ms. Megawati initially opposed allowing the East Timorese to vote on their future in a referendum.
Although she later seemed to soften that view, the Security Council mission that visited Indonesia last week said she again criticized President Habibie strongly for agreeing to sign the May 5 agreement with Portugal and the United Nations. She told the team that President Habibie's "legitimacy as leader of Indonesia was fading away."
Mr. Habibie, like Ms. Megawati, is a likely candidate for the presidency when a choice is made by indirect election through the parliament later this year. She could attract support in the armed forces and other strongly nationalist groups.
It is not inconceivable, some United Nations officials and diplomats say, that a strong nationalist tide could undo the East Timor agreement, or at least weaken it and allow a civil war to break out.
Jose Alexandre Gusmao, the rebel leader known as Xanana, told the Security Council mission last week that the conditions for an outbreak of fighting between his forces and the Indonesian Army already existed.

LENGTH: 170 words

HEADLINE: India Can Make Room To Embrace the New

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 10 front-page article reports that the campaign for the Indian parliament by N. Chandrababu Naidu, the chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, one of India's largest and poorest states, raises doubts whether the attempts at modernization by a progressive politician like Mr. Naidu can coexist with the "mostly rural, illiterate" people he represents. 
 Similar doubts were raised when Norman Borlaug, a farm scientist and Nobel laureate, ushered in the "Green Revolution" in India in the late 1960's. However, tradition-bound farmers in India quickly adapted to the concepts of modern scientific farming advocated by Dr. Borlaug, raising grain production by many millions of tons.
Much of the credit for the increasing growth rate of India's gross domestic product goes to the "rural, illiterate" farmer. He knows how to do his job, and in time he will learn enough about the computer revolution and what it can do for him.
KANGAYAM R. RANGASWAMY
Maryland Heights, Mo., Sept. 10, 1999

HEADLINE: Mother of 3 Is Charged in Daughter's Death

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A 21-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday with killing one of her three small children, a bruised and battered 2-year-old girl who apparently had borne the brunt of her mother's secret abuse for a long time until Sunday night, when she fell unconscious after another beating and died, city officials said.
The mother, Venisha Clarke, of 600 Park Place, who has a record of petty theft but no record of child abuse, was charged with second-degree murder after an autopsy found that her daughter, Rickiana Campbell, had died of "child abuse syndrome," the cumulative effects of severe and repeated beatings. 
 Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, said the autopsy showed that the child had suffered a skull fracture and other injuries, including broken bones and bruises, that had been inflicted over many weeks or months and were "in various stages of healing."
Neighbors and a sister of Ms. Clarke in a rundown, four-story walk-up on the border of Prospect Heights and Crown Heights were stunned over the child's death and the mother's arrest. They said Ms. Clarke seemed a devoted if frustrated mother, pregnant with a fourth child and apparently overwhelmed by the problems of single parenthood and poverty.
While neighbors had not detected signs of child abuse, several recalled that Rickiana had worn long, concealing dresses and long-sleeved shirts throughout the burning summer, while her brothers and the other children playing on the sidewalk had worn shorts and T-shirts. Others remembered that she had become increasingly quiet and withdrawn.
"We were shocked," a neighbor, Lisa Johnson, 28, said. "Nobody knew she was beating the child. We knew the little girl wore long dresses during the summer and long-sleeved shirts, but we just thought that was how she dressed."
Ms. Clarke's sister, Simone Thompson, who lives in the same building, said that after Rickiana died Sunday evening, the police showed her pictures of the child's battered body. "I never saw the bruises before," she said. "So when they showed me the pictures last night, it was shocking. My sister is a happy person and a good mother. I don't know what happened."
Ms. Clarke's two other children -- a boy nearly 4 years old and a 10-month-old boy -- bore no signs of physical abuse and were placed together in a foster home yesterday by the Administration for Children's Services, according to Jennifer Falk, a spokeswoman for the city agency, which has a broad mandate to protect children from abuse and neglect in New York City.
Ms. Falk said that Ms. Clarke had never been reported as a child abuser, but had come to the agency's attention in early 1998, when she had to serve 38 days in jail at Rikers Island for shoplifting and asked a friend to care for the two children she then had -- her son and daughter -- in her absence.
The friend, however, was arrested for beating the children and was herself sent to Rikers Island. The children, who came under the jurisdiction of the city, were placed in foster care and were returned to Ms. Clarke after she completed a course in parenting skills in June 1998.
The boy, Ricardo, known as Bobby, was returned to Ms. Clarke in November 1998, and the daughter, Rickiana, was returned to her in February. The youngest boy, Paul, was born in November, according to Ms. Falk, who did not provide the names of the children, although neighbors of Ms. Clarke did.
"We had no indication that this woman ever abused her children," Ms. Falk said, "only that she had perhaps neglected them by leaving them with someone incapable for caring for them."
According to the city's most recent count, 36 abused or neglected children who had been identified in reports to the children's services agency died last year, up from 30 children in 1997 and 24 in 1996. The numbers, Ms. Falk said, include suicides and deaths attributed to accidents and illness, as well as homicide, and not all of those children were slain by persons known to the agency, which investigates 51,000 reported cases of child abuse or neglect annually.
Ms. Clarke, an unemployed welfare recipient who paid $750 a month for a two-bedroom apartment on the top floor of a gloomy brick building, had a record of five convictions for shoplifting, and neighbors said she had tried to make ends meet by stealing clothing from shops and selling it on the street. Her children had different fathers, but none lived with her, the neighbors said.
Ms. Johnson recalled that Ms. Clarke had seemed to turn her life around after emerging from Rikers Island early last year. "After she came out of jail, she seemed to go straight," Ms. Johnson said. "She was always with the kids, always seemed to be very attentive."
It was unclear when the abuse of Rickiana began, although the long dresses and long sleeves had been worn all summer, the neighbors said. It was also unclear when the skull fracture was inflicted.
But about 3 P.M. on Sunday, the police said, Ms. Clarke called 911 to report that Rickiana had lapsed into unconsciousness. Valerie Fletcher, 48, a resident of the building whose grandchildren played with Ms. Clarke's children, recalled that the police and paramedics arrived almost simultaneously and went up.
She said the paramedics carried the little girl out and put her in an ambulance, while Ms. Clarke was taken out and put in a police car. "First I saw her with the police, and she seemed so calm," Ms. Fletcher said. "But then as they took her away, I could tell she was crying."
Rickiana was taken to Methodist Hospital, but never recovered consciousness. She was pronounced dead about 6 P.M. Confronted with pictures of her daughter's body, Ms. Clarke acknowledged, investigators said, that she had beaten the girl.
Why it had happened was anybody's guess.
"She had three kids and she was pregnant with another," Ms. Johnson said. "I think she was overwhelmed taking care of her kids, and with another on the way it may have been too much to handle. She didn't have a husband or a mother who could help her. It could send someone over the line."

HEADLINE: Going Beyond the 'Wow' Factor on Giant Screens

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
Shot with a 70-millimeter camera and chockablock with spectacular adventure and nature scenes, the giant-screen movie has become a hugely popular fixture at 300 specially equipped theaters worldwide, but it is experiencing an identity crisis.
Should the films be devoted only to outsize visual effects or should they also be built around story lines? 
 Can the entertainment values of the commercially shown giant films be retained in educational films shown in museums and other institutions?
These are among the issues being discussed this week at one of the more sedate movie conventions of the year, one held by the international Giant Screen Theater Association around Manhattan and at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, a major site for showing large-format movies. The convention, which ends today, has attracted 1,000 delegates, conservatively dressed, eminently civil and concerned about the future of a medium that has recently taken off commercially.
Movies like "Everest," which has earned $91 million, an unprecedented amount for a giant-screen film, have put a Hollywood spin on a field that has always enjoyed a rather documentarylike gentility.
"There's great growth in the commercial area and also in the institutional, though that's a bit slower," said Jim Marchbank, the association's president and chief executive of Science North, a science center in Sudbury, Ontario. "Many more films are being made for both segments, and more films will cross over."
Giant-screen movies, like those shown at the Sony Imax theater in Manhattan, have been around for about 30 years. Traditionally they have been designed for either commercial or institutional audiences, although the occasional film appeals to both. Each year about 20 films are released, all running 40 to 45 minutes for fast audience turnover.
The large screen, which can be six stories high, lends itself to spectacle, which in turn calls for dazzling clarity and stupendous sound. Many films have nature motifs: "Africa: The Serengeti," "The Living Sea," "Island of the Sharks." Others are about adventure and sports: "Everest," "Olympic Glory," "Extreme" (about extreme sports). But filmmakers are wondering if they should be delivering more narrative with the grand sights.
The conference has attracted producers, distributors and representatives of museums, science centers and theater chains. While they are a far cry from their hard-partying, rabidly self-promoting counterparts at standard festivals, their goals are similar. They have come to discuss and pitch projects, attend screenings of a dozen films, take part in workshops, and schmooze about the complications of making movies, sometimes in 3-D, for soaring vertical or domed screens in auditoriums so steeply pitched that viewers can get vertigo.
Producers of such movies earn much less from box office revenues than do conventional filmmakers. Institutions use the films as fund-raisers and keep much of the proceeds. And while directors are not working with stars like Tom Cruise, costs are high. "Prints are about $100,000 U.S. a minute," said Mr. Marchbank.
Being in the field with a 70-millimeter camera is not a relaxing experience. "I'm daunted by the difficulties," said Tim Liversedge, whose production company is close to the Okavango swamps in Maun, Botswana. He has made standard wildlife films for the BBC and National Geographic, and now, attracted by the growing audience for giant-screen movies, he is trying the 70-millimeter format. In keeping with the trend, he would like to stir some dramatic narrative into the action. "I want to tell the story of the region," he said.
One problem faced by filmmakers like Mr. Liversedge is the camera, which weighs almost 90 pounds and is not exactly geared for quick strikes in the bush. Also, there is only one camera, not three as there are on many wildlife shoots. A film cartridge lasts only three minutes, making it tricky to reload at a crucial moment. On top of this, the camera sounds like a small motor, thereby announcing itself to wary beasts. Finally, filming doesn't begin until eight seconds after the camera has been rolling, by which time the animal could be in the next game park.
Working with conventional equipment, Mr. Liversedge said, it takes years to complete a nature film, mainly because of uncooperative animals. He hesitated to guess how long it would take with a 70-millimeter camera.
Well, they took a camera up Mount Everest, didn't they?
"Everest doesn't move," Mr. Liversedge said.
Along with the nature films, there has been a recent influx of biographical and historical films with dramatic themes. Large-screen movies experience their identity crisis most when visual spectacle meets story line. As productions grow more ambitious, they run the risk of overstepping themselves. Dramatic scenarios often are not effective with audiences conditioned to seeing roller-coaster rides, bounding lions, 40-foot waves and crashing avalanches.
"The primary aspect has to be entertainment," said Greg MacGillivray of MacGillivray Freeman Films, which made "Everest" and other films. "The audience pays a lot of money for their tickets and for a short amount of time they want a unique entertainment they can't get elsewhere."
The entertainment factor is important to museums, as well. The institutions charge a healthy admission fee for giant-screen movies, deriving important revenue from them and raising money that often helps finance new films. "It's possible for films to have high educational and entertainment value," said Mr. Marchbank of Science North. "If people aren't having fun, they aren't learning."
In museums, a film must both entertain and educate. For example, Science North was the co-producer of "Gold Fever," which chronicles the Klondike gold rush and examines the cultural and economic significance of gold. A film like that is not likely to show in a commercial theater. But often the distinction is not so clear-cut. "Some of these films are neither fish nor foul. They don't fulfill either market," said Truett Latimer, president of the Houston Museum of Natural Science.
The Houston Museum produced "Alaska: The Spirit of the Wild," which was nominated for an Academy Award in 1998. Mr. Latimer is a keen appraiser of the emerging scene in giant movies. "You see the Hollywood types drawn by the grosses 'Everest' makes, not realizing what the economics are," he said. Or that lions don't like multiple takes.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
A company aims to make it easier for executives to work while flying around in corporate jets.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey 

 BODY:
ON occasions when retired chief executives and other corporate bigwigs run into one another, they seldom talk about how they miss the old grind at the office. But they can get downright teary when they talk about how much they miss that lovely airplane.
The corporate jet is the perk of perks for business travelers. If you've flown in one -- soaring at a turbulence-free 50,000 feet near the speed of sound, breathing abundant fresh air in a cabin as comfortable as a living room, able to leap from exit door to car without making that death march through some vast dingy airport -- you know why there are 8,000 corporate jets now under registry. Or why there is an industry backlog of several years for new orders for most top models. And other companies are creating a big new market by acquiring a supply of corporate jets and essentially dispatching them, like airborne rental limousines, to customers who buy shares in the venture. 
 A good many working stiffs, including those who fly first and business class but most especially the ones wedged into coach on those eight-hour flights, obviously resent the fact that the boss might travel in such luxury, without having to deal with passive-aggressive flight attendants, in a Gulfstream V that set the stockholders back about $40 million. But for the sake of argument, assume that flying the brass in a private jet makes economic sense to many companies whose executives' time means real money. Shouldn't the stockholders at least expect the boss to work at something more important that the games on his laptop while traveling in such comfort?
"No matter where you sit on a commercial plane, that trip from New York to Los Angeles uses up basically the whole day," said Dennis Ferguson, the president of a company called Airshow Inc. that is the major supplier of flight-information systems to corporate jets.
The most familiar of these systems is the in-flight map display, a video screen that shows topographical maps of the ground below superimposed with the airplane's present position, course, speed, altitude and estimated arrival time.
Though some executives say they can watch this gizmo for hours, mesmerized as it depicts them soaring over the earth, that's pretty old technology. At the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York recently, Mr. Ferguson and the company's vice president for business development, Patrick Flynn, were talking about new technology, including a system that allows the so-called information superhighway to start finding its way into the skies and keeping the tycoon actively on the job.
For years, corporate and other aircraft have had systems that can receive television signals from satellites, though the service usually works only when flying over land. But Airshow recently introduced a product, Network '99, that collects and transmits real-time, customized textual information, including news, financial and market data, as well as E-mail and other text messages, to specific aircraft from the company's headquarters in Tustin, Calif.
The system is still in its infancy because of current bandwidth limitations on the transmission to text. But that's changing, and in a few years, the corporate jet, and commercial planes as well, could be fully linked not only to on-ground data banks but to to the Internet, with companies like Airshow acting as information providers as well as distributors.
Getting this technology to fly means that Airshow has to keep track of where all those company planes are in the air at any given time. This raises issues of both logistics and security.
Mr. Ferguson says he has that covered. He used to run a company in Chicago that provided high-security limousine transportation for corporate clients.
"I see corporate travel as a security issue as well as an information issue," he said.
 
Not So Fast
There was a flurry of dissenting reader responses to an item in this space two weeks ago about the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Inspass system, which is designed to allow frequent business travelers at selected airports to bypass long immigration lines by scanning a card and their hand through a machine. The I.N.S. said that the system hadn't expanded as quickly as anticipated because international business travelers didn't seem to be aware of how easy it was to get and use the pass (the only requirement is two or more international business trips a year).
"Easy my foot!" one executive hooted. "Every time I've tried to use mine, the system has been down, and that means you go to the end of the immigration line. Then, seeing that you tried to use the pass, the immigration officer can get surly, because the pass represents a threat to his job. I let my pass expire because it wasn't worth the trouble."
Another caller said that the airport I.N.S. offices to apply for the cards were not open at convenient times -- "not even the hours they have posted," he said.
The I.N.S. did not return a phone call yesterday asking for comment on these complaints.

HEADLINE: Trading With China

 BODY:
Relations between the United States and China, which lurch from crisis to friendship to crisis, appear to be at least temporarily back on a positive footing. On Sunday President Clinton and Jiang Zemin, the Chinese President, gave a welcome nudge to negotiators to complete a broad agreement enabling China to enter the World Trade Organization, possibly before the organization's meeting in Seattle in November. It is not clear how quickly China wants to close a deal. But bringing China into the global trading community will yield big dividends, and the Administration should make a maximum effort to conclude an agreement.
Arrangements for Chinese entry into the W.T.O. were supposed to have been announced in April during the American visit of Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. But because of last-minute political pressure from Congress, where antipathy toward China runs high, the Administration backed away. Its failure of nerve embarrassed the Chinese and proved costly. Valuable negotiating time was lost because China stopped its talks with the United States in protest over the accidental bombing of its embassy in Belgrade in May. China may now be trying to use the bombing incident to squeeze more trade concessions from Washington. In addition, the recent disclosures about possible espionage and China's bellicose language directed at Taiwan have made it hard to get the talks started again. 
 Some parts of the American economy, including textiles, are bound to suffer from increased Chinese competition. On the positive side, American farmers, investment firms, telecommunications and other businesses will gain from greater market access in China. The whole world would benefit by China's agreeing to adhere to the openness, fair access and rules for the resolution of disputes embodied in the W.T.O.'s charter.
Whatever happens, the issues raised by trading with China are certain to have repercussions in American politics. Patrick Buchanan, the most vociferous advocate of protectionism in the Republican field, has vowed to make China a major issue if he bolts the party and runs as an independent on the Reform Party ticket. Many Republicans in Congress also want to punish China for its alleged espionage at American nuclear laboratories, its threats of military action against Taiwan and its crackdown on dissidents. On the Democratic side, many union leaders are pressing Congress to reject a trade agreement. The unions are also demanding that both Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley take a more skeptical view of China than President Clinton has.
There is ample reason to be wary of Chinese intentions. Bellicose statements from Chinese leaders on Taiwan have been troublesome, and their intolerance of dissent has been repugnant. The charges of espionage, though not yet proved, have alarmed many. China may also be reluctant to make last-minute concessions necessary to get a trade deal. But for Americans to reject a trade agreement that benefits everyone is misguided. Provided China meets all the conditions, a deal could actually improve the possibility of dialogue on other contentious issues.

HEADLINE: Republicans Step Up Attack On Clinton's Russia Policy

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans ratcheted up their attack on President Clinton's Russia policy today, expanding the scope of hearings into the Russian banking scandal and Washington's dealings with Moscow.
The House International Relations and Senate Foreign Relations committees announced that they would hold separate, wide-ranging hearings later this month about American policy toward Russia. The House Banking Committee said hearings it had previously announced would begin on Sept. 21 to examine allegations of Russian corruption and money-laundering, possibly including the diversion of billions of dollars in international aid. 
 The Joint Economic Committee, a leading critic of the International Monetary Fund's lending practices, especially to Russia, announced that it would review the fund's plan to create a financial mechanism to derive income from gold it owns.
The volleys fired from Capitol Hill left no doubt that Republican leaders intend to use the economic turmoil and widening reports of corruption in Russia as a campaign issue against Democrats through the 2000 elections. "The Clinton Administration's Russia policy is the greatest U. S. foreign policy failure since Vietnam," declared Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. "The stated purpose of the Clinton-Gore policy was to help Russia become a peaceful and productive free-market democracy. Instead, Russia has become a looted and bankrupt zone of nuclearized anarchy."
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, accused the Administration of blocking a domestic tax cut bill at the same time United States aid to Russia was being "stolen by Russian thieves."
Mr. Armey, Mr. DeLay and other House Republicans spoke to reporters moments after the House approved a measure, 419 to 0, to punish foreign enterprises or institutions, especially from Russia, that provide sensitive missile technology or expertise to Iran.
Congress has expressed growing alarm at Iran's drive to build long-range missiles that could hit American troops and allies, and frustration with Russia for failing to curb the export of missile know-how. Mr. Clinton, who vetoed a similar bill last year, has said the legislation could further strain relations with Russia.
Democrats counterattacked throughout the day, accusing Republicans who are trying to link Vice President Gore to the failure of economic reform in Russia of political opportunism.
"I'm sure there have been some mistakes made," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader. "But we've been trying to help Russia get through the extremely difficult transition from communism to capitalism. If the alternative is to stand to one side, do nothing and hope Russia figures it out on its own, then that is a mistake."
A spokesman for the National Security Council, David C. Leavy, defended the Administration's Russia policy, citing advances in individual liberties for Russians, nuclear arms reductions and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Central and Eastern Europe.
Frank Luntz, a leading pollster, criticized the congressional Republican strategy. He said the Russian banking scandal does not yet affect "Americans in their day-to-day lives." He added, "If Republicans are trying to draw a political connection now, it ain't there."
No evidence has surfaced so far of the laundering of siphoned aid provided by the United States or the I.M.F., but the Administration remains politically vulnerable on the issue. Administration officials are likely to be grilled on what they knew of a Justice Department inquiry into Russian corruption before the investigation became public, and what steps they took to pressure Moscow to combat corruption.
Russian and American investigators met today in Washington, largely to discuss the money-laundering accusations, a Justice Department official said.
In addition to the Russian scandal, critics of the I.M.F. got added ammunition today in the form of an independent report commissioned by the monetary fund on its efforts to analyze economic conditions around the world. Although it praised the quality of the fund's work in many areas, the report found that the I.M.F. had failed to anticipate the severity of the Asian financial crisis and did not foresee the degree to which problems in one country could spill over into others.
The fund published a response today defending its research but acknowledging that it could make improvements.
