HEADLINE: Study Says Overweight Adults Push Up Cost of Health Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Spending on health care for the growing number of adults who are seriously overweight accounts for almost one-third of the national cost of treating 15 important diseases, including diabetes, heart disease, stroke and hypertension, the Lewin Group, a health care research and consulting group, said yesterday.
The study was commissioned by the American Obesity Association, which urges the Government and private employers to give more attention to problems of people who are overweight. 
 Diabetes and cardiovascular diseases are the main medical risks for the obese, which describes one in five Americans. They are also vulnerable to getting arthritis, several types of cancer, kidney, gallbladder and liver disease, the Lewin study said. "The country has been in denial about the whole obesity issue," said Morgan Downey, executive director of the American Obesity Association. "In a full employment economy, the work force is getting heavier and heavier," he said, and "blood pressure, diabetes and stroke are quickly becoming problems for younger and younger people."
The growing costs of treating these conditions "are going to frustrate almost all the efforts to control health care costs," Mr. Downey said.
The Lewin study said the cost of all treatments for obese adults would be $238 billion in 1999, including $102 billion for the 15 diseases and $136 billion more based on their chances of getting other ailments.
The study did not include $33 billion in annual spending on weight-loss products or indirect costs attributed to overweight workers, such as lost productivity and absenteeism that earlier studies said exceeded $47 billion in 1995.
Government experts have defined obesity as a body mass index -- a weight-to-height relationship -- of 30 or higher: for example, 180 pounds at 5 feet 5 inches, 209 pounds at 5 feet 10 inches or 221 pounds at 6 feet.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Posted Gain Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Retail sales surged in August as people bought up cars and clothing, Government figures showed today, indicating optimism about an economy that is closing in on a record expansion.
Sales grew 1.2 percent last month, to $252.4 billion, Commerce Department figures showed. The increase was almost double what analysts had expected and the biggest jump in six months. It also followed a 1 percent increase in July that topped the initial estimate of a rise of 0.7 percent. 
 "People are feeling very confident about their job and income prospects, so they're continuing to spend," said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
Apparel sales rose for the first time in three months as back-to-school sales lured buyers. Auto sales last month reached their highest level in almost 13 years, aided by manufacturer discounts.
The biggest sales increase occurred among durable goods, which include autos, appliances and furniture. The August rise of 1.8 percent came after a gain of 1.7 percent the month before. Sales of nondurable goods like groceries and gasoline rose 0.7 in August after a 0.5 percent increase in July.
Excluding automobiles, the retail sales increase was seven-tenths of a percent. Analysts had expected a seven-tenths of a percent increase in overall retail sales and a four-tenths of a percent gain in sales excluding autos.
A separate Commerce Department report showed that the United States trade deficit in goods, services and investments widened to a record $80.7 billion in the second quarter from $68.7 billion in the first quarter. The increase reflected Americans' growing appetite for imported goods.
The report also showed that purchases of United States stocks, bonds and real estate by international investors rose 171 percent in the second quarter, to $241 billion from $88.9 billion in the first quarter. Foreign direct investment increased 417 percent, to $118.6 billion in the second quarter from $22.9 billion in the first quarter.
The retail sales report will figure in deliberations over the need for a third increase in interest rates when Federal Reserve Board officials meet on Oct. 5. They have raised the overnight bank loan rate twice the last two months to keep inflation from accelerating.
"Certainly the strength in August retail sales increases the odds" for another rate increase, said Dana Saporta, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: CURRENCIES;
Japanese Again Intervene, But Fail to Brake Yen's Rise

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The Japanese central bank sold yen today for the second time in less than a week in an effort to curb the currency's recent heady rise, but the intervention barely managed to nudge the yen off its three-year high against the dollar.
The Japanese authorities seemed more alarmed by the speed of the yen's appreciation -- nearly 5 percent in the last week -- than in the rise itself, even as economists began wondering aloud whether a stronger yen might stifle the little vitality that a long-moribund Japanese economy is starting to exhibit. 
 "I guess I have mixed feelings about it," said Ronald Bevacqua, senior economist at Commerz Securities Japan.
Those most likely to complain are the giant Japanese exporters, whose products become more expensive abroad when the yen gets stronger. But they have been remarkably silent on the matter.
In fact, the Honda Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation both said this week that they hope to substantially increase their sales in Europe -- where the yen lately has risen even more steeply against the sagging euro -- suggesting that their strategic planning pays little heed to currency fluctuations.
Toshiba did push its earnings estimates down on Monday, but attributed that to falling semiconductor prices, shortages of components it uses in manufacturing personal computers and restructuring charges rather than to the yen's strength.
Toyoo Gyohten, a senior economic adviser to Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, likes to note that a stronger yen also means that Japanese manufacturers pay lower prices for raw materials and components. And to the extent that a stronger yen means that corporations must work harder to eke out profits, it keeps the pressure on them to be more efficient.
The brighter-than-expected economic outlook here and elsewhere in Asia also contributes to Japanese companies' acceptance of a strong yen. "One reason you haven't heard much out of the large exporters is that they've been pleasantly surprised by domestic growth," said Matthew Poggi, an economist with Lehman Brothers in Tokyo.
Mr. Poggi said that for each 10 percent the yen appreciates in a year, it knocks about three-quarters of a percentage point off economic growth over the next two years. "Demand from Asia and, to a lesser extent, from the U.S., has also been picking up, so while they may be losing out on the currency, they're making it up with more robust sales," he said.
To some extent, the yen's appreciation is nothing new to Japanese companies, which have lived through such strength before, particularly against the dollar. The average exchange rate in 1994 was 102 yen to the dollar, improving to an average of 94 in 1995 and weakening to an average of 109 in 1996. "It was strong but not disastrous," Mr. Bevacqua said.
The difference this time, however, is the reason for the yen's rise. The last time the yen strengthened, the United States had adopted a policy of benign neglect toward the dollar.
Now, the demand for yen is coming largely from foreign investors, who are betting that Japan's economic recovery will last. Their robust appetite for Japanese stocks has driven the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues to heights that no equity analyst imagined at the beginning of the year -- a close today of 17,777.22, up 37.8 percent in yen terms, year to date. Yet as the foreign investors push the yen's value higher, they threaten to cast a shadow over the profitability of the very companies whose shares they are buying.
The Nikkei's rise has strengthened the resolve of a new group of currency officials, led by Haruhiko Kuroda, vice finance minister for international affairs. He replaced Eisuke Sakakibara, known as "Mr. Yen" for his ability to manipulate the currency markets with his statements.
"Sakakibara would draw a line in the sand and dare people to cross it," a currency specialist said. "Kuroda isn't going to do that."
So long as the Nikkei stock index remains above 16,000, the point at which weak banks would have to recognize unrealized losses on their equity portfolios, the authorities seem unwilling to act more forcefully to contain the strength of the yen -- which settled in New York today at 105.79 to the dollar, improved from 106.44 on Monday.
Mr. Kuroda has let it be known that he believes intervening unilaterally in the currency markets is futile, a view underscored by today's all-but-useless effort to rein in the yen and a similar move on Friday that also failed to curb its rise.

HEADLINE: Liability Fears Sink Republic New York's Share Price

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Fears about the Republic New York Corporation's liability in what prosecutors are now calling a huge fraud dragged down the company's stock for the third consecutive trading session yesterday.
Shares of Republic New York fell 1.6 percent, to close at $59, for a total decline of nearly 15 percent this month. Investors are apparently concerned that the fraud could derail or alter HSBC Holdings' planned acquisition of Republic for $72 a share. 
 Officials at HSBC declined to comment on the status of the deal and referred a reporter to the bank's statement on Sept. 1 announcing an internal investigation into trading losses generated by its customer, Martin A. Armstrong, chairman of Princeton Economics International Inc., which in turn controlled Cresvale International, a brokerage firm based in Hong Kong. At that time, HSBC said its offer to acquire Republic was proceeding but would be postponed until the investigation was concluded.
Republic's stock has fallen since then on investor concerns that the trading losses generated by Mr. Armstrong, estimated by prosecutors at more than $500 million, might cause HSBC to lower its bid.
Republic's securities unit, Republic New York Securities, held Mr. Armstrong's accounts in its Philadelphia office. The bank holding company has not been charged with wrongdoing in the case and is cooperating with prosecutors. But two top officials at the securities subsidiary have been suspended.
Mr. Armstrong, chairman of Princeton Economics, an investment advisory firm, surrendered to Federal authorities in Trenton on Monday on charges that he orchestrated a huge securities fraud that had bilked Japanese investors since 1997. Prosecutors say Mr. Armstrong lured $3 billion from Japanese companies into fixed-rate notes with promises of a return of at least 4 percent annually and that he lied to his clients about his returns and illegally pooled investor funds to hide trading losses. Furthermore, Mr. Armstrong never registered as an investment adviser or commodity trading advisor as required.
Of the roughly $1 billion the money manager still owes his clients in principal and promised interest, only $46 million has been located by prosecutors in Mr. Armstrong's trading accounts.
Marc Durant, the lawyer representing Mr. Armstrong, said that his client disputed the accusations and would fight the charges.
Mr. Armstrong's trading accounts were responsible for 90 percent of the futures business at Republic Securities, according to prosecutors. James Sweeney, president of Republic Securities, and William H. Rogers, president of the unit's futures division, have been suspended.
Securities lawyers say that if an employee is found to have been involved in the fraud, Republic could face a sizable financial liability. In the complaint against Mr. Armstrong unsealed Monday by Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, prosecutors say that Mr. Rogers supplied Mr. Armstrong with letters on company stationery that inflated customers' accounts.
According to the authorities, Mr. Armstrong would ask Mr. Rogers for such letters and would provide the asset value he wanted. Mr. Rogers would then provide Princeton Economics with the letter and the asset value dictated by Mr. Armstrong. If the amount in the account held at Republic New York Securities was less than the figure specified by Mr. Armstrong, funds were shifted from other clients' accounts to make up the shortfall, prosecutors say.
Exactly how Mr. Armstrong lost so much money remains unclear. But a major factor was probably the collapse in the price of the dollar against the Japanese yen in the past year or so. On Aug. 11, 1998, the dollar traded at 147.32 yen; yesterday it traded at 105.93.
In 1998, Mr. Armstrong had expressed great optimism about the strength of the dollar, forecasting that it would rise to 170 yen or higher by this year. Instead, the dollar has plunged, hurting Mr. Armstrong in two ways.
First, Mr. Armstrong was almost certainly making currency bets for his customers in keeping with his optimism on the dollar. Moreover, the strong yen made his promises of 4 percent returns, payable as they were in Japanese currency, much more costly, since he had to exchange far more dollars for the yen than he would have if the dollar had remained high.
The investigation into Mr. Armstrong's activities started in May in Tokyo when the Financial Supervisory Agency, Japan's securities regulator, conducted a surprise audit of Cresvale, which has offices in Tokyo. Cresvale convinced Japanese companies of Mr. Armstrong's trading prowess, attracting billions in funds.
Kiyotaka Sasaki, the Financial Supervisory Agency official in charge of inspections of foreign financial concerns operating in Japan, said Japanese officials would be closely watching the case against Mr. Armstrong in the United States to gauge its impact on Japanese investors, who face substantial losses.
Mr. Sasaki pointed to the close cooperation between Japanese and American officials as an example of how regulators can police global financial markets. Earlier this year, the Financial Supervisory Agency's work with British regulators helped it close a derivatives unit of Credit Suisse First Boston that sold products to help Japanese corporations defer losses.
"For us, such cooperation has turned out to be very useful and effective," he said.

HEADLINE: It's a Hybrid In Sport Utility Clothes;
A Car-Based Light Truck, It Obeys the Fuel Rules, and It Helps Make Money

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Scheduled to go on sale next spring, the Chrysler PT Cruiser is not quite a sport utility vehicle and not really a minivan.
It does not look like a conventional car, either, although it uses much the same underbody and even a few of the same parts as the Dodge Neon, which is definitely a car. 
 But officials at DaimlerChrysler A.G. have decided that as far as Federal regulations are concerned, their lightweight, fuel-sipping vehicle is a truck and not a car. "We certainly are intending to have this classified as a light truck," said Jan Zverina, a DaimlerChrysler spokesman.
DaimlerChrysler has chosen to call the Cruiser a truck because of breaks it can get under the complex system of separate Federal fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks.
Counting the Cruiser as a light truck stands to improve the average fuel economy of the entire fleet of DaimlerChrysler's light trucks, which include sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups. The more Cruisers DaimlerChrysler sells, the more big, high-profit sport utilities and pickups it can sell while still meeting the gas mileage averages required by law.
After heavy lobbying by the auto industry, the Senate is expected on Wednesday to extend a four-year-old ban that prevents the Clinton Administration from studying or changing these two-decade-old fuel economy regulations. Meanwhile, auto makers are preparing to introduce as many as two dozen vehicles with car-based designs in the coming years and to ask that many of them to be certified as light trucks.
Two car-based sport utility vehicles, the Toyota RAV-4 and the Honda CR-V, have been on the market in limited numbers for two years and are categorized as light trucks. BMW A.G. will start selling its car-based sport utility vehicle, the X5, in December and has asked that it be certified as a light truck. Next spring, the Ford Motor Company will put on sale the Escape, a small sport utility vehicle that is based on the Ford Contour compact sedan. And the Cadillac, Buick, Pontiac, Saturn and Chevrolet divisions of the General Motors Corporation are all developing models that will combine car and light truck features, although G.M. has not said when they will go on sale.
Auto executives say that Americans want automobiles that combine the rugged appearance of a light truck with the handling and easy access of a car. The new models are not being created for fuel-economy reasons, said Lawrence D. Burns, G.M.'s vice president for planning, research and development. "That is not the driving force behind what we're doing here," he added.
Surveys show that with gasoline prices low, consumers care very little about fuel economy. Yet as buyers have switched from cars to light trucks, fuel economy has declined, increasing the nation's dependence on imported oil and increasing emissions of gases that many scientists have linked to global warming.
Each auto maker is required to produce a fleet of cars with an average gas mileage of at least 27.5 miles a gallon. But manufacturers are permitted to sell their fleets of light trucks with average fuel efficiencies of just 20.7 miles a gallon.
The rules that govern whether automobiles are classified as cars or light trucks have remained virtually unchanged since they were first written in 1976, and they are riddled with loopholes. Current and former regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the Federal agency that administers the fuel-economy laws, say the agency has never challenged an auto maker's decision on whether to register an automobile as a car or as a light truck.
When Republicans took control of Congress in 1995 and began trying to curb what they called regulatory excesses, one of the first things they did was prohibit the Clinton Administration from spending any money even to study increases in fuel-economy standards or changes in the fuel-economy rules. The House has already voted this year to extend the prohibition for another year as part of the Federal budget; the Senate is scheduled to vote on Wednesday on a nonbinding resolution that would urge Senate budget negotiators to remove the provision during conferences with House leaders. That vote is expected to fail.
Environmentalists have been lobbying hard for passage of the Senate resolution, but the auto industry has fought back with full-page newspaper advertisements and radio spots in nine states and appears likely to prevail. The Administration has sat on the sidelines during the current debate.
Even some auto executives acknowledge the shortcomings of the current system. BMW, for example, has sold only cars until now, and its executives had been very critical of the breaks that are available for auto makers who sell vehicles that qualify as light trucks. But BMW changed that position when it developed the X5.
Victor Doolan, BMW's president for North American operations until he was hired by Ford a few weeks ago, said in an interview early this year that he had decided to submit the X5 to regulators as a truck primarily because of the preferential treatment afforded light trucks under fuel-economy rules. "That's the major reason: Why should we pay punitive penalties that Mercedes and Lexus do not" on their sport utility vehicles? he said. "It's the rules that are wrong, not the way we play the game."
Most crossover vehicles ride high off the ground and have all-wheel drive. Those two features qualify them as "off road" vehicles, which the fuel-economy rules classify as light trucks.
But few of these crossover vehicles are ever likely to be driven up a rocky mountain trail. "Every crossover vehicle is being called a sport utility even if they can't go up a wet driveway," said Jamie Jameson, the vice president for sales and marketing at DaimlerChrysler, which takes pride in the off-road capacities of its Jeeps.
The company does not make such claims for the PT Cruiser, which has front-wheel drive instead of all-wheel drive. The Cruiser is being classified as a light truck through an obscure provision of the fuel-economy rules often applied to minivans. The provision says that vehicles can be so classified if they have removable back seats and a flat load floor.
Barry Felrice, a top regulator at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for two decades and now a top lobbyist in DaimlerChrysler's Washington office, said the provision was written in the 1970's to cover about 12,000 cargo vans a year. Without the provision, those vans might have been classified as cars. But since the 1970's, the auto industry has used the provision to classify the entire minivan market, or 1.2 million a vehicles a year, as light trucks.
The Cruiser is no gas-guzzler. It may even get high enough mileage to match the mandated average for cars. Indeed, Mr. Zverina, the DaimlerChrysler spokesman, said the vehicle's combined city and highway gas mileage might reach 30: the Environmental Protection Agency will issue an official figure when the vehicle goes on sale.
By adding the Cruiser to its light truck offerings, DaimlerChrysler will improve the overall average fuel economy for its fleet. This will allow the company to sell more large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which are the most profitable models, with margins of up to $15,000, but which also tend to have thirsty V8 engines.
The Cruiser "helps us because on the light truck side, there's very strong demand for V8's," Mr. Zverina said.
The average fuel economy of new light trucks appeared to improve slightly in the 1998 model year, the most recent data available. Auto makers acknowledge that this is largely because of anomalies in the rules.
Ford and DaimlerChrysler, for example, began equipping many of their minivans and pickups to run on either gasoline or ethanol to take advantage of Federal fuel-economy credits for dual-fuel vehicles -- even though fewer than 100 service stations in the country actually sell ethanol. G.M. redesigned its four-wheel-drive Suburbans to make them too large to be counted as light trucks; they ceased to be included in any gas mileage averages at all.
Regardless of whether they are classified as cars or light trucks, the new, car-based vehicles have a number of advantages. Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, says they might be safer than current sport utility vehicles because they will tend to be lower and less likely to roll over. The new vehicles are also less likely than sport utility vehicles to kill other motorists in crashes because they have lighter underbodies that are not as stiff.
The new automobiles get 20 to 30 miles a gallon, a level several miles a gallon less than the small and mid-size cars on which they are based, but far better gas mileage than most current sport utility vehicles. Over all, the effect of the new vehicles on the nation's fuel efficiency depends on what kind of vehicles they will replace. If they attract customers who might otherwise buy big sport utility vehicles, then the net effect would probably be to improve fuel efficiency slightly.
But most customers for crossover vehicles seem likely to switch from cars, hurting overall fuel efficiency. Except for a few, low-volume luxury models, like the BMW X5 and the Lexus RX 300, most new crossover vehicles will sell for less than $20,000 and be fairly small. Three-quarters of the sport utility vehicles now sold cost $26,000 and up, including all of the big gas guzzlers.
The success of the giant vehicles, despite their price tags, has put DaimlerChrysler, G.M. and Ford all perilously close to falling short of the light truck fuel-economy standard. For each tenth of a mile per gallon that an auto maker falls short of the standard, it must pay $5.50 for each vehicle sold. This can add up to tens of millions of dollars for a big auto maker.

HEADLINE: A Catholic Women's College Prays for a Miracle

BYLINE: By MARIALISA CALTA 

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 13

 BODY:
Last year, when reports of financial instability surfaced at Trinity College of Vermont, a small Roman Catholic liberal arts institution and the state's only women's college, people in the academic community gathered occasionally to pray for the welfare of the college.
This year, the prayer meetings are held weekly. 
 "I guess we've upped the ante," said Sister Jacqueline Marie Kieslich, Trinity's newly appointed president. She began her job just a few weeks ago, knowing that her task was to close the college on June 30, 2000.
"We've been hoping for a miracle," said Donna Dalton, vice president for academic and student affairs. "A miracle would be very nice."
In July, Trinity's board announced that the 74-year-old college, founded and run by the Sisters of Mercy, could no longer support a $6 million debt -- due mostly to declining enrollment -- on a $13.2 million operating budget. At the end of the fiscal year, the trustees declared, Trinity would cease to exist as an independent institution for its 1,150 students.
American colleges are "incredibly hardy," in the words of Terry W. Hartle, senior vice president of the American Council on Education in Washington. Yet every year, two to three of the country's estimated 3,500 two- and four-year colleges fall victim to demographics or cultural trends.
"A school closing affects not only the students, faculty, staff and alumni, but the community as well," Mr. Hartle said. "Our diversity of choices is diminished. And the community loses an engine of economic and cultural vitality."
Next door to the comparatively more sprawling University of Vermont, Trinity College sits on 28 acres of well-trimmed paths, maple trees and neat, sensible brick buildings in a corner of Vermont's largest city. Students stroll the grounds sporting buttons with quotations from Gandhi ("An eye for an eye makes the whole world blind"), John Lennon ("You may say I'm a dreamer, but I'm not the only one") or the occasional "I am a sensuous woman." There seem to be fewer body piercings than at most higher education institutions.
The college, which opened in 1925 to educate what was then an underserved population -- Vermont women -- has long been a pioneer in education and community service, with a stated mission to "promote social justice."
In the 1970's, Trinity was among the first private colleges to open its doors to older nontraditional students. In the 1980's, it began a study program for single mothers. A campus-based child-care center for the community serves as a laboratory for education students. The college's education department, which has supplied the state with an estimated 10 percent of its teachers, sends its professors to Vermont elementary schools to teach graduate courses on site. And every year, through a program endowed by a former trustee, Trinity brings to the community speakers like Elie Wiesel, Kenzaburo Oe, Maya Angelou, Joyce Carol Oates and Alice Walker.
Students and faculty members are clearly reluctant to let these programs die. They are, they point out, part of the reason that U.S. News & World Report ranked Trinity in the top tier of Regional Liberal Arts Colleges for 1999.
"My overwhelming feeling is of sadness, because no other students will be able to experience what I have been able to experience here," said Mattie Pontecorvo, a sophomore from Woodstock, Vt. She described the Trinity experience as one of empowerment and support.
"When you are a student here, you feel like you can do anything," said Ms. Pontecorvo, who is president of her class, co-editor of the student newspaper, a member of the student senate, a resident assistant and is active in community service projects sponsored by the college. She said the atmosphere at Trinity, "where women support women," had helped her assume leadership roles. "I don't think I would have been doing all these things in my second year at a co-ed institution. I wouldn't have had the confidence."
Tosca Zern, a junior and biology major from Shelton, Conn., frowned over her computer during a physiology laboratory. She is worried, she said, about her chances of getting into medical school if the college closes. "What about recommendations?" she asked. "What about getting a degree from a place that will no longer exist? When I say I'm going home, I mean I'm coming here. This place is home to all of us."
Jessica Campbell, a sophomore from Portland, Me., whose smiling visage graces the Trinity catalogue, echoed the feelings of many when she said she had returned "determined to have the best year ever, no matter what happens," and added, "If Trinity closes, these two years would definitely have been worth it."
Such expressions of optimism, using the word "if," are "what we all need to be able to get up in the morning," said Sister Jacqueline.
Since the trustees' decision, administrators have been trying to find a sponsoring institution to adopt some of the programs and enable Trinity students to complete their degrees with as little disruption as possible. Sister Jacqueline said the college was "exploring new relationships" with other colleges, like merging, forming partnerships or collaborating. Many administrators hope talks with St. Michael's, a Catholic college in nearby Winooski, will prove fruitful.
But even the most optimistic Trinity booster seems to agree that, come June 30, the college will cease to exist in its current form.
"Even if we were to receive a windfall, we would have to re-evaluate our structure, concentrate on our strengths, and cull some of our weaker programs," said Sister Jacqueline. "We can't continue as we are."
While the number of graduate students has hovered at about 550, the number of traditional-age undergraduates at Trinity fell from 415 in 1989 to 263 this year, and the number of nontraditional undergraduates, who include older women and men, has dropped to 338 from 659 a decade ago. Pamela Jarvis, vice president for finance and administration, said the reasons for the decline were unclear but might include a turnover in the admissions department, an increase in choices for nontraditional students and the waning popularity of single-sex colleges.
Nationally, the number of women's colleges has decreased to 77 from 300 in 1960. While those colleges that have hung on are "quite competitive" and drawing increasing interest in recent years, said Jadwiga Sebrechts, president of the Women's College Coalition in Washington, an all-women's college must work especially hard to "tell its story" and attract students.
Ms. Jarvis said Trinity's financial problems were compounded by the fact that to remain competitive, the college could not reduce expenses, particularly in areas like technology, nor raise their charges (about $21,400 for tuition, room, board and fees). In the meantime, the relatively small endowment of $2 million has not substantially increased.
That would change, of course, if Peggy A. McCluskey, the president of the alumni board, gets her wish. Ms. McCluskey, a 1960 Trinity graduate, has been buying lottery tickets in the hope of winning money for her alma mater.
"It would be a miracle," she acknowledged. "But if any school deserves a miracle, it's Trinity."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Financial Shares Depress Dow; Technology Buoys Nasdaq

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as fears of rising interest rates continued to deter investors.
Trading was dominated by a Government report on retail sales that showed consumers were much more active buyers last month than analysts had thought. 
 The report sent shivers through the bond market, where interest rates rose, and it further depressed prices of financial services stocks. Insurance shares, which are not helped when rates climb, were weakened further by worries that the advance of Hurricane Floyd suggested big damage claims in the making.
"A year ago these sales figures wouldn't have caused a ripple," said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jefferies & Company. "But it is very difficult to invest more when there is so much uncertainty about the course of interest rates and the dollar."
Selling yesterday was most heavily concentrated among blue-chip stocks.
Led by J. P. Morgan, which fell 2 13/16, to 122, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 120 points, or 1.09 percent, closing at 10,910.33. General Electric, parent company of GE Capital, lost 1 13/16, to 116 3/4. And American Express dropped 7/8, to 139 3/8.
With financial and drug company shares weakened, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also lost ground, falling 7.84 points, or 0.58 percent, to 1,336.29.
But worries about an overly vigorous economy and rising rates did not dampen demand for technology shares. The Nasdaq composite index gained 23.52 points, or 0.83 percent, to 2,868.29, led by Qualcomm, which gained 17 1/8, to 170 1/2. Qualcomm, which makes cellular phones, said it would meet or exceed fourth-quarter profit estimates, reassuring investors, who had sent the company's shares down sharply on Monday after it pulled out of an investor conference.
Other technology stalwarts also rose, further lifting the Nasdaq average. Microsoft was up 1 3/16, to 95 1/16. Intel gained 1 7/16, to 85 13/16. And Cisco Systems rose 1 1/4, to 71 15/16.
The ferocity of Hurricane Floyd created some anxiety about insurers. But analysts said that by and large the industry was in far better shape to handle a disaster than in August 1992, when Hurricane Andrew ripped through South Florida.
Homeowner insurers, which potentially face the biggest claims, suffered yesterday. Allstate dropped 1 7/16, to 32 1/8. Hartford Financial lost 1 5/16, to 46 15/16. And the St. Paul Companies fell 1, to 31 5/8.
"The market's reaction was rational," said Alice Schroeder of Paine Webber. "We do expect that the storm will result in reduced earnings this quarter, but we just don't know by how much. However, it is a one-time event and will not affect next year."
Jay A. Cohen, a Merrill Lynch insurance analyst, said that "when Andrew hit, the level of equity capital for the industry was about $160 billion."
"Now," he said, "that figure is just over $340 billion. Floyd would have to have an absolutely enormous impact to have an effect on the industry as a whole."
Similarly, entertainment analysts said the Walt Disney Company's decision to close Disney World for the first time in 27 years should not have a tangible financial effect. The company plans to keep the park closed for the next two days. But the Disney World hotels, which are fully booked, remain open.
"I don't think it will be material to earnings," said Jill Krutick of Salomon Smith Barney, although she said her assessment could change if there were severe damage to the Orlando, Fla., property.
Investors did not seem much concerned: Disney shares, which have been under pressure for about a year, closed at 27 15/16, down 1/8.
And news that air carriers were canceling flights in and out of Miami did not dissuade buyers of airline stocks. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, gained 1/4, to 55 1/8. Delta Air Lines rose 1/2, to 50 5/8. And UAL, parent of United Airlines, was up 1 1/4, to 68 1/8.
"Weather hurts the airlines, whether it is a blizzard or a hurricane," said Glenn Engel, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "But they are vulnerable to everything, from weather to a change in oil prices to a change in fares."
In the final analysis, said Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, investors remained more concerned about a man-made threat, higher interest rates, than about a possible natural disaster. "Hurricanes come and go, and people generally look beyond them," Mr. Goldman said. "Rising interest rates hit you right between the eyes."

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Big Aid Package To Rally a Reeling Colombia

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
With Colombia's Government buckling under the pressure of guerrilla attacks, a thriving drug trade and the worst economy in decades, the Clinton Administration is putting together a major new effort to prop up the country's democracy that will include hundreds of millions of dollars in economic and military aid.
The aid package, which is expected to be completed soon, will have large amounts of new military equipment, including arms and helicopters, as well as more intelligence support and training for Colombia's army and police units, senior Administration and defense officials said. 
 The Administration is also planning new moves that officials hope will ease Colombia's economic crisis, strengthen the criminal justice system and help local governments in the country's large, sparsely populated interior.
But even before it has been completed, the plan is generating strong reservations among some within the Administration who fear that the United States is being drawn more deeply into a convoluted civil conflict that has left tens of thousands dead over nearly four decades. "It is going to be a very dangerous mess," said a senior official who has worked on Colombia. "And we are going to be in the middle of that mess."
Not since the Central American civil wars of the 1980's has the United States been so tempted to go to the aid of a Latin American ally threatened by an insurgency. Pushed by a small group of Republican leaders in Congress, the Administration is already giving Colombia $309 million this year, making it the fourth-largest recipient of American aid after Israel, Egypt and Jordan.
The Administration's new effort will mark a significant shift in American policy toward Colombia after nearly two decades in which it has focused almost entirely on combating the cocaine trade. While fighting drugs will remain a central goal, the United States is about to make a broader commitment to support Colombia's embattled Government than it has in years.
Administration officials said they had used months of wide-ranging discussions about the aid to reconsider American objectives and to press the Government of President Andres Pastrana to come up with a comprehensive strategy to address the country's problems. Mr. Pastrana is expected to outline that strategy next week in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly and in meetings with officials in Washington.
The Administration has not yet decided how large its aid package will be, but the officials said that in their internal discussions it ranged from $1 billion to $1.5 billion over the next three years.
They said the size of the package was not likely to be settled until the White House and Congress resolved their increasingly contentious fight over balancing the budget.
But the discussions have also been complicated by deep divisions within the Administration itself over how to get involved and how deeply.
Some more hawkish officials, led by the White House's drug policy adviser, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, are pressing for a large increase in aid to Colombia's armed forces. Citing "a drug-related emergency," General McCaffrey has called for at least $1 billion concentrated on the military and the police.
At the Pentagon, however, there are reservations about how deeply to get involved with Colombia, a country with two leftist guerrilla armies fighting the Government, right-wing paramilitary forces fighting the guerrillas, and civilians ever in the crossfire. The perils of a stronger American role came into clearer relief in July when a United States spy plane crashed during a counterdrug mission, killing five American soldiers and two Colombians.
Officials at the State Department and the National Security Council, in particular, have pressed to broaden Washington's agenda in Colombia while trying to limit American involvement in the war. The officials have played down the immediate threat to Mr. Pastrana's Government, arguing that a modest rise in military aid should be balanced by support for social-development projects, the economy and a negotiated settlement to the war.
Administration officials say they have made it clear to the Colombians that increased American support will come with pressure for changes, including greater efforts to clean up human-rights abuses by the military, and a new, probably tougher Government approach to the peace talks with the insurgents.
But while Administration officials say that they will not dictate policies to Mr. Pastrana, some Colombian officials involved in the aid negotiations already appear uncomfortable with the growing American role.
"We have a strategy," a senior Colombian official said curtly, suggesting that the Administration's elaborate search for a new approach was little more than packaging for a new financing pitch to Congress.
United States aid to Colombia fell sharply after the Bush Administration, which had targeted the Andean countries in an attempt to stem the flow of cocaine at its source. But American aid to the Colombian military and the police has risen steadily since 1996, and the Colombian Army has also bought new loads of American arms.
The new engagement of the Clinton Administration is partly a consequence of its close ties to Mr. Pastrana, who took office a year ago. In the previous four years Washington essentially boycotted the Government of his predecessor, Ernesto Samper, after evidence emerged that his political campaign had taken huge contributions from cocaine traffickers.
Despite their early hopes for Mr. Pastrana, however, United States officials generally describe his efforts to negotiate with the guerrillas as a failure that has left the insurgents stronger and more defiant. Nor do those officials hide their view that Colombia's multiple crises may be beyond Mr. Pastrana's ability to resolve.
Colombia's cocaine industry, which has long depended on coca leaf from Peru and Bolivia, is becoming more self-sufficient as it grows more of its own coca and a more potent strain of the plant is introduced, intelligence analysts say.
Last year, the Central Intelligence Agency estimated that Colombia could have produced about 165 metric tons of cocaine from its own crop, up from 65 tons in 1993 and 80 tons in 1995. This year, according to an internal Government document, analysts expect Colombian traffickers to produce as much as 250 tons.
The increase comes despite a jump of nearly 50 percent in American drug-eradication efforts last year, and it is concentrated largely in fields that are guarded or taxed by leftist guerrillas or right-wing paramilitary groups, the document indicates. Many American officials believe that the guerrillas -- particularly those of the leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia -- have reaped a windfall from the coca boom that has turned them into a far more serious military threat.
In an attempt to build trust with the FARC, as the rebel group is known, Mr. Pastrana withdrew army troops from a large swath of the rebel-dominated countryside last November. The move drew open dissent from his officer corps, however, and the guerrillas have shown little sign of compromise since. In July, the talks were suspended after the insurgents refused to accept observers in the demilitarized zone, and the rebels began one of their biggest offensives in years.
"Pastrana seems to have bent all the way over in a Gumby-like way," an American military official said, "He's about used up what he's got to offer, and it is not working."
Administration officials are less critical of Mr. Pastrana's economic management, but his political standing has also been hurt by economic troubles that were long in the making: the worst recession in decades, a growing debt burden and an unemployment rate that has reached nearly 20 percent.
The worsening situation began to command the attention of the White House this summer, officials said, when an interagency meeting presided over by President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, turned from a discussion of Caribbean radar installations to the turmoil in Colombia. "This is a third-order issue that is going to become a first-order issue," two officials quoted Mr. Berger as saying.
Officials said Mr. Berger asked those present to consider what additional aid Colombia needed. The initial result, however, was a deluge of different and sometimes contradictory proposals.
On July 13, General McCaffrey struck preemptively, writing Cabinet members to warn of an "explosion of coca cultivation" in Colombia. His letter, which was quickly and widely leaked to the news media, outlined $1 billion in new spending, most of it for Colombia, including $360 million to help the army expand its reach in southern Colombia and $120 million to increase the interdiction of drug flights.
Officials at the Pentagon and the State Department drew up their own lists, and different priorities emerged. Law-enforcement officials argued for more support for Colombian police anti-drug operations and the country's judicial system. State Department officials pushed proposals ranging from trade benefits to temporary refuge for Colombian immigrants to the United States.
"You are getting policy by proposal rather than by planning," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. "Everybody seems to agree, 'Hey, let's send some money down there.' But I have heard relatively little discussion or debate about what the U.S. interests are."
White House and State Department officials said they had been struggling to define those interests more clearly in a series of meetings over the summer.
For the most part, the officials take pains to sound less alarmed than General McCaffrey and Republicans on Capitol Hill, who have grown increasingly critical of President Clinton's policies. After visiting Bogota last month, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Thomas R. Pickering, said he was "sobered but certainly not panicked" by Colombia's problems.
In fact, some military analysts believe that the Colombian Army has been doing better against the guerrillas in recent months. In addition, a secret assessment by American intelligence recently estimated that the rebels' profits from the drug trade ranged from perhaps $30 million to $100 million a year, far less than the amounts cited publicly by some officials, including General McCaffrey.
The Clinton Administration's more deliberate approach also owes much to battles being fought far from Colombia. Last fall, the Administration was caught off guard by an emergency spending plan drafted by Republicans in Congress that added $287 million in anti-drug and military aid to Colombia almost overnight. This year, officials said they were determined not to be outflanked again, although prominent conservatives in the House have drafted their own wish lists, including one by Representative Dan Burton of Indiana that calls for $930 million in new aid.
So the Administration has devised an early plan of its own. In an effort to inject energy into the peace talks, the United States will press both sides to heed the experience of countries like El Salvador and Nicaragua and accept international mediation.
And to shore up Colombia's economy, Administration officials said, they are backing talks with the International Monetary Fund for as much as $3 billion in financing, in addition to cash support from the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.
Nevertheless, the bulk of American aid will go to military and antidrug operations. The officials said it would probably include a squadron of new helicopters for the Colombian Army, a package of excess equipment from the Pentagon and considerable training for Colombian soldiers and police officers.
American soldiers and advisers have already begun training a new anti-drug battalion of 950 soldiers and 200 police officers and the officials said the Administration would most likely approve the training of two more battalions.
"To deal with the drug problem," said a senior Administration official, "you have to deal with the guerrillas intimately involved in the drug problem."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan Sells Yen to Curb Sharp Rise Against Dollar
The Japanese central bank sold yen to curb the currency's recent heady rise, but the intervention barely managed to nudge the yen off its three-year high against the dollar. And in New York, the yen gained again, to 105.79 to the dollar from 106.44 on Monday.
The Japanese authorities seemed more alarmed by the speed of the yen's appreciation -- nearly 5 percent in the last week -- than in the rise itself, even as economists began wondering aloud whether a stronger yen might stifle the little vitality that a long-moribund Japanese economy is starting to exhibit. Page C3. 

Oracle Shares Fall on Profit Report
Shares of Oracle dropped sharply in after-hours trading after the company reported first-quarter earnings that met the consensus estimate of analysts but fell short of the so-called whisper number. After closing at $45.4375, shares fell as low as $41. C21.
 
AT&T to Cut Thousands of Jobs
As AT&T continues to cut costs amid its campaign of cable television acquisitions, thousands of employees in AT&T's core long-distance telephone operation could lose their jobs before the end of next year, executives close to the company said. Many of those employees could find jobs in other, faster-growing AT&T divisions that will continue to add jobs, but others could be laid off. Shares of AT&T fell 62.5 cents, to $44.50. C4.
 
Seagate Technology, the computer disk-drive maker, said that it would cut 8,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its workers. C3.
 
Investors See HSBC Deal in Danger
Fears about Republic New York's liability in what prosecutors are calling a huge fraud dragged down the company's stock 1.6 percent, to $59, for a decline of nearly 15 percent this month. Investors are concerned that the fraud could derail or alter HSBC Holdings' planned acquisition of Republic. C2.
 
Nasdaq Is Up, but Dow Declines
Stocks were mixed as robust retail sales heightened fears of rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average decreased 120 points, to 10,910.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 7.84 points, to 1,336.29. The Nasdaq composite index gained 23.52 points, to 2,868.29. C9.
 
Bond yields climbed to 6.12 percent from 6.05 percent on Monday. C9.
 
U.A.W. Extends Contracts
The United Automobile Workers union granted contract extensions to auto makers as talks continued past the midnight expiration of current labor contracts, which allowed factories to keep humming. C21.
 
Daimler's Smart Car Chief Quits
Lars Brorsen will resign as chief executive of DaimlerChrysler's struggling Smart car business at the end of the month. The surprise resignation, which Daimler executives disclosed at the Frankfurt international automobile show, came as sales of the tiny two-seater, called a city car, finally appeared to be picking up after the company reduced prices and added safety features. C2.

HEADLINE: A Higher Minimum Wage

 BODY:
With the economy strong and the unemployment rate at its lowest in more than 25 years, Democrats in Congress are right to push for an increase in the minimum wage. An increase now will boost income for the poorest workers without the danger of creating more unemployment. But Republicans resist the idea, even though the minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, has declined in purchasing power over the past three decades.
Senator Edward Kennedy has drafted a bill to raise that wage by 50 cents this year and another 50 cents in 2000. The $1 increase would restore the actual buying power of the minimum wage to what it was in 1980, and would raise the pay of nearly 12 million Americans who now earn less than $6.15 an hour. Currently a minimum-wage employee working full time earns about $10,700 a year, which is roughly $3,000 below the poverty line for a family of three. A boost to $6.15 would increase annual pay by about $2,000 a year, an amount that can make a significant difference in reducing poverty. Nearly three-quarters of the workers who would benefit are adults, 60 percent are women, and nearly half work full time. 
 Opponents argue that an increase would result in lost jobs. But a modest hike is not likely to cause higher unemployment, even among low-skilled workers. Indeed, jobless rates fell after the 90-cent minimum-wage hike of 1996-97. The unemployment rate, 5.2 percent in 1996, dropped to 4.2 percent this year.
Senator Kennedy is expected to offer the minimum-wage bill as an amendment to the bankruptcy reform bill when it comes to the Senate floor. Moderate House Republicans are also getting the message from voters that they want the wage increase, but they may be tempted to add tax cuts that might make an increase less painful for the business lobbies. The wage hike should be approved without such tax breaks. For millions of workers, a higher minimum wage means a better shot at self-sufficiency. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Trust But Verify

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
After W. dropped his handkerchief in June, he sat on the porch by the ocean in Kennebunkport. I asked him if it was scary to run for President, when he knew so little about foreign affairs.
"There will be moments when situations, incidents will flare up," he replied. "It's important for the President to think globally." He said the crucial thing was how a chief executive dealt with Russia and China, and whether he knew which foreign-policy advisers to trust and which to "kiss off," as he put it. 
 "But," he added, picking a regional hot spot out of a hat, "if the East Timorians decide to revolt, I'm sure I'll have a statement."
He talked about the murderous state of the Indonesian territory with that W. touch of flipness and swagger we have come to know. He was so unfamiliar with the tensions there that he called the citizens East Timorians rather than East Timorese. His implicit point was that there was still plenty of time for lessons from his foreign-policy tutors, Poppy's crowd -- George Shultz, Condoleezza Rice and Dick Cheney.
But we're in a fast, mercurial universe. One minute we're scarcely paying attention to some roiling conflict on the other side of the world, and the next we're debating whether to send American troops over there, wherever there is, and whatever it is they're killing each other about.
Less than three months after talking about that Timor statement, the Texas Governor had to actually put it out. Or more likely, his tutors did.
W. sensed the irony of this. After visiting a Bedford, N.H., elementary school last week -- where he drolly told the kids, "Some people say that I proved that if you get a C average, you can end up being successful in life" -- he answered reporters' questions about his position on East Timor. Before and after he spoke the words "East Timorese," he paused pregnantly.
Then the candidate who had recently learned the correct term himself asked the press, with a sly smile, "Everybody knew that?"
It's a weird reversal of his father's '92 campaign. Bush Senior fumbled because he seemed too obsessed with foreign policy at a time when the economy was tanking. "In my life," W. told me dryly that day in Maine, "I never tried to rush the natural progression of growing up."
And that is the issue that gnaws. Has he grown up? Can we trust him? He wants us to believe that his gut instincts and moral framework can carry him over the lacunae in his knowledge of geopolitics. He wants us to believe that his transformation from rowdy late bloomer to mature statesman is complete and non-reversible.
"A lot of people around the world would find it rather frightening to envision a President of the United States, at the moment of probably America's greatest power in history, who seems completely uninformed on the state of the world," says Alan Brinkley, a history professor at Columbia University. "It's one thing to rely on the advice of aides because you have respect for their judgment. It's another to do it because you don't know enough to distinguish good advice from bad advice."
But Michael Beschloss, another historian, says that, post-cold-war, "we have a lot of local and regional threats that are probably indecipherable even to a Presidential candidate who has had a lot of history in foreign policy. So we might be better with a President who is a quick study, who chooses good people, and who knows how to use them."
He notes that Ronald Reagan had no foreign-affairs experience when he was elected, yet he had a lot to do with ending the cold war. (Although he did know what he thought of pinkos.)
And, Mr. Beschloss says, we might have avoided Vietnam if Lyndon Johnson had been as secure on foreign policy as he was on domestic policy. He might not have been so easily swayed by misguided Kennedy holdovers like Robert McNamara.
Bill Clinton did a lot of reading about the history of the Balkan conflict. But he still miscalculated the determination of Slobodan Milosevic when he developed the plan to bomb Serbia. And even if we did not worry about Mr. Clinton's grasp of the issues, we had to worry about whether there was any post-Monica "Wag the Dog" syndrome involved in his bombing decisions about Iraq and Sudan.
W.'s father greatly admired Henry Stimson, the diplomat and soldier, whose credo was: "The only way to make a man trustworthy is to trust him."
That's true -- occasionally. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Stanford President to Resign in 2000 and Teach Law Full Time

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Gerhard Casper, the president of Stanford University, announced yesterday that he would resign at the end of August 2000, citing the perpetual need for fresh perspectives on campus and his desire to focus on teaching undergraduates.
Mr. Casper, 61, became president of Stanford in 1992, as it was recovering from disclosures that it had overcharged the Federal Government millions of dollars in indirect research costs and as the university was trying to rebuild after the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake. 
 Mr. Casper began several initiatives intended to improve education during students' first two years; led a merger of the hospitals at Stanford and the University of California at San Francisco; increased fund-raising to more than $300 million annually and started a $200 million endowment campaign to support graduate students.
"At a university, no time is ever an appropriate one to claim that tasks have been completed," Mr. Casper told a regularly scheduled meeting of deans and department heads on the Palo Alto, Calif., campus yesterday afternoon, according to the prepared text of his remarks. "All days of a university need to be first days. The work of the university is work that cannot be done unless it is continuously reconsidered."
Quoting from Ecclesiastes, "To every thing there is a season," Mr. Casper noted that he had spent two decades in top administrative posts, starting as dean of the law school at the University of Chicago and then provost there.
Of his seven years at Stanford, he said jokingly, "Ten years at least is the way it feels."
 Nestled in the heart of the booming Silicon Valley, Stanford has become among the hottest names in higher education during Mr. Casper's tenure, rivaling Ivy League institutions in competitiveness, prestige and fund-raising.
Faculty members were stunned by Mr. Casper's announcement, a week before classes are scheduled to begin at the 14,000-student campus, and praised their president for unifying the university and refocusing it on academics.
"His dedication to and love of teaching undergraduates permeated everything," said Lucy Shapiro, a professor of developmental biology at the Stanford Medical School. "He's almost unique in his desire to learn in depth how different schools work, how different disciplines work, and how to put a research university like Stanford squarely in the center of training the next generation."
Principal elements of Mr. Casper's legacy will be Stanford Introductory Studies, a series of seminars for first- and second-year students, and Sophomore College, a two-week program in which students take one intensive course before regular classes begin in the fall.
On the graduate level, he founded the fellowship program to support up to 300 science students free of sponsored research, and another initiative that brings graduate students from Asia for a yearlong seminar on politics and economics.
Mr. Casper, who also oversaw restoration of landmarks damaged in the earthquake and construction of a new science and engineering quadrangle, plans to take a sabbatical and then return to Stanford to teach constitutional law.
Richard C. Levin, the president of Yale University, who is a Stanford alumnus, said Mr. Casper "is a true scholar, a person of really wide learning and wide tastes."
"It's a great loss for Stanford, and a great loss for higher education," he said.

HEADLINE: Power Failures Are a Warning

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "After Summer's Power Failures, Concerns About Large Utilities" (front page, Sept. 13): 
 Over the past 30 years, electric utilities have been bullied by politicians, who demand low electric rates for their constituents, and by Wall Street, which cannot tolerate investments that do not reap vast rewards within two years. As a result, few new power plants of any kind have been built. Yet our growing economy and desire for more electrical gadgets, from cell phones to Web TV, continue to drive demand.
It is time to stop worrying about whether power costs another tenth of a cent per kilowatt and start putting a premium on reliability. That means expenditures on major power plants, not a handful of windmills and tiny dams on little streams, and a full-scale review of the adequacy of our national power distribution system to meet our growing needs.
 
ROBERT BOYDEN LAMB
New York, Sept. 14, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of management and finance at the Stern School of Business, New York University.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall on Stronger-Than-Expected Retail Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
A report yesterday of stronger-than-expected retail sales last month helped send bond yields higher, stoking investors' fears of further rate increases by the Federal Reserve.
The price of the 30-year Government bond fell 31/32, to 100 3/32, as its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 6.12 percent from 6.05 percent on Monday, the highest level in almost two weeks. 
 Kim Rupert, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, called the numbers quite robust. "It appears that consumers have yet to show any inclination of spending less," she said. "Just what that means in terms of Fed policy is not quite clear. After all, we've seen strong consumption and a low inflation environment coexist for years."
But that is not to say that market participants are not concerned, especially since the Fed has already increased short-term interest rates twice this year.
Investor jitters generally make the market vulnerable to speculation and idle talk. Yesterday there was plenty of talk giving traders the excuses they needed to sell securities.
Bonds fell after a Government report showed that retail sales in August posted their biggest gain in six months, a strong 1.2 percent, or 0.7 percent excluding auto sales. Even though the numbers were broad-based, traders were a little reluctant to chase prices sharply lower ahead of today's closely watched inflation report, the August Consumer Price Index. Some economists expect a gain of 0.5 percent after a gain of 0.7 percent in July.
"We heard some talk that insurance companies were sellers of paper in anticipation of huge claims from Hurricane Floyd," Ms. Rupert said. "Also we hear that the Bank of Japan might be in the market buying sizable amounts of notes. There was good buying in the 10-year maturity, tied to the unwinding hedges surrounding Freddie Mac's $6 billion offering priced today."
Freddie Mac, the nation's second largest buyer of home mortgages behind Fannie Mae, priced its global sale of 10-year reference yesterday through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston, Merrill Lynch and Bear, Stearns.
The notes yielded 6.729 percent, or about 79.5 basis points more than a comparable Treasury security. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield of a 10-year Treasury note, a benchmark for many corporate borrowers, rose to 5.95 percent.
Renewed weakness in the dollar against the Japanese yen also worsened negative market sentiment.
The Treasury auctioned $10 billion of 52-week bills yesterday with what analysts called decent results given the rate had increased to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Campaign Finance Tactics

 BODY:
In one of its finest moments, the House of Representatives listened to its collective conscience Tuesday night and passed the Shays-Meehan campaign finance reform bill. Representative Christopher Shays reflected both the historic importance of the vote and the tremendous challenge ahead with an apt comparison to the great civil rights debates of the 1960's. As they did a generation ago, proponents of progress will now have to force an obstructionist minority in the Senate to face vote after vote to expose their motives. It may, therefore, be the moment to consider tactical changes in the legislation if there is a possibility of winning more Republicans on the next vote.
The focus of attention now turns to John McCain -- Presidential candidate, Vietnam War hero and anti-establishment Senator from Arizona. With Russ Feingold of Wisconsin, Mr. McCain has pushed for a ban on unregulated "soft money" to political parties since President Clinton's out-of-control 1996 re-election campaign. Unlike most Republicans, Mr. McCain was not content to deplore Mr. Clinton's excesses. The McCain-Feingold bill would ban soft money to parties and extend Federal regulations to money raised by independent groups for campaign ads two months before an election. 
 Today Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold are planning to introduce a stripped-down version of that bill, eliminating the curbs on fund-raising for so-called "issue ads" by independent groups. In effect, they are calling the bluff of Trent Lott, the majority leader, and his fund-raiser in chief, Mitch McConnell, who have obsessively focused on the issue-ad curbs as a violation of free speech. This is a risky change. Banning unlimited money for political parties might lead to the money going to bogus groups for use in even more destructive campaigns. The Democrats and Republicans in the House who bravely stood by the issue-ad controls against relentless attacks by special interests will no doubt be upset over such a concession.
But with the issue-ad curbs out of the bill, there will at least be no excuse for other Republicans not to sign on to reform. However distrustful and upset they may be, Democrats should be prepared to go along. Reform, like any other large cause, is never something that gets achieved overnight. The battle to rid American politics of corruption has been fought since the late 19th century. Allowing independent groups to raise unlimited money for phony issue ads is far from ideal. But a ban on soft money for the parties would be a significant step in the long, grinding effort to drive corrupt money out of the process.
It is clear from the 252-to-177 vote in the House that a strong consensus in both parties favors reform. More than a quarter of the Republican Party's members in the House defied their leadership and supported the bill, sending a strong message to the Senate, where campaign reform is supported by all 45 Democrats and 7 Republicans. That adds up to 52 votes, a majority that can only be thwarted by the determination of Mr. Lott to engineer a filibuster to kill the bill. To get the McCain-Feingold bill passed, 60 votes are needed to cut off the filibuster.
Many of the Republican holdouts say they oppose campaign reform, especially the curbs on independent groups, as an infringement of free speech. But the ban on corporations contributing to candidates has been in effect since 1907. The ban on donations by unions was enacted in 1947, and the Watergate-era ceiling on contributions to candidates by individuals and political action groups has been in effect for 25 years. Extending these curbs to political parties is not a radical change.
Mr. McCain is also making a novel argument to these Republicans that campaign reform might even make tax cuts for the average citizen more achievable. The $792 billion tax cut bill passed this summer was loaded with so many favors for individual businesses, stuffed into the bill because of campaign donations, that hardly any money was left over for taxpayers of modest means.
If these Senators are not willing to listen to voters demanding reform, then they should listen to a growing chorus of business leaders who are also demanding a ban on soft money. The Committee for Economic Development began by enlisting executives from General Electric, Merck, Xerox and Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu. Its ranks are growing with executives from Hasbro, Prudential, International Paper and State Farm Insurance. Businessmen use words like legalized bribery to describe the current fund-raising system.
Mr. McCain should direct his lobbying to Republicans with a record of some independence or those who have complained eloquently about being forced to become fund-raising automatons. Now is the time for Republicans like Richard Lugar of Indiana, William Roth of Delaware, John Warner of Virginia, Chuck Hagel of Nebraska and George Voinovich and Mike DeWine of Ohio to show some of the gumption their constituents have come to appreciate. As for Democrats unhappy about dropping the regulation of independent "issue ads," we understand the difficulty of dropping a vital measure long supported by this page. But it makes sense to win what is achievable now and then move on to greater battles to come.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Even a Mouse That Roars Can Sit on the Sidelines

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
BUILD a better mousetrap, and the world will beat a path to your door. It stands to reason that the time-worn adage about innovation and capitalist reward would apply to better mice as well, at least of the computer variety.
By that measure, the vertical mouse, which resembles a gamer's joystick, ought to be poised for commercial success. Last week, The International Journal of Human-Computer Interaction, a respected quarterly, published a study that said switching to the odd-looking mouse had reduced the pain suffered by computer users in their hands, arms and necks and also trimmed the number of workdays lost to sick leave. 
 Still, if the past is any guide, the Anir Vertical mouse, also known as Dr. Mouse, faces an uphill struggle, and its producer, Animax International of Norway, will not be minting a fortune anytime soon.
Industry history, economics and human nature resist an insurgent product unless it promises a huge improvement in price or performance or some other benefit. Economists call the forces favoring the incumbent product "lock-in" and describe the steep hurdle faced by an innovative newcomer as high "switching costs."
"Often, it's the brain that is the real lock-in -- people's habits are so difficult to change," said Hal Varian, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
The producers of ergonomic computer keyboards and mice have found it frustratingly difficult to make major inroads. As many as 20 percent of the nation's 150 million computer users, especially those working on their machines for four hours or more a day, are considered by experts to be at risk of suffering repetitive stress injuries. Most ergonomic products try to reduce the strain of computer work by putting the hands in a more natural position -- tilted with the thumbs raised somewhat instead of having the hands splayed flat, as they are when typing on a conventional keyboard or when manipulating a standard mouse.
The most successful ergonomic product by far has been the Microsoft Natural Keyboard, a wave-shaped, split keyboard that raises the thumbs and separates the hands. Indeed, Microsoft's hardware unit -- which produces mainly keyboards, mice and joysticks -- is a quiet success story within the software giant.
It is also a success story that contradicts the repeated claim of the company's critics that Microsoft owes its success to the inherent and unfair edge it enjoys because of its industry-standard Windows operating system. Microsoft has no natural advantage in hardware other than a well-known brand and deep pockets.
Yet Rick Thompson, vice president of the hardware unit, said the Natural Keyboard, introduced in 1994, did not take the market by storm, as he had hoped. Today, roughly 120 million PC's are shipped worldwide each year, nearly all of them with flat keyboards. The so-called aftermarket for replacement or enhanced keyboards is about 3 million, and one in five of those have an ergonomic design. In the ergonomic keyboard niche, Microsoft holds an estimated two-thirds of the market.
"You simply can't cause most people to change from the standard design even if your product is better," Mr. Thompson said.
Mr. Thompson's sense that the best product does not always win in the marketplace is contradicted, however, by two economists who have sided with Microsoft in its antitrust battle with the Government. Stanley J. Liebowitz, a professor of managerial economics at the University of Texas at Dallas, and Stephen E. Margolis, a professor of economics at North Carolina State University, argue in their new book, "Winners, Losers and Microsoft: Competition and Antitrust in High Technology" (Independent Institute) that the best products do come out on top. They say the importance of economic lock-in and switching costs are vastly exaggerated, and that Microsoft's dominates the PC software market thanks to hard work and superior business acumen.
Dr. Liebowitz and Dr. Margolis are known for their shrewd critique of a classic story about the success of a second-best product -- the Qwerty keyboard layout, which became the standard design in the 1880's when it was used in vocational schools to teach touch-typing. Later designs, notably the Dvorak keyboard, were said to allow faster typing, but they never caught on. But Dr. Liebowitz and Dr. Margolis concluded that August Dvorak had inflated his claims for his keyboard.
Yet Dr. Liebowitz and Dr. Margolis have a bit more trouble explaining away the leading modern example of what is often said to be a second-best winner, Microsoft's DOS and, later, Windows, which mimicked the look of Apple's Macintosh operating system, which was introduced in 1984. They dismiss the Mac's several-year lead over Windows, until recently, in ease of use as merely superior "elegance" -- not a real consideration, economically, they suggest.
Still, it remains to be seen whether an innovation like the vertical mouse can overcome the daunting challenges it faces.
The field study just reported seems encouraging. It was conducted by Dr. Arne Aaras, coordinator of health medical services in Norway for Alcatel, the European telecommunications company, and two assistants over six months. The study looked at 69 computer users; it measured pain by using questionnaires. Pain levels dropped 30 percent to 50 percent. Alcatel and the Norwegian Government financed the study.
Other ergonomic experts are impressed. Marvin Dainoff, director of the Center for Ergonomic Research at Miami University in Ohio, called the study powerful.
Yet the hurdles of habit and price are high. Researchers say that it takes a day or so to learn how to use the vertical mouse and that performance drops slightly.
And the Anir Vertical mouse costs $50. "Anything that knocks up the price of a system is very tough to sell," said Neal Taslitz, president of Humantouch Products.
Mouse experts at Microsoft have not ruled out a vertical design, but they are skeptical. "You have to take account of the social context in which a product will be used," said Edie Adams, ergonomics manager of the company's hardware unit. "A vertical mouse would take a lot of motivation on the buyer's part."
