HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
League Presidents Out As Baseball Centralizes

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 15

 BODY:
From Morgan Bulkeley in 1876 to Leonard Coleman in 1999, from Ban Johnson in 1901 to Gene Budig in 1999, the National and American Leagues have had presidents who operated offices separate and apart from one another. No longer.
Major league club owners voted unanimously today to abandon the traditional arrangement and consolidate all operating functions in the commissioner's office. 
 "This is an historic moment that many have felt was long overdue," said Commissioner Bud Selig, who spearheaded the move to consolidate such matters as umpiring, scheduling and discipline. At the same time, Selig stressed that the leagues would remain separate and competitive on the field.
The move, which apparently generated little or no opposition among owners but drew a negative vote in the executive council from Coleman, was the primary piece of business the owners conducted, but also among the least controversial.
The owners, meeting near the Hall of Fame at the Otesaga Hotel, declined to approve the sale of the Oakland Athletics and the Kansas City Royals, causing concern about the future of both franchises. They took no vote on the sale of the Montreal Expos, who asked for a delay, but they approved the $67 million transfer of the controlling ownership shares of the Cincinnati Reds from the controversial Marge Schott to Carl Lindner, a billionaire Cincinnati businessman (Chiquita bananas), who has been a limited partner.
In announcing the act of centralization, Selig said that Budig has been offered the role of senior vice president for educational and government affairs in baseball and confirmed that Coleman was resigning as the National League president after the season. But, Selig added, Coleman will serve as senior adviser to the commissioner and president of Major League Baseball charities.
"I did not want to serve in a ceremonial post or be a figurehead," Coleman said. Earning a $650,000 salary in his sixth year as National League president, Coleman, who is black, has been the most outspoken advocate within baseball for the hiring of members of minority groups in decision-making positions.
At least two of the functions that have heretofore been handled by the league presidents will have to be negotiated with baseball's players and umpires unions. Placing the umpires under the supervision of the commissioner's office is expected to be an issue in the upcoming negotiations for a new labor agreement to replace the current one, which expires Dec. 31. The umpires' lawyer, Richie Phillips, maintains that the move constitutes a change in terms and working conditions. Centralization was one of the issues that triggered the recent dispute that led to the loss of jobs for 22 umpires.
The players' labor representatives have said a change in meting out disciplinary measures for players must also be negotiated. "This is all about eliminating redundancy and being more efficient in the league office," Jerry Colangelo, managing partner of the Arizona Diamondbacks, said. "Baseball's unique with two leagues. I know there's tradition involved, but I don't think this takes anything away from it."
Sandy Alderson, executive vice president for baseball operations in the commissioner's office, is expected to oversee much of the consolidation. He will most likely have umpiring supervisors working under him, and baseball will very likely name someone to be the official who determines discipline for on-field personnel, as other leagues have.
Selig, at a news conference following the two-and-a-half-hour meeting, ticked off ways in which the leagues will remain separate and retain their identities: the All-Star Game, the World Series, league records, the debate among fans over which league is better. The American League's designated hitter will not be affected by today's change.
Baseball, Selig said, "has had to re-evaluate how it operates its business off the field." Separate functions, he added, have "become an encumbrance that inhibits sound and timely decisions."
"We're getting ready for the 21st century," Selig said.
Some of his constituent teams, however, may go limping into the next century. Miles Prentice, a New York lawyer, heads a group of 42 investors who have agreed to buy the Royals for $75 million, but the owners voted, 29-1 today, with the Royals being the one, to ask the Royals to consider other alternatives.
The owners voted by 28-2 (the Athletics and the Chicago Cubs cast the no votes) to take no action on the $122.4 million sale of the Athletics until a Selig task force completes its study of baseball economics.

HEADLINE: Bank and Developer Seek to Buy Site for 42d Street Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A Canadian bank and a developer are in negotiations to buy a highly coveted development site for a new 35-story skyscraper at one of the most desirable corporate addresses in the city, Madison Avenue and 42d Street.
Although no deal has been signed and there are several other potential buyers circling the parcel, the Brookfield Properties Corporation and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce are the prime contenders for the property, according to rival bidders and real estate executives. An agreement could be struck by the end of the month between Brookfield and the current owner, Credit Suisse First Boston, they say. 
 It is a bittersweet moment for Harry B. Macklowe, a developer with sharp elbows who put together the parcel two years ago for a skyscraper of his own that would mark his comeback to the top ranks of the real estate industry. But as part of a settlement with his lender, Mr. Macklowe was finally forced to walk away from the building this week.
The largest bank in Canada, C.I.B.C. has crisscrossed the city in search of a prestigious location for headquarters since it lost a deal last year to move to 7 World Trade Center. Two large but nearly vacant office towers and several smaller buildings would be demolished to make way for the new 1.1 million-square-foot skyscraper, near Grand Central Terminal on the west side of Madison Avenue, between 41st and 42d Streets.
"It's a wonderful site," said Scott Resnick, whose company, Jack Resnick & Sons, like Jerry I. Speyer, Stephen M. Ross, Boston Properties and Blackstone Real Estate Advisers, has tried to acquire the property. "I wouldn't say it's a fait accompli," he added, "but Brookfield and C.I.B.C. have emerged as the front-runner. That's why we've backed off a bit."
According to city officials, John E. Zuccotti, a former city official and a real estate executive who oversees Brookfield's New York operations, and the bank have already talked to the city about a tax break.
First Boston has no intention of declaring a victor before a deal is done or another more lucrative offer lands on the negotiating table. "At any given moment, there have been a number of front-runners," said William V. Adamski, co-head of the real estate investment banking group at First Boston. "We'll do what makes sense for our institution."
If a deal is consummated, it would be a sweet victory for Mr. Zuccotti, Richard B. Clark and others at Brookfield. They were part of Olympia & York, New York's largest commercial landlord until the recession put the company into bankruptcy court. Mr. Zuccotti and Mr. Clark have been eager to resume building ever since Brookfield took over the remnants of Olympia & York.
For Mr. Macklowe, 62, the settlement with his lender, First Boston, over $250 million in loans was something of a defeat. He gave up his interest in the development but got control of two other buildings and up to $9.5 million in fees from First Boston for acquiring air rights for the Madison Avenue project.
"We took a very dispassionate economic view of the situation," Mr. Adamski said. "Harry ended up losing a property where he wanted to build a major skyscraper. What was relevant to me was what maximized the proceeds for our institution."
An aggressive developer, Mr. Macklowe became infamous in 1985 when one of his contractors razed two of single-room-occupancy hotels on 44th Street only days ahead of a city-imposed ban on demolition. One of his executives eventually pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges and an irate Mayor Edward I. Koch returned Mr. Macklowe's $10,000 campaign contribution.
Mr. Macklowe disputes any notion that he is in financial straits. "I've built three buildings," he said. "I'm back in the development game."
Mr. Macklowe was referring to three different apartment houses, including one under construction at 28th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. But in a city of skyscrapers, it is the people who build the commercial towers that spike the New York skyline who are considered to be the industry elite. And no one in the industry expects Mr. Macklowe to build an office tower.
"Residential projects tend to be less economically and physically glamorous and less scary," said Thomas Falus, president of Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial broker. "Commercial buildings tend to be big and splashy. The dimensions are different in every sense."
First Boston and the other investment banks that fueled the current real estate boom have taken a tougher stance with troubled developers than the commercial banks and pension funds did during the recession in the early 1990's. Lenders took months and even years to work out problems with builders who had defaulted on their loans. By contrast, First Boston moved quickly to resolve its dispute with Mr. Macklowe.
"They're prepared to do whatever it takes to maintain the greatest level of control over the assets in which they've invested," said Scott Latham, a managing director at CB Richard Ellis.
Mr. Macklowe might have been able to salvage his comeback bid on Madison Avenue had he been able to land a tenant for the building. But the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and other companies were unwilling to strike a deal with the developer.

HEADLINE: Creator of Tetris Looks for New Ways to Dazzle and Beguile

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
IF ever there was a common touchstone of cyberculture, it is the engaging little computer game known as Tetris. This first truly cross-platform, cross-generational, across-the-sexes digital diversion is, some 15 years after its birth, still drawing players to all manner of computers -- from desktops to electronic organizers -- to play it.
And 15 years later, people in the gaming industry are still drawn to the creator of Tetris, 44-year-old Alexey Pajitnov. That suits him fine. Making games, playing them and discussing how much fun they are to make and play have been a large part of his life since he was a clever boy growing up in his native Moscow. 
 There was very little to do for entertainment, he recalls, in what was then the Soviet Union. So he occupied himself mostly by solving complex mathematical puzzles on paper. He soon graduated to solving three-dimensional puzzles like Rubik's Cubes. "I loved them all," Mr. Pajitnov said in a heavy Russian accent that makes him sound more like a cosmonaut than an American-based game designer.
But his creation of Tetris in the mid-1980's has made Mr. Pajitnov, a man with a boyishly round face framed with a full beard, a celebrity in game circles and somewhat beyond. In Japan, the birthplace of the Sony Gameboy, the handheld game device that helped to sell more than 30 million copies of Tetris, Mr. Pajitnov is hounded by autograph seekers. In professional game conferences around the world he is often regarded as a living legend, a sort of stocky Jedi master of computer code and game play.
"He created what I still think is the single most addictive game ever made," said Cliff Bleszinski, the lead game designer for Epic, a computer game company based in North Carolina.
Mr. Pajitnov is hoping to strike gold again with a new game on CD-ROM called Pandora's Box. The game, which is being released this month by Microsoft, is a collection of 10 visually dazzling puzzle types with more than 350 individual variations. The puzzles are connected in a plot line that carries the player around the world restoring order wrecked by seven tricksters released from Pandora's box. The game is rooted, Mr. Pajitnov says, in his time-tested theme: players' instinctive urge to replace chaos with order.
"The way he thinks about the customer, and how they approach the game, and what they are going to get out of it, he almost seems like a psychologist," said Ed Fries, general manager of the Microsoft game group. "He's in your head and he is thinking about what he is going to do to make this game compelling to you."
Mr. Pajitnov's approach to computer games is certainly not accidental. By the time he was 14, Mr. Pajitnov, whose mother was a journalist and whose father was a philosopher, writer and political dissident, had fallen into the mind-whirling embrace of advanced mathematics and strategy games. The former he studied hard; the latter he explored gleefully. He earned a master's of science degree in applied mathematics from the Moscow Institute of Aviation and did postgraduate work at the Academy of Science Computer Center in Moscow. All the while he continued to play games, even designing some to test the computers at the center, where he also worked as a programmer in speech recognition, artificial intelligence and computer-assisted design.
In the midst of his heady research, Mr. Pajitnov decided that he was more interested in "bringing the computer to people, directly," as he put it. At first, he said, he tried to find ways of using the computer to help unlock psychological processes. Nothing really came to fruition, but he gained an extraordinary understanding of the psyche, he said, a kind of engineer's insight into human behavior. "That kind of helped," he said, in deciding what he would do next.
In about two weeks in 1984 he wrote the primary computer code that would become Tetris. He recalled that he could have written it more quickly, but he found the game so compelling, even in its embryonic stages, that he kept playing rough versions, telling himself that he was "testing it." After many refinements, the game finally made it to the West in 1988 by way of a Hungarian programming consortium.
The following year the game earned four Excellence in Software Awards, the computer game equivalent to the Oscars, from the Software Publishers Association. Since then, the game has sold some 50 million copies in many variations.
"Tetris is one of the few games that has transcended the casual gamer and the hard-core gamer," Mr. Bleszinski said. It is widely believed that even the occupants of the Russian space station Mir passed some of their idle hours circling high above Earth playing Tetris.
When asked about being recognized as the creator of one of the world's most popular computer games, Mr. Pajitnov paused and spoke slowly. "The first time it is agreeable, but the hundredth time?" His voice trailed off as he shook his head.
Tetris is very unusual in that it is widely played by women, a distinction in a computer game universe that is often mapped by the tastes and habits of male players. "There is just something about it that is so appealing," said Linda Helin, the general manager of XS New York, a game arcade and cybercafe in Times Square. "I still play it."
Mr. Pajitnov said he is not surprised. "Tetris is very nonviolent," he said. "Women don't feel bad that this is some kind of stupid male activity. And Tetris is a kind of game which helps you order the world. You fight against chaos. I'm not sure it is very politically correct, but that's what women prefer to do."
Mr. Pajitnov was still living in the Soviet Union when he developed the game and so was unable to cash in on the wild success of Tetris. Under Communism, he explained, he was prohibited from personally profiting from his work. The rights to his game were given up to the State for 10 years. Only recently, years after he emigrated to the United States in 1991, have the rights to the game reverted to him. "I'm getting some royalties," he said beneath his breath, conceding that the game's economic life is all but over. "I'm losing my humor sense about it."
He'd much rather talk about games than the fortune that got away. "I am always thinking about how he will be puzzled," Mr. Pajitnov said of a potential player, "how he will be intrigued, how he will figure it out and how to fool him." Central to his method of creating computer-based puzzles is to try to create those that will interest and hold his attention. Then he "simplifies, simplifies, simplifies, simplifies until it is understandable." His reason for this, he said, is simple: "It's a lot of frustration when you are just confused on how to operate the puzzle."
After running his own company in the Soviet Union in the late 1980's and working for others in the United States, Mr. Pajitnov created a string of relatively successful games like El-Fish, Welltris and Hatris. In 1996 he joined Microsoft as its first game designer.
Today he is one of 10 game designers nestled in offices on one of Microsoft's campuses just outside Seattle. His second-floor office is comfortable, he said, overlooking the Microsoft cafeteria building.
"Whatever skills I have I use," Mr. Pajitnov, who is married and the father of two sons, said of his work for Microsoft. Dismissing his star status, he shrugged and said, "I'm a working person."
And now he is making the media rounds around the country to talk about his latest project, Pandora's Box.
"Our main goal it to give you a good time, a relaxing time," he said as he mouse- clicked his way through one of the new game's puzzles that requires players to restore the famous form of Rodin's "Thinker" from globs of 3-D pieces.
"Myself, I love this kind of puzzle," he said with an impish grin. "It is kind of meditative stuff."

HEADLINE: Little Theaters Are Suddenly In Demand Yet in Peril

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
For 12 years the 74-year-old Biltmore Theater has stood dark and lifeless, blackened by fire damage, crumbling with neglect.
Now with Times Square suddenly prime real estate and theaters in increasingly great demand, people are fighting over the 948-seat house, at 261 West 47th Street. 
 The battle, between a real estate developer, who says he wants to restore and book the theater, and the Nederlander Organization, which says it may try to more than double the house's size so that it can accommodate musicals, has cast a light on some of Broadway's most beautiful and neglected jewel boxes: the small, two-balcony theaters, mostly on the less popular east side of Broadway, that have fallen into disuse.
Theater operators, who had considered these properties obsolete money losers, and real estate interests are now vying over at least three of the theaters, suggesting that a recent trickle of serious, straight drama on Broadway could lead to a busier future for houses like the Biltmore, Belasco, Cort and Lyceum. Yet the strengthening real estate market in Manhattan could threaten the theaters as never before.
There is new interest in the Lyceum Theater on West 45th Street, which has been dark 70 percent of the time over the last 12 years, according to a report by Richard Frankel, one of several Broadway producers interested in putting a tourist attraction in the theater.
Pointing to a number of successful plays in smaller theaters, including last season's "Blue Room" at the Cort on West 48th Street, Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, said, "All of this bodes well for the future." He once campaigned unsuccessfully against designating the theaters as city landmarks, arguing that theater owners should receive tax breaks or other compensation for the burden of operating under landmark status.
Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, said: "Do we have a new paradigm? I don't think anybody knows the answer to that. This season if you had a telephone booth you could book it if it had a fire exit."
Indeed, Broadway theaters are booked to capacity.
The battle over the Biltmore involves all the issues that are likely to shape the theaters' future.
Joseph Moinian, a real estate developer, said he wanted to restore the Biltmore and build a 43-story residential hotel next to it. He is suing the Nederlanders, the prominent theater owners, arguing that the organization improperly terminated his contract to purchase the property because real estate values had tripled since 1997, when he arranged to buy the property for $14.4 million. Owners believe that the Biltmore can fetch a higher price, he argued.
The Nederlanders have moved to dismiss Mr. Moinian's complaint on the ground that he failed to show up for the real estate closing last April, thereby defaulting on the deal. The theater owners are considering transforming the Biltmore into an 1,800-seat theater as they shop it to other prospective buyers.
The Biltmore's interior became a city landmark in 1987, as did the interiors of five other Broadway theaters, meaning that any changes made for a production, like taking out rows of seats to expand the stage, must be reversed after the show closes.
"One of the options they're considering is rehabilitation of the interior and exterior in compliance with landmark regulations," said Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the Nederlanders, in reference to the Biltmore. "They will either sell it or rent it or retain it. They're looking at all three options."
On Monday, Judge Herman Cahn of State Supreme Court in Manhattan heard arguments in the case.
The prospects for the Biltmore are sharply different than they were in the 1980's, when all of Broadway's theater owners fought landmark designation for theaters that they did not see as economically viable. These small theaters are difficult to book because many people do not want to sit in a second balcony and producers need a certain seating capacity to earn a return on their investment.
Larger theaters like the Gershwin, the Majestic and the Marquis each have about 1,600 seats and only one balcony. And some theaters, like the Helen Hayes, rarely use their second balconies.
Can theater owners be blamed for wanting to update these small houses or get rid of them? "Most of these buildings are approaching 100 years old, and you can't just recreate them easily," Mr. Bernstein said. "By the same token you can't remodel them easily.
"So it's really hard for theater owners to grapple with the problem. There is no other business I can think of where the owners of the factories are still operating with the same plant as they were 100 years ago."
In the early 1990's theater owners struggled to fill seats because of the economic downturn, and some sought to unload their properties. In 1991, for example, the Nederlanders sold the Mark Hellinger theater to the Times Square Church. About three years later, the Shubert Organization agreed to install a community court in the Longacre Theater for three years.
The Biltmore is not the only house of its size that is suddenly coveted. Two blocks down, a fight is raging over the fate of the foundering Lyceum on 45th Street. Several producers want to open an hourlong show geared toward tourists, "The Spirit of Broadway," which would run several times a day. But Mr. Schoenfeld contends that the production is not a legitimate theatrical attraction and does not belong in the Lyceum.
Although he called the Lyceum a money-losing liability when he sold the Lyceum's air rights to Bertelsmann A.G., the German media company, Mr. Schoenfeld nevertheless said: "We're not interested in doing anything other than preserving these theaters for the presentation of legitimate theatrical attractions."
Another developer holds a similar option at the Belasco, a Shubert theater.
Despite the recent demand for Broadway houses of almost any size, many people in the theater district say the Biltmore-sized theaters do not have much of a long-term future.
Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns the two-balcony Walter Kerr Theater, said he believed that the demand would change with the economy. "The future of the two-balcony playhouse is still extremely grim right now," Mr. Landesman said. "There's a theater shortage and booking backlog, but it's not going to last. We've been through these cycles before."
As a result, Mr. Landesman said, he does not consider the Walter Kerr newly valuable property. "If I can get a good price, I would take it," he said "It's tough to book."
The Biltmore, home of "Barefoot in the Park," "Hair" and "My Sister Eileen," was built in 1925. Designed by Herbert J. Krapp and developed by Irwin Chanin, the neo-classical theater needs extensive repairs.
Mr. Moinian said he originally intended to turn the Biltmore into a lobby for the adjacent high rise he planned to build on the east side of Eighth Avenue between 47th Street and 48th Street, which he would call the Biltmore. But because of the theater's landmark interior, Mr. Moinian said the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission informed him that such plans would be impossible.
Mr. Moinian said he proceeded with plans to restore the theater. Unable to locate the original blueprints, Mr. Moinian hired an architectural firm, Issac & Stern, that recreated the plans from scratch. He then hired the architectural firm Li Saltzman, which specializes in restoration. The plans were submitted to the Landmarks Commission.
Terri Rosen Deutsch, the chief of staff for the landmarks commission, said, "When we heard about the litigation, it was decided we would wait to hear the outcome on ownership before any permits were issued."

HEADLINE: The Renegade As Rejuvenator

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is a history professor at Columbia and the author, most recently, of "Liberalism and Its Discontents."

 BODY:
Fourteen months before the 2000 election, the Presidential race is running in full gear and sinking from utter torpor. The two front-runners are conducting campaigns so cautious and so vacuous that they are virtually indistinguishable from one another. Nor have their principal challengers defined themselves clearly.
But suddenly, a somewhat shopworn face emerges to roil the waters: Pat Buchanan, apparently set on running for President as the Reform Party candidate. Now both George W. Bush and Al Gore must deal with a challenger determined to dredge up all the economic and cultural issues they have tried to submerge. 
 Third-party candidacies are a recurrent feature of American political life, but they take on a special importance in years when the main parties fail to address matters that large numbers of voters care about.
In 1968 George Wallace, the segregationist Governor of Alabama, exploited anger about social disorder and won 13 percent of the voters, who felt that Richard Nixon and Hubert Humphrey did not address their concerns.
In 1992 Ross Perot seized on the budget deficit and unhappiness with the economy and ended up with 19 percent of the vote.
Third-party candidates seldom have a chance of winning. People vote for them to make a point -- to force the political world to acknowledge the existence of a passionate belief or a searing discontent. Often, in doing so, they scare the mainstream into taking notice of them and trying to embrace (or co-opt) their grievances. In 1968, would Nixon have moved so determinedly to embrace "law and order" and his "Southern strategy," reaching out to disenchanted Democrats, if Wallace had not been breathing down his neck? In 1992, would Mr. Clinton have turned away from his proposal for a middle-class tax cut if Mr. Perot had not so effectively hectored him on the deficit?
Mr. Buchanan is a classic third-party figure -- too ideologically divisive and demagogic ever to win an election, but able to arouse voter passions similar to his own.
Like the agrarian populists of the 1890's, Mr. Buchanan is not afraid to attack the rich and, as he puts it, the "trans-national corporations whose only loyalty is to the bottom line."
Such language sounds tinny to those in the political mainstream, never more so than during the extraordinary boom of the last few years. But Mr. Buchanan is alert, as almost no other politician is, to the enormous and growing inequality that lies beneath the present abundance. If his past is any guide, he will try to exploit it in an election year in which talk of injustice has been otherwise banished to the sidelines.
But like so many populists of a century ago, Mr. Buchanan has not stuck to economic arguments alone. He fuses his class antagonisms with cultural and social grievances. He rails against abortion, homosexuality, illegitimacy, immigration, sexual license, moral decay and godlessness. Some commentators, including conservatives, have accused him of xenophobia and anti-Semitism.
A committed Roman Catholic, he is happy to make common cause with those evangelical Protestants at war against the excesses of modern culture. Such issues have far less wide-ranging appeal than the economic ones he flogged in the 1996 Republican primaries, but they do have a passionate constituency. That is why the Bush campaign, which had hoped to hold onto the party's social conservatives even while studiously ignoring them, finds Mr. Buchanan's impending defection so alarming.
What effect can Mr. Buchanan hope to have in an election year in which voters seem prematurely tired of the major candidates? Both Republicans and Democrats could lose votes to Mr. Buchanan.
But barring an unusually close election, Mr. Buchanan will probably not win enough votes to sway the election toward one party or the other. Instead, he may well pressure Republicans and Democrats to depart from their cautious, carefully scripted centrism and take a stand. Whatever one thinks of Mr. Buchanan, that may not be such a bad thing.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Regulators Get a 2d 'Scalp' Under Their Belts

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 16

 BODY:
It was a signature that caught the eye of an investigator sifting through documents in the Tokyo office of Cresvale International, the Hong Kong-based brokerage firm that sold what were apparently fraudulent investments to a wide range of Japanese corporate investors.
Why, he wondered, was the head of futures trading at Republic New York Securities, a unit of the Republic New York Corporation, signing a routine letter from the back office confirming the status of a client's account? "It didn't make sense," said Kiyotaka Sasaki, who is in charge of inspections of international financial institutions at the Financial Supervisory Agency, Japan's financial watchdog. "It showed a lack of controls." 
 That question ultimately led to the arrest in the United States on Monday of Martin A. Armstrong, a show-boating investment manager who was well known among Japanese corporate investors for his persuasive sales pitches.
Mr. Armstrong, 49, has been accused by United States prosecutors of defrauding Japanese investors of hundreds of millions of dollars. Two Republic New York Securities officials, William H. Rogers, the futures trading head, and James Sweeney, the unit's chief executive, have been suspended.
Through his lawyer, Mr. Armstrong has denied any wrongdoing.
But the sleuthing that uncovered the purported fraud is likely to help burnish the reputation of Japan's fledgling financial regulators, who began operations a little more than a year ago and have struggled under severe financial and personnel constraints, considering the size and complexity of the markets and institutions they must police.
"We've had some concern about morale here," Mr. Sasaki said. "We have few resources and lots of challenges."
Mr. Armstrong's arrest is the second "scalp" the inspection department has collected this summer, coming roughly two months after regulators revoked the license of Credit Suisse First Boston's derivatives unit and imposed sanctions on the Swiss firm's other operations here for their role in helping Japanese corporations and financial institutions mask their huge losses.
Indeed, what many have assumed was dumb luck on the part of the investigators from the Financial Supervisory Agency was at least in part a matter of weaving together bits of information gleaned in previous forays into the operations of other financial institutions.
The investigators used information they uncovered during their audit of Credit Suisse First Boston and decided to take a look at Cresvale. They suspected that the brokerage firm, which was owned by Mr. Armstrong's Princeton Economics International Ltd., had sold similar financial instruments.
What they found were a group of notes, known collectively as the Princeton notes, issued by an offshore investment company based in the Turks and Caicos Islands that did not fall under the purview of any financial regulator. The proceeds from the sale of those notes and the interest they generated were supposedly held in segregated accounts at Republic New York Securities, but the Japanese regulators suspected that accounts were in fact commingled to mask losses.
Their suspicions no doubt were a result of the environment in which most of them grew up: the old, vague, opaque regulatory system administered by bureaucrats at the Ministry of Finance who were particularly sensitive to the strict maintenance of "firewalls" and boundaries between financial businesses.
Indeed, the companies that were purportedly defrauded by Mr. Armstrong largely seemed to be in the dark until last week, when newspapers here began reporting that the agency had contacted United States regulators with questions about Princeton that ultimately led to Mr. Armstrong's arrest.
Junsei Atarashi, a spokesman for the Yakult Honsha Company, which stands to lose several billion yen from its investment in Princeton notes, said Yakult scrambling to collect information in May, after news broke of the investigation into Cresvale. "The people in charge of investments here bought these notes because they earned a good interest rate," he said. "We never imagined they were going to become trash."
The Amada Company and two of its affiliates could lose a total of 13 billion yen, or $125 million at current exchange rates. "We received an explanation at the time we bought these notes that the principal was secured and the accounts were separately maintained by Republic," said Koshichi Kikuchi, Amada's head of accounting. "Now we are finding out that the accounts were not separately maintained and the principal was not secured, so I can't avoid saying that we were cheated."
It was the 10 percent return that Amada had made on a previous investment in Princeton notes that enticed it into buying another set of notes this spring, Mr. Kikuchi said. Mr. Kikuchi and other company officials denied that notes were purchased to hide losses, but regulators suspect otherwise and the Japanese Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting a separate investigation into corporations that have purchased Princeton notes.
Far from feeling sorry for the investors, many Japanese regard them as foolish, and in fact, Mr. Armstrong apparently did not try to sell Princeton notes to investors in any other country. "This shows a weakness in risk management on the part of Japanese investors," one regulator said.

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
AALY TRIO AND KEN VANDERMARK, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. Mr. Vandermark, the Chicago saxophonist who recently was awarded a MacArthur award, hooks up semi-regularly with a trio of Swedes including the saxophonist Mats Gustafsson, and they make an energized semi-free jazz that's interestingly classical: it harks back lovingly to the 1970's. But it also has a bite and urgency to it. They play tomorrow at 10 P.M.; admission is $10 (Ben Ratliff). 

DOT ALLISON, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. On her album "Afterglow" Dot Allison juxtaposes eerie, languorous electronics, bleary borderline dance music and quietly torchy pop songs; this is a chance to hear if her delicacy can survive outside the recording studio. Tomorrow night at 9, in a lineup of songwriters that also includes Joe Arthur (at 8), Rebecca Gates of the Spinanes (at 10) and Eszter Balint (at 11). Admission is $10 (Jon Pareles).
BASEMENT JAXX, Twilo, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 268-1600. Club music like house and drum-and-bass -- even the best of it -- generally doesn't adhere to the form of an album; focusing on repetitive beats for half an hour on the headphones becomes boring at home. So the rich pleasures of "Remedy," the new album by this English house-music duo of producers, come as a surprise. There's a huge amount going on in the music, some good singers, and various samples and electronic gurgles battle it out for dominance. Tonight at 1 A.M.; tickets are $25 (Ratliff).
BETTIE SERVEERT; GAY DAD; FOO FIGHTERS, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. Only the most diligent or well-connected fans will squeeze into this early-evening club gig by the Foo Fighters, the tartly smart power-punk band led by the former Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl. Hype followers will show up later, to assess Gay Dad, a quietly glamorous (and possibly overrated) new English band. And die-hard fans of earnest underground rock will stick around for the formerly hyped, now just beloved Dutch group, Bettie Serveert. Foo Fighters play tonight at 7:45, Gay Dad at 10 and Bettie Serveert at 11. Admission is $15 for Foo Fighters and $10 for Bettie Serveert (Ann Powers).
BIS; SUKPATCH; TITAN. Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. Bis is a Scottish pop trio that pretends to be a gang of superheroes, and the ruse got that much more plausible when the group composed the title song for the Cartoon Network's "Power Puff Girls." Fans see maturity but still plenty of fun on the band's new "Social Dancing." Titan and Sukpatch, Bis's mates on the supercool label Grand Royal, share the bill. Tomorrow night at 9. Tickets are $12. Tomorrow night at 11:30, following Sukpatch (at 9) and Titan (at 10); admission is $12 (Powers).
* THE BOTTLE ROCKETS; SALLY TIMMS, KELLY HOGAN AND JON LANGFORD; PERNICE BROTHERS; KEVN KINNEY, Mercury Lounge 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. The high point of this evening should be the friendly duel between two modern-day sweethearts of the rodeo: Sally Timms, who has earned much adoration over the years in the Mekons, and who just released an album that may be her best work yet, and Kelly Hogan, who established her own slavish following when in the Rockateens and the Jody Grind. The gals are neighbors in Chicago now and will share the stage with a rather more manly sweetheart, Jon Langford of the Waco Brothers (and of course the Mekons). All-American roots rockers the Bottle Rockets and the Pernice Brothers, as well as the former Drivin' and Cryin' frontman Kevn Kinney, round out the night. (Fans of Ms. Hogan, Ms. Timms, and Mr. Langford can also relax with them tomorrow night at Brownies, 169 Avenue A, between 10th and 11th Streets, East Village, 212-420-8392, when they play the annual Bloodshot Records picnic, which starts at 2 P.M.) Tonight at 8. Tickets are $15 (Powers).
BILLY BRAGG; FREEDY JOHNSTON, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824. The personal and the political both matter to Billy Bragg, an English songwriter with a gruffly endearing voice and and leftist ideals that don't preclude a sense of humor; he sings self-deprecating love songs and pro-labor arguments, and he recently put music behind some rediscovered Woody Guthrie lyrics. Freedy Johnston's finely turned folk-rock songs have carefully balanced melodies that he sings in a winsome tenor. But for all their classic symmetry, they're the confessions of some some desperate, unsavory and unbalanced characters. Tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $25 and $30 (Pareles).
* DMC/TECHNICS WORLD DJ CHAMPIONSHIPS, Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Midtown, (212) 564-4882. The world championships of this annual contest haven't been held in New York before, and it was invented in the city, after all. Last year the regional semifinals turned out to be a great hip-hop event, a chance to see the hunger and craft in hip hop. Tonight 20 individual semifinalists, performing mind-boggling tricks of agility with two turntables and a stack of records will be narrowed down to five; six turntable teams from around the world compete, and there will be intermission performances by the Rock Steady Crew and the Legendary Cold Crush Brothers. Tomorrow night DJ Craze from Brooklyn, who won the world championships in Paris last year, will defend his title; guest appearances by the X-ecutioners and others will keep the crowd occupied while the judges deliberate. Doors open at 7 tonight, and at 8 tomorrow night; tickets are $30 to $40 each night (Ratliff).
* JOHNNY DOWD, Brownies, 169 Avenue A, at 11th Street, East Village, (212) 420-8392. In his cracked Texas twang Johnny Down sings about murder and passion and sin; his band plays a version of honky-tonk that's been dragged through a swamp and encrusted with electronics. Today at 4:30 P.M.; admission is $7 (Pareles).
* TOM FREUND, Living Room, 84 Stanton Street, at Allen Street, Lower East Side, (212) 533-7235. It would be easy to overlook a show like this during such a busy weekend, but the locally based, low-key singer-songwriter Tom Freund deserves a spot on the club-hopper's dance card. His thoughtful stories offer sweet respite from the groove-chasing whirl. Tonight at 11; admission is free (Powers).
* TOMMY FLANAGAN TRIO, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Mr. Flanagan, a master mainstream pianist who flowered rather late in life after serving as Ella Fitzgerald's accompanist, has a deep well of be-bop numbers, theater songs and tunes by jazz composers like Billy Strayhorn and Thad Jones. And with his trio's arrangements, he makes them over so fully that they're practically rewritten. This is the first week of a two-week stint at the Vanguard. Sets are at 9:30 and 11:30, tonight through Sunday night; admission is $20 and $15 on Sunday (Ratliff).
* JUAN GABRIEL, Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741. One of Mexico's most flamboyant and crowd-pleasing singers, Mr. Gabriel works with slick pop bands, mariachi groups and brass bands, sometimes all in the same marathon concert. Naturally, he belts love songs, but he also ponders whether Mexican culture can survive in a world of free trade. Tonight at 8. Tickets are $40 to $75 (Pareles).
BENNY GREEN TRIO, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Green is a young classicist, and one of the better ones playing jazz piano; he plays funky and hard, and breathes not only be-bop but Oscar Peterson's virtuosic effusions as well. Sets tonight and tomorrow night are at 8, 10:30 and midnight; Sunday night at 7 and 9. Cover charge is $20, $15 on Sunday and for the midnight show tomorrow; $10 minimum (Ratliff).
* GUNGA DIN; FIREWATER; BOTANICA, CBGB, 315 Bowery at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052. The romantically moody punk rockers of the Lower East Side are growing up to be excellent full-fledged bohemians, making rich, florid rock-and-roll that makes one want to wear velvet and drink absinthe. Three-star ensembles of this scene's blue period share the bill tonight. Stay up late for Botanica, the enjoyably indulgent auteur project of this crowd's ambassador to Los Angeles, Paul Wallfisch. Tonight the Gunga Din plays at 11, Firewater at midnight, and Botanica nurses the insomniacs at 1:30 A.M. Tickets are $10 (Powers).
JIM HALL AND DAVE HOLLAND, Iridium, 48 West 63d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. The versatile guitarist Mr. Hall has been flourishing in recent years: making a string of heavily arranged albums for large ensembles, currently recording an unusual record with Andrew Hill and Greg Osby, and appearing in exploratory situations like this one, with the sympathetic and rhythmically encouraging Dave Holland, the bassist. Sets through Sunday night are at 8:30 and 10:30; with midnight sets tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30 and $10 minimum (Ratliff).
BUTCH HANCOCK; TISH HINOJOSA, Rodeo Bar, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-6500. Two scions of the singer-songwriter community of Austin, Tex., share this bill. Mr. Hancock, who played Summerstage this year with his longtime buddies Joe Ely and Jimmie Dale Gilmore, is the more subtle flavor in that crowd's hot musical sauce. Ms. Hinojosa is a multitalented Chicana performer whose songs traverse the border with ease. Tonight about 10; no admission or cover charge (Powers).
HELLACOPTERS, CBGB, 315 Bowery, East Village, (212) 982-4052. This Swedish rock quartet makes you think of artisans in remote economies who make beautiful, functional things: an excellent wooden bowl, or a chair, or a loaf of bread. The Hellacopters make perfect hard rock, early 70's Detroit style, devoid of any greater significance. They look like mechanics and play as if in a hurry to make the next gig in another town. They're conscious of what makes a rhythm section powerful, and they know their job is to stun, not to try patience. With Murder City Devils, Zen Guerillas and others. Music starts at 8:30 tomorrow night; the Hellacopters perform at 12:30. Tickets are $12 (Ratliff).
JEFFERSON STARSHIP; DAVE MASON BAND, Carnegie Hall, (212) (247-7800). The Jefferson Starship traded the Jefferson Airplane's psychedelic volatility for a long string of pop hits in the 1970's and 80's. It now includes three original Jefferson Airplane members: Marty Balin, Paul Kantner and Jack Casady, who could start feuding again at any moment. The Dave Mason Band is guaranteed to play "Feelin' Alright." Tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $35 to $75 (Pareles).
* USTAD VILAYAT KHAN, SHUJAAT KHAN AND SABIR KHAN, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 545-7536. Ustad Vilayat Khan, a sitar player who is one of the greatest living improvisers in North Indian music, has invented a technique of bending a note after it has been plucked, tracing a sonic after-image like a curving jet trail. He is performing with his son Shujaat Khan, a sitarist who is already a mature improviser in his own right, and with Sabir Khan (no relation) on tabla. Tonight at 8 P.M.; tickets are $25 to $50 (Pareles).
L7, Life, 158 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 420-1999. The empresses of down-and-dirty punk metal have a new album out, called "Slapp Happy," and they're still burning up stages coast to coast. These Los Angeles-based pioneers are living proof that women can spend their lives chasing their passion for rock-and-roll. Tomorrow night at 10. Tickets are $15 (Powers).
MAN OR ASTRO-MAN?, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street between Church Street and Broadway, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Surf guitar meets science fiction in Man or Astro-Man?, which laces its rowdy instrumentals with B-movie snippets about the future. Tonight at midnight, preceded by Delta 72 at 11 and the Swingin' Neckbreakers at 10; admission is $12 (Pareles).
* PAT MARTINO; JOYOUS LAKE/JOHN SCOFIELD QUARTET, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592. A young jazz guitarist's dream bill. Pat Martino is an heir to Wes Montgomery's warm, bluesy guitar style, but he says what he wants to say with an unflappable, pianistic fluency; his note-bendings are almost surreally poised. He shares a double bill with John Scofield, who's a bit more raucous and funky and among the most influential guitarists in the last 20 years. Sets through Sunday are at 9 and 11:30 P.M.; cover charge is $30, with a $5 minimum (Ratliff).
MOMUS; KAHIMI KARIE; LOUIS PHILIPPE, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. There's an international cabal of songwriters who love the 1960's pop that hovered outside rock: lounge combos, soundtracks, bossa nova, Burt Bacharach and Martin Denny and Brian Wilson. Three sometime collaborators appear on this bill. Momus is a word-loving, mildly misanthropic character who sets his proudly clever ruminations to slightly haywire synthesizer tracks. He also writes for Kahimi Karie, who shyly whispers her songs onstage. Louis Philippe, born in France and living in England (where he works as a BBC sports announcer), applies his sweetly wistful voice to songs full of twisted harmonies and lovelorn yearning. Tonight, Louis Philippe at 11:15, Kahimi Karie at midnight and Momus at 12:45 A.M. Admission is $20 (Pareles).
MORTIIS, Downtime, 251 West 30th Street, Manhattan, (212) 253-1046. In approaching Mortiis you have to think about the arc of civilization a little bit. Here we have a former member of the Norwegian death-metal band Emperor in his solo project, and he appears as an animal spirit with an elongated prosthetic nose, bat wings, and pointy ear extensions. This is his "mellow" endeavor, reverberant dungeon-and-druid music made by electronic keyboards and acoustic guitar; a singer named Sarah Jezebel Deva sings wordlessly on top. It's as unashamedly grim and dramatic as underground metal gets, and it's totally serious. What more do you want from the end of the millennium? His set begins tomorrow night at 1 A.M.; tickets are $10 (Ratliff).
WOLFGANG MUTHSPIEL TRIO, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319. Mr. Muthspiel, a guitarist who has played with Paul Motian's electric be-bop quintet, has a lot of ideas about what jazz can sound like: he's recorded solo pieces on acoustic guitar, with samplers, in duets with percussion, with regular jazz trios and quartets. Tomorrow night he plays guitar, violin and electronically created loops with two excellent musicians, the bassist Scott Colley and the drummer Tom Rainey. Music starts at 9; admission is $8; $5 drink minimum (Ratliff).

With her electric keyboard set to sound like bells or violins or a music box, she sings waywardly ethereal songs, full of dreamlike journeys and mysterious rendezvous, opening up a private sphere. Like the Rolling Stones if they'd never reached stadiums, the Pretty Things started out as a band of rowdy, hard-driving, blues-loving English musicians in the 1960's; they also came up with pre-psychedelic garage-rock nuggets ("L.S.D.," which they claimed was about pounds, shillings and pence) and what was likely the first rock opera, "S.F. Sorrow." Reunited in the 90's, they sound as hard-bitten as they did three decades ago. Tonight at 10 at Maxwell's; tickets are $20. Sunday night at 9 at the Bowery Ballroom; tickets are $16 (Pareles).

"Emocore" is the underground antidote to the macho angst of best-selling rock bands like Limp Bizkit. HEADLINE: Factory Production Rose More in August

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Production at factories, mines and utilities exceeded expectations in August, paced by surging demand for automobiles and trucks, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Output rose three-tenths of 1 percent for a seventh consecutive monthly increase, the Fed said. While that was less than the gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, it surpassed the consensus forecast of economists for no change for the month. 
 "This is evidence of a broad-based recovery in manufacturing," said William Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "It extends not only to exporters, but to domestic producers."
Automotive production rose 8.1 percent in August, the biggest increase in a year, as manufacturers bet that low unemployment and rising incomes would keep demand high. The Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation, DaimlerChrysler A.G. and the Toyota Motor Corporation all posted higher August sales as the industry recorded its best month since 1986.
Production of computers and electrical equipment also rose in August, the Fed said.
Another Government report underscored the expectation that the economic expansion, now in its ninth year, is cruising toward a record in January. First-time claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell 4,000 to 288,000 last week. Analysts interpreted that as a sign employment gains are continuing.

HEADLINE: Rubin Is Planning to Return to Wall Street

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that he planned to return to Wall Street, though he has not decided where he will work.
Mr. Rubin, who is 60, said in a phone interview that he was likely to rejoin the financial world "in some fashion and in some serious way." 
 "I don't know with whom I'll be doing it," he said, "or how I'll be doing it."
Since leaving the Treasury Department on July 2, Mr. Rubin has been considering job offers, he said. He was co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs before joining the Clinton Administration in 1993 as chairman of the National Economic Council. He became Treasury Secretary in 1995.
Mr. Rubin said he would spend some time in community service as chairman of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a community development support organization.
The group raises money to support nonprofit community organizations that work to revitalize distressed urban and rural areas. Mr. Rubin will succeed John P. Mascotte, president and chief executive of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri, as the chairman of Local Inititives.

HEADLINE: Stockman Forming Own Buyout Concern

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
David Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan Administration, is resigning as senior managing director and partner of the Blackstone Group to form a buyout concern focused on industries based in the Midwest.
Mr. Stockman's company, which will be known as Heartland Industrial Partners, intends to raise as much as $2 billion to buy companies. Mr. Stockman said he would work closely with Blackstone, the private merchant bank where he has worked for 12 years. Blackstone will invest in Heartland. 
 Mr. Stockman, 52, a former Michigan Congressman, said Heartland would enable him to return to his roots as an entrepreneur.
"This sector of the U.S. economy, once disparaged as the 'rust belt,' is today one of the developed world's most efficient manufacturing centers," he said. "Traditional manufacturing businesses are undervalued, and the industrial sector remains under-penetrated by private equity funds. These factors provide a context for significant opportunity for buyout and buildup investors with the right vision and the right strategy."
The new company will have offices in New York and the Midwest.

HEADLINE: James R. West, 84, Diplomat Married to Mary McCarthy

 BODY:
James R. West, a career diplomat and the husband of the writer Mary McCarthy for nearly 30 years, died on Monday at Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor. He was 84 and lived in Castine, Me.
Dashing and worldly with a superlative wit, Mr. West immediately captured Ms. McCarthy's attention when they met in Warsaw in January of 1960. He was a cultural attache with the Foreign Service; she and Saul Bellow were on a lecture tour sponsored by the State Department at the recommendation of the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr., who introduced the couple. 
 Ms. McCarthy said of Mr. West that he was the first real man she had met. A fan of her writing, Mr. West already esteemed Ms. McCarthy's intellect before being further swept away by her charms. Though they were both married at the time -- she to Bowden Broadwater, her third husband; he to Margaret Jacobson, his second wife and the mother of his three children -- he is said to have remarked after their first dance that he would marry her. Divorces followed on both sides.
"He has a kind of exquisite tenderness, toward things as well as persons," Ms. McCarthy wrote of her new acquaintance to a friend, the philosopher Hannah Arendt. "The ordinary Poles . . . all love him."
Mr. West was born in Maine and attended Bowdoin College. After briefly trying his hand at writing, he joined the Air Force in World War II. Shortly after the war, he began his career in the Foreign Service and became director of personnel for the Marshall Plan in Paris. After moving back to the United States in 1955, Mr. West was posted in Warsaw as Cultural Attache.
In 1961, following his marriage to Ms. McCarthy, and to be close to his children, he joined the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group that promotes worldwide economic growth, as the director of information. He held the post until his retirement in 1979.
By all accounts, their life in Paris offered a brilliant marriage of the diplomatic and the literary, as intellectuals, artists, government officials and various friends passed through their salon on the rue de Rennes for nearly 20 years.
Following Mr. West's retirement in 1979, he and Ms. McCarthy divided their time between Paris and Castine and, later, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., where Ms. McCarthy taught at Bard College. In Castine they lived in the 1805 Daniel Johnston house, where they recreated the life Ms. McCarthy once had with her parents, who died when she was 6. It was a sort of romantic idyll centered on a handsome and winning couple whose days were enlivened by memorable gatherings of family and friends including the poet Robert Lowell and the critic Elizabeth Hardwick.
After Ms. McCarthy's death in 1989, Mr. West moved permanently to Castine. In 1990, he married Barbara Byrnes, whom he had met during college. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three children, Daniel of Los Angeles, Alison of New York and Jonathan of Lodz, Poland, and by four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: United States Sets a Record for Living Beyond Its Means

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THERE are few things more enjoyable than spending more than you earn. Especially if you are convinced you can keep doing so indefinitely.
The United States is now in that position. As a nation, it is outspending its income by more than ever before. 
 That fact does not prove that the party is about to end. Many of the trends that have enabled Americans to spend so much remain in place. But the recent weakness of the dollar against the Japanese yen may be the first sign that this party's liquor supply is running low.
The measure of such overspending is known as the current account deficit -- the broadest measure of what we pay to foreigners for goods, services and other miscellaneous things, less what we collect from them. It's been big for some time, but now it is ballooning out of control.
This week the Commerce Department reported the deficit reached $80.7 billion in the last quarter, or nearly a billion dollars a day. That was up 18 percent from the previous quarter -- which itself had been a record.
The proper way to look at such figures is relative to the size of the economy. There, too, it's a record, equaling 3.63 percent of gross domestic product, more than twice what it was a couple of years ago. The previous peak, set in the final three months of 1986, was 3.53 percent.
The growing deficit has not been a problem so far because the rest of the world has been happy to take all those dollars we pay for things and invest them in dollar-denominated assets. They give us cars and barrels of oil, and we give them pieces of paper called securities. The United States was attractive because it had been growing while Japan was in a prolonged recession, Europe was plagued by low growth and high unemployment, and much of the developing world was in crisis.
Now, however, things are starting to change for the better overseas. Japan is growing, albeit in a stuttering manner, and attracting investment. The yen has risen sharply against the dollar, as the Japanese central bank has intervened only half-heartedly. The recovery in most of developing Asia is well under way. Europe is also looking healthier, although the German Government's weakness and indecision have hurt the euro.
In other words, alternatives to investing in the United States are starting to look more attractive. The resulting downward pressure on the dollar probably is not going to be too intense for a while. The Japanese are likely to do a better job of holding the yen down, and speculators who have lately been betting against the dollar will move on to other markets. But at some point the huge current account deficit will begin to seem important to investors and currency traders. Then the dollar will really begin to slide. "The trade deficit can get bigger and bigger, and no one will care -- until they do," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
Then the United States Government will face difficult choices. Protectionist pressures will grow in Washington, and the Federal Reserve will be forced to raise interest rates -- already higher than in Europe or Japan -- to attract investment. But those higher rates could depress inflated stock prices and cause foreigners to flee America rather than invest more. The higher interest rates rose, the more pressure the dollar would face.
You may remember that that is exactly what happened to Mexico in 1994, when the world suddenly stopped sending the capital needed to finance a growing current account deficit. In the aftermath of that, the United States has lectured that countries must live within their means. Physician, heal thyself.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE;
Turning Old School Into Apartments

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Work is nearing completion on a $10.5 million conversion of the turn-of-the-century St. Agnes elementary school in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn into a 90-unit middle-income rental apartment building.
When completed next month, the Italian-Renaissance-style former school at 421 Degraw Street will have studio to three-bedroom units to be rented to people with annual incomes of $30,000 to $100,000. Monthly rents for the apartments, with 450 to 1,200 square feet, will be $800 to $1,750. The developer and area brokers said those rents were 20 percent lower, on average, than rents for apartments at the eastern edge of this reviving neighborhood. 
 The project, called the School House in Carroll Gardens, will have a parking lot for 50 cars. The building is between Hoyt and Bond Streets, not far from the area's low-income housing developments and the recently restored Gowanus Canal. Since leasing began in May, contracts have been signed or are pending on 50 of the apartments, and applications are in various stages of review for the rest, said Getz Obstfeld, a principal of Community Developers Inc., of New Rochelle, N.Y., which is developing the project in partnership with the Cheever Development Corporation, based in Brooklyn.
The School House project is part of the city's New Housing Opportunities Program, intended to spur the production of middle-income apartments by providing developers with construction and/or permanent financing as well as a public subsidy in the form of a second loan at an interest rate of 1 percent for up to $30,000 per unit. In exchange, the developer must build or renovate rental buildings or limited-equity cooperatives for income-eligible tenants. Depending on family size, the tenant's annual income may not exceed seven or eight times the monthly rents for the apartments, or 250 percent of the median New York City income, or $133,500, whichever is less.
The School House project received a $7.7 million construction loan, which will be converted to a permanent one, from the New York City Housing Development Corporation, which raises the financing for the program from the sale of tax-exempt bonds. The corporation, using its own reserves, also provided a $1.7 million second loan, or $19,000 per unit. The rest of the financing came from the partners' own funds.
Since the corporation started issuing financing 16 months ago, $113 million has been given to 15 projects with a total of 1,061 residences. Five of the projects are complete and the rest are to be completed over the next eight months, among them, the conversions of an old knitting factory at 79 Clifton Place in Clinton Hill to 40 rentals and of a former armory at 167 Clermont Avenue in Fort Greene to 110 rental apartments. An additional $150 million to $175 million is expected to be given over the next year to produce 1,200 to 1,500 more middle-income residences, according to the housing corporation.
Russell A. Harding, the housing corporation's president, said that with projects like the School House in Carroll Gardens, "the result is more affordable housing for the city's resurgent middle class and the preservation of a piece of a community's history."
The former school, across the street from St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, has been vacant since 1987, and over the years, there were unsuccessful attempts to salvage it. Under a 1996 plan, the church, working with two local nonprofit groups -- the Carroll Gardens Association and the Gowanus Canal Development Corporation -- tried to recycle the old school into low-income rentals for the elderly, but the groups and the church were unable to obtain financing, and the project was abandoned a year later.
Mr. Obstfeld said that last year, after he and his partners, who had been involved with the nonprofit groups in plans to convert the school to housing for the elderly, secured financing from the city, they switched to the current project and bought the old school for $1.1 million. "Three years ago," he added, "this area of Carroll Gardens could not support this project as market-rate housing, and while it may today, the goal, then as now, was to provide housing that people in the community could afford."
The Rev. John Delendick, the former pastor of St. Agnes, who is on the real estate committee of the Diocese of Brooklyn, which reviews the sale of church-owned properties, agreed with that assessment. "This was one of the best offers," he said, "and we took it because the project will save a local landmark, benefit the community and help the church keep parishioners and draw new ones."
The developers have exercised their option under the city's middle-income housing program to give preference to income-eligible applicants from the community for up to 30 percent of the apartments.
Father Delendick, who is now the pastor of nearby St. Michael's Church, said the money from the sale has been invested by the diocese, creating funds to help the financially strapped St. Agnes parish "pay some of its bills."
Mr. Obstfeld said that in converting the old school, its exterior, which features classical limestone and terra-cotta details, has been refurbished in keeping with its original design, and that interior features like marble wainscoting, mosaic tile flooring and wrought iron railings, were saved, whenever possible. To create the apartments, the partners, following a design by Grasso & Menziuso Architects of Manhattan, reshaped the building's high-ceilinged four floors into seven floors.
The result is that the units have 8.5-foot to 18-foot-high ceilings and unusual layouts. Some are on two floors, while others have lofts or terraces, Mr. Obstfeld said, adding that most also offer views of Manhattan or the rest of Brooklyn. In addition to the parking spaces, which cost $125 a month, amenities include a laundry room and a 24-hour doorman. Initial occupancy is to begin next month.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Reform Party 101

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Gov. Jesse Ventura has come up with the exciting idea of recruiting Donald Trump to run as the Reform Party Presidential candidate. This is the sort of creative coupling that could come only from a chief executive who moonlights as a professional wrestler. Who better for the balanced-budget party than a man whose fundamental business philosophy has always been that if you borrow enough, the banks can't afford to foreclose on you?
The Reform Party's search for a Presidential candidate has left many people puzzled, wondering how any organization's leadership could apparently regard Mr. Trump, Patrick Buchanan, Lowell Weicker and Ross Perot as equally suitable standard-bearers. I have been looking into this matter and I am prepared to answer questions. 
 Who is eligible to become the Reform Party candidate for President of the United States?
According to party leaders, any American citizen who agrees with the Reform platform and is prepared to spend the money necessary to get on the ballot. All it takes is several million dollars and a dream.
What's in the Reform Party platform?
A whole lot of stuff, actually, down to abolishing the Appalachian Regional Commission. But the three biggest points seem to be government reform, trade protectionism and balanced budgets. The platform specifically says the party opposes tax cuts until the national debt is paid down.
Does Pat Buchanan oppose tax cuts until the national debt is paid down?
According to his spokesman, Mr. Buchanan's only problem with the Republicans' proposed $792 billion tax cut is that it is not large enough.
What does the Reform leadership say about that?
The chairman, Russell Verney, says he "can envision Pat Buchanan with a straight face saying he supports the party platform."
Does Jesse Ventura, the only Reform Party member ever to actually get elected to anything, support Pat Buchanan?
Mr. Ventura, who calls Pat Buchanan a "retread," has been floating the names of Mr. Trump and former Governor Weicker of Connecticut.
Is Lowell Weicker a protectionist?
Mr. Weicker says, "Hell, no."
Does Donald Trump support the Reform Party platform?
Mr. Trump could probably work it into his current political ideology, which seems firm only in regard to the virtues of tax incentives for real estate development and the evils of alimony.
What is the current makeup of the Reform Party membership?
The Reform Party members seem united mainly on the goal of opening up the political process until it is finally yawning so wide that they can step into elective office themselves.
What ever happened to Ross Perot?
When last seen, Mr. Perot was still promising to assemble a panel of first-class experts to come up with a new plan to look under the national hood and retool the governmental engine, as soon as he gets the crazy aunt out of the attic.
What are the chances that Mr. Perot will change his mind and run for President again himself?
Very slim, since Mr. Perot dislikes the limelight and never swerves unexpectedly from one course to another on the basis of an inexplicable, lunatic whim.
Will the Reform Party survive into the next millennium?
The 16th-century prophet Nostradamus had a great deal to say about this topic in a passage translated from Latin only minutes ago:
The money-mantled minion leaps into the abyss,
Then rises up.
His second, shouting, leans upon the rope.
The seer is unusually forthright here. The rope-leaner is obviously Governor Ventura in his wrestling persona, whose promotion of Mr. Trump will bear fruit in the year 2000. The first stanza depicts the luxury-apartment and casino developer accepting the Presidential nomination, in a ceremony followed by a final cataclysm and the Rapture. A slightly different interpretation argues that the text foresees President Clinton's recent trip to New Zealand, during which the economic adviser Gene Sperling was photographed bungee-jumping off a 150-foot bridge.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Partying In China

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Riding with the waves, Fortune magazine in New York has come up with a terrific, with-it, win-win idea.
For Oct. 1 the Chinese Communist Politburo has organized a national celebration of the 50th anniversary of the People's Republic following the military triumph of Mao Zedong. Everybody knows where office and factory workers will stand, precisely what slogans to shout, and which Chinese with a dissident political or religious record the police will take off the streets during the celebration. 
 But every big party needs celebrities. Not very many would have shown up on their own just for the Communist Party's victory banquets. So Fortune invited the kind of celebrities the Politburo loves most -- top foreign business executives from America and other countries to go to Shanghai Sept. 27 to 29 for an economic forum and then to Beijing, where their private planes are guaranteed red-runway treatment. Only multinational business, please, and only chairmen, presidents and C.E.O.'s.
The enticement was knowing they would get the chance to meet Chinese who interest them most, those who approve business contracts.
Fortune said President Jiang Zemin had "graciously" agreed to give the keynote speech in Shanghai. You learn to talk real humble if you do business with the Chinese Communists.
More than 200 C.E.O.'s have signed up already; a real A-list. About a dozen of the world's communication chiefs whose employees are supposed to report on China are listed -- including Time Warner, Fortune's owner, CNN and NBC.
Top folk from American industry, finance and commerce will be there, from Boeing to Calvin Klein. The Boeing man will be Philip M. Condit, chairman, forever a historical footnote for saying that his attitude toward human rights violations in China was the same as his attitude toward them in America -- after all, people have been beaten and shot in the U.S. civil rights struggle, haven't they?
I think that for any member of the press to organize a party for a government dictatorship is damaging to the publication and the rest of us.
But the basic problem is what goes on in the minds of the Condits: The pretense of American business, and the legislators its money helps elect, that it cannot see the obligation of American corporations to use their economic power to help the viciously oppressed; the sardonic stand that American faults can be equated with Beijing's use of terror as the instrument of government; the philosophy that money comes uber alles, even uber Americans' principles, and what their own religions teach.
So, of course, uber God.
Everything having to do with business and profits and how to get more of both is on the Shanghai agenda -- everything except the human rights of the Chinese who are buying our products and providing our cheap labor.
Human Rights Watch in China is not questioning, as I am, the very idea of businessmen getting together to worship the money idol in China. But it pleads with business people to read the accounts of the independent-minded Chinese sentenced to labor camps and how they were tortured, sometimes forced to exist in their own feces. And then please -- stand up in China, and use the safety of foreign passports to dare to speak up.
People often ask me -- Don't you get a feeling of defeat, writing so much about human rights in China and other dictatorships, all the while knowing that leaders of America, particularly the President and the business community, grovel to the Chinese?
Often. But then I think of the former Chinese prisoner Harry Wu, who secretly went back to the labor camps to track the fate of those still there. And I think of Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat who has not weakened on Chinese human rights for a moment. She represents San Francisco, so I asked her what she would say this time. She thinks about it and then sends me this message:
"The spectacle of the U.S. C.E.O.'s kowtowing to the Chinese Communist leaders is grotesque but not new. This time, however, when the C.E.O.'s stand in Tiananmen Square with the Beijing regime to 'celebrate' 50 years of killing and repression, they will have blood on the soles of their shoes."

AT&T and British Telecom To Link Wireless Operations
AT&T and British Telecommunications said they would expand their global communications alliance by linking their wireless telephone operations around the world.
AT&T and British Telecom are already trying to create a $10 billion joint venture to serve the international communications needs of multinational corporations. While the new wireless alliance would not technically be part of that venture, its formation underscores the growing importance of wireless as part of the comprehensive package of services that carriers are trying to build. Page C2. 

Rubin to Return to Wall Street
Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, plans to return to Wall Street, though he has not decided where he will work. Mr. Rubin said he had been sifting through job offers. He has decided to spend part of his time in community service as the new chairman of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation. C5.
 
Cablevision to Buy Sony Equipment
Sony made its first big move into the United States cable television market with the announcement that Cablevision Systems would buy more than $1 billion worth of Sony equipment to deliver advanced digital television services in the New York City area. C5.
 
Web Sites to Share Auction Listings
In an attempt to catch up with Ebay, nearly 100 Internet sites, including three of the biggest -- Microsoft's MSN, Excite@Home and Lycos -- have agreed to share their auction listings so that an item put up for sale on one site will be available on the other sites. C2.

Stock were mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 63.96 points, to 10,737.46. The Nasdaq composite index fell 7.45 points, to 2,806.72. The S.& P. 500-stock index edged up half a point, to 1,318.48. C8.
 
Football Strategy Before the Games
The studio programs that precede National Football League games on Sundays are promoting themselves in ads that focus on entertainment, expertise and the interaction among announcers. In some spots, Fox has transformed its announcers, including, from left, Howie Long, Terry Bradshaw and Chris Collinsworth, into animated Claymation characters. Advertising. C6.
 
Fraud Case Highlights Regulators
The sleuthing in Japan that uncovered the purported fraud of Martin A. Armstrong, the chairman of Princeton Economics International, is likely to help burnish the reputation of Japan's fledgling financial regulators, who began operations a little more than a year ago and have struggled under severe financial constraints. FDX, the parent of Federal Express, said that rising fuel prices hurt its first-quarter earnings and might keep it from meeting this year's profit forecasts. C5.
