HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
A Price for Everything, Even Testaverde's Heel

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
When Vinny Testaverde collapsed to the Giants Stadium turf with a season-ending torn Achilles' tendon last Sunday, did the Jets' potential sale price plunge?
If the Jets were a publicly traded stock, Testaverde's injury would have sent shares reeling, just as if a company's earnings had come in below projections or the sales of a ballyhooed product had gone into the tank. 
 Potential buyers seeking to acquire the Jets started to assemble last month with the expectation that the team might play in the Super Bowl. Such anticipation had to figure into the price one of the suitors would pay. Now, with Testaverde out and Rick Mirer in, the anticipation is considerably muted.
"These are emotional buys and factors like that can't be ruled out," John Moag, the managing director of the sports industry group at the investment banking firm Legg Mason, said of the impact of Testaverde's injury. "How a team is playing has a psychological effect."
Are the Jets now worth $10 million less than they were before 2 P.M. last Sunday? Or did the value drop by $25 million? Or $50 million?
Will the loss of each game lop $5 million from the price? Will each of Rick Mirer's interceptions cause a $750,000 drop? Will Wayne Chrebet's return from injury be worth $2.5 million more? Will each first down be worth $10,000?
The estimated 26 suitors who have signed confidentiality agreements to examine the Hess estate's sale prospectus know, however, that winning isn't the only consideration. The Washington Redskins' 6-10 record last year did not scare Daniel Snyder away from from buying them for $800 million, a price largely determined by the cash horde coming from the team's two-year-old stadium.
"I don't see the Testaverde situation affecting the value, but you can say for sure that if the Jets are out of the playoffs early -- say they're 1-7 or 2-6 -- it takes some glamour off the team," said Michael Ozanian of Forbes magazine, which values the Jets at $363 million in its current issue, slightly more than half the Dallas Cowboys' value of $663 million.
Marc Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Ltd., a Chicago consulting firm, added: "Being without Testaverde shouldn't make a difference. We're not talking about Peyton Manning or Tim Couch, quarterbacks in their early 20's, but a guy who's in his 30's and at the tail end of his career."
Of greater concern for the value of the Jets, Ganis and Ozanian insisted, is the coaching future of Bill Parcells. If he leaves after a disappointing 1999 season, it would be like Lee Iacocca leaving Chrysler in the 1980's before the company's recovery was completed. "I see Parcells staying on as coach as being worth $10 million or $20 million," Ganis said.
If the Jets sell for $500 million or more, it will be because of the hope of getting a new stadium when the team's Giants Stadium lease expires in 2008.
Among the Jets' suitors are Cablevision's Charles Dolan; the Devils' owner, John McMullen; the builders Sam Grossman and Samuel LeFrak; the cosmetics heir Ronald Lauder; the Mets co-owner Fred Wilpon, and the tandem of developer Steve Ross and developer/financier Bill Mack. For whomever wins the bidding, the biggest challenge might be negotiating an expensive and difficult buyout with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to get a new stadium and sweetheart lease in place by 2003 or 2004.
With the Nets and the Devils planning arenas away from the Meadowlands, the authority wouldn't want to make it easy for another team to leave, especially one that had never squawked about its lease when Leon Hess was alive.
 
Pay-Per-View Take
 TVKO hopes that a blitz of advertising will push pay-per-view purchases for tomorrow night's $49.95 Oscar De La Hoya-Felix Trinidad welterweight fight over the million mark. No nonheavyweight bout has attracted more than the 800,000 for De La Hoya-Pernell Whitaker in April 1997.
"We're not predicting one million buys, but we may do it," said Lou DiBella, a senior vice president of TVKO, a division of HBO Sports.
The fight's nine national sponsors, including GTE, Western Union, Anheuser-Busch, Golden Ram and Excite.com are spending a combined $7 million on commercials and providing TVKO with $1 million in cash. Three sponsors -- McDonald's, Puma and Met-Rx -- are also in De La Hoya's endorsement portfolio.
"We've never seen a fight with so much sponsorship -- it's more than we got for Holyfield-Foreman in 1991," said Mark Taffet, a TVKO senior vice president. "Economically this is a heavyweight fight. They're getting as much as Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis will be paid for their rematch."
TVKO is looking ahead to a De La Hoya-Trinidad rematch -- neither man is likely to get more money by fighting any other foe -- and DiBella projected the inaugural matchup into "one of the great trilogies in boxing history."
First, let's get one fight finished -- with a legitimate decision rendered by three competent judges -- before we think of three of them.
 
Airwaves
There hasn't been a better episode of a TV comedy this year than an "Arliss" -- replayed this week -- with a boozing, loud, yet sympathetic Marge Schott-like character played perfectly by Kathleen Freeman. . . . Spectacular ratings for the United States Open tennis semifinals and finals powered CBS to a 3.5 Nielsen rating for the tournament, up 52 percent from last year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Rebuffing an Early Selloff, Dow Still Falls 63.96 Points Traders Leave Early to Beat Hurricane

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices pulled out of an early sinking spell yesterday to close with modest losses for two of the major gauges, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eked out a slender gain.
Among the forces buffeting the market were warnings of corporate profit shortfalls, a rebound by the dollar from a 44-month low against the yen, a stronger-than-expected report on industrial output last month, a rise in a barometer of Philadelphia-area manufacturing and the approach of Friday's triple-witching session when options and futures contracts expire. 
 Many traders heeded official advice to leave early to beat the full effects of Hurricane Floyd, in some cases covering short positions -- that is, buying securities to repay borrowed securities they have already sold -- and that helped fuel the comeback that began about mid-day.
"It seems that traders closed out positions they'd normally close out tomorrow," said Warren Epstein, head trader at Richard A. Rosenblatt & Company.
The New York Stock Exchange kept normal hours and said it would do so again today.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which at one stage was down nearly 175 points, finished with a loss of 63.96 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent. At 10,737.46, the Dow is 5.2 percent off its Aug. 25 peak but is still 17 percent higher for the year.
The Nasdaq market fell 7.45 points, or a quarter of 1 percent, to close at 2,806.72. The S.& P. 500 edged up 0.51 of a point, to 1,318.48.
Interest rates eased, apparently reflecting diminished concern about the dollar.
Hewlett-Packard fell 4 9/16 to 103 15/16 to account for more than a third of the decline in the blue-chip Dow, where 21 stocks fell and only 8t gained.
The session's most active issue was Quintiles Transnational, a North Carolina company that is the biggest conductor of clinical trials for drug makers. Quintiles skidded 14 3/4 a share, to 20, after it said profits would be shy of expectations this year and next. Almost 39.5 million shares changed hands.
FDX, parent of Federal Express, and Eastman Chemical also warned of lower profits; FDX fell 5 7/16 a share, to 38 1/4, while Eastman lost 2 3/8, to 43 15/16. Xerox, which shuffled its sales force again, slumped 4 5/16, to 42 3/4.
American Home Products gained 3 1/2, to 46 3/4, on word that it may be near settling injury claims by users of its diet drugs.
Even though the Nasdaq set a closing high in September, the Dow industrials in August and the S.& P. 500 in July, the general market has lagged well behind. According to an analysis by Alfred Goldman of A. G. Edwards, 51 percent of S.& P. companies closed Tuesday 20 percent or more below their 52-week highs prior to mid-May.
Leah Modigliani, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, called the market "overvalued," but said it still offered values in basic materials, energy and some cyclical stocks. "We think a global recovery is under way," she said, predicting that the Federal Reserve would avoid raising short-term interest rates at its Oct. 5 policy meeting.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancing ones 2,063 to 916 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 220 making new lows and only 18 new highs.
Stocks fell overseas, the biggest losses being 2.7 percent in Tokyo, 1.5 percent in Germany and 1.5 percent in Sao Paulo.

Treasuries Edge Up
By The Associated Press
Bond prices moved slightly higher yesterday in a session cut short by the approach of Hurricane Floyd.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 1/32, to 100 2 3/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.07 percent from 6.10 percent on Wednesday.
With heavy rains from the hurricane threatening to disrupt travel in and around New York, the Bond Market Association, an industry trade group, decided yesterday morning to close the session at 1 P.M.
The Treasury bond market benefited from the end of a selling spree by insurance companies, which were raising money in case Hurricane Floyd led to extensive insurance claims along the Atlantic Coast.
A slight strengthening by the dollar against the Japanese yen also contributed to the bond market's gains.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rises, in Seeming Conflict With Job Creation

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New York City's economy is booming, companies are creating new jobs at a record pace -- but the unemployment rate is 6.9 percent, significantly higher than it was just six months ago, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor.
The seeming paradox of rising employment and rising unemployment may indeed reflect what is going on in New York City's labor market, economists say. But it probably says more about the peculiarities of the economic statistics that politicians and businessmen rely on, but that economists concede are often flawed and easily manipulated. 
 Just changing the time period can change the whole employment picture. If the city's current unemployment rate is compared with its rate a year ago, 7.8 percent, today's rate looks good. If it is compared with March's 6.4 percent, it looks bad. The rate in July was 7 percent.
Unemployment data "are worthless, month-to-month, or virtually worthless," said Mark Zandi, chief economist of Regional Financial Associates. And New York City's numbers, he said, are even more volatile than those of other cities or states.
That is because the unemployment figures are based on a monthly survey of fewer than 1,500 households in the city. Their responses are fed into a complicated econometric model created by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington. That Government agency, which runs the survey along with the Census Bureau, says that it makes every effort to talk to households that are representative of the city's population as a whole.
But that is difficult in a city with a highly diverse population. New York has more immigrants, more rich people and more poor people than almost any other place in the United States.
A lower percentage of the population is in the labor force -- working or looking for a job -- than in most other parts of the country, although the percentage has been rising. And people who are paid in cash may be reluctant to tell the Government that they are, indeed, employed.
The survey sometimes produces surprising results, as it did back in March, when the percentage of people who said they were looking for work but could not find a job dropped from 8.2 percent to 6 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Even after this information was fed through the bureau's computer program, it showed a drop of 1.2 percentage points, which is, as economists like to say, statistically significant.
"I didn't understand it, and I don't understand it to this day," said Vincent S. DeSantis, state economist for the New York State Department of Labor. That steep drop early in the spring is what makes the current rate look relatively high.
Like many other economists, Mr. DeSantis says he prefers to emphasize the job-creation numbers, which are based on a survey of employers and which can eventually be updated, using tax records, to reflect almost every employer in the city.
By those lights, New York City's economy looks fabulous. In the last 12 months, employers have added a net 78,200 new jobs, an increase of 2.2 percent.
Government employment has been shrinking, but the private sector has increased its work force by 2.7 percent, far higher than the 1.9 percent increase for all of New York State, said Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki.
But these figures, too, may not tell the whole story. Not all jobs in the city are held by city residents. About a quarter of new jobs, on average, go to commuters, said James Parrott, an economist at the Fiscal Policy Institute; on Wall Street, that figure rises to about 40 percent.
And while the number of jobs in the city has been rising, the number of city residents who say they have jobs has been growing far more slowly -- by just 1 percent in the last 12 months, according to the figures released yesterday.
Such figures are naturally of concern to city officials, whose goal is to have their citizens gainfully employed and paying taxes. But Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, cautions against reading too much into them.
And he should know. Two years ago, Mr. Bram wrote a paper trying to explain why, in mid-1997 as now, payrolls seemed to be growing so much faster than the number of people who said they had jobs. He found that after Government revisions to the data were taken into account, the trend was reversed.
Mr. Bram has since concluded that while the unemployment level is probably right, especially if several months are averaged together, the other information in the unemployment survey is unreliable. "Now," he said, "I just look at the data and chuckle."

HEADLINE: New Airline Gets Waivers For Flights to Upstate Cities

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A new airline promising low-cost fares to upstate New York received a Federal waiver today permitting it to fly out of Kennedy International Airport, moving it a step closer to takeoff in 2000.
Jetblue Airways was awarded 75 daily slots for takeoffs and landings at Kennedy, which is one of only a handful of airports subject to a high density rule restricting the number of arrivals and departures. With the waiver, Jetblue will use Kennedy as a base and fly to 30 cities during the next three years. 
 The airline has promised to fly to Buffalo, Syracuse and Rochester within its first 18 months in business with fares about 65 percent lower than current fares.
Upstate New York has been plagued with air fares that rank among the highest in the country, and critics say the high rates have crippled the region's economy. A ticket between Rochester and Albany, a distance of 200 miles, costs about $500, for instance.
The introduction of Jetblue is expected to remedy that by adding a low-fare carrier to a market with little competition. Supporters are hoping Jetblue will do for upstate New York what Southwest Airlines did for air fares in that region of the country.
"I feel like a proud uncle," Senator Charles E. Schumer said at a news conference today announcing the deal. Mr. Schumer had made lowering air fares in upstate New York one of his campaign promises last year.
"Jetblue will offer jet service on a regular basis at reasonable fares, and people will no longer be treated with the arrogance of a monopoly," Mr. Schumer said.
Jetblue's one-way rates from Kennedy to upstate New York cities are likely to be $39 to $99, said David Neelman, the airline's chief executive.
Jetblue will begin operation next year, and will serve 12 cities with 10 Airbus A-320's by the end of the first year. It plans a fleet of 82 jets.
Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater said the decision to grant the high number of exemptions was part of the Clinton Administration's effort to encourage "vigorous but fair competition" in the aviation industry.
Jetblue also needs Federal Aviation Administration certification, and will begin that process after it receives its first jet in December. It expects to start service in February, and has pledged that Buffalo, Rochester or Syracuse will be among the first cities served.
United States Representative Louise M. Slaughter, whose Rochester district is home to Fortune 500 companies like Xerox and Kodak but has the fourth highest air fares in the nation, said she would be fighting hard to see that Rochester is the first upstate destination.
"We will start incantations, burning candles, whatever we can do to make Rochester your first stop," Ms. Slaughter, a Democrat, said today.
Mr. Neelman said service to Albany was also being considered, but no decision had been reached.
Also pending in the House of Representatives is legislation sponsored by Representative John Sweeney, Republican of Rensselaer County, that would remove slot restrictions at Kennedy and the country's three other slot-controlled airports thatwould, in theory, spur more competition. Some people oppose the legislation because it would create additional airplane noise near Kennedy.
The House and Senate are set to seek an agreement on the legislation in conference this fall.
In addition to upstate New York, Jetblue is considering offering service to major destinations like Washington, Atlanta and Houston, as well as smaller markets like Charleston, W.Va., and Grand Rapids, Mich.

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler And Auto Union In Tentative Deal;
One U.A.W. Local Official Calls Deal 'a Great Package'

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Sept. 16

 BODY:
Paving the way for contracts covering the nation's 400,000 unionized auto workers, the United Automobile Workers union and DaimlerChrysler A.G. this morning reached tentative agreement on a four-year pact calling for a $1,350 signing bonus and pay increases of 3 percent a year on top of adjustments for inflation.
If workers ratify the deal later this month, as expected, they will also get heftier pension benefits and additional job security, even as the company is allowed to continue downsizing through attrition, according to local union officials. Under the current contract, auto workers have earned between $50,000 and $100,000 a year, depending on the amount of overtime they work and the level of corporate profits. 
 The four-year agreement is unusual because no auto labor contracts have lasted longer than three years since the 1950's. Had the new contract run for three years, it would have expired just as the union president was to retire, possibly amid contentious elections to choose his successor. This contract would provide raises of 3 percent for the first three years, plus a lump-sum payment in the fourth year of 3 percent of annual wages, according to union and company officials.
The raises come in addition to the inflation adjustments that have been a mainstay of the union's contracts with auto makers since 1948. In the current contract, that adjustment amounted to 90 percent of increases in the Consumer Price Index. So far this year, inflation is running at a 2.6 percent annual rate, which would trigger a 2.3 percent increase for auto workers. Workers would also get a share of corporate profits, as they have in past years.
The new agreement includes language prohibiting spinoffs of auto companies' parts units, local union officials said, and that could cause headaches for the Ford Motor Company, which plans to sell its Visteon auto parts unit, a move that would affect 23,500 union members.
U.A.W. national officials and company executives refused to disclose the details of the deal today, saying they wanted to first inform workers nationwide. Bargainers reached the deal after 48 hours of round-the-clock talks. "We have a lead company agreement," Frank Joyce, a union spokesman, announced about 8 A.M.. David Barnas, a DaimlerChrysler spokesman, declined to discuss the terms of the deal.
Because the union typically reaches a deal with one of the Big Three auto makers, then insists the others accept similar terms, the DaimlerChrysler pact is expected to lay out a pattern for the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor to follow in their contracts, which are being negotiated.
"The companies early on realized that with car sales at record levels and profits at record levels, they couldn't plead poverty," said David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities. "It is a generous contract."
Some local labor officials agreed. "We're pretty certain that it will be a pretty good deal for us," said Roger Brown, president of Local 550 in Indianapolis.
"It is a great package," said H. Scott Stanton, vice president of a Local 624 in Syracuse.
The language in the DaimlerChrysler contract covering spinoffs is a big concern for Ford, which is in the process of selling off Visteon, just as G.M. spun off its Delphi parts unit to investors earlier this year. Relations between Ford and the union, which for a decade have been the best in the industry, soured this year because of the company's plans to sell Visteon. That is one reason Ford is expected to be the last company to reach a deal on a new contract.
Ford executives said they did not know whether the agreement reached with DaimlerChrysler would make it more difficult for the company to divest the auto parts business. "We need to see the contract language before we can draw any conclusions," said Ed Miller, a Ford spokesman.
The deal reached today may result in similar pay raises for nonunion auto workers. Toyota Motor, Honda Motor, Nissan Motor and Mitsubishi Motors have in the past matched the Big Three's hourly pay rates.
And because of the auto industry's sheer size, the deal also has significance for many American workers, said labor experts, who noted the strength of the wage gains.
"It sends a strong message that if the economy is so good, workers should be sharing it a bit more," said Harley S. Shaiken, a labor professor at the University of California at Berkeley. "The high wages and the job security provisions promise a more motivated work force and a better relation with the union."
Mr. Shaiken, industry analysts and economists cautioned that their comments were based on an incomplete knowledge of the contract's contents.
Some economists said that the pay raises and heftier pension benefits might signal a trade with the union. The U.A.W. has been pressing the companies to replace retiring workers, but this contract allows faster downsizing by allowing the company to replace just one worker for every two who retire, according to local union officials. The current contracts require the companies to preserve 95 percent of existing jobs.
Nearly half the U.A.W. workers at the Big Three auto companies are eligible to retire within the next five years, the union says.
"For the nation's auto workers, it is a windfall," said Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago. "This is like the big buyouts that we've seen in the Fortune 500 for the past 20 years for white-collar workers."
The contract will allow the companies to build more cars with fewer workers, she said. "The U.A.W. got lucky that the auto makers are doing well enough to offer an olive branch of wage increases, but I'd be surprised if they stop the downsizing."
Wall Street is counting on continued downsizing. "The Street is right now presuming that G.M. will continue to ride the attrition wave," said Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The matter is most important for G.M. because it has been cutting its labor force while DaimlerChrysler's American factories have been hiring, and Ford's employment levels have been slowly falling since 1996.
Mr. Girsky called the deal "one of the richest contracts ever." He calculated that at 3 percent, three years of wage increases would cost G.M. another $2.26 billion in those years, or between $1.10 and $1.15 a share, assuming volume and productivity stayed the same. The lump-sum payment would cost G.M. approximately $375 million. Costs would be lower for Ford and DaimlerChrysler, perhaps 30 to 35 cents a share, Mr. Girsky estimated, because they have fewer workers. These numbers do not include adjustments for inflation.
The 1996 contract, which was extended on Tuesday, featured a $2,000 lump-sum payment in the first year and 3 percent raises in the next two years in addition to cost-of-living adjustments.
One sticking point in negotiations with DaimlerChrysler was a dispute over union organizing drives at a Mercedes sport utility factory in Vance, Ala., and at four factories building Freightliner trucks and components in North Carolina, South Carolina and Ontario, Canada.
The five nonunion factories were owned by Daimler before it bought Chrysler. The union received some reassurances that the company would stay neutral in the bargaining process, but details were unavailable today.
Around 8 A.M., the union president, Stephen P. Yokich, looking tired, gathered with his negotiators in DaimlerChrysler's parking lot here, and called them "a great team."
Asked whether they had popped champagne corks to celebrate reaching an agreement, Mr. Yokich shook his head. "Champagne? No. Some of us drank beer, some drank tea and some drank Diet Coke," Mr. Yokich said, as an empty Miller Beer can clattered to the concrete of the parking lot, having been dropped by one of his colleagues. One by one, members of his bargaining team gave him bear hugs and clapped him on the back, then got in their cars and drove away.
Mr. Yokich refused to characterize the talks, which seemed at several points over the last 20 hours to be nearly concluded. But he pooh-poohed the idea that the agreement had been close to final several times, but had been derailed by last-minute sticking points. "Close only counts in horseshoes, hand grenades and bocci balls," Mr. Yokich said.

-- Three percent raise, above inflation, in each of the first three years, 3 percent lump sum payment in the last year of contract. Average pay in 1998 was $70,000 for assemblers and $81,735 for skilled workers, including overtime and profit-sharing bonuses.
-- Four-year contract adds one year to traditional three-year contract.
-- $1,350 signing bonus.
-- More job security for senior workers.
-- Downsizing allowed through attrition.
-- Increased pension benefits.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Another Blast in Russia Highlights Vulnerability
An explosion tore apart an apartment complex in Volgodonsk, in the south of Russia, killing at least 18 people and injuring more than 200. The bombing was the fifth in Russia in less than three weeks and underscored how vulnerable Russia remains to terrorist attack, even with heightened security. A1 

Albright Defends Russian Aid
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright criticized Russia's leaders for failing to combat corruption, but defended the Clinton Administration's policy of supporting aid to Russia. A8
 
Schroder Blames Opposition
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said there was no alternative to proposed budget cuts meant to reshape Germany. In a speech to the Reichstag that amounted to an effort to shore up his political position after defeats for his party in three state elections, he blamed his Christian Democratic opponents for driving the country into debt. A5
 
NATO Assesses Kosovo Air War
Gen. Wesley K. Clark, NATO's Supreme Commander, offered evidence at a NATO press briefing to counter suggestions that the allied military command had exaggerated claims of damage to Serbian military and police forces in Kosovo. A10
 
200 Americans in Timor Force
President Clinton dispatched 200 troops to the East Timor peacekeeping mission to serve in intelligence, logistics, communication and transportation jobs, but not in combat units. Foreign troops, ships and planes converged on Darwin, Australia, as the international peacekeeping mission prepared to depart within days for East Timor. Soldiers from 11 countries will join 4,500 Australian troops. A6
 
Indonesia's military commander in East Timor promised that he would begin withdrawing his troops from the province next week, ending a long, bitter occupation and making way for the peacekeeping force. A6
 
Suicide Note Blames Mexico
A former Mexican justice official who apparently killed himself on Wednesday rather than face money-laundering charges in the United States blamed President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico for both the official's own death and the assassination of his brother in 1994. A10
 
Pro-Israeli Lebanese Sentenced
A military court in Lebanon sentenced 17 former militiamen of the South Lebanon Army to prison terms ranging from 1 to 18 months for collaborating with Israel, judicial officials said. The army, financed by Israel, aids its occupation of a border strip in southern Lebanon. (AP)
 
Treason Charges in Zanzibar
The authorities in anzibar have issued arrest warrants for 10 opposition leaders -- including a 1994 presidential candidate, Seif Shariff Hamad -- who they plan to try for treason, officials said. (AP)

Waning Storm Disrupts But Doesn't Devastate
Hurricane Floyd arrived as a tropical storm whose high winds and heavy rainfall closed schools and businesses, pounded beaches and flooded highways in the region. The tail of the storm was expected to leave the area by early today. A1
 
Subways withstood the storm with only scattered disruptions, but some regional systems faltered. B9

BYLINE: By Alan Cowell 

 BODY:
The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, forecast that British economic growth would reach 2.75 percent next year and 3.25 percent in 2001 in what he called a "virtuous cycle of low inflation, high investment and high and stable levels of growth." Addressing the Council for Foreign Relations in New York, Mr. Brown said he had supported the quarter-point interest rate increase by the Bank of England last week. Alan Cowell

HEADLINE: Clinton Given Bill for Raise For Congress And President

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Congress today passed and sent to President Clinton a spending bill that will increase its members' salaries, as well as those of Federal workers and the next President.
The measure contains a $4,600 raise for members of Congress, increasing their annual incomes to $141,300 a year, a 3.4 percent raise. The sum is about twice the average lawyer's income and roughly five times what the average American wage earner makes. 
 Mr. Clinton is expected to sign the measure, which would increase Congressional salaries in January. It would be the third increase Congress has given itself in seven years. Lawmakers voted themselves a raise in January 1998 and in January 1993.
Though conservative lawmakers have opposed raises, Federal law grants members of Congress an annual salary increase unless the members vote to block it, which they chose to do from 1994 until 1998.
Government workers would receive pay increases next year averaging 4.8 percent, which would be their biggest increase in pay in 18 years. The bill would also double the salary paid the President to $400,000 in January 2001, when Mr. Clinton's successor will be sworn in. That would be the first pay increase for a President in 32 years.
If the $200,000 salary paid back then to President Richard M. Nixon had been adjusted for inflation, it would now be nearly $900,000. That salary would be about average for a chief executive of one of the nation's 200 largest corporations.
The salaries of Federal judges are usually linked of those paid to lawmakers. But a House-Senate conference will have to add an increase if judges are to keep pace with Congress next year.
Also today, the Senate voted 95 to 0 for a $49.5 billion transportation bill that increases spending for roads, mass transit and airports. The House has passed a $50.7 billion measure, and the two bills must now be reconciled in a House-Senate conference.
The spending bill Congress completed and sent to Mr. Clinton today, a measure financing the Treasury Department and several smaller agencies, is only the third of 13 annual spending bills Congress has completed this year. A fourth, financing the District of Columbia, was finished late Thursday.
Hope is evaporating for Congress's finishing on time its only required task: spending the Government's money. Eight working days remain for Congress until the 2000 fiscal year begins on Oct. 1. "There are lots of obstacles ahead," said Representative C. W. Bill Young, the Florida Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee.
The obstacles include the Republican leadership, which has been unable to agree on a strategy to pass this year's spending bills.
Spending caps imposed by Congress have left the bills about $30 billion shy of what many members think will be needed to finance favorite programs, win passage and send the bills to the President.
Republican leaders are considering measures like charging billions of dollars in emergency agriculture aid that would be spent in the fiscal year 2000 against the previous year's books and delaying billions of dollars in Medicaid payments due to the states in September 2000, thus charging them against the fiscal year 2001.
In both cases, no money would be saved, but the spending would not be counted in the coming fiscal year.
If the new fiscal year begins on Oct. 1 without spending bills signed into law, the Government must operate on stop-gap bills called continuing resolutions. That is a fragile architecture, and if it breaks down in political disarray, a repeat of the Government shutdown of 1995 is possible.
The biggest and most complicated spending bills are in limbo. The measure financing labor, health and human services has been drained of billions of dollars to finance other spending bills, and it has not even been written, much less debated. Congressional aides said it was increasingly likely that the measure would never be completed but instead rolled into an omnibus spending bill that could be passed in October or November.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Red Tape vs. Green Cash: Making an Economy Thrive

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
John Stossel comes out tomorrow night fervently in favor of capitalism American style. Abetted by conservative theorists, he argues in "Is America No. 1?" that it's freedom that makes countries rich and government red tape that keeps them poor.
For his prime examples, he contrasts the vibrant economy of Hong Kong with sluggish India, where he finds himself beset by beggars every time he leaves his Calcutta hotel. The key to Hong Kong's prosperity, says Milton Friedman, the Nobel-winning economist, is leaving business alone. Enterprising businessmen in the former British colony report that unhampered by regulations, they are allowed to go forth and make money. 
 To prove his point, Mr. Stossel tells us he started his own business selling Frisbees and yo-yos. Well, he half proved it. It turned out to be easy for him to go into business, but hard for him to sell any Frisbees.
In India by contrast, it took Kentucky Fried Chicken months of political debate before it could get permission to peddle its fowl. Aspiring Indian entrepreneurs get lost in a regulatory rigmarole supposedly concocted for the public benefit. As Mr. Friedman puts the situation, "There is nothing that does so much harm as good intentions." Dinesh D'Souza of the American Enterprise Institute says that the Indian people owe their "vacant look" to poverty induced by Government interference.
If this line of argument seems a bit simple and doctrinaire, Mr. Stossel has no apologies. Turning homeward, he says that freedom is at the root of America's success story, too (even though the United States is overregulated compared with Hong Kong and nobody is lining up for the Stossel Frisbee). He draws his evidence from immigrants who were held back in France or Germany or Sweden or Jamaica and made fortunes as soon as they were on these liberated shores. "America today is just a great place to be," one prosperous immigrant announces.
Although the program, at Channel 7 at 9 P.M., overdoes the cheerleading, it does serve as a corrective to more customary television whining. Mr. Stossel grants that America may have its drawbacks -- pollution, racism, poverty, decadence -- but he finds that its record is good even where things seem bad. On a visit to the South Bronx, he discovers that people lining up for handouts have apartments with color television sets, microwave ovens and all the usual amenities. They aren't in line because they have been going without food, he asserts: "They come because the food is free."
Mr. D'Souza sums up by citing "one objective measure" for judging whether countries work well: "Do people want to come there?" To which Mr. Stossel cries amen: "And by that measure, America wins hands down." Having selected his evidence and his experts, our guide declares victory.

HEADLINE: Students Seek Some Reality Amid the Math Of Economics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
On my first day as a graduate student in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the professor introduced the discipline by intoning, "All of economics is a subset of the theory of separating hyperplanes." (You don't want to know what that mathematical term means.)
I started to giggle. But then I looked around. Everyone else was scribbling notes. So I wiped the smirk off my face and muttered, only to myself, that I had thought economics was about the plight of people living in sub-Saharan Africa or the impact of technological change on living standards. Apparently I thought wrong -- and wondered whether I had made a terrible career choice. 
 Decades later, I find economics graduate students asking themselves the same question: where is the economic substance in graduate economics programs? I recently joined several dozen first- and second-year students at a conference in Airlie, Va., that was convened to help them find their way toward applied economics -- analyzing problems that real people face. During the weeklong conference, organized by the Social Science Research Council and paid for by the John D. and Catherine T. McArthur Foundation, eminent scholars presented lectures on applied topics ranging from the plight of low-income mothers under the 1996 welfare law to the long-term determinants of innovation.
To noneconomists, these lectures would no doubt appear heavily theoretical, laced with mathematical and statistical derivations. But at least since the writings of Paul Samuelson, Nobel laureate from M.I.T., in the 1940's, economists have used large doses of mathematics to create insight and clarity.
The difference at Airlie was that the object of the lectures was to improve understanding of the relationships among people rather than among mathematical symbols. After the lectures students met in small groups to pose follow-up questions and design research strategies. The idea was to motivate them to do applied work and give them a head start in developing an applied focus for their Ph.D. theses.
David Weiman, the former director of the council's program and now at the Russell Sage Foundation, hopes that the summer conference and research grants that the council provides can offset what he sees as a lamentable tendency among young graduate students. Too often, he says, they allow mathematical technique to dictate the questions they ask rather than first seizing a pressing social question from which the choice of appropriate technique would then follow. Graduate programs, he says, "emphasize teaching students how to prove theorems, misleading them into thinking that economics is a deductive exercise, the mere application of mathematical logic."
Prof. Alan Blinder of Princeton University considers it damning to some of the country's most prestigious graduate programs that their students need to flock to summer camp to find an outlet for their interest in applied work. Mr. Blinder, a former member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers and a driving force behind the council's efforts to promote applied economics, said in a recent interview that too much of what young scholars write these days is "theoretical drivel, mathematically elegant but not about anything real." He attributes the problem in part to the first year of training, or what he calls mathematics boot camp, during which students are handed a steady diet of theory but not taught to connect it to the real world. They soon forget the issues that attracted them to economics.
Mr. Blinder makes an important distinction. He remains scrupulously agnostic over whether graduate training is overly theoretical. "That's a tough issue." But he is unwavering when he criticizes the training as "increasingly aloof and self-referential."
Indeed, the students at Airlie seemed surprisingly unfamiliar with many current economic issues. Chatting at lunch with a half-dozen of so of the graduate students, one of the guest lecturers referred to the earned-income tax credit as the E.I.T.C., the country's most successful anti-poverty program next to Social Security. "What's that," one student asked. Nor could many of the students distinguish Medicare from Medicaid or demonstrate familiarity with simple facts about the American economy. They had studied the theory of financial markets, but not its connection to the crisis sweeping through Asia.
Many of these students admitted that they do not read newspapers. Nor do many see much of a connection between knowledge of economic reality or Government policies and their chosen course of study.
Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution lectured the group about the economic factors that determine when people decide to retire. I joined a half-dozen students in their follow-up session. The students were asked what interesting questions Mr. Burtless's lecture provoked. After a slightly awkward silence, one student launched into the speculation that the group could develop a "two-sector general equilibrium model" that could be tweaked in this or that direction. When the students were asked again to pose questions, not design models, the conversation drifted once more toward mathematical modeling.
So has graduate economics training run off the rails? There is another side. Economics professors and graduates from the very schools -- Michigan, M.I.T, Columbia, Stanford, Wisconsin, Harvard, Colorado, University of Pennsylvania, New York University -- that supplied students for the conference do a great deal of excellent applied work. Compared with 20 or even 10 years ago, there has been an explosion in the number of academics who are consultants to think tanks for policy analysis, corporations and Government agencies.
Franklin Fisher of M.I.T. is the Justice Department's chief economist in the Microsoft antitrust trial; his colleague, Richard Schmalensee, is Microsoft's chief economist. Harvard's Lawrence H. Summers is Secretary of the Treasury; Stanford's Joseph Stiglitz is senior vice president of the World Bank; M.I.T.'s Stanley Fischer is deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Harvard's Lawrence F. Katz and Princeton's Alan Krueger designed labor-force policies for the Clinton Administration. Harvard's David Ellwood designed President Clinton's original welfare proposal.
Research economists at the influential think tanks and nonprofit research organizations, like the Brookings Institution and the American Enterprise Institute, were trained at many of the same graduate programs feeding students to the council's summer conference. The National Bureau of Economic Research, led by Prof. Martin Feldstein of Harvard, turns out hundreds of papers each year on applied topics by some of the nation's best academic economists.
Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard and a prolific author of reports for the bureau, says that "applied economics is perfectly healthy and fine, at least at the better graduate programs." Her point is that students at the major Ph.D. programs do not have to look very far to find faculty heavily involved in applied research to serve as role models and advisers. But Ms. Goldin does echo part of Mr. Blinder's anxiety that the first year of courses can be relentlessly abstract, creating at least a temporary barrier to those who started out thinking they want something applied.
Then perhaps economics has stumbled onto an unwittingly workable life-cycle for many academics. During the first couple of years of training, professors pile on a formidable amount of abstract theory at the only time that students can study uninterrupted at the feet of their masters. But, Mr. Blinder observes, as professors age, they turn increasingly to applied subjects. Though graduate programs make it hard for students to follow applied interests early on, many eventually find their way.
Even so, problems remain. Many of the students at Airlie complained that their Ph.D. programs provided few clues on how to do applied research and even less encouragement. That, Mr. Blinder says, may contribute to a gnawing anxiety, pinpointed in 1991 by a commission appointed by the American Economic Association, that Ph.D. programs are not attracting their share of the brightest undergraduates. The increasingly sterile nature of early courses may be driving many undergraduates to other disciplines. Mr. Weiman's and Mr. Blinder's goal is to shorten the time it takes graduate students to tackle the applied problems that captivated them as undergraduates.
Neither Mr. Blinder nor Mr. Weiman are calling for wholesale change in graduate training. Economics is heavily mathematical and usefully so. The most ambitious Ph.D. programs are teaching students how to make theoretical breakthroughs. No one wants theorists like Paul Samuelson to be teaching welfare policy rather than the mathematics of a hanging string. But early training may have evolved to a dysfunctional extreme. Prof. Lawrence J. White of the Stern School of Business at New York University observes, "It's ironic that economists, who make their living telling everyone else what's efficient, can't figure out whether their own educational process is efficient."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Firm Has Control of Korea First Bank

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
After 10 months of tortuous off-again, on-again negotiations, the Government of South Korea signed a binding agreement tonight to sell a controlling stake in Korea First Bank to Newbridge Capital Ltd., a United States-based investment firm.
The sale marks the first time that foreigners have attained control of a South Korean bank. 
 Newbridge, backed by the investors Richard C. Blum and David Bonderman, has agreed to pay 500 billion won, or about $417 million, for a 51 percent stake and total management control of Korea First, one of South Korea's oldest and biggest banks.
Korea First is one of two banks nationalized after a $58 billion bailout of the South Korean economy by the International Monetary Fund in 1998.
The Government will take on all nonperforming loans and add to the bank's reserves should its existing reserves fail to meet new accounting standards. It has also agreed to take on loans that go bad over the next few years.
"This was a phenomenal opportunity to buy a terrific franchise in a great economy, all of which says it should work out very well," said Dan Carroll, a managing director at Newbridge.
The deal is further evidence that South Korea intends to carry through with the sweeping changes in its economic landscape that President Kim Dae Jung promised in the aftermath of the country's financial crisis, albeit not without some fits and starts.
After the Government's decision in July to force a wrenching overhaul at Daewoo Group, one of South Korea's biggest, most troubled and most recalcitrant business conglomerates, the sale of Korea First looks like another step toward integrating South Korea into the global marketplace.
"This is a testament to President Kim's commitment to reform the financial sector, in fact, a showcase for it," said Hyun Hong Choo, a lawyer and former politician.
The deal, which is binding but still requires further negotiation and documentation, has encountered numerous delays. Signed in the waning hours of last New Year's Eve to meet a pledge made to the I.M.F., the transaction was to have been completed by March 31, then by the end of April, then by the end of May, after which the Government stopped setting targets.
One reason for the delay was the lack of negotiators representing the Government. Lee Jun Hai, the chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, basically conducted all the negotiations himself in addition to handling his many other duties as head of South Korea's financial watchdog.
The deal was also delayed by bureaucratic stalling, political wrangling and South Korea's strong economic recovery.
But the near-collapse of Daewoo and the questions it raised about the effectiveness of economic reforms in South Korea appear to have shaken the Government's confidence. When a deal to sell Seoul Bank, the other nationalized bank, to HSBC Holdings fell through last month, it put pressure on the commission to complete the deal with Newbridge or face international criticism for its failure to let foreign capital and expertise help revitalize the banking system.
In addition, keeping the bank on life support was proving costly. The Government poured $3.5 billion of taxpayer money into Korea First during the negotiations.
Newbridge becomes the fourth international investor in the Korean financial system and the biggest. Commerz Bank A.G. of Germany owns 30.4 percent of the Korea Exchange Bank, and Goldman, Sachs & Company has a 17 percent stake in Kookmin Bank, a major retail bank. ING Groep N.V., the sprawling Dutch financial services company, has a 10 percent stake in the Housing and Commercial Bank.

HEADLINE: Greenspan on Year 2000

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that a risk of bottlenecks in the economy might result from fear of Year 2000 computer problems, but that major catastrophes were unlikely. At a gathering of the President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion, he called the chance of big disruptions to critical business infrastructure "negligible." He said the major challenge for policy makers was calming the worries of business and households. Inventory building by businesses could add to economic growth and inflation risks while a widespread technical breakdown and public panic might undermine the economy.

HEADLINE: Ford Facing Unrest in U.S. And Canada

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 17

 BODY:
After enjoying the best labor relations in the auto industry for a generation, the Ford Motor Company is likely to face a strike next week in Canada and heavy pressure in the United States from the United Automobile Workers union.
Auto labor leaders on both sides of the border have been emboldened by the rich contract that the U.A.W. tentatively reached on Thursday with DaimlerChrysler A.G. The four-year contract revived a practice from the union's glory days of the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's by calling for annual wage increases of 3 percent in addition to cost-of-living adjustments that almost match the rate of inflation. 
 Under the leadership of an aggressive new chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser, Ford is trying to cut costs. It is also trying to spin off its giant parts division, Visteon Automotive Systems, to match the General Motors Corporation's spinoff in May of its auto parts unit.
But the U.A.W. is resisting the Visteon sale, and the Canadian Auto Workers union contends that Ford's record profits should produce substantial increases in wages. That raises the possibility that Ford might face the same kind of one-two punch that hurt G.M. in 1996, when the Canadian workers staged a three-week strike and the United States union followed with four-day walkouts at G.M.'s most profitable factories. Though a strike against Ford in the United States is far from certain, the new, hard-line leadership of the U.A.W.'s Ford division could yet force a showdown, union officials said.
Ford made its initial bargaining offer to the Canadian union today on wages and other financial issues, and it provoked a furious reaction from Basil Hargrove, the union president. Mr. Hargrove called the offer too low even to negotiate and repeated his union's threat to go on strike when the current three-year contract expires at 11:59 P.M. on Tuesday. "Given where we are today," he added, "I think the odds are one in a thousand we can have a settlement by Tuesday."
The Canadian union almost always calls a strike against the first company with which it holds labor talks, and this year it is Ford's turn to go first. Canadian labor laws prevent the union from staging strikes while a contract is in force, whereas the U.A.W. can call factory-level strikes at any time simply by saying that there are health or safety violations.
Canadian union leaders were particularly unhappy today with the terms of Ford's initial offer, copies of which they made public and were confirmed by the company. The offer called for a wage increase of 1 percent in each of the three years of the contract in addition to annual cost-of-living increases, plus a $500 bonus in the first year of the contract.
Prepared before the DaimlerChrysler settlement on Thursday, the offer looked stingy by comparison. The DaimlerChrysler contract included a $1,350 bonus in the first year as well as four 3 percent wage increases, according to people familiar with the agreement. They denied initial reports that the contract only called for a lump sum payment of 3 percent in the fourth year, saying that a last-minute change during the negotiations had resulted in wage increases in all four years.
By comparison, the contract over the last three years called for a $2,000 bonus in the first year with no wage increase other than the cost-of-living adjustment, followed by 3 percent wage increases and the cost-of-living adjustment in the second and third years. Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said the DaimlerChrysler contract was a little better than the previous contract but would not affect inflation in the United States because few private-sector workers are unionized these days.
The DaimlerChrysler contract is subject to a vote by workers next week, and is expected to win ratification easily.
The U.A.W. did not win all of its battles in the DaimlerChrysler negotiations. The company agreed to stay neutral in the union's struggle to organize workers at the Mercedes sport utility vehicle factory in Vance, Ala. But the company insisted that workers hold a secret ballot to decide whether to unionize, rather than allow the U.A.W. to gather the signatures of half of the workers, which would have been an easier task, people familiar with the labor contract said.
The U.A.W. traditionally takes the wages and benefits provisions of a national contract like DaimlerChrysler's and insists that the other unionized auto makers accept the same terms. Some union officials said on Thursday that the DaimlerChrysler contract also had a provision prohibiting the spin-off of business units. If the U.A.W. was to demand that Ford accept a provision barring the spin-off of Visteon, a nasty battle could ensue.
It was unclear today what the provision said. Provisions barring spinoffs at other auto makers in the past have been in side letters of agreement, not in the actual labor contracts, and have not been applied across the entire industry.
The U.A.W. has been holding intensive talks with G.M. all this week, while leaving Ford for last. Mr. Hargrove said this was not part of a strategy to use Canadian workers to soften up Ford with a strike because his union does not represent any Visteon workers and so will not negotiate a contract affecting them.
A Canadian strike would shut down Ford's production of Windstar minivans, the Ford Crown Victoria and the Mercury Grand Marquis full-sized sedans and one of Ford's pickup truck factories. It also could eventually stop production of engine parts for most of Ford's factories in the United States.
In the United States, Ford faces an emotional struggle by workers at its Visteon division, most of whom have worked for Ford Motor and the Ford family all their lives and some of whom are third- and even fourth-generation Ford workers. Roughly 1,000 Visteon workers and their family members joined Detroit's Labor Day parade this year, wearing black shirts and waving signs calling for Ford not to spin off or sell the unit.
William Clay Ford Jr., a great-grandson of Henry Ford and now the nonexecutive chairman of the company, once ran what is now Visteon's car heaters and air conditioners unit. He even had an office at the factory in Plymouth, Mich., that produces these parts and that has become the focal point for resistance to a spin-off.
Roger D. Caldwell, the president of the U.A.W. local unit at the factory, said spinning off the Visteon factories would betray the traditions of the Ford family and the company. "The whole background and culture is that this has been a family company, and proud of it," he said today.
But if Ford does not spin off Visteon, it could put itself at a lasting competitive disadvantage. Though auto makers pay all assembly and parts workers high, equal wages, independent auto parts companies, even those that are unionized, pay much less. Chrysler sold most of its auto parts factories in the early 1980's, and now G.M. has disposed of its parts business, although the business has agreed to continue paying G.M.-level wages at first.
One possible settlement would be for Visteon to become independent but agree to continue paying the same wages and benefits as Ford. The Internet site for Mr. Caldwell's local union says such a plan might prevent a national strike. But Mr. Caldwell said he would not be satisfied with anything less than Visteon's remaining part of Ford.

HEADLINE: New-Home Starts Rise, Despite Higher Mortgages

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments rose four-tenths of a percent in August, leaving analysts marveling at the continued strength in housing despite rising mortgage rates.
The Commerce Department reported today that construction climbed to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.68 million units last month, led by another big rise in apartment building. 
 Many analysts had been expecting a 2 percent decline in housing starts because of the higher mortgage rates. Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages hit a high of 8.15 percent in mid-August, their highest point in more than two years. Rates have since eased to 7.82 percent, according to this week's Freddie Mac survey, still above the 6.79 percent at the start of the year.
Many economists, noting that the slowdown they have been forecasting for some months has yet to occur, said they were revising their housing forecasts upward.
"It would be foolish to characterize the housing market as anything but still going flat out," said David Orr, chief economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders, said that the rising lending rates had failed to dampen demand because the overall economy was performing better than expected, with unemployment in August at a 29-year low of 4.2 percent.
"Incomes and employment have at least as much effect on housing as mortgage rates, and they are doing better than expected," he said.
Still, analysts detected some hints that rising mortgage rates were beginning to dampen demand a bit. Construction starts on single-family homes fell in August by 1.3 percent.

HEADLINE: DEATH IN A CHURCH: THE KILLER;
A Troubled Man Went Free, As Long as None Were Hurt

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Anybody who had been around Larry Ashbrook could tell that the man had problems.
Neighbors say he would lie flat on the roof of his house, hiding behind a chimney, as if he were conducting surveillance. He sent rambling letters to The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, telling of strange encounters with the Central Intelligence Agency. And he was described as a paranoid schizophrenic by his brother, Aaron Ashbrook, in a call to the Wise County Sheriff's Department in July. 
 But the life of this emotionally troubled loner, who opened fire in the Wedgwood Baptist Church here on Wednesday, killing seven people before killing himself, demonstrates how little can be done in such a case before something terrible happens.
"It's kind of tricky because we can't force people to have treatment," said Shelley Buttgen, a spokeswoman for the Mental Health-Mental Retardation agency in Tarrant County. "When someone is acting strange, you can't just run right out and throw them in a hospital."
Capt. Harold Denney of the Wise County Sheriff's Department said a deputy was sent to the home of Aaron Ashbrook, who lives in Wise County, north of Fort Worth, after the call about Larry Ashbrook's mental condition.
"His brother called and said their father had just died, and he was worried he was going to come to the house and cause trouble," Captain Denney said. "So a deputy went out, stayed about an hour, and the guy never showed up. So the deputy went off duty. And that was the end of it."
Captain Denney said his department did not take any further action because no law had been broken.
"There's not a whole lot you can do," he said. "Unless the guy's done something, you let it go."
The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, where Mr. Ashbrook sent two long, bizarre letters this summer, did not alert the authorities because Mr. Ashbrook had not made any threats. It did not publish the letters, and Mr. Ashbrook subsequently came to the newspaper's office to ask why they had not been published but he did not act hostile, officials at the paper said.
"We get letters all the time that don't make any sense," said Bob Ray Sanders, a vice president and associate editor of The Star-Telegram. "You think he's a little off, but what do you do?"
In his letters, Mr. Ashbrook wrote of "being targeted by some investigative group," and told of going to the Fort Worth office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. "An agent, I will not list his name here, invited me to sit in his office and he would hear what I had to say," Mr. Ashbrook wrote. "The problem, though, is that he listened for about one minute, then stood up and told me that I would be contacted."
Marjorie Poche, a special agent for the F.B.I. in Dallas, said that there was no record of Mr. Ashbrook's visit but that it would not likely have been logged anyway. She said many emotionally disturbed people visit the bureau's offices.
"They bring in pages and pages of writings, with words scrawled up and down the sides of the paper," she said. "It's so common, much more common than most people realize."
"You listen, apologize, and send them on their way," she continued. "Who would you call? The local hospital? For us to do anything, they would have to show they are a danger."
Social service agencies in Texas, especially those dealing with people who are mentally ill, struggle to reconcile their vast workloads with their lean budgets.
In Tarrant County alone, the mental health agency saw more than 13,000 people with emotional or psychological disturbances last year, Ms. Buttgen said.
Texas spends less on mental health services, per person, than any other state, said Bernard Weinstein, a professor at the University of North Texas in Denton.
"Part of the Texas ethos is that government is not going to solve your problems," said Mr. Weinstein, an economics professor who has written about the state's low level of spending on social services. "But holes have opened in the safety net."
Professor Weinstein said a lack of mental health services could be especially troublesome in a state where guns were so plentiful. Texas has 80 million guns, he said, four times the state's population.
While there is no record of Mr. Ashbrook's being seen at public mental health centers, it is possible that he had been counseled in private practice. A search of his home turned up no medications for mental illness.
Mr. Ashbrook's sister, Elizabeth Gentry, is a marriage and family counselor living in Austin, Tex., but it is not clear whether she talked to her brother about his troubles. The family could not be reached for comment.
Neighbors of Mr. Ashbrook related a litany of his bizarre behavior. Some teen-agers said he was known as "Crazy Larry."
Mabel Arfman, a 74-year-old retired secretary, said Mr. Ashbrook "seemed to be out of step with everybody." She would watch him circle the block in his father's car, and worry about him.
She wished there was a way to help, but did not know how. "As long as he didn't hurt anybody, we ignored it," she said.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Falls to 2.1% in Connecticut, Lowest in Nation

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in Connecticut has fallen to 2.1 percent, the lowest level in the nation and the lowest for the state in more than 20 years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
"Basically, anyone that wants to find work is finding a job," said Salvatore DiPillo, labor statistics supervisor for the Connecticut Department of Labor. 
 Nationally, the jobless rate, which measures the percentage of the labor force that is actively looking for work, remained at 4.2 percent in August; in New York State, the rate is 5.1 percent.
When Connecticut's unemployment rate fell sharply in July, to 2.6 percent from 3.4 percent, economists suggested that it might be a fluke. The unemployment rate calculations are based on a survey of fewer than 600 households.
But now that there has been a second month with a steep decline, economy-watchers are starting to say that the figures may reflect the real world.
"It's hard to believe it could be 2.1 percent, because that's a World War II number, when everybody was in a full-court press," said William McEachern, a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. But, he added, "a low unemployment number is consistent with everything we have seen in the economy."
Employers in the state, having difficulty finding enough employees, are trying new strategies to find workers. While the number of jobs in the state has been growing, Connecticut's labor force has been shrinking, according to data released yesterday.
"Companies are no longer waiting for openings to occur before they look for people," said Wendy Alfus Rothman, managing partner of Advantage Human Resourcing in Stamford. In addition to recruiting almost continuously, she said, employers are also talking to a wider variety of people, including older workers, those who have been out of the work force for a while and those who want to work from home.
On Wednesday, a state-sponsored job fair in Hartford attracted a record 120 would-be employers, said John Tirinzonie, who runs the job fairs for the State Department of Labor. More than 1,300 job seekers showed up -- but a survey of them suggest that at least half already had jobs.
In fact, the state is willing to help find jobs for out-of-state workers because employers are so needy.
Later this month, it will sponsor a job fair in Danbury that is cosponsored by the Chamber of Commerce in nearby Brewster, N.Y., Mr. Tirinzonie said. "Danbury has the bigger companies and the jobs, while New York tends to have the work force," he said.
Though the rock-bottom unemployment rate in Connecticut has revived fears that inflation will reignite, so far there is little evidence of sharp rises in either workers' wages or consumer prices.
Nor does the low unemployment rate seem to be discouraging companies from staying in -- or moving to -- Connecticut, local officials said.
In the year ended in June, 29 companies moved to Stamford, where the unemployment rate is 1.2 percent, said Joseph McGee, vice president of Sacia, which is the business council of southwest Connecticut. That number is not significantly below the recent average of 30 to 35 new corporate arrivals a year, Mr. McGee said, although he said the recent newcomers have been somewhat smaller than in the past.
But in the long run, such a low unemployment rate can eliminate a state from consideration when a company is thinking of moving or expanding.
"Among all the factors that a company uses to determine an area's suitability, the availability of a plentiful work force is at the top of the list," said Rob DeRocker, senior vice president of Development Counselors International, a consulting concern. "Nothing else is even close."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Covered Cost of Ads Backing It in Antitrust Suit

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Newspaper advertisements that a California institute presented as independent views supporting the Microsoft Corporation's position in its antitrust trial were actually paid for by Microsoft, the institute said today.
The full-page newspaper ads, published in The New York Times and The Washington Post by the Independent Institute last June, were in the form of a letter signed by 240 academic experts. They prompted news stories and courtroom discussion during the trial. 
 The academics were not told that Microsoft was paying for the ads, and at least one now says he would not have signed if he had known the source of the financing.
Greg Shaw, a public relations manager for Microsoft, tonight confirmed that the company had paid for the ads. "We thought this was an important, substantive letter, and we were interested in contributing to making it visible," he said. "In our view, the letter speaks for itself."
During the yearlong public relations war that has been fought in parallel with the antitrust trial, a dozen or more institutes and lobbying organizations have weighed in with advertisements, reports, news conferences or books that offer strong opinions on one side of the case or the other.
Many of the organizations have acknowledged that they were financed by Microsoft, or by its rivals. But the Independent Institute made an extraordinary effort to portray itself as beholden to no one. The institute, based in Oakland, Calif., has written papers and offered opinions on a broad range of political, social, business and foreign policy issues over the 14 years of its existence. Throughout the trial, it has often taken Microsoft's side.
According to its literature, the institute "adheres to the highest standards of independent scholarly inquiry." Its president, David Theroux, describes himself as a scrupulously disinterested academic and adds: "We are not doing contract work. We're independent. Our intention is to do work that holds up to any type of scrutiny."
But internal institute documents show that Microsoft has secretly served as the institute's largest outside financial benefactor in the last year. The documents were provided by a Microsoft adversary associated with the computer industry who refused to be further identified.
Microsoft has mounted an elaborate public relations campaign as part of its trial strategy, to influence public opinion and, perhaps, the trial judge. Much of it is open and above board, but today's admission by the institute suggests that an important part is intended to be secret.
On June 2, the day the antitrust trial resumed for its final month of testimony after a three-month break, the institute ran full-page ads in The New York Times and The Washington Post signed by 240 academics who were said to support the view that antitrust prosecution was harmful to consumers -- a key argument Microsoft was making in court. Complemented by a heavily promoted news conference in Washington, the effort received enough attention that David Boies, the Government's lead lawyer in the antitrust suit, referred to it in court on June 3.
Last month, the institute published a book titled "Winners, Losers and Microsoft: Competition and Antitrust in High Technology." The book argued that Microsoft had succeeded in dominating the software industry principally because it makes superior products -- another often-voiced theme of Microsoft's trial defense. The company's economic witness at the trial, Richard J. Schmalensee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, cited the book as a source for an important assertion in his direct testimony.
Mr. Theroux has long acknowledged that Microsoft is a dues-paying member of his group, a point that is usually made in news articles about the institute. But he has insisted all along that Microsoft is "just one of 2,000 members" and as such pays a membership fee of roughly $10,000 a year -- an inconsequential part of the organization's overall budget that gives the company no special standing. All Microsoft gets for that, he said, is "free copies of our publications, discounted tickets to our events."
He has also maintained that Microsoft had nothing to do with the newspaper advertisements. The ads, he said in the interview, "were paid for out of our general funds."
His letter to economists soliciting participation made no mention of Microsoft.
But, in fact, among the institute's internal documents is a bill Mr. Theroux sent to John A. C. Kelly of Microsoft for the full costs of the ads, plus his travel expenses from San Francisco to Washington for the news conference, totaling $153,868.67. Included was a $5,966 bill for airline tickets for himself and a colleague. Unfortunately, he wrote Mr. Kelly, "the airlines were heavily booked" and "we had to fly first class to D.C. and business class on the return."
Asked this evening about that bill, Mr. Theroux acknowledged that Microsoft had paid for the ad but said it made no difference. "The academic process we use is independent of sources of revenue."
At least one academic who signed the ad disagreed.
"He should have told us," Simon Hakim, an economist at Temple University, said today when told of the financing. "I would not have participated if I had known. It's not right to use people as a vehicle for special interests."
On the other hand, Stan J. Liebowitz, a professor of economics at the University of Texas at Dallas who was one of the authors of the "Winners, Losers and Microsoft" book, said that he, too, had been unaware of the Microsoft payments, but added, "it doesn't matter to me."
Also among the institute's internal documents was an accounting of 337 contributions the institute received for the fiscal year that ended June 30. Mr. Theroux said those donations accounted for 60 percent or 70 percent of the institute's overall budget.
The accounting sheets show that Microsoft contributed significantly more than $10,000 last year -- $203,217, in all, the most from any outside individual or organization and about 20 percent of the total outside contributions for the period. (Not counted in that tally was $304,725 that Mr. Theroux contributed to his own foundation.)

Nasdaq Composite Up 2.2% As U.S. Dollar Strengthens
Stocks rose, led by the Nasdaq composite index, which jumped 62.90 points, or 2.24 percent, to 2,869.62. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 66.17 points, to 10,803.63, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 16.94 points, or 1.28 percent, to 1,335.42. 
 The markets benefited from the rising dollar in foreign-exchange markets, which makes dollar-denominated investments more attractive to foreign investors. The dollar closed at 106.86 Japanese yen in late trading. Page C3.

Newspaper advertisements that a California institute presented as independent views supporting Microsoft's position in its antitrust trial were actually paid for by Microsoft, the institute has conceded. A1.

President Clinton ordered a far-reaching easing of economic sanctions against North Korea, as the first step in a plan to induce it to abandon certain nuclear programs. North Korea will now be allowed to buy consumer goods from the U.S. and to transport cargo and passengers back and forth from the U.S. A1.

The Commerce Department reported that construction climbed to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.68 million units last month. Many analysts had been expecting a 2 percent decline in housing starts because of the higher mortgage rates. C14.
