HEADLINE: Plan to Strengthen Colombia Nudges U.S. for $3.5 Billion

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Responding to concern in the United States about surging drug production and guerrilla activity here, the Colombian Government today unveiled a plan for "peace, prosperity and strengthening the state" that calls for $3.5 billion in assistance from the United States and other allies during the next three years.
Aides to President Andres Pastrana, who is scheduled to leave on Saturday for a visit to the United States, said he intended to discuss the proposal with President Clinton when the two meet in New York City early next week. 
 They said that later in Washington he also planned to lobby Congress on behalf of the plan, which includes diplomatic initiatives and trade liberalization measures as well as requests for a dramatic increase in American aid.
In a meeting this afternoon with a group of foreign reporters, Jaime Ruiz, Mr. Pastrana's closest aide and an architect of the proposal, said that "a bit more than half" of the money budgeted is intended for "strengthening and restructuring of the army" or combatting drug trafficking. Colombia's two main left-wing guerrilla groups have been fighting the Government for decades, and in recent years have taxed drug traffickers to obtain money to buy weapons.
Speaking to the nation of 40 million people tonight in a 15-minute televised address, Mr. Pastrana said that "narcotics trafficking is the main enemy of peace" and that his plan would strengthen the democracy by helping to "defeat the pernicious financing of armed groups."
In another reference to the drug trade, always Washington's principal concern here, he added that "only by fortifying the legal economy can we defeat the illegal economy."
Colombia is earmarked to get $289 million in American aid in the fiscal year about to end. But in July, following a guerrilla offensive that forced Mr. Pastrana to impose a limited curfew in one third of Colombia, Minister of Defense Luis Fernando Ramirez visited Washington with a request for an additional $500 million in military assistance.
Since then, two American delegations, one led by Gen. Barry McCaffrey, Mr. Clinton's drug czar, and the other from the State Department, have visited Colombia to assess a situation that Washington believes is deteriorating. American officials were said to have strongly urged Mr. Pastrana to be more aggressive in meeting the combined guerrilla and drug trafficking challenge.
"Colombia has paid a price that is truly disproportionate" in the global struggle against narcotics trafficking, he said, and therefore has the right to "demand that the rest of the world recognize that effort" and show solidarity.
While maintaining that "we have always had a strategy," Mr. Ruiz said the revamped program that has been drawn up envisions spending $7.5 billion during the next three years. He said Colombia had about $4 billion of that amount already budgeted and expected to receive $750 million soon from international lending agencies for social programs, but will need foreign help if the program is to be fully effective.
"We are not asking for money," Mr. Ruiz said, adding that no one in Washington has suggested that he ask for any specific amount. "We are not saying, 'Give us this or this or that.' We are saying, 'Here is our strategy, and this is how much money we are short.' "
Since taking office in August 1998, Mr. Pastrana has been accused by some in the United States, especially Republican members of Congress, of having a commitment to peace talks with the guerrillas at any cost, rather than a comprehensive strategy. But Mr. Ruiz made an effort to stress that Mr. Pastrana is prepared to step up military action against the rebels if talks with the principal group prove unsuccessful, as many here and in Washington have predicted.
"A country cannot bet everything on a peace process," he said. "We're going with the peace process because we believe in it. But that is not the only thing we are doing." The revised plan, he added, "functions with or without a peace process" because "it is a general strategy of strengthening the state."
Mr. Ruiz also cautioned that the revised strategy, though ambitious, would not in itself be sufficient to end the longstanding military conflict or wipe out the drug trade. "With this I am not going to resolve the problem," he said. "But it can make a difference at a crucial moment."

HEADLINE: TRADE SANCTIONS ON NORTH KOREA ARE EASED BY U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton today ordered a broad easing of economic sanctions against North Korea in what officials said was the first step in a long-term plan to induce the North to abandon its missile and nuclear programs.
The announcement -- the most extensive relaxation of sanctions against the North since the Korean War -- came four days after North Korea agreed to a temporary halt in its tests of long-range missiles. 
 A senior North Korean official is expected in Washington soon to begin talks on a comprehensive accord that would also end North Korea's missile exports to Pakistan and the Middle East.
But even Administration officials question whether the North Korean military, on whom President Kim Jong Il depends to exercise power in the Stalinist state, will go beyond the freeze on long-range tests and dismantle the dozen or so medium-range Nodong missiles they have deployed.
Under the terms of the announcement today, North Korea will be able to purchase consumer goods from the United States -- if it can get the hard currency. And it will be able to transport cargo and passengers back and forth from the United States. Until now, all such shipments have been banned.
Individuals in the United States will also be allowed to transfer funds to North Koreans.
The North already enjoys many such privileges with Japan, home to a large community of ethnic Koreans with some loyalties to the North. Japan has threatened to cut off their flow of cash and goods if North Korea tests the long-range missile.
American companies will be able to invest in North Korea's drastically underdeveloped raw materials industries, including agriculture, petroleum and timber. But in a country where there are no laws protecting investors and no protection against nationalization, it is far from clear that any American businesses will take the enormous risks involved.
"Making sure that there are concrete results for the North Koreans is a big issue, and it is one we are only now beginning to explore," William S. Perry, a former Secretary of Defense who developed the strategy as President Clinton's special envoy on North Korean affairs, said in an interview at the State Department.
Earlier in the day, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called the decision to relax sanctions "a road that holds out the possibility of long-term stability and even eventual reconciliation on the Korean peninsula."
But, she added, "it is not a one-way street" and "if circumstances require that we go down a different road altogether, we will do so to defend our interests."
Today's order relaxes a total embargo on trade imposed in 1950. Since then some prohibitions have been relaxed, to permit academic, sports and cultural exchanges and the delivery of American food to relieve starvation in the North.
None of the actions announced today require Congressional approval, although the next step -- lifting sanctions imposed by legislation -- would require approve.
While some Republicans, like Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, supported the move today, the chairman of the House International Relations Committee, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, said, "We are once again entering a cycle of extortion with North Korea."
Echoing the words of a recent Republican fundraising appeal written by Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, Mr. Gilman called North Korea "one of the most significant threats to American national security in the world today."
Mr. Perry said he was braced for the criticism that the Administration was paying off the North Koreans. But he argued that the alternative -- strengthening American forces along the Demilitarized Zone between the North and South Korea -- would be far more expensive.
He pointed to the 1994 accord that froze North Korea's production of plutonium, in return for $40 million a year in fuel oil from the United States and construction of two power plants financed by South Korea and Japan.
"It was a good buy," he said. "If you look at the potential cost of the deterrence action we were looking at in 1994," he said, when the two countries came the closest to armed confrontation since the Korean War ended in 1953, "the bill would have run to the tens of billions of dollars."
In relaxing the sanctions, Mr. Clinton calculated that he had little at risk, his aides said. The restrictions can be reimposed at the stroke of a pen if North Korea tests one of its new missiles over Japan, a launching that seemed imminent a few weeks ago. And before today's announcement goes into effect, the Commerce and Treasury Departments must issue regulations, a process that could be slowed -- or stopped -- if North Korea threatens a launching or similar action.
Soon after he began his review of North Korea policy last year, Mr. Perry, who was Defense Secretary during the 1994 crisis over the North's nuclear capability, concluded that freezing the missile program had to be Washington's top priority.
American intelligence has already concluded that the North probably possesses a small quantity of weapons-grade plutonium, enough "for perhaps the manufacture of one or two nuclear weapons," Mr. Perry said, which might be fitted into the nose cone of one of its missiles. The newest of those missiles could reach Alaska or the western United States.
But putting together the whole package -- designing a workable weapon, making it small enough to launch, then guiding the missile to a target -- is considered a task beyond the North's ability without help.
There has been speculation that the North has sought that help from Pakistan, trading missile parts for nuclear expertise. But intelligence officials say that so far, there is no evidence of such deals.
Despite the easing of sanctions, many restrictions remain on dealings with the North. The country is still classified as a terrorist state, meaning American companies cannot ship goods with a military as well as a civilian purpose, including advanced personal computers, without special approval.
The United States will still oppose loans to the North from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, or from American financial institutions. North Korean assets in the United States will remain blocked by the Trading With the Enemy Act.
Under Mr. Perry's plan, worked out over a period of months with the White House and presented to the North Koreans several months ago in a mission to Pyongyang, many of these restrictions are on the table for negotiation.
But in return, the North would have to join the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international accord that limits the range of missiles a country can deploy and that would mean dismantling some of the North's current missile fleet. The North Korean military is dead set against that, American officials say.
"We have a hard time believing that we represent a threat to the North," Mr. Perry said today. "But they clearly see us as a military threat to them."
He said a top North Korean military officer had told him during his mission to North Korea, "We're not going to be another Yugoslavia."
Mr. Perry interpreted this to mean that the North would not allow itself to be bombed by the United States without an ability to strike back.
On Sunday President Clinton outlined the relaxations announced today to President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and to Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan. Both agreed to the plan, American officials said, though a top Japanese military official departed from the official line several days ago to say he doubted that the North Koreans had agreed to suspend their missile testing, even temporarily. His remarks were later disavowed by the Japanese Government.

HEADLINE: Albany Tightens Standards For Teachers and Training

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
New York State set new higher standards for teachers yesterday that will for the first time require all teachers in middle schools and high schools to have completed college majors in the subjects they propose to teach.
The new rules, adopted by the Board of Regents yesterday, also set up procedures to penalize teaching schools where students routinely fail the state's licensing examination for teachers, which is itself being made more rigorous. 
 The new standards are among the toughest in the nation, state officials said, and are part of a national movement in education to improve schools by setting ever-higher standards. Already New York has introduced new reading and math tests in fourth and eighth grades and has set rules requiring high school students to pass Regents exams in five subject areas for graduation.
"This is a major piece in a structure to raise all children to high standards," Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner, said yesterday. "The heart of the matter is teaching."
Mr. Mills said the new standards were aimed at addressing the growing concern that many teachers are trained in educational methods but lack a strong grounding in the subject -- whether math or American history -- that they are supposed to teach in the classroom.
Studies show that large numbers of teachers across the country lack either college majors or minors in the subjects they teach, especially in science and math, and that the problem is most severe in inner-city schools serving poor black and Hispanic children.
Beginning in the current school year, at least 80 percent of the students who graduate from New York State teaching programs must pass the state licensing exam for teachers or that teaching school can be put on probation for three years and then shut down.
If the 80 percent rule were in effect today, state officials said, at least two dozen of New York's 113 teacher education programs could lose their accreditation, including several at the City University of New York. The teaching exams are also being stiffened so that teachers will have to answer about 20 percent more questions correctly, state officials said.
The standards will not be retroactively applied to the current teaching force. Most will affect prospective teachers entering college next fall. But state officials said standards would have a major impact in the years ahead as half of the state's teaching force becomes eligible for retirement within the next decade.
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, the New York City teachers' union, said she supported the requirements that teachers have stronger training in the subjects they teach.
But she said she feared that raising the standards would disproportionately affect black and Hispanic students enrolled in teaching programs that have historically not prepared their graduates to pass the state exams.
More and more states are tackling low achievement scores among students by focusing on the training of teachers. Texas has adopted a rule that 70 percent of a training program's graduating teachers must pass the state exam or the program can lose accreditation -- a somewhat lower standard than the one passed by New York State yesterday.
Educators said that studies have found that the scores of students on standardized tests improve in direct relation to the amount of training teachers have in the subjects they teach, especially math and science.
"This is a huge national issue because in state after state we're asking teachers to teach to higher standards, but in the core content areas they don't have the preparation to do that," said Stanley S. Litow, a vice president at the IBM Corporation in Armonk, N.Y., and a former deputy chancellor of New York City schools.
A study by the Education Trust Inc., an education research group based in Washington, found that large numbers of public school teachers across the country do not have undergraduate majors or minors in their fields, including 25 percent of English teachers, 17.4 percent of social studies teachers, 39.5 percent of science teachers and 34 percent of math teachers.
Lewis H. Spence, the New York City school system's Deputy Chancellor for Operations, said that while raising the bar is "terrific" in theory, the city is already having trouble recruiting enough qualified teachers and the new standards could make that even more difficult.
It is possible, he said, that college students who now choose education as a career will simply choose other fields, or will choose elementary teaching, where the standards are lower, instead of high school or middle school.
"The question is, will the pool of people respond or will it simply close out," Mr. Spence said. He urged the state to increase the amount of reciprocity between teaching licenses in New York and those in other states.
Under the new rule, high school and middle school teachers will have at least 36 credits -- the minimum required for a major -- in the subject they are teaching, state officials said. Under the current requirements, they only need a concentration in that subject, typically 24 credits, sometimes less, state officials said.
Elementary school teachers will now need to have 30 credits in the liberal arts, including some courses in a foreign language, math, science and history. Although they can still major in education, it is no longer enough. "It will no longer be acceptable to have a smattering of courses in a number of different fields," Mr. Mills said. "They will have to be deeply educated as well as broadly educated."
All teacher education programs will have to be accredited by a national accrediting body. Currently, only a handful -- state officials estimated four or five -- of those in New York State meet that credential.
As part of their training, teachers will be required to student-teach in urban, rural and suburban settings, to make sure that they understand the needs of students from various economic, racial and social backgrounds, Mr. Mills said.
"We want to make certain that we have a stream of teachers who are not only willing to teach in cities and rural communities but able to," he said.
All teachers will be required to have training in teaching children with disabilities, regardless of whether they have degrees in special education. And students who plan to teach special education will have to have an undergraduate major in the arts and sciences.
Teachers who earn a masters degree may still earn it in education; but if they do, they must take at least 12 additional credits in an academic subject area.
Mr. Mills said the plan to close down teaching programs that did not meet state standards was modeled on a similar program at the kindergarten-to-12th-grade-level, called Schools Under Registration Review, in which the state may close schools that fail to meet goals including standardized test scores.
In 1997-98, 6 out of the 10 teaching programs at the City University of New York failed to meet the 80 percent rule adopted by the Regents yesterday, according to state statistics.
The failure rate was highest in programs that serve large numbers of minority students. At Medgar Evers College, only 47 percent of the teacher candidates passed the liberal arts and sciences test, while 49 percent passed at City College and 58 percent at York College.

HEADLINE: An F-22's Worth of Education

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Jack Shanahan argues (Op-Ed, Sept. 17) that the money for the F-22 fighter would be better spent investing in the country's schools, thereby producing a stronger recruit pool. The logic is good, but the math is off. 
 Mr. Shanahan claims that canceling the F-22 and a new submarine and reducing the nuclear arsenal to 1,000 warheads would save $23 billion a year, but the savings would total less than $10 billion a year. Moreover, that would be needed to finance more mundane defense equipment, since today's military hardware is wearing out fast after a decade of low Pentagon procurement budgets. Today's defense budget need not go up -- and Mr. Shanahan is right to criticize Pentagon officials for weapons modernization plans that would require it to do so. But the budget is already $100 billion a year less in inflation-adjusted terms than in the 1980's and probably should not go down any more, either.
 
MICHAEL O'HANLON
Bethesda, Md., Sept. 17, 1999
 
The writer is a fellow in foreign policy studies, Brookings Institution.
